Certain foods tu f fs may be imported only by the Guyana Marketing Corporation, e.g., those that f a ll under the agricultural ma rke t ing protocol of the CAR I FTA /CAR ICOM Agreement. Payments for au tho r ized impo r ts are pe rm i t ted upon application and submission of the necessary documen- tary evidence. Exchange control fo rms have to be com- pleted for all transac t ions. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all coun tr ies requ i re ap- proval, which, except for tourist t ravel and dep rec ia t ion allowances, is usually given free ly, provided th at no illegal capital t rans fer seems to be involved. The basic exchange allocation for tour ist travel has been sus- pended. Travel allowances to residents may only be granted on an ind iv idual basis. Foreign-based compan ies (other than those based in CAR ICOM coun t r ies) and the ir subsidiaries are prohibited f rom t r a n s f e r r i ng dep rec ia t ion allowances. S tandard allocations are applied to cer ta in paymen ts of a personal n a t u re on an annu al basis, e.g., for educa t ion at schools abroad (G$3,360 for each ch i ld ), for educa t ion at un ive rs i t ies and comparable ins t i tu t ions (G$4,800 for each s tud en t ), and for f am i ly ma in tenance (G$4,800 for each f am i l y ). Resident and nonresident travelers are subject on depa r tu re to an exit tax of G$3 a person. Travelers going abroad may take w i th them G u y a na currency notes not exceeding G$15; these notes do not form part of any a l lo tment of exchange for trave l. In addition, foreign currency notes up to the va lue of G$50 may be taken out as part of any travel exchange allowance. Nonresident travelers may w i th in one month of their last en try free ly take out any foreign currency notes declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to the Republic of China, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Exports of rice may only be made by the Guyana Rice Marke t ing Board. Cer ta in other exports also are channeled through official agen- cies. Most exports do not require export licenses, but are supervised by the Bank of Guyana and the Customs and Excise Depa r tment to ensu re that the exchange pro- ceeds are repatriated and, if obtained in listed specified currencies (see footnote 1), surrendered. Exchange control forms have to be completed for all exports exceeding G$2,000 in value. Proceeds from Invisibles Specified currencies (see foo tno te 1) received on account of invisibles must be sold to an authorized GUYANA bank, but other currencies may be retained by the recipient. Travelers may bring in freely any amount in fore ign banknotes; domestic banknotes may be brought in by r e tu rn ing travelers only and must not exceed G$15 a person. Capital Foreign investors must obtain from the Bank of G u y a na "approved status" for new investments at the t ime of inves tment in order to be able to repatriate capital. Such approval is normally given for direct investments in new projects that would benefit the balance of payments or the economy of Guyana; it carries w i th it an assurance that profits may be remitted and that upon liquidation of the investment, the pro- ceeds, inc lud ing any capital increments a f ter payment of all taxes, may be repatriated in full in the currency of the o r ig inal investment. For the time being, however, foreign-based companies (other than those based in the CAR ICOM a rea) and the ir subsidiaries are prohibited f rom exporting depreciation allowances and from bor- row ing in Guyana. The export of capital by residents is not normally pe rm i t ted. Listed specified currencies (see footnote 1) ob ta ined by residents through capital transactions must be surrendered to an authorized bank, but other curren- cies may be retained by the recipient. Em ig ran ts of Guyanese na t iona l i ty may not t rans fer abroad any part of their cap i ta/ assets other than a se t t l ing - in allowance of G$100 for each member of a f am i ly u n i t; emigrants of foreign nationality may export all declared capital assets, viz., G$24,000 a f am i ly un it at the t ime of emigration and G$17,300 in each follow- ing calendar year. Any unremittable capital proceeds must be retained in Guyana indefinitely, but the funds are not directed into Blocked Accounts. Borrowing f rom nonresidents requires exchange con- trol approval. However, on January 5, 1976 it was announced that publicly-owned enterprises would be encouraged to borrow abroad for the financing of spe- cific projects. Foreign-owned companies also would be encouraged to borrow more f rom overseas financial institutions. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Guyana for num i sma t ic purposes. Residents other than the mone- ta ry authorities, authorized dealers, producers of gold, and authorized indus t r ial users are not allowed w i thout special permission to hold or acqu ire gold in any fo rm other than jewelry or coins for num isma t ic purposes, at home or abroad. Neither the Bank of Guyana nor any other official institution purchases gold to supply domes- tic indus try. Not for Redistribution HAITI (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.147332 gram of fine gold per Haitian Gourde. The parity rate for the U.S. dollar is G5.00 = US$1, and this rate is applicable to all transactions. The in terven t ion currency is the U.S. dollar. Besides the gourde, the U.S. dollar is legal tender. On December 22, 1953, Haiti notified the Fund that it was prepared to fo rm a l ly accept the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agree- ment. Administration of Control There is no exchange control law, and no obligations prescribing the method or currency for paymen ts to or from nonresidents are imposed. Exchange regulations are issued by the Na t ional Bank of the Republic of Haiti and are imp lemen ted by th at Bank and c e r t a in com- mercial banks. Imports and Import Payments Import licenses are required for ce r ta in foods tu f fs, certain footwear, pa in ts, and passenger automobiles valued at over US$5,000 c . i . f .; licenses are gran ted freely. Imports f rom member coun tr ies of the Council for Mu tual Economic Assistance and Japan require prior au thor iza t ion by the M in i s t ry of Commerce and Indus try. The M in is try's pr ior au tho r i z a t ion is also required for imports f rom any source of certain types of foo twear and of a few other i tems that are con tro l led for other t h an ba lance of paymen ts reasons. The domes- tic marke t ing of certain imports is controlled by the State Tobacco Monopoly. Impo r te rs op en ing letters of cred it at the Na t ional B ank are requ i red to make cash deposits of up to 100 per cent of the amount of the letter of cred i t. Ce r ta in impor ts are sub ject to sur- charges of 4, 5, or 6 per cent of the c . i . f. va lue, in addition to the applicable import du ty; goods subject to the 4 or 6 per cent tax are also sub ject to an add i t ional tax of 2 per cent. Impor ters pay an "economic libera- tion tax" on the am o u nt of the cus toms invo ice; when it exceeds G 10,000, the tax is 1 per cen t. Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports requ i re pr ior au tho r i z a t ion f rom the M in i s t ry of Commerce and Indu s t ry. Expo rt au thor iza- tion is u sua l ly g ran ted f ree ly but may be w i thhe ld when domestic supplies are low. Expor ts of essential oils are regulated by the Ma rke t ing O f f ice for Essential Oils. Gold coins, gold and s i lver bu l l ion, etc., may be exported only by the Na t ional Bank. The proceeds of expor ts are not sub ject to exchange con t ro l. Expor ters must pay an "economic liberation tax" levied on the amount of the customs invoice; when this amount exceeds G 10,000, the tax is 1 per cent. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments for invisibles are not restricted. No exchange control requirements are applied to proceeds from invisibles. A regulation which is not enforced prohibits the export and impo rt of U.S. banknotes in denom ina t ions of over $20. Residents t rave l ing abroad must pay a tax of G 20 on tickets to a destination in the Caribbean area and G 50 on tickets to a destination outside that area; diplomats and staff of in terna t ional organizations are exempt. Capital Capital t r an s f e rs abroad are not no rma l ly permitted but impo r ts may be made freely. Foreign inves tment in Ha i ti is regulated by a law of 1949 and a decree of March 13, 1963 and requires prior government approval. Permission is not no rma l ly granted to non- res iden ts for inves tmen ts in h and i c r a ft industries. Under a decree of Ap r il 6, 1973, p r iva te banks ope ra t ing in Ha i ti are requ ired to keep in the fo rm of domestic assets a m i n im um of 85 per cent of t h e ir l iab i l i t ies to local customers. Gold Res iden ts may hold and acqu ire gold coins in Haiti for n um i sm a t ic purposes. W i th this exception, residents other than the mone ta ry au tho r i t ies and authorized indu s t r i al users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any fo rm other than jewe lry, at home or abroad. Impor ts and exports of gold in any fo rm other th an jewe l ry carried as personal effects by travelers may be made only by the National Bank; exports requ i re in add i t ion pr ior au tho r iza t ion by the M in is try of F inance, wh i le impo r ts for indu s t r i al use requ ire prior authorization by the M in is try of Commerce and Indu s t ry and the M in i s t ry of F inance as well as an endorsement by the M in i s t ry of Commerce and Indus- try before customs clearance. Foreign companies, which were hitherto required to d i lu te their fore ign equ i ty ho ld ing to 40 per cent, were allowed to re ta in a ma jo r i ty share of 51 per cent or more und er the Foreign Exchange Regu la- tion Act depending on the extent to which such com- panies are engaged in core indu s t ry produc t ion, in activities requiring sophisticated technology, or in export production. Foreign companies can re ta in a 51 per cent nonresident equity as long as their combined core sector production, application of sophisticated technology, and export production account for no less t h an 60 per cent of their annu al turnover. Fu r the rmo re, such compan ies would be requ i red to export a m i n i m um of 10 per cent of their annu al turnover w i th in a period not exceeding two years f rom the date of approval by the Reserve Bank. If their combined core sector produc t ion, appli- cation of sophisticated technology, and export produc- tion account for no less than 75 per cent of their annual turnover, fo re ign compan ies can retain a 74 per cent nonresident ownership. Companies w i th exports exceed- ing 40 per cent of the ir tu rnove r, irrespective of core production or the technology involved, will also be allowed to operate with a non res ident equ i ty of 51 per cent, and those that are able to gua ran tee a higher percentage of exports on a sus ta ined basis would be eligible on merits to operate w i th a higher percentage of nonres ident equ i ty. Companies which export 100 per cent of produc t ion may be who l ly owned by non- residents. If none of the above -men t ioned cond i t ions are met, the non res ident equ i ty mu st be reduced to 40 per cent. April 22. Gold No Iran ian gold coins are legal tender.4 Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold and silver in any fo rm in I ran, and there is a free market for both. Authorized banks may import and export gold and silver (bullion on ly, which for gold must be at least 995/1000 fine) with prior approval of the Central Bank, against settlement through the official rate market, and sell these metals to any person in I ran. The import and export of gold for mone tary purposes or for in terna t ional settlements is reserved for the Cen- tral Bank, while the import for indus tr ial and dental use is effected by professional organ iza t ions, at the off i- cial rate and subject to supervision by the Central Bank. The Central Bank accepts gold bu l l ion on deposit f rom domestic banks as well as nonbank residents and issues gold certificates against such deposits. Travelers may freely import and export gold bullion up to 1 kilo- gram a person a trip; the Central Bank is empowered to approve larger quantities. The export of I ran ian gold coins for num isma t ic purposes requires prior approval by the Central Bank. Imports of gold are free f rom customs duty and commercial benefit tax but are subject to the 1 per cent impo rt registration fee. The Cen- t ral Bank of I re land quotes the pound s t e r l ing at par w i th the Irish pound, and transac t ions in s ter l ing are f ree of commission. The Bank also quotes buy ing and se l l ing rates for other currencies, which are app rox ima te ly equal to the rates quoted against s ter l ing in London. As of December 31, 1976, the Central Bank's buy ing and sell- ing rates for the U.S. dollar were US$1 .7025 and US$1.7015, respectively, per Irish pound. Certain cap i tal transactions invo lv ing inves tment cu r rency (see section on Capital, below) take place at d i f fe rent e f fec t ive ra tes; on December 31, 1976 the inves tment cu r rency p r em i um was 413/s per cent (based on the spot exchange ra te of US$1.6990 per Ir ish p o u n d ). Administration of Control Exchange control is operated by the Central Bank. Much of the au tho r i ty for app rov ing no rmal payments is delegated to commercial banks authorized for this purpose. Import licenses, where necessary, are issued by the Department of Industry and Commerce if the goods are of an industrial nature, or by the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries if they are agricultural in character. Import licensing is not used for exchange control purposes. Import and export controls are adm in- istered by the Revenue Commissioners. Prescription of Currency Irish exchange control regulations d is t ingu ish between (1) the Scheduled Territories, cons is t ing of Ireland, Northern Ire land, Great B r i ta in, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, and Gibraltar, and (2) the rest of the world. The latter is subdivided in to ( 1) the Overseas Sterling Area (OSA ), i.e., the coun tr ies which on June 23, 1972 ceased to be regarded as Scheduled Terri- tor ies ;1 (2) EEC member coun tr ies other than the 1 The Overseas Sterling Area thus comprises Au s t r a l i a, Bahamas, Bahra in, Bangladesh, Barbados, Belize, Bermuda, Botswana, British I n d i an Ocean Te r r i to ry, British V i r g in Is lands, B run e i, Cayman Islands, Cyp ru s, Fa lk land Islands and Dependencies, Fiji, The Gamb ia, Ghana, Gilbert Islands, G renada, Guyana, Hong Kong, Iceland, India and S ikk im, Jama ica, Jo rd an, Kenya, Kuwa i t, Leewa rd Is lands, Lesotho, Ma law i, M a l a y s i a, M a ld iv e s, M a l t a, M a u r i t i us a nd D e p e n d e n c y, N am i b ia (Sou th West A f r i c a ), N a u r u, New Zealand, N ig e r i a, Oman, Pak is tan, P apua New Gu inea, P i tca irn Islands, Qa ta r, St. Helena and Depen- dencies, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, S ingapore, Solomon Islands, South Afr ica, Sri Lanka, Swaziland, Tanzania, Tonga, Trinidad and Tobago, Turks and Caicos Islands, Tuva lu (E l l ice I s l a n d s ), Uganda, Un i ted A rab Emirates, Western Samoa, W indwa rd Islands, People's Demo- cratic Republic of Yemen, and Zambia. 244 Un i ted Kingdom and Ireland; (3) Rhodesia; and (4) the Rest of the Non-Scheduled Territories (RNST), which consists of all other coun t r ie s. Balances on these accounts may be t r an s f e r r ed free ly to other External Accounts in Irish pounds or in sterling, used for payments to residents of the Scheduled Territories, or converted through an authorized bank in Ireland into any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. Not for Redistribution Imports and Import Payments All impor ts of commodities o r i g i n a t i ng in Rhodesia require a special license. W i th th is exception, the import of goods into Ireland is subject to three types of adm in- istrative control. Under the first type, which covers only a limited range of commodities for protective and other nonbalance of payments purposes, impo r ts of ce r ta in commodities are subject to q u a n t i t a t i ve re s t r ic t ion s, which, in most cases, are on a world-wide basis." Indi- vidual import licenses are requ ired for these goods and are used to l im it the qu an t i ty of goods impo r ted. In addition, special quota res tr ic t ions apply to (a) cycle tires f rom non-OECD coun t r ies and J a p a n, and (b) certain textiles and ya rns o r ig in a t ing in any of 16 spe- cified countries or terr i tor ies .4 Second, impo r ts of ce r ta in goods f rom non-EEC sources may f r om t ime to t ime be subject to restriction or surveillance by v i r tue of EEC decisions, d irec t ives, or regu la t ions. All other impo r ts generally are f ree of qu an t i t a t ive res t r ic t ion. Under the third type of control, prior permission of the Cen tral Bank is required before orders may be placed for goods originating outside the Scheduled Terr i tor ies, if they are not to be used in Ireland or are to be delivered more than nine months a f t er the da te of the order. In addi- tion, Ireland operates a system of su rve i l lance licensing for imports f rom all sources of ce r ta in foo twear, cloth- ing, and other textiles, and for impo r ts f r om non-EEC sources of sisal binder tw ine; under this system, licenses generally are issued v i r tua l ly au toma t ica l ly. Imports f rom non-EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Ag r icu l tu ral Policy of the EEC are subject to variable import levies which have replaced all previous barriers to impo r ts; common EEC regula- tions are also applied to imports f rom non-EEC countries of most other agr icu l tural and livestock products. For permitted imports, appropriate exchange or per- mission to credit Irish pounds or s ter l ing to an External Account is granted au toma t ica l ly. Exports and Export Proceeds A system of export licensing is applied to a l im i ted range of goods. There is a special restriction on exports to Rhodesia. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no specific requirements governing exchange receipts f rom invisibles, but if fore ign currencies are received they must be o f fe red for sale to an author- ized bank or permission for their retention must be obtained. Any fore ign currency held by a person af ter his re tu rn f rom a t r ip abroad may be retained for three months f rom the date he received the exchange, for use on a subsequent t r ip abroad. There are no l im i ta- tions on the import of Irish or foreign banknotes. Capital Inward and outward movements of capital between Ireland and other Scheduled Territories are not subject to exchange control and take place at the official exchange rate. Exchange control approval is required for all transfers of capital to countries outside the Sched- uled Territories. Applications for transfer of capital at the official market rate of exchange by residents of the State emigrating to OSA countries, EEC member countries other than the United Kingdom, or RNST countries are approved up to a l im it of <£Ir 20,000 a f am i l y; there is no such allowance for emigration to Rhodesia. Agent banks may acqu i re un re- fined gold abroad upon subm i s s ion of licenses issued by the M in i s t ry of Foreign Trade to I ta l ian firms for indus- tr ial use. Exports of w rought and s em im a n u f a c t u r ed gold, other than jewelry, are subject to licensing. Impor ts of un r e f in ed gold are in p r inc ip le subject to va lue -added tax, but at the end of 1976 the rate of tax was zero per cent. Impo r ts of gold coins for n um i sm a t ic purposes are subject to value-added tax at 18 per cent. The un it of cu r rency is the CFA Franc ,1 wh ich is o f f i c i a l ly m a i n t a i n ed at the ra te of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French f r a n c. Exchange t ransac- tions in French f r a n c s, the i n t e r v e n t i on cu r rency, between the Banque Cen tra le des E ta ts de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and comme rc ial banks take place on the basis of CFAF 1 = F 0.02; the BCEAO levies a commission of 2.50 per m i ll for t r a n s f e rs to coun t r ies outside the West A f r i c an M o n e t a ry U n i o n, wh i le no comm iss ion is charged on t r a n s f e rs w i t h in the U n i on or f rom coun t r ies ou ts ide the U n i o n. B anks levy a commission on t rans fe rs to all coun tr ies ou ts ide the West A f r i c an Mone ta ry U n i o n, part of w h i ch m u st be surrendered to the T reasu ry. With the exception of those r e l a t ing to gold, Ivory Coast's exchange con t rol measu res do not app ly in finan- cial re la t ions w i th ( 1) F rance ( a nd i ts Overseas Depa r t- ments and Terr i tor ies, except the French T e r r i to ry of the A fa rs and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) a ll o ther countries whose bank of issue is l inked w i th the French Treasury by an Ope ra t ions Account (B e n i n, Came roon, the Central A f r ican Empire, Chad, the People's Repub- lic of the Congo, Gabon, Ma l i, N ige r, Senega l, Togo, and Upper V o l t a ). Not for Redistribution JAMAICA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.900364 gram of fine gold per Jama ica Dollar. On Feb rua ry 20, 1973, a central rate of J $l = US$1 .10 was established, corresponding at the time to J$ 1.09668 = SDR 1 or 0.810328 gram of fine gold per Jamaica dollar. The in terven t ion currency is the U.S. dollar and Jamaica avails itself of wider margins. In practice, the Bank of Jama ica's dea l ings aga inst Jamaica dollars are confined to transactions in Canad ian dollars, pounds s ter l ing, and U.S. dollars, to purchases of Canad ian, U.K., and U.S. bankno tes, and to pu r- chases of certain Caribbean and European b ankno t es (see be low ). It deals in other currencies on ly aga inst s ter l ing and U.S. dollars. The Bank buys and sells U.S. dollars at par, plus a comm iss ion of %« of 1 per cent on the se l l ing side. Exchange rates for cu r renc ies other than the U.S. dollar are based on the Bank of Jamaica's b u y i ng and se l l ing rates for the U.S. dollar and the rates against the U.S. do l lar for the currenc ies concerned in in te rna t ional marke ts. The Bank of Jama ica sets da i ly off ic ial buy ing and se l l ing rates for dea l ing w i th the b anks in s ter l ing and Canad ian dollars on the basis of the prev ious day's c los ing quo ta t ions in New York. On the basis of these rates, the B ank also fixes d a i ly rates at wh ich commercial banks must deal w i th the ir cus- tomers in t ransac t ions invo lv ing Jama ica do l lars against Canad ian dollars, pounds s ter l ing, or U.S. dollars. The Bank of Jamaica is authorized by law to fix its buy ing and se l l ing rates of exchange. On December 31, 1976 these rates re la t ing to spot dea l ings w i th the com- merc ial banks reflected no commission charge on pur- chases but a charge of %o of 1 per cent on sales. The comme rc ial banks applied a comm iss ion charge (pre- m i um) of % of 1 per cent on sales of fo re ign exchange to customers and a comm iss ion charge (d i scoun t) of Vs of 1 per cent on purchases. For purchases equ iva lent to J$ 1,000 or more, the comm iss ion charge ( d i s c o u n t) was waived. The Bank of Jama ica's b u y i ng and se l l ing rates for the U.S. dollar on December 2 1, 1976 were US$1 = J$0.9075 and US$1 = J$0.9125, respectively. Administration of Control The exchange con trol system is opera ted by the M i n- istry of F inance, the M in i s t ry of I n t e r n a t i o n al Trade and Industry (M I T I ), and the B ank of Japan as the Gov- ernment's agent. Nonresident Accounts There are two ma in non res ident accounts, as described below. 1. Nonresident Free Yen Accounts. These accounts may be opened by any nonresident with any authorized bank in Japan and may be credited w i th the yen pro- ceeds f rom exports of goods to Japan and f rom other authorized transactions, w i th yen proceeds f rom sales of all foreign currencies, w i th t rans fe rs f rom other Free Yen Accoun ts, w i th in terest accrued on balances in these accoun ts, and w i th the coun te rva lue in yen of au tho r ized ou twa rd paymen t s. There are no restrictions on p a ym e n ts f r om these accounts, and balances may be conver ted f ree ly in to any fo re ign cu r rency. 2. Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts. These accoun ts may be held by any nonres ident w i th any authorized b ank in Japan. They may be credited w i th yen proceeds f r om t r an s a c t ions other than those wh ich are au tho r ized to be credited to Non re s ident Free Yen Accoun ts. P e rm i t t ed credits to Non re s ident Yen Deposit Accoun ts are l im i ted m a i n ly to proceeds f rom the sales of deben tures and bene f ic ia ry certificates sold w i th in six mon ths f r om the da te of va l ida ted acqu is i t ion. Balances o u t s t a n d i ng on December 31, 1970 were perm i t ted to be t r an s f e r r ed to Non re s ident Free Yen Accounts or to be r em i t t ed abroad. Balances accrued a f t er that da te are not convertible into fore ign currencies, although remit- tances are pe rm i t ted each year up to 30 per cent of the ba lance at the end of the previous year or the equ iva lent of ¥ 720,000, wh ichever is h ighe r. W i thd r aw a ls f rom these accounts are au tho r ized for cer ta in purposes, such as mee t ing the ou t lays invo lved in m a n a g i ng inves t- men ts in J ap an and the expenses of nonres iden ts s tay ing in Japan. Transfers to other Non res ident Yen Deposit Accoun ts may be made f ree ly, thus enab l ing the ind i- v i d u al account holder to repa t r ia te h is f u n ds by se l l ing them to ano ther non re s ident in r e t u rn for fo re ign cu r- rency, but there is no market for such funds in Japan. Imports and Import Payments Impor ts f rom Rhodesia are in pr inc ip le proh ib i ted. O ther impor ts are sub ject either to ind iv idu al l icens ing by the au thor ized banks or, if l ibe ra l ized, to declaration to such banks. Most private imports are liberalized. There are two procedures for imports r equ i r ing payment in fo re ign cu r renc ies: ( 1) Under the Impo rt Quota System (cove r ing impor ts of goods on the "negative list," wh ich comprises 82 items, in t e rms of the fou r- d ig it Brussels nomenc la tu re; 27 of the 82 items on the "negative list" have been notified to the GATT as res idual res t r ic t ions wh i le the other 55 i tems have been no t if ied as f a l l i ng under the na t ional secur i ty, pub l ic health, and moral protection provisions of the GATT), the impor ter must first obtain f rom MITI an import quota, which is based on the quan t i ta t ive principle. If the quo ta is g ran ted, the impo r ter receives an impo rt quota cer t if ica te wh ich entitles him to receive an import license f rom an au thor ized bank au toma t ica l ly upon application. Practically all import quota certificates are issued on a global basis, w i thout regard to the coun t ry of o r ig in or the currency of settlement, by MITI. (2) Under the Declaration System, imports are free of quan t i ta t ive res tr ic t ion and l icens ing and requ ire only a 269 ©International Monetary Fund. Items under state trading include certain da iry prod- ucts, certain cereals, salt, raw silk, and raw and manu- factured tobacco. Payment for imported goods must be made under one of the "standard" me thods of settlement for imports. When the settlement proposal is not in accordance w i th one of the "standard" methods (i.e., when certain advance payment is proposed or payment is to be made more than four mon ths a f ter customs c lea rance ), prior approval of MITI must be obtained. Payments for Invisibles All payments to Rhodesia are subject to the approval of the Minister of Finance or the M in is ter of In te rna- t ional Trade and Industry. Paymen ts to other coun tr ies for invisibles also require approva l, but cu r rent payments are not restricted and most such paymen ts are approved f ree ly by fore ign exchange banks w i thout any l im i t a t ion or w i th in cer ta in established l im i ts. Residents may purchase fo re ign currenc ies for paymen ts in connection w i th travel abroad up to US$3,000 a person a t r ip, subject to va l ida t ion by a foreign exchange bank; app l ica t ions in excess of US$3,000 a person a t r ip requ ire the approval of the Bank of Japan. A traveler is pe rm i t ted to pay in yen or in foreign cu r rency, before depa r tu re, the cost of t ran spo r ta t ion to and f rom h is des t ina t ion and for a ll side trips. Cer ta in in su r an ce and technical assistance contracts requ i re app rova l; but when a license for a con t ract has been g ran ted, any pay- ment re su l t ing f rom the con t ract may be made f ree ly. Settlements which are not made under a "standard" method require, in pr inc ip le, i n d i v i d u al app rova l; w i thout such approval, paymen ts for services, etc., may not be made more than three mon ths be fo re or la ter th an s ix mon ths a f ter receipt of the services, etc. Both residents and non re s iden ts may take out f r e e ly up to ¥ 100,000 in Japanese currency. Subject to ve r i f i- ca t ion, i.e., upon presen ta t ion of d o c um e n t a t i on show ing any prior conversion of fo re ign cu r rency, a non re s ident may free ly purchase fo re ign currenc ies up to the amount which he brought in to Japan; w i thout ve r i f ica t ion the conversion into fore ign currenc ies is l im i ted to the equivalent of US$1,000. 270 Exports and Export Proceeds With minor exceptions exports to Rhodesia are pro- hibited. All exports to Iran, Iraq, and Nigeria require special authorization. All exports (except exports with- out exchange) must be registered with a fore ign exchange bank ("bank cer t if ica t ion"). Licenses are not generally required, except for goods subject to the fo l low ing restrictions: restrictions on cer- ta in goods to control their export to specified com- munist countries; restrictions on goods in short supply in the domestic market (e.g., some staple foods ); and restrictions designed to forestall the imposition of import restrictions by other countries (e.g., on sewing machines and certain tex t i le s ). Exports under processing and con- s ignment sale contracts and exports for which settlement is not und er the "standard" method also requ ire ind i- v i d u al licenses. Export r e s t r a int may be exercised by v i r tue of the Export and Impo rt Transaction Law and an export trade con trol order issued "under the Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Control Law. Export res tra int may be applied either globally or to specified destinations, and it may cover export volumes, prices, and other conditions. At the end of 1976, 79 export cartels existed under the provisions of the Export and Impo rt Transaction Law. Of these, 50 requ ired pr ior notice of exporters' agree- men ts in respect of export t ransac t ions, 29 required prior approval of m anu f a c tu r e r s' agreemen ts on domestic t ran sac t ions in goods for export, and 10 were reinforced by an export license requ i remen t. In add i t ion, 20 items were subject to export license under the Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Control Law. There were also a number of i n f o rm al practices to vo lun tar i ly res t ra in exports of certain items to specified markets, w i th or w i t h o ut gu idance by MITI. Under the "s tandard" method of se t t lement for exports, the va lue of the exported goods must, in gen- era l, be settled by d r aw ing a bill of exchange payable w i t h in f ive mon ths a f t er sight or w i th in s ix mon ths a f ter sh ipmen t. There are no su r render requ iremen ts for fo re ign cu r rency ea rn ing s. The conversion into yen of advance receipts in respect of exports, i.e., proceeds received be fo re sh ipmen t, requ ires an ind iv idual license when they exceed the equ iva lent of US$500,000. Proceeds front Invisibles Receipts und er the "s tandard" method of se t t lement may be accepted w i thout a l icense. On December 31, 1976, the Central Bank of Jordan's buy ing and se l l ing rates for the U.S. do l lar were US$3.03 and US$3.01 per J D 1, and those for s ter l ing were <£ stg. 1.77 and <£ stg. 1.75 per JD I .1 The buy ing and se l l ing rates quoted by the commercial banks for these and other currencies must be based on the spot rates quoted by the Central B a n k; as a result, no fo rwa rd exchange transac t ions take place. A fee of 4 per cent is levied on the issue of import licenses. A fee of Vio of 1 per cent is levied on exchange perm i ts approved by the Central Bank for sales of exchange for imports, except impo r ts of government depa r tmen ts and ce r ta in other approved in s t i tu t ion s. Administration of Control Exchange con trol is adm in i s t e r ed by the Foreign Exchange Control Depa r tment of the Cen t ral Bank of Jo rdan, which also issues exchange p e rm i t s; the Cen t ral Bank has, however, delegated to au tho r ized banks the issuance of exchange perm i ts for import paymen ts and, up to a pe rm i t ted a n n u al l im i t, for p aym en ts for educa- t ional expenses of Jo rdan ians s tudy ing abroad and for va r ious other purposes. An Impo rt Comm i t tee com- p r i s ing represen ta t ives of the M in i s t r ies of I n d u s t ry and Trade and of F inance and Customs and the Cen t ral Bank presents f rom t ime to t ime suggestions and recom- m end a t ions conce rn ing changes in impo rt policy to the M in i s ter of Indu s t ry and Trade. In add i t ion, an Eco- nomic Secur i ty Comm i t tee is empowe red to am end exist- ing regu la t ions or issue new ones conce rn ing any aspect of Jordan's economic policies when th is is considered necessary to the n a t i o n al in teres t. Not for Redistribution Payments for Invisibles Rem i t tances by postal order do not requ i re exchange control approval, provided that they do not exceed JD 10 a person a mon th (JD 50 a person a mon th for Kuwa i t ). With this exception, all payments for invisibles are subject to exchange control approval. Paymen ts for the following types of invisibles are generally permitted up to certain l im i ts: income of nonresidents; savings of foreign na t iona ls who in tend to re tu rn to the ir own countries; rem i t tances to residents' dependents; reason- able l iv ing expenses of Jo rdan ian na t iona ls abroad; expenses of Jo rdan ian residents traveling abroad; ex- penses for educa t ion; expenses for medical t rea tmen t; business expenses abroad; and in su r an ce paymen ts in accordance w i th special regulations .4 The exchange a l lowance for business and tour ist travel is the equ iva lent of JD 5,000 a person (JD 500 for ch i l- dren under 18). These allowances are granted for one or more trips once a year. For f am i ly suppo r t, an a n n u al allowance of JD 5,000 for each benef ic iary is permitted, once a year; however, r em i t t an c es by postal order may be made for amoun ts not exceed ing the equ iva lent of JD 10 a mon th to any one person res ident abroad (JD 50 a mon th for K uw a i t) and are not sub ject to th is ceiling. The policy in respect of p aym en ts for inv is ib les is, in gene ra l, l ibe ral and n o n d i s c r im i n a t o r y. In practice, the Cen t ral Bank does not res tr ict rem i t tances of income accru ing to non res iden ts or of sav ings of fo re ign nationals r e t u r n i ng to the ir own coun t ry. Not for Redistribution KENYA Imports and Import Payments Some imports f rom all sources are prohibited for rea- sons of public policy; imports of certain other goods are not being licensed. All imports f rom Rhodesia and South Afr ica are prohibited. W i th cer ta in exceptions, imports f rom Tanzania and Uganda are unres tr ic ted, but many goods imported f rom these countries require a specific license unless they are of Tanzan ian or Ugandan or ig in. Many goods may be f ree ly impor ted f rom other sources under open general license, but others require a specific license. Certain items are imported on ly by the Kenya Na t ional T rad ing Corporation, Ltd. These inc lude sugar, sa l t, rice, edible oils, b lanke ts, and cotton piece goods. In add i t ion to the open general impo rt license, there a re four commod i ty schedules for imports. W i th m i n or exceptions, all private sector impor ts of commod i t ies in Schedules I, II, III, and IV f r om countries other th an Tanzan ia and Uganda requ i re a fo re ign exchange alloca- tion license issued by the Director of Trade and Supplies; applications must be subm i t ted before firm orders are placed. Impor ts of goods on open general license requ i re an exchange a l loca t ion license, wh ich is given au to- ma t ica l ly, and must be preregistered w i th the Director of Trade and Supplies before firm orders are placed. All goods in the first th ree schedules requ i re a spec if ic impo rt license f rom the Director of Trade and Supplies. Once the specific import license has been ob ta ined, for- eign exchange is g ran ted f ree ly for goods in Schedule I and on the basis of quo tas re f lec t ing past impor ts for goods in Schedule II. No fo re ign exchange is g r an t ed for Schedule III items. For items in Schedule IV, a specific impo rt license is not requ ired but fo re ign exchange is allocated on a quo ta basis. From t ime to t ime, exemp t ions may be gran ted f r om the quo tas established under Schedules II and IV and f rom the proh ib i t ions of Schedule III. App l ica t ions for fo re ign exchange a l loca t ion licenses for impo r ts are subject to a charge of 1 per cent of the am o u nt of the app l ica t ion. When an exchange a l loca t ion license has been ob ta ined f r om the Cen t ral Bank or when such a license is not requ ired, au tho r ized banks are pe rm i t ted to p rov ide exchange au tom a t i c a l ly, but not no rm a l ly pr ior to cus- toms e n t r y. Pr ior exchange con t rol app rov al must be ob ta ined for impo r ts of cap i tal goods on de fe r red pay- ment terms, and for impo r ts of m a c h i n e ry and equ ip- ment when the v a lue is requ i red to be regarded as a con t r ibu t ion towa rd cap i tal or to be accoun ted for on a loan basis. Most impor ts w i th a pro forma invo ice v a lue in excess of K Sh 20,000 are also sub ject to p re sh ipment inspection as to qua l i ty, q u a n t i t y, and price by the Gen- eral Superintendence Company ac t ing for the Cen tral Bank. A "Clean Report of F ind ings" must be ob ta ined before sh ipmen t, and au thor ized banks in Kenya may not issue shipping gua ran tees for the c lea rance of imports un t il this "Clean Report" has been received. 278 The buy ing and con f i rm ing commission w i th respect to imports in to Kenya may not exceed 3 per cent of the value of the impo r t. The interest rate on suppliers' credit normally is l im i ted to 11 per cent per annum. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all coun tr ies other than Tanzan ia and Uganda are controlled. Authorized banks are empowered to approve specified categories of cur- rent paymen ts w i thout l im i ta t ion or up to established l im i ts; amoun ts above these l im i ts as well as other cur- rent paymen ts may be approved adm in is t ra t ive ly, and most cu r r ent paymen ts are in fact un res t r ic ted. The Central Bank may approve h igher rem i t tances for bona f ide educa t ion expenses. Facilities exist whereby na t iona ls of coun t r ies other t h an Tanzan ia and Uganda who come to work in Kenya as employed persons (as well as ce r ta in categories of the se lf-emp loyed, such as doc- tors and den t is ts) for not more th an f o ur years may rem it abroad as sav ings up to 33!/3 per cent of the ir mon th ly salaries but not more than K Sh 3,000 a m o n t h; in add i t ion, they may rem it funds to cover ma in- tenance, educa t ion expenses, etc., provided that their to tal rem i t tances i n c l u d i ng sav ings do not exceed 50 per cent of the ir mon th ly sa lar ies. Expa t r ia tes who have s tayed for over f o ur years in the Scheduled Territories 3 may con t inue to effect rem i t tances f r om salaries as above, but those who a v a il themse lves of the fac i l i t ies for r em i t t a n ce of sav ings f rom sa la r ies are not en t i t led to t r a n s f er a d d i t i o n al sav ings upon em ig ra t ion. Rem i t tances to South A f r i c a, o ther th an those of ce r ta in pensions, a re p roh ib i ted. Non re s ident i n d i v i d u al p rope r ty owne rs m ay r em it up to K Sh 20,000 of net r en t al income in each 12-month period. Any excess of net r e nt over the pe rm i t ted t r an s- fer is placed in a Blocked Account and may be invested in approved secu r i t ies w i th at least f ive years to m a tu r i ty, a f t er wh ich period the redemp t ion proceeds may be r em i t t ed to the non r e s id ent b e n e f i c i a r y. Imports and Import Payments Imports f rom Rhodesia are prohibited. All imports requ i re licenses; for cer ta in imports (see be low) licenses are issued upon application. Imports are divided into two categories: those paid for w i th Korean fo re ign exchange (KFX impo r t s) and those paid for w i th foreign loan fund s. KFX imports are classified as au toma t ic approva l, res tr ic ted, or pro- hibited items. All commodities may be imported freely (i.e., app l ica t ions for impo rt licenses are au toma t ica l ly approved) unless they are in a list of restricted or pro- h ib i ted commodities, subject to the general l im i ts set by the Foreign Exchange Supply and Demand P lan. The commercial terms of payment on wh ich impor ts may be contracted are regu la ted, and advance impo rt deposits are required for most types of goods impor ted by the private sector. These are met, for KFX imports, by deposit of local currency at the t ime of open ing the letter of credit in the case of impo r ts on letters of credit, and for imports not on letters of credit, at the t ime of app ly ing for import licenses. Capital All capital remittances require approval. Not for Redistribution LESOTHO (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange and Trade System Lesotho's currency is the South A f r i c an R a n d. Lesotho fo rms part of the R and Mone ta ry Area, which is a single exchange control te r r i to ry comp r i s ing Lesotho, South A f r ica, and Swaz i land. In re la t ion to countries outside the Rand Monetary Area, Lesotho applies exchange controls that are in all ma te r ial aspects similar to those of South A f r ica and Swaz i land. Pay- ments to nonresidents for cu r rent t ransac t ions, wh i le subject to control, are not norma l ly restricted, but app l i- cations for ou tward t ran s fe rs of capital are considered on their merits. The amounts allowed are up to 25 per cent of the net salary for bachelors and persons having their family in Madagascar, and up to 45 per cent for those whose family lives outside Madagascar (100 per cent for all concerned during leave spent outside Madagascar); in no event, however, may the transferable amount exceed F MG 300,000 a person a month. Resident and nonresident travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to F MG 5,000 in Malagasy banknotes. Nonresident travelers may take out any remaining foreign banknotes and coins and other foreign means of payment declared by them on entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to a ll destinations of products under quota and of so-called controlled products require an exit permit (autorisation de sortie) issued by the Directorate of Commerce or the appropriate commodity stabilization office; these products include coffee, van i l la, cloves, pepper, sugar, rice, and petroleum and petroleum products. SONACO has a monopoly over exports of beans. Export proceeds received in foreign currencies must be surrendered; such export proceeds normally must become due not later than one month after arrival of the goods at their destination. A ll export transactions valued at F MG 50,000 or more must be domiciled with an authorized intermediary and the exporter must sign a commitment to repatriate the foreign currency pro­ ceeds not later than one month after arrival of the goods at their destination. Proceeds from Invisibles A ll amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services, and all income or proceeds accru­ ing in those countries or from nonresidents, must be repatriated within one month of the due date. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of means of payment denominated in a foreign currency. The import of Malagasy banknotes in excess of FMG 5,000 is prohibited. Capital Capital movements between Madagascar and foreign countries and between residents and nonresidents are subject to prior authorization by the M in i s t ry of Finance and Planning. Special controls are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, and over the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Madagascar. Foreign direct investments in Madagascar,2 and Malagasy direct investments abroad,-5 require prior 2 Including those made by companies in Madagascar that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Madagascar of foreign companies. :! Including those made through the intermediary of foreign com­ panies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in M ad a­ gascar and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of com­ panies in Madagascar. M A D A G A S C AR approval of the M in is ter of Finance and Planning (i.e., the Directorate of the Treasury). The total or partial liquidation of such investments must be declared to the M in is t ry of Finance and Planning. Both the making and the liquidation of direct investments, whether these are Malagasy investments abroad or foreign invest­ ments in Madagascar, must be reported to the M in is ter of Finance and Planning within 20 days following each operation. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company, but such participation is subject to prior declaration to the M in i s t ry of Finance and Planning. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Madagascar requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance and Planning. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection w i th shares similar to securities whose issue, offering, or sale in Madagascar has previously been authorized. Borrowing abroad by physical or jur id ical persons, whether public or private persons, requires prior authori­ zation by the M in is ter of Finance and Planning. How­ ever, loans contracted by authorized banks or credit institutions with special legal status are exempt from approval. Lending abroad is subject to authorization by the M in is t ry of Finance and Planning. In accordance with the Investment Code of September 19, 1973, foreign or domestic enterprises of special interest for the economy may be granted pref­ erential treatment in accordance with an "order of approval" (arrete d'agrement). Such enterprises may benefit from specified advantages relating to import and export duties, income taxes, import licenses, the intro­ duction of quotas for competing imports, etc. The same benefits may be granted temporarily to investments not qualifying for an "order of approval." Exceptional treatment beyond the benefits provided for by the Investment Code and other existing legislation may be granted in a participation contract (contrat de participation ). Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Madagascar. Imports and exports of gold require prior authorization by the M in is t ry of Economy and Commerce. Exempt from this require­ ment are (1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Central Bank; (2) imports and exports of manu­ factured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports by travelers of gold jewelry and other articles of gold up to 500 grams a family and collector's coins up to 200 grams a family. Imports of gold, whether licensed or exempt from license, are subject to customs declara­ tion. New ly mined gold must be surrendered to the Directorate of Industry and M ines, which, in principle, must deliver it to the Central Bank after processing. 295 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution M A D A G A S C AR Changes during 1976 January 1. Ordinance N o. 75-043 of December 30, 1975 came into force. It abolished the tariff prefer­ ences granted to the original member states of the E E C. March 15. France again suspended its participation in the European common margins arrangement; the parity between the Malagasy franc and the French franc remained unchanged. March 22. Order N o. 843/3.1 introduced new import licensing procedures designed to facilitate control over the execution of the general import program. March 25. Order N o. 921/3.1 required any natural or jur id ical person to obtain the approval of the M in i s­ try of Economy and Commerce before engaging in import activities. The objective was to reduce the num­ ber of importers so as to facilitate state control over foreign trade. If approval was granted, an "importer's card" was issued, which was a prerequisite for engaging in import transactions. Approved importers had to undertake to purchase goods in any country that the authorities might specify. March 31. Supplement N o. 1005 to Order N o. 843/3.1 provided that all imports had to be shipped within six months following the issue of the import license. April 3. Notice N o. 1006 was gazetted setting out the general import program for 1976. A list of pro­ hibited imports also was issued. June 25. The President announced the nationalization of the petroleum sector. 296 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAWI (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.06641 grams of fine gold per Malawi Kwacha. Since June 7, 1975 the currency has been pegged to the SDR, at MK 1 = S DR 0.9487. The middle rate for the U . S. dollar is determined on the basis of the Fund's daily calculations of the U . S. do l la r -SDR rate; rates for other currencies are determined on the basis of cross rates in the London market. On Decem­ ber 31, 1976, the Reserve Bank's buying and selling rates for the U . S. dollar were MK 1 = US$1.1048 and MK 1 = US$1 .0992, respectively, per US $ 1. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Reserve Bank of Ma lawi under powers delegated to it by the Minister of Finance. M u ch of the authority for approving normal current payments is in turn delegated to commercial banks designated as authorized dealers. Import policy is formulated by the M in is ter of Trade and Industry, sub­ ject to the approval of the Cabinet. The M in is ter is also responsible for the issue of import and export licenses. Prescription of Currency Payments to nonresidents (other than residents of Rhodesia) may be made in M a l awi kwacha to the credit of a nonresident account maintained by the recipient or in any convertible foreign currency 1 traded in M a l aw i. Payments from residents of other countries (except Rho­ desia) may be received in M a l awi kwacha from a non­ resident account or in any convertible foreign currency. Special regulations apply to settlements with Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in M a l awi kwacha held by residents of other countries (except Rhodesia) are designated nonresident accounts. These accounts may be credited with the pro­ ceeds from sales of any convertible foreign currency, with authorized payments in M a l awi kwacha by residents to countries other than Rhodesia, and with transfers from other nonresident accounts. Balances on these accounts may be used to make payments to residents of Ma lawi for any purpose and may be transferred freely to other nonresident accounts; these accounts may also be debited for payments to the account holder while temporarily resident in M a l aw i. Externa! Accounts—Rhodesia are accounts in M a l awi kwacha that are held by persons regarded as residents of Rhodesia. They may only be credited w i th (1) the proceeds from the sale of Rhodesian currency to an authorized dealer in M a l aw i, and (2) transfers from another Rhodesian External Accoun t. The accounts may be debited w i th (1) payments to residents of M a l awi for 1 Under Malawi's exchange control regulations, all currencies other than the Ma lawi kwacha are considered foreign currencies. any purpose; (2) payments to the account holder while temporarily staying in M a l aw i; (3) transfers to another Rhodesian External Accoun t; and (4) transfers to the account holders in Rhodesia. Blocked Accounts in Ma lawi kwacha held with autho­ rized banks by residents of any country other than M a l awi are credited with nontransferable capital sums in Ma lawi currency which have accrued to nonresidents. A ll debits and credits to such accounts require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. No rma l ly, approval is given for the investment of balances of Blocked Accounts in Ma law ian securities, provided that these are held in Ma lawi to the order of an authorized dealer. The interest on Blocked Account balances is freely transferable to the account holder's country of residence. Imports and Import Payments The statutory basis of the principal import restrictions is the Con t rol of Goods A c t, which authorizes the M i n­ ister of Trade and Industry to control and regulate the import, export, distribution, disposal, purchase, sale, wholesale price, and retail price of any goods. It also has provisions which, when brought into operation, w i ll require all importers and exporters to be registered. The import from Rhodesia of asbestos, iron ore, pig iron, chrome, tobacco, copper, and hides and skins is prohibited. F or a number of items,2 import licenses are required regardless of the country of origin. A ll other goods may be imported under an open general license when originating in Commonwealth countries or in non- Commonwealth countries that are members of the G A TT (except Po l and ). Imports originating in the Republic of Ch ina are treated similarly but require an individual license. W i th respect to other countries (including Po land ), an import license is required for all commodi­ ties except certain items that are free from licensing irrespective of origin, such as petroleum products, exposed cinematographic films, bona fide unsolicited gifts not exceeding MK 50 in value, samples, and adver­ tising materials. Payments for imports from a ll countries must be made within six months after the date of import, except with the express permission of the exchange control authorities. Foreign exchange for these payments is automatically granted by the authorized dealers, subject to the presentation of relevant documents and comp l i­ ance with import licensing requirements, and provided that payment does not take place against a sight letter of credit or a sight b i ll of exchange. A ny transfer of - Certain agricultural and food products, new (military type) and used clothing, gold, sugar, wheat flour, cement, fertilizers, newsprint and certain paper products, pencils, ball-point pens, office stapling machines and staples, printing inks, erasers, hand-operated numbering stamps, flick knives, explosives, arms and ammunition, game traps, mist nets, wild animals, live fish, cassava, and copyright articles. 297 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution M A L A WI funds in anticipation of imports is prohibited, except with the permission of the exchange control authorities. Advance payments may, however, be made for imports valued at up to MK 100 on presentation of an invoice or other evidence indicating that the seller requires pay­ ment in advance. A surtax of 15 per cent is levied on most goods imported into M a l aw i, irrespective of their or ig in; the surtax is calculated on 120 per cent of the sum of the value for customs duty purposes and any customs duty payable. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain limits, for other purposes such as travel, is provided by the authorized dealers without prior reference to the exchange control authorities. The basic exchange allowance for private travel is MK 20 a day for an adult, w i th a maximum of MK 600 a calen­ dar year, and MK 10 a day for each ch i ld under 18 years of age, with a maximum of MK 300 a calendar year for children between 10 and 18, and of MK 200 a year for children under 10. The annual allowance is not cumula­ tive but may be increased by up to 50 per cent if the traveler has not applied for a travel allowance during the preceding three years. These allocations are subject to a combined maximum of MK 2,000 a year for a family traveling together. The basic exchange allowance for business travel is MK 40 a day, up to MK 400 a trip for any number of trips a year. Exchange is provided, subject to certain limits, for other purposes such as edu­ cation, medical treatment, and family remittances. A p p l i­ cations for amounts exceeding the standard allocations may be submitted to the exchange control authorities. Foreign nationals employed in M a l awi on contracts or holding a temporary employment permit are allowed to remit up to two thirds of their current net earnings to their country of normal residence. Travelers may take out up to MK 20 in M a l awi cur­ rency and the equivalent of MK 20 in foreign currency in addition to their basic travel allowance. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of goods of any description that exceed MK 100 in value are prohibited, unless the Controller of Customs and Excise is satisfied that payment has been made or w i ll be made in an appropriate manner to a resident of M a l awi not later than six months after the date of exportation. Certain commodities 3 are subject to export licensing, mainly to ensure the adequacy of their domestic supplies. Export proceeds in foreign cur­ rency must be sold to an authorized dealer. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any foreign currency must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer. There is no : {Implements of war, petroleum products, nickel, atomic energy materials, and certain agricultural and animal products. 298 limitation on the amount of foreign currency notes and coins that may be imported by travelers, but not more than MK 20 in M a l awi currency notes and coins may be imported. Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted, w i th the exception that the taking up of loans from abroad by residents requires prior exchange control approval. This is normally granted, provided that the terms of repay­ ment are realistic. Outward transfers of capital are controlled, but nonresidents are permitted to repatriate their investments when they have satisfied the authorities that the original investment was made w i th funds brought into the country from sources outside M a l aw i; there are no restrictions on the transfer abroad of dividends and profits of foreign-owned companies, provided that no recourse is being made to local borrowing. In general, residents are not permitted to transfer capital abroad and, w i th certain exceptions, are required to offer for sale to an authorized dealer any foreign exchange wh ich accrues to them. Emigrants are granted exchange as follows: (1) Persons 50 years of age and over are allowed exchange up to MK 15,000 whether single or married. (2) M a r r i ed persons who have not reached the age of 50 are allowed MK 6,000 on depar­ ture, together with MK 500 for each ch i ld, up to a maxi­ mum of MK 8,000 for a family. (3) Unma r r ied persons who have not reached 50 years of age are allowed MK 3,000 on departure. (4) The balance of the emi­ grant's funds is blocked, but he is permitted to transfer to his new country of residence a sum equal to the origi­ nal emigration allowance on each anniversary of his departure from M a l aw i, up to a maximum of MK 8,000. Applications for emigrants' allowances, whether initial or subsequent, must be submitted to the exchange con­ trol authorities for approval. Residents require prior approval to lend to nonresi­ dents or to resident firms controlled directly or indirectly from outside M a l aw i. App roval to lend to nonresident- controlled firms may be withheld if it is felt that exces­ sive recourse is being had to local borrowing, and that the firms have brought in insufficient work ing capital from abroad; the permissible ratio between nonresident- controlled firms' domestic borrowing and their externally obtained funds is subject to change. Gold Residents of M a l awi may purchase, ho ld, and sell gold coins in M a l awi for numismatic purposes. W i th this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Not for Redistribution MALAYSIA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.290299 gram of fine gold per Malaysian Ringgit, and Malaysia avails itself of wider margins. On June 21, 1973 the authorities ceased to maintain the exchange rate within announced margins, and since September 27, 1975 the ringgit has been pegged to a composite of the currencies of Malaysia's major trading partners. The closing buying and selling rates for the U . S. dollar in the Malaysian foreign exchange market on December 31, 1976 were M$2 .5340 and M$2.5355 per US $ 1, respectively. The commercial banks are free to determine and quote exchange rates for all currencies to customers and are permitted to deal forward in all currencies. Ma lays ia formally accepted the obligations of A r t i­ cle V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from November 11, 1968. Administration of Control The Central Bank of Malaysia administers exchange control on behalf of the Malaysian Government through­ out Ma lays ia, the Governor of the Bank being the Con­ troller of Foreign Exchange. Most of the authority for approving payments abroad is delegated to commercial banks authorized for this purpose; no such delegation has been granted for the repayment of foreign loans or the payment of interest on such loans. The authority for import control rests with the Central Government. The day-to-day administration of import control through­ out Malaysia 1 is carried out jointly by the M in is t ry of Trade and Industry and the Royal Customs and Excise. Prescription of Currency A ll payments to countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca may be made either in ringgit through an External Account, or in any currency other than Israel, Rhodesian, and South A f r ican currencies. Receipts from exports to countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca must be obtained, within the time of payment specified in the commercial con­ tract but subject to a maximum period of six months from the date of exportation, either in ringgit obtained from the sale of a specified currency to a bank in Ma lays ia, or in any specified currency. Special regula­ tions apply to settlements with Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i c a. Nonresident Accounts The accounts in ringgit of residents of countries other than Malaysia are treated as nonresident accounts and, unless specially restricted, are designated External 1 The three territories of Malaysia are Peninsular Ma lays ia, Sabah, and Sarawak. Labuan is a free port. 300 Accounts. There are no restrictions on debits to External Accounts. Credits to these accounts for what­ ever purpose are freely permitted subject only to the completion of exchange control forms for amounts above M$ 1,000; the proceeds from the sale of any foreign currency may be credited to External Accounts. For amounts exceeding M$ 1,000 and up to M $l million, permission may be given by commercial banks; above M $l m i l l ion, permission is given by the Controller of Foreign Exchange. Balances on External Accounts may be transferred to any other account, whether resident or nonresident, and may be converted into any currency except Israel, Rhodesian, and South A f r ican currencies. Accounts of residents of Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are designated as Israel Accounts, Rhodesian Accounts, and South A f r ican Accounts, respectively. A ll debits and credits to such accounts require prior approval. Imports and Import Payments Tariffs and import controls of the various parts of Ma lays ia have not yet been fully unified, although steps toward unification are being taken. Some internal tariffs and other trade restrictions still exist between the terri­ tories of Ma lays ia. Most imports are permitted freely. Depending on the nature and origin of the goods, specific licenses are required for certain imports for health, security, or moral reasons; various conditions must be satisfied before licenses for such goods are issued. Cer­ tain other imports are subject to quantitative restrictions as a temporary measure to protect local industries; these restrictions are reviewed from time to time. Imports into a ll parts of Ma lays ia of a ll commodities from Israel, South A f r i c a, Rhodesia, or any territory administered by any one of these are prohibited. Imports into all parts of Ma lays ia of all commodities from the People's Republic of Ch ina are subject to specific license, and applications to import must be submitted through PERNAS, except those for items subject to quantitative restriction. Imports into all parts of Ma lays ia of all com­ modities from the German Democratic Republic and No r th Ko r ea also require specific licenses. Imports into Peninsular Ma lays ia of primates from all sources, including Sabah and Sarawak, are prohibited except under specific license; imports of other live ani­ mals (except sheep and goats), bones, and bone meal from Brune i, Burma, Cambodia, Indonesia, the Lao People's Democratic Republic, Tha i land, and Viet Nam also require a specific license. Imports into Sarawak of sulfur, certain chemicals, and live sheep and goats from a ll sources, including Peninsular Malaysia and Sabah, are prohibited, except under specific license. Imports of motor vehicles into a ll parts of Malaysia are also subject to specific import licensing. Payment for ©International Monetary Fund. Virtually a ll imports into Ma lays ia (including Penang but excluding Labuan) are subject to a surtax of 5 per cent ad valorem. Some essential goods, such as rice, common salt, and kerosene, are exempt, and a drawback may be granted on goods intended for re-export or for export after processing. In addition, most imports into Malaysia (excluding Labuan) are subject to a sales tax; the standard rate of tax is 5 per cent ad valorem, but certain luxury goods are subject to a rate of 10 per cent ad valorem. of Ch ina, the Republic of Ch ina, Hong K o n g, N o r th Ko rea, the Republic of Ko rea, Macao, and V iet N am. Proceeds from Invisibles The exchange c o n t r ol requ i remen ts gov e rn ing exchange receipts from invisibles are, in principle, s im i­ lar to those for export proceeds. Travelers may bring in up to M$ 1,000 in Malaysian currency notes; otherwise, permission is required for the import of Malaysian notes. No limitations are imposed on the import by travelers of currency notes of other countries. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to a ll countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca may be made without restriction after exchange control requirements have been met. There are no restrictions on the amount of foreign exchange made available for travel abroad. Remittances to nonresidents of dividends, interest, and profits on a ll bona fide investments are permitted, subject only to the completion of exchange control forms for amounts in excess of M$ 1,000. Unless special permis­ sion is obtained, not more than M$ 1,000 in Ma lays ian notes and the equivalent of M$ 1,000 in foreign notes may be taken out of Ma lays ia by travelers. Nonresident travelers are allowed to take out foreign currency notes up to the amount declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds The three territories of Ma lays ia at present maintain separate export control systems, although the Federal Government retains the right to legislate in respect of exports from any Ma lays ian territory. Exchange con­ trol forms have to be completed and authorized by banks in Ma lays ia for exports valued at M$5 ,000 f.o.b. or more.2 Proceeds from exports must be received within the time of payment specified in the commercial contract but subject to a maximum period of six months from the date of export, either in a specified currency or in ringgit obtained from the sale of a specified currency to a bank in Ma lays ia. Exports of rubber from Penin­ sular Ma lays ia require a certificate issued by the Ma lay­ sian Rubber Exchange and Licensing Board. Exports of rubber and tin to South A f r i ca and any territory admin­ istered by South A f r i ca are prohibited. A ll exports to Israel and Rhodesia and any territory administered by either also are prohibited. Exports of cement, scrap iron, steel bars, formic acid, wheat flour, rice bran, and sugar are subject to licensing, and licenses for these and a few other items (such as fertilizers and pig iron) are adminis­ tratively denied. A l so subject to licensing are exports of all textiles, certain confectionery items, tiles, fish meal, bricks, "dollar area goods," a ll commodities used in barter trade, and a ll exports to the People's Republic 3 In the case of exports to Indonesia, in excess of M$100,000. Capital Inward investment covered by the guidelines issued on February 20, 1974 (regarding the acquisition of assets, mergers, and take-overs) or by those issued on October 29, 1975 (regarding foreign equity participa­ tion) requires prior approval by the Foreign Investment Committee. The proceeds of investments may be repa­ triated freely on resale, subject to the completion of exchange control forms for amounts above M$ 1,000. Malaysian residents require approval for borrowings from nonresidents in either ringgit or in foreign cur­ rencies. Companies in Ma lays ia controlled by nonresi­ dents are permitted to borrow in Ma lays ia up to M$500 ,000 without exchange control approval. The permission of the Controller of Foreign Exchange is freely given for direct and portfolio investment by Malaysian residents in countries other than Israel, Rho­ desia, and South A f r i c a. Gold Residents other than authorized dealers in gold are not permitted to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than gold that has been materially increased in value by skilled craftsmanship. The manufacture, import, or export of gold coins is prohibited, as is domestic trading in gold coins other than the M$100, M$200, M$250, and M$500 gold coins of Malaysian currency and the S$ 150 gold coin of Singapore currency. Resident and nonresident travelers, however, may bring in or take out, on their person, one piece each of the M$100, M$200, and M$250 gold coins. A traveler may also bring in on his person one M$500 gold co in. The export of the M$500 gold coin in any manner is prohibited. In addition, each traveler is allowed to bring in from any country outside Ma lays ia one S$150 gold coin issued by the Singapore Board of Commissioners of Currency, and each traveler may take out one such coin, but only to Singapore. Licensed goldsmiths are permitted by the exchange control authorities to purchase certain quanti­ ties of gold from an authorized dealer at local free market prices for the manufacture of bona fide jewelry and ornaments. Furthermore, producers of gold are per­ mitted to sell their output at local free market prices to authorized dealers in gold. 301 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution M A L A Y S IA Imports of gold are restricted under the Customs A c t, 1967, and require licenses from the M in is t ry of Trade and Industry. Permission for imports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler is normally not given except for imports by authorized dealers in gold to meet the genuine require­ ments of goldsmiths for manufacturing jewelry and ornaments and for industrial use. Imports are allocated to authorized dealers in gold by means of a tender sys­ tem; successful tenderers must pay a premium to the Government. Imports are subject to a 7 per cent import duty and a 5 per cent surtax as well as a sales tax of 10 per cent ad valorem. The sale of gold by domestic producers is subject only to the sales tax, at 10 per cent ad valorem. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler are prohibited under the exchange control regulations; any export licenses that might be issued for gold or gold coins would require in addition the approval of the exchange control authorities.
