Not for Redistribution MA LD IV E S1 (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System No par value or central rate has been established for the currency of Maldives, the Ma ld iv ian Rupee. A fixed official rate is maintained of M ai Rs 3.93 = US $ 1. There is also a fluctuating exchange rate in a free market conducted by the two commercial banks; on Decem­ ber 31, 1976 this rate was about M ai Rs 8.5 = US $ 1. The official rate is applicable to all public sector trans­ actions and the free market rate to the transactions of the private sector. There is no central bank. U . S. do l­ lars, pounds sterling, and certain other foreign curren­ cies circulate freely and may be used for domestic payments. Administration of Control No exchange control legislation has been issued. Exchange and trade controls are administered by the Department of Finance. This Department also issues import and export licenses. Most import and export trade is conducted by the State Trad ing Organization. Prescription of Currency There are no rules prescribing the currencies in which transactions between residents and nonresidents must be settled. No bilateral payments agreements are in force. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by residents and those held by nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments The importation of alcoholic beverages and a few other items is restricted for reasons of public policy. Imports are subject to licensing only if undertaken to match licensed exports of domestic products (see Sec­ tion on Exports and Export Proceeds, be low ). Import licenses, where required, are issued freely. The foreign exchange for licensed and unlicensed imports by the private sector must be obtained in the free market. Most staples (including rice, sugar, wheat flour, and kerosene) are imported at the official rate by the State Trading Organization. 1 Maldives is not a member of the International Monetary Fund. Payments for Invisibles The private sector may freely make payments for all current invisibles through the free market. Payments by the public sector are made at the official rate. Trave l­ ers may freely take out any amount in domestic or foreign currency, subject to declaration only. Exports and Export Proceeds The Government has a monopoly over the export of fresh and dried "Ma ld ive fish." Private sector exports of all other domestic products require licenses. These are not normally withheld, but exporters are required to import equivalent commodities within a specified period. In the interim before the counterimports are paid for, the export proceeds are freely disposable through the free market. Re-exports are exempt both from export licensing and from the requirement of matching the transaction with future imports. Proceeds from Invisibles Private sector receipts from current invisibles need not be surrendered and may be disposed of freely through the free market. Travelers may freely bring in any amount in domestic or foreign currency, subject to declaration only. Capital Residents of the private sector as well as nonresidents may freely import and export capital through the free market, and residents do not require permission to maintain foreign currency accounts at home or abroad. A ll public sector transactions take place at the official rate. Inward direct investment requires approval, and the acquisition of land by noncitizens is prohibited. Gold Transactions in gold are not subject to regulation. Residents may freely hold and negotiate gold in any form, at home or abroad, and the import and export of gold do not require licenses. Changes during 1976 No significant changes took place. 303 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALI (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System No par value or central rate for the currency of M a li has been established with the Fund. The official unit of currency is the M a li Franc, which is officially main­ tained at the rate of MF 1 = 0.01 French franc. There is also a fixed rate for C FA francs of MF 2 = C F AF 1. Exchange rates for other currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned. W i th the exception of those relating to gold, Ma l i 's exchange control measures do not apply to (1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories, except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera­ tions Account (Benin, Cameroon, the Central A f r ican Empire, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper V o l t a ). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. A ll other countries, except M a li itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only w i th foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control The Minister of Finance and Commerce has sole authority in exchange control matters; certain exchange control powers have been delegated to authorized banks. The bilateral payments agreements are operated by the Development Bank of M a l i. Licenses for imports and exports are issued by the Directorate-General of Eco­ nomic Affairs in the M in is try of Finance and C om­ merce. Exchange control is applicable only to foreign countries. Prescription of Currency Settlements on account of transactions covered by bilateral payments agreements are made in currencies and through accounts established under such agree­ ments. Bilateral accounts are maintained with the Peo­ ple's Republic of Ch ina, the German Democratic Re­ public, Egypt, Hungary, Mo rocco, Poland, Romania, the U .S .S .R ., and V iet N a m .1 M a li is an Operations Account country of the French Franc A rea, since its Central Bank maintains an Opera­ tions Account with the French Treasury; settlements with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc A rea are made in M a li francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Settlements with all other countries with which no payments agree­ ment is in force are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those coun- tries or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. Settlements w i th the Central Bank of West A f r ican States (for Benin, Ivory Coast, N iger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Vo l ta) and The Gamb ia, Ghana, L ibe r ia, N iger ia, and Sierra Leone are normally made through the West A f r ican C lear ing House. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are, in principle, based on those applied in France. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few commodities are prohibited for health, safety, and similar reasons, and licenses are not normally issued for certain other goods. Imports of all other goods, when originating outside the West African Economic Community, require individual licenses, and imports from foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank. Imports originating in a country of the West A f r ican Economic Community require only an import certificate. Imports from the Republic of Ch ina, Israel, Ko rea, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Imports are licensed in accordance w i th an annual import program. The program consists of two parts: an allocation for clearing countries and one for the convertible area (defined as comprising a ll other coun­ tries, including the French Franc A r e a ). Certain aid- financed imports are not included in the import program and do not require an import license. Imports may be made either by private importers or by state enterprises, among which the Societe Malienne d'lmport-Export (SOMIEX) is by far the most important, having a monopoly over the import of a number of items.2 A ll imports from and exports to countries that have payments agreements with M a li are made by SOMIEX or UNICOOP. The Office des Produits Agricoles du M a li ( O P A M) has a monopoly over the import of cereals. An allocation commission establishes quotas for each private importer on the basis of his turnover. Import licenses are issued to the private importer up to the limit of the quota accorded to h im. In addition, exporters may with an import license import any goods under the E X IC (Exportation et Importation Concomitante) pro­ cedure. The authorized banks are permitted to make foreign exchange available for a ll licensed imports. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above) and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc A r ea are permitted freely; those to other 1 The payments arrangement with Morocco is inoperative. 2 These include cement, flour, milk, salt, soap, sugar, and tea. 304 ©International Monetary Fund. For tourist travel, residents traveling to countries other than France (as defined above) and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc A rea may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equiva­ lent to MF 150,000 a person, which may be taken up twice a year; any foreign exchange remaining after return to M a li must be surrendered. For business travel, there is a special allocation of the equivalent of MF 40,000 a day, subject to a maximum of MF 400,000 a t r ip .3 The transfer of the entire salary of a foreigner working in M a li is permitted upon presentation of the appropriate pay voucher, provided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period. Resi­ dent travelers, irrespective of destination, may take out up to a maximum of MF 50,000 in M a li banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Opera­ tions Account countries ( MF 5,000 for trips of less than 24 hours). They may also take out MF 50,000 in M a li banknotes and any payments instruments drawn up abroad in their name. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank, and export proceeds received in currencies other than those of France or another Opera­ tions Account country must be surrendered; export pro­ ceeds must normally be collected and repatriated w i th in 90 days after the arrival of the goods at their destina­ tion. Exports to countries outside the West A f r ican Economic Community require individual licenses; those to countries of the West A f r ican Econom ic Community require only a certificate. The export of cotton and groundnuts is reserved in principle for SOMIEX and that of meat and hides and skins for the Societe Malienne du Betail, des Peaux et Cu irs (SOM B E P EC); in practice, hides and skins may also be exported by private firms and individuals. The marketing of cereals is entrusted to O P A M. Under the E X IC procedure, exporters may retain 75 per cent of the proceeds from exports of commodities of the traditional sector except those covered by the monopoly of state trading companies, for payment for their own imports that are made through regular official channels. Resi­ dent and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the Central Bank of M a l i, the Bank of France, or a bank of issue maintaining an Operations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc A r e a. Capital Capital movements between M a l i, France (as defined above), and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc A rea are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls ( in addition to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad; the Development Bank of M a li is exempt. The special control measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above) or to coun­ tries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Accoun t. Not for Redistribution MA L TA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Ma l ta Pound. In December 1971 a central rate of 2.18613 grams of fine gold per M a l ta pound was established, cor­ responding at the time to <£M 0.3744112 = U S $ 1, or £M 0.406504 = S DR 1, and Ma l ta avails itself of wider margins. However, since July 8, 1972 the Ma l ta pound has been pegged to a basket of currencies. The Central Bank of Ma l ta quotes daily rates for deutsche mark, Italian lire, pounds sterling, and U . S. dollars based on developments in the principal exchange markets abroad. The Central Bank's basic rate (middle rate) for the pound sterling on December 31, 1976 was <£ stg. 137.80 per <£M 100, and its basic rate for the U . S. dollar was US$2,344 per <£M 1. The commercial banks' rates for currencies not quoted by the Central Bank are based on market rates in London and New Y o r k. Administration of Control Exchange controls are administered by the Central Bank as agent for the Minister of Finance, Customs and People's F inanc ial Investments; trade controls are administered by the Director of Trade in the M in is t ry of Trade. A large number of authorities to approve appli­ cations for the allocation of foreign exchange have been delegated to the authorized banks. Prescription of Currency Authorized payments to all countries may be made by crediting Ma l ta pounds to an External Account or in any foreign cu r r en cy ;1 the proceeds of exports to a ll countries may be received in Ma l ta pounds from an External Account or in any foreign currency. Nonresident Accounts Residents of all countries outside Ma l ta may maintain with authorized banks nonresident accounts in Ma l ta pounds, designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited freely with authorized payments to non­ residents, with transfers from other External Accounts, with the proceeds from sales of gold or any foreign currency (including banknotes), and with M a l ta bank­ notes mailed from outside Ma l ta. External Accounts may be debited freely for payments to residents, for transfers to other External Accounts, for payments in cash in M a l t a, and for purchases of any foreign currency (including banknotes). Authorized dealers may also freely open and maintain foreign currency accounts for nonresidents. These accounts may be credited with payments in foreign currency to the account holder, with transfers from another foreign currency account belonging to a non- 1 Foreign currencies are defined as all currencies other than Malta pound. the resident, and with interest payable on foreign currency accounts. They may be debited for payments by the account holder to residents, for transfers to other foreign currency accounts, and for transfers abroad. Blocked Accounts in M a l ta pounds are maintained for Maltese nationals who emigrate. Assets of such emigrants in excess of the amount ( £M 7,500) that may be transferred to the new country of residence are credited to a Blocked Account; funds so credited are normally released three years after the date of departure on application to the Central Bank. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain commodities are either prohibited or restricted. A ll imports from A lban ia, Bulgaria, Czecho­ slovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, No r th Ko rea, Poland, Rhodesia, Romania, the U .S .S .R ., and V iet N am are subject to specific licensing, are as imports of certain items from any country of origin. Imports from countries other than those mentioned that are not prohibited and do not require a specific license may be made freely under open general license. Imports subject to state trading include sugar, cereals, and cement. Payments for all authorized imports may be made freely, provided that the prescription of currency regulations are complied w i th and that supporting documents, including the customs entry form, are sub­ mitted to the intermediary bank. Payments for Invisibles A ll payments for invisibles in excess of <£M 50 require the approval of the exchange control authorities; the approval authority has been delegated to authorized banks for most types of payment. There is a standard exchange allocation for tourist travel of the equivalent of <£M 250 a person a trip; a business travel allowance of £M 250 a trip or £ M 3 0a day (for up to 30 days a t r ip ), whichever is the larger; and an allowance for educational expenses abroad of <£M 3,000 a person for an academic year.2 Applications for allowances in excess of these amounts are approved by the Central Bank if the latter is satisfied that there is no i l l ic it capital outflow involved. The transfer of genuine profits, dividends, and interest from approved foreign investments requires Central Bank permission, which is normally given, after com­ pliance with certain formalities. L ife insurance expressed in Ma l ta currency may be contracted with nonresidents lawfully engaged in insurance business in M a l t a, pro­ vided the policy is made for a term exceeding five years and is not linked to equity or property units. Travelers may export Ma l ta banknotes and coins up to <£M 25 for each person. Exports of foreign currencies may be made by resident travelers up to <£M 250 for each person and by nonresident travelers up to the amount brought in. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of works of art and strategic war materials are prohibited and, with the exception of some 80 items that may be exported freely, all other exports are subject to specific licensing. The proceeds of exports are subject to surrender within six months of shipment. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Travelers may bring in any amount in Ma l ta and other currency notes. Capital No control is exercised over receipts. Receipts in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an autho­ rized bank, and payments of a capital nature in such currencies require prior approval. Applications for out­ ward direct investment by residents of Ma l ta and for direct investment in Ma l ta by nonresidents are con­ sidered on their merits. The purchase of real estate in Ma l ta is controlled by the Immovable Property (Acqu is i­ tion by Non-Residents) A c t, 1974. This A c t, which is administered by the M in is t ry of Finance, prohibits the acquisition of immovable property in Ma l ta by non­ residents,3 with the exception of certain special cases which would be mainly related to the economic devel­ opment of M a l t a. Applications for the acquisition of property for use as a residence from individuals who do not already hold any property in Ma l ta are given favorable consideration. The Central Bank has delegated to authorized dealers the authority to approve the acquisition of foreign investments up to the equivalent of £M 500 a person a calendar year by resident persons over 18. Purchases of personal real estate situated out­ side M a l ta in excess of the <£M 500 limit require prior exchange control approval. Foreign nationals who repatriate or take up residence outside Ma l ta normally are allowed to transfer all their assets to their new country of residence. Maltese nationals who emigrate may transfer abroad up to £M 7,500 for each family; any excess amount is nor­ mally released three years after the date of departure on application to the Central Bank. : {F or the purpose of this A c t, the term nonresidents means (1) individuals who are not citizens of Ma l ta; (2) any association of persons, or any entity, whether corporate or not, if (a) it is registered outside Ma l ta, or (b) it has its principal place of residence or of business outside Ma l ta, or (c) 20 per cent or more of its share or other capital is owned by a nonresident person, or (d) it is in any manner, and whether directly or indirectly, controlled by one or more nonresident persons. 308 Banks, other than those licensed to borrow and lend outside M a l ta only, are restricted in the acquisition of net foreign assets. Gold Ma l ta has issued 16 gold coins which are legal tender. Residents other than authorized banks are allowed to hold coins or acquire jewelry. Residents may freely pur­ chase, sell, and hold any gold coins. The import of gold coins for numismatic purposes is controlled to ensure that such coins are genuinely for numismatic purposes. A specific import license is required for imports of gold coins, gold bullion, and manufactured or semimanu­ factured articles of gold; imports of filigree work of gold or silver are prohibited. Au thor ized importers are per­ mitted to import gold (bullion and coins) only for the purpose of disposing of it to jewelers and other indus­ trial users. The export of gold by residents other than the monetary authorities requires the permission of the exchange control authorities. G o ld bullion and gold coins are free of import duty. Deposits made in 1976 and 1977 would earn interest at 8 per cent and S3A per cent, respectively. U p on maturity of a deposit, it could either be retained in the scheme or withdrawn, in which case the funds could be reinvested abroad. February 13. Not for Redistribution MAURITANIA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange System No par value or central rate for the currency of Maur i tan ia has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the Ouguiya, which is defined as equivalent to 0.016 gram of fine gold. Since January 22, 1974 the Central Bank of Maur i tan ia has quoted daily buying and selling rates for the U . S. dollar and 16 other currencies 1 on the basis of variations in the relationship between the U . S. dollar and four European currencies (Belgian francs, deutsche mark, French francs, and Netherlands guilders). The exchange rate on December 31, 1976 was UM 43.31 buying, and UM 43.97 selling, per U S $ 1. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in the Central Bank and the Minister of Finance. The former also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Maur i tan ia, inward direct investment and all outward investment, the purchase abroad of domestic and foreign securities, and the solicitation of funds in Mauritania for placement in foreign countries. The approval authority in respect of exchange control has been delegated to the Central Bank, which in turn has delegated some approval authority to authorized banks. The Central Bank is authorized to collect, either direct or through the inter­ mediary of the banks and the Postal Administration, any information necessary to compile the balance of pay­ ments statistics. A ll exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks or, in some cases, through the Postal Adm in is tra­ tion. Import and export licenses are issued by the Foreign Trade Department in the M in is t ry of Commerce. A ll import licenses require exchange control approval by the Central Bank. The Na t ional Import and Export Corporation (SONIMEX) has a monopoly over imports of sugar, tea, rice, and certain textiles and over exports of gum arabic. Prescription of Currency A ll settlements with Israel and South A f r ica are pro­ hibited. Settlements with other countries usually take place in convertible currencies. Nonresident Accounts There are two kinds of nonresident accounts in domes­ tic currency: Convertible Accounts, which may only be credited with proceeds from the sale of foreign cur­ rency or transfers from other Convertible Accounts, and 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, C FA francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, M a li francs, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, and Swiss francs. 310 Internal Nonresident Accounts, which may be credited with domestic banknotes. Convertible Accounts may be debited without Central Bank approval for any payment inside or outside Mau r i tan ia. Imports and Import Payments Imports of Israeli and South A f r ican origin and/or provenance are prohibited. The import of a few goods is prohibited from any source for reasons of health or public policy. Imports from a ll countries require an import license. Only holders of importer-exporter cards are permitted to engage in import transactions. SONIMEX has a monopoly over the import of sugar, rice, green tea, percales, and Guinea cloth. Import transactions must be domiciled with an authorized bank, except in the case of imports "without payment." After the approval (visa) of the Central Bank has been obtained, the import license entitles the importer to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than ten days before shipment if a documentary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodities have already arrived. Advance pay­ ments for imports require prior approval by the Central Bank. There are special arrangements for imports in border areas. Payments for Invisibles Payments to Israel and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Payments for invisibles to other countries are subject to the approval of the Central Bank, which has delegated its approval authority for certain specified payments (subject to conditions laid down in circulars) to autho­ rized banks. Basic exchange allocations have been established for various types of invisibles. F or tourist travel, residents traveling to any foreign country may obtain an annual exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to UM 10,000 a person ( UM 5,000 for children under ten). There are special arrangements for travel to neighbor­ ing countries. The use of all travel allocations must be marked in a personal travel exchange booklet (carnet de change). The transfer of savings from salaries by for­ eigners working in Maur i tan ia is permitted up to varying percentages, according to family status. Travelers are not allowed to take out domestic banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports to Israel and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Only holders of importer-exporter cards are permitted to engage in export transactions. Export transactions to a ll countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds UM 5,000. Exporters must sign an undertaking to repatriate and surrender the foreign exchange proceeds (engagement de change). Exports to ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution all countries require an export license and the approval (visa) of the Central Bank. Export proceeds must be surrendered not later than the due date of the payment, which must not normally be more than 60 days after shipment. Exports of gum arabic are the monopoly of SONIMEX, and exports of cattle of SONICOB. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles must be sur­ rendered. A ll amounts due from nonresidents in respect of services and a ll income earned abroad from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date of the payment. The importa­ tion of domestic banknotes by travelers is prohibited. Capital Transfers of capital between Maur i tan ia and Israel and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Cap i tal movements between Maur i tan ia and a ll foreign countries are subject to exchange control; capital transfers to all countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts normally are permitted freely, although the subsequent investment of the funds in Mauritania may require approval, as indicated below. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and a ll outward investment, over the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Maur i tan ia, and over the solicitation of funds in Maur i tan ia for placement in foreign countries; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to payments or receipts. A ll investments abroad by residents of Maur i tan ia require prior authorization by the Central Bank. Foreign direct investments in M a u r i t a n i a2 and Mauritanian direct investments abroad ,3 must be declared to the Central Bank before they are made. The Central Bank has a period of two months from receipt of the declara­ tion during which it may request the postponement of the projects submitted to it. The full or partial liquida­ tion of inward or outward investment also requires declaration. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Mauritanian investments abroad or foreign investments in Maur i tan ia, must be reported to the Central Bank within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, 2 Including those made by companies in Maur itan ia that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Maur itan ia of foreign companies. 3 Including those made through the intermediary of foreign com­ panies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in M a u r i­ tania and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Mauritania. M A U R I T A N IA provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Mau r i tan ia requires prior authorization by the Central Bank. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection w i th loans backed by a guarantee from the Maur i tan ian Government. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Central Bank. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constituting a direct investment, wh ich are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans con­ tracted by authorized banks; and (3) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount outstand­ ing of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed UM 10 m i l l ion for any one borrower and provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate. The repayment of loans not constituting a direct investment requires the special authorization of the Central Bank if the loan itself was subject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Furthermore, such prior approval is required for the repayment of a ll amounts borrowed abroad prior to the publication of Decree N o. 72-249 of November 27, 1972. Lend ing abroad is subject only to exchange control authorization. Domestic bank credit is restricted. The Investment Code (Law N o. 76-251 of October 16, 1976) provides for various benefits for private invest­ ments in Maur i tan ia. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Maur i tan ia. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the Central Bank. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by the Central Bank, and (2) imports and exports of manufactured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles). Changes during 1976 January 1. Law N o. 75-351 of December 31, 1975 came into force. It eliminated the tariff preferences granted to the original member states of the E E C. Specified items, however, were exempted from customs duty when imported from a member state of the enlarged E E C. February 25. Law N o. 76-017 of January 27 was gazetted. It lifted the prohibition on trade w i th Portugal. October 16. A new Investment Code, Law N o. 76-251, was adopted. 3 11 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAURITIUS (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.159961 gram of fine gold per Mau r i t ian Rupee. The central rate is SDR 1 = M au Rs 7.713759, and Mauritius avails itself of wider margins. The pound sterling is the intervention currency. Commercial banks are authorized to deal with customers in sterling at rates based on the SDR transaction rate for sterling and in other foreign currencies 1 at rates based on London market rates for these currencies. The Bank of Maur i t ius' rates for sterling on December 31, 1976 were M au Rs 11.28 buying, and M au Rs 11.32 selling, per <£ stg. 1. The commercial banks' rates for sterling on the same date were M au Rs 11.223 buying, and M a u Rs 11.353 selling, per <£ stg. 1, and for the U . S. dollar the rates were M au Rs 6.61 buying, and M au Rs 6.73 selling, per US$1 (for transactions in excess of US$12 ,000 ). A different effective rate results from the application of a stamp duty of 35.70 per cent to outward capital transfers other than transfers of banking funds and to payments for gold coins and gold bu l l ion. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of M a u­ ritius under powers delegated to it by the F inanc ial Secretary. The authority for approving practically all current payments is in turn delegated to the commercial banks. The M in is t ry of Commerce and Industry is responsible for the issue of import and export licenses, where required. Prescription of Currency F or prescription of currency purposes Mauritius dis­ tinguishes between Sterling A rea coun tr ies2 and Exter­ nal Account countries. Payments to residents of Sterling A rea countries may be made in rupees to a Sterling A r ea Account in Mauritius or in any Sterling A rea currency. Payments from residents of the Sterling A rea may be received in rupees from a Sterling A rea Account in Mauritius or in any currency of the Sterling A rea. Pay­ ments to residents of countries outside the Sterling A rea may be made in rupees to a Sterling A rea Account or an External Account in Mauritius, in sterling to an External Account in the United K ingdom, or in any non-Sterling A rea currency other than Rhodesian cur­ rency. Payments from residents of countries outside the Sterling A rea may be received in rupees from an External Account in Mauritius, in sterling from an External Account in the Un i ted K ingdom, or in any non- Sterling A rea currency other than Rhodesian currency. Special regulations apply to settlements w i th Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts There are two main types of nonresident accounts: Sterling Area Accounts and External Accounts. Sterling Area Accounts wh ich may be opened by per­ sons and firms resident in countries of the Sterling A r e a ,2 may be credited with (1) authorized payments by resi­ dents of Maur i t ius; (2) any transfers from other Ster­ ling A rea Accounts; (3) any payments from External Accounts held in Maur i t ius or elsewhere in the Sterling A rea; and (4) the proceeds of the sale to an authorized dealer of any foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) or gold by nonresidents of Maur i t ius. They may be debited for (1) payments from residents of the Sterling A r ea to residents of Mau r i t ius; (2) transfers to other Sterling A rea Accounts; (3) transfers to External Accounts in Mauritius or elsewhere in the Sterling Area in respect of which the permission of the exchange con­ trol authorities in the appropriate Sterling A r ea country has been given; and (4) the cost of purchase of any Sterling A rea currency. External Accounts may be opened by persons and firms resident outside both Maur i t ius and the Sterling A rea. They may be credited w i th (1) authorized pay­ ments by residents of Mau r i t ius; (2) payments from Sterling A rea Accounts in respect of wh ich the permis­ sion of the exchange control authorities of the appro­ priate Sterling A r ea country has been given; (3) any transfers from other External Accounts; and (4) the proceeds of the sale to an authorized dealer of any non-Sterling A r ea currency (other than Rhodesian cur­ rency) or gold by nonresidents of Maur i t ius and the Sterling A rea. They may be debited for (1) any pay­ ments to residents of Maur i t ius; (2) any transfers to Sterling A rea Accounts; (3) any transfers to other External Accounts; and (4) the cost of purchase of any foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) or gold. In addition to the above, there are also Blocked Accounts to which are credited funds owned by persons and firms resident outside Maur i t ius realized from investments made by them prior to A p r il 5, 1966, as well as funds representing emigrants' assets in excess of M au Rs 100,000. Such accounts may be credited with payments by residents of Maur i t ius that have been spe­ cifically authorized for credit to a B locked Account and may be debited for certain specified transactions. Funds from Blocked Accounts may, with approval, be invested in Maur i t ius. U p on the realization of such investments, the proceeds are directed once more to a Blocked Accoun t. 1 The exchange control regulations of Mauritius define foreign cur­ rencies as all currencies other than the Maur it ian rupee. - The exchange control regulations of Mauritius define the Sterling A r ea as comprising the United K ingdom, the Channel Islands, the Isle of M a n, and the Republic of Ireland. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. There is a list of commodities for wh ich a specific license from the 312 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Ministry of Commerce and Industry is required, regard­ less of or ig in. A ll other goods may be freely imported under open general licenses granted to individual traders when imported from countries of the Sterling A r ea (as defined before June 23, 1972), but most of these goods require a specific license when imported from non- Sterling A r ea countries. General licenses are granted liberally. Specific licenses are issued on the basis of domestic requirements. The issue of a general or spe­ cific license automatically carries w i th it exchange con­ trol authority to make the corresponding import pay­ ments, subject to compliance with the prescription of currency regulations. Certain imports are subject to temporary customs surcharges. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain limits, for certain other purposes such as travel, is provided by the commercial banks without prior reference to the exchange control authorities. The basic travel allowance for tourist purposes is the equiva­ lent of <£ stg. 400 a person a year for travel to any country except Rhodesia. The allowance for business travel is the equivalent of <£ stg. 35 a day. Applications for exchange for business travel are examined by the Bank of Maur i t ius. There are also established limits for payments and transfers to Sterling A rea countries and to non-Sterling A r ea countries in respect of family sup­ port, salary remittances by non-Mauritian nationals, trade commissions, subscriptions to clubs and societies, publishing rights, advertising outside Maur i t ius, royalties, professional and technical services, education, and leave salaries. Applications for amounts exceeding the stan­ dard allocations may be submitted to the exchange con­ trol authorities. Residents and nonresident travelers may take out Mau Rs 350 in domestic currency. Resident travelers may take out foreign currency notes up to the amount of their travel allowance. Nonresident travelers may take out any foreign currency declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. A l so prohibited, unless permission is obtained from the F inanc ial Secre­ tary, are exports of (1) articles made wholly or partially of gold, platinum, or silver; (2) diamonds, precious and semiprecious stones, pearls, and articles mounted w i th these; and (3) works of art. A ll exports valued at more than M au Rs 1,000 and a ll exports of food valued at over M au Rs 50 require a license from the M in i s t ry of Commerce and Industry. The Maur i t ius Sugar Syndicate is the sole exporter of sugar. A 6-12 per cent export tax is levied on sugar exports, as well as an additional export levy of M au Rs 100 a ton. A ll export proceeds in any currency other than Mau r i t ian rupees must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer. However, per­ M A U R I T I US mission may be given to large export-import companies to retain export proceeds for a reasonable period of time to meet payments for imports. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any currency other than Mau r i t ian rupees must be offered for sale to an autho­ rized bank. There is no limitation on the amount of foreign currency notes and coins that may be imported, but not more than M au Rs 700 in domestic currency notes and coins may be imported by travelers. Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted. Out­ ward transfers of capital are subject to certain restric­ tions. Nonbank residents of Mauritius may transfer a reasonable amount of capital to any country in the Sterling A r ea (see footnote 2) on payment of a 35.70 per cent stamp duty (a duty of 34 per cent plus a surcharge of 5 per cent thereon); they may, subject to permission, which is freely granted, also transfer a rea­ sonable amount of capital to External Account A r ea countries on payment of the stamp duty. Nonresidents require permission to transfer capital to any country; transfers are subject to the payment of stamp duty at the rate of 35.70 per cent and, if directed toward a country outside the Sterling A r ea by a resident of the Sterling A r e a, require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities of the Sterling A rea country con­ cerned. Foreign-owned companies may freely transfer abroad dividends, profits, and interest on capital. Per­ mission for the repatriation of capital is not granted for capital brought in before A p r il 5, 1966, irrespective of the country of origin, but is, in normal circumstances, given for capital brought in on or after that date. P ro­ ceeds from the sale, liquidation, etc., of foreign capital that may not be repatriated must be credited to Blocked Accounts. Emigrants may take out, at the official rate of exchange and free of stamp duty, the equivalent of M au Rs 100,000 from their Mau r i t ian assets when emigrating to any country except Rhodesia; this facility is available upon redesignation as a nonresident, wh ich occurs upon departure. The balance of an emigrant's funds must be credited for an indefinite period to a Blocked Accoun t; any releases that may be approved for transfer abroad are subject to payment of the 35.70 per cent stamp duty. Persons emigrating from Maur i t ius are not entitled to draw their personal travel allowance in addition to the emigration facilities. Gold Residents other than the monetary authorities are permitted to hold gold in the form of numismatic coins (including commemorative gold coins of M au Rs 200 and M au Rs 1,000) or personal jewelry and ornaments. The import and export of monetary gold are prohibited, 313 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution M A U R I T I US except when made by the monetary authorities. Imports of gold for industrial purposes are subject to a quota and specific import license. Exports of articles made wholly or partially of gold, other than jewelry consti­ tuting the personal effects of a traveler, are prohibited. Payments in respect of private imports of gold coins and gold bullion are subject to the 35.70 per cent stamp duty. Imports of certain jewelry are subject to temporary cus­ toms surcharges. Changes during 1976 January 5. The Mauritian rupee was repegged from sterling to the SDR. A central rate of SDR 1 = Mau Rs 7.713759 was established, and Mauritius availed itself of wider margins. The pound sterling remained the intervention currency. Previously, the official rate for ster­ ling had been maintained at Mau Re 1 = <£ stg. 0.075. February 27. Importers were required to pay from their own resources at least 25 per cent of the cost of imported goods, and banks were required to restrict their credit in respect of such imports to at most 75 per cent of the invoice value. Exempt were imports by the Gov­ ernment. Subsequently, exemptions were also granted for imports by manufacturing industries and educational institutions, as well as imports of rice, lentils, beans, split peas, powdered milk, sardines, and other canned fish. 314 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MEXICO (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0589330 gram of fine gold per Mexican Peso. Since September 1, 1976 the exchange rate has not been maintained within announced mar­ gins. On December 31, 1976 the closing rates for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, were Mex$ 19.90 buying, and Mex$20.00 selling, per US $ 1. Banks may freely engage in exchange transactions between the peso and any other currency. There are forward exchange facilities for transactions between Mex ican pesos and foreign currencies. On November 12, 1946, Mex ico notified the Fund that it was prepared to formally accept the obligations of Ar t ic le V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agree­ ment. Prescription of Currency No obligations prescribing the method or currency for payments to or from nonresidents are imposed on importers, exporters, or others. In accordance with payments agreements with Iran and Yugoslavia, pay­ ments for direct commercial transactions and related expenses with those countries handled through the Mexican banking system may, with the prior authoriza­ tion of the Bank of Mex ico, be made through special accounts denominated in U . S. dollars. Payments between Mexico and Argentina, Bo l iv ia, B r a z i l, Ch i le, Co lomb ia, Ecuador, Paraguay, Peru, Uruguay, and Venezuela may be settled through accounts maintained with each other by the Bank of Mex ico and the central banks concerned, within the framework of the L A F TA multilateral clear­ ing system. Similar arrangements exist for payments between Mex ico and the Dom in ican Republic and between Mex ico and Cuba. Payments to Costa R ica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua in respect of trade and invisibles may be settled in Mex ican pesos or Central Amer ican currencies in accordance with the reciprocal credit agreements between the cen­ tral banks of those countries. Imports and Import Payments Payments and transfers abroad may be made freely. A few imports are prohibited. A ll imports must be accompanied by an exporter's declaration of shipment. For many goods, irrespective of origin, import licenses from the M in is t ry of Commerce are required before firm orders are placed; the issuance of such licenses may be subject to quantitative restriction. F or specified commodities, "open end" import licenses (permisos abiertos) may be granted that permit limited importa­ tion during a specified period o f - t im e, such as six months or a year; subject to screening of the importer's performance, repeated renewal of the license is possible. Applications for import licenses are screened by the M in is t ry of Commerce w i th the aid of committees composed of importers, producers, and consumers. Import licenses for certain goods, including leather goods, alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, and automobiles and their spare parts, are subject to an overall annual l im i t. Imports of certain goods for which licenses from the M in is t ry of Commerce are required (such as unas­ sembled automobiles and trucks, iron and steel pipes, firearms, watches, synthetic fibers, some types of jewelry, radio and television sets, and whiskey, wines, and other liquors) are subject to the payment of a fee of usually between 1 per cent and 6 per cent of the value of the import transaction, the proceeds of which are allocated to a fund handled by the Mex ican Foreign Trade Insti­ tute ( I M C E) for the promotion of exports. F or a small number of luxury items, no licenses are granted. Imports by official Mex ican agencies are subject to prior approval by I M CE after screening by the Institute's Import Committee of the Pub l ic Sector ( C I S P ); this approval is not given if a reasonably competitive domestic equiva­ lent is available at a price differential of 15-20 per cent. V i r tua l ly all imports are subject to an import surcharge of 2 per cent ad valorem, the proceeds of which accrue to an export trust fund the Federal Government has established with the Bank of Mex ico. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are not restricted. The con­ tracting of insurance for persons in Mex ico, or on property of Mex ican ownership, or where the risks are for the account of persons in Mex ico or may occur in Mex ico, is only permitted with Mex ican companies or with branches of foreign companies established in Mex ico in accordance w i th Mex ican law. Exports and Export Proceeds Certain exports require licenses. No exchange con­ trol requirements apply to the proceeds of exports. Rebates of indirect taxes by means of a system of CEDIS (certificados de devolucion de impuestos) are granted on exports of certain manufactured and semimanufactured products (and of certain services). Proceeds from Invisibles No exchange control requirements apply to proceeds from invisibles. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents. New foreign investment in the capital of Mex ican bank­ ing or insurance companies and investment funds is prohibited. Certain sectors, such as petroleum, basic petrochemical production, radioactive minerals, elec- 315 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution M E X I CO tricity and nuclear energy, certain mining activities, railroads, and telecommunications, are reserved to gov­ ernment investment. Investment in a number of activi­ ties is reserved exclusively for Mex ican individuals or corporations (radio and television, the public trans­ portation system, forestry, etc., as well as any other areas specified by the Federal Government), while new investments in other sectors must have a majority par­ ticipation of Mex ican capital. Foreign investments in Mex ico must be registered with the Na t ional Foreign Investment Register in the M in is t ry of Commerce. Applications by foreign natural or juridical persons to acquire more than 25 per cent of the capital of a Mex ican company, or over 49 per cent of its fixed assets, require the prior authorization of the competent ministry, after the Na t ional Foreign Investment Com­ mission has granted the necessary registration. A ll acquisitions of stock in Mex ican companies by foreign natural or jur id ical persons must be registered within 30 days with the Na t ional Foreign Investors Registry. Borrowing abroad (or within Mex ico in foreign cur­ rency) by the public sector and by state-owned banks is subject to approval by the M in is t ry of Finance and Pub l ic Credit. Borrowing abroad by private banks is subject to certain requirements imposed by the Bank of Mex ico; these banks are permitted to accept foreign currency deposits from residents as well as non­ residents.1 Gold Domestic transactions in nonmonetary gold are limited to purchases of gold bars by goldsmiths or manu­ facturers effected through authorized Mex ican credit institutions. Residents may freely purchase, ho ld, and sell monetary gold in Mex ico. The Bank of Mex ico does not buy or sell gold in transactions w i th private banks, individuals, or firms. There is a 15 per cent tax on "first hand" sales of newly mined gold. Producers of gold undertaking not to sell it at prices exceeding inter­ national quotations plus normal marketing costs are eligible for an automatic subsidy of up to 100 per cent of the tax, when selling newly mined gold in Mex ico to private banks for resale to goldsmiths or manu­ facturers in Mex ico. Exports of gold are prohibited unless they are made by the Bank of Mex ico. Imports of gold are subject to import license from the Bank of Mex ico. Changes during 1976 January 1. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.175610 gram of fine gold per Moroccan D i rham. The Bank of Mo rocco quotes daily buying and selling rates for the French franc; its rates for the franc are determined in the light of quotations for certain major currencies on the official exchange market in Paris and taking into account the geographic distribution of Morocco's foreign trade transactions. The Bank of Mo rocco also quotes buying and selling rates for specified "convertible currencies," 1 based on quotations in the leading foreign exchange markets abroad and the Bank of Morocco's daily quotation for the French franc. In addition, the Bank quotes daily buying and selling rates for the Tunisian dinar. The rates of the Bank of Mo rocco for the U . S. dollar on Decem­ ber 31, 1976 were DH 4.4730 buying, and DH 4.4955 selling, per US$1 and those for the French franc were DH0.90146 buying, and DH 0.90416 selling, per F l. A ll sales and purchases of foreign currency are cen­ tralized in the Bank of Mo rocco, but the authorized banks are permitted to marry (offset) their purchases and sales on behalf of their private customers in each currency separately. The authorized banks must pur­ chase from or sell to the Bank of Mo rocco each day, at the rates communicated to them by the Bank, the balances of their purchases and sales in each currency; compensation between banks is not permitted so that no foreign exchange market exists in Mo rocco. The Bank of Morocco also establishes buying and selling rates for transactions with travelers in banknotes, travelers checks, and letters of credit expressed in French francs, C FA francs, the "convertible currencies," and specified other currencies;2 the authorized banks sell to the Bank of Morocco their excess holdings of banknotes and replen­ ish them at the Bank whenever necessary. Fo rwa rd exchange transactions are not permitted. Foreign currency repatriated in the form of transfers to a bank or postal account by Moroccan workers abroad is eligible for a premium of 5 per cent payable on the dirham equivalent. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Exchange Office, an agency under the M in is t ry of Finance. This Office has delegated the execution of certain exchange control measures to authorized banks. Import certificates and export licenses are issued by the M in is t ry of C om­ merce; they must be countersigned by the Exchange 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos. pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U .S. dollars. 2 Finnish markkaa, Iranian rials, Kuwa i ti dinars, Lebanese pounds, Libyan dinars, Saudi A rab ian riyals, and U . A . E. dirhams. L ibyan dinars are traded only by the agencies of the Bank of Mo ro c co. Office. Import commitments for liberalized goods are signed by the importer himself; they do not require the visa of the Exchange Office unless the country of origin of the goods is not the country of shipment, or the goods are bought on a c.i.f. basis. A part of the port of Tangier is designated as a free trade zone and is exempt from taxation and from trade, customs, and exchange control. Prescription of Currency Although Morocco's regulations still make a distinc­ tion between the French Franc A r ea and the so-called area of convertibility, Mo rocco applies exchange control also to transactions with the former .3 F or prescription of currency purposes, countries are classified as follows: (1) the French Franc A rea countries; (2) the payments agreement group, comprising countries with which Mo rocco maintains bilateral payments agreements;4 and (3) all other countries, the so-called area of convertibility. Settlements with the French F ranc A rea are made in French francs or, with the exception of settlements for imports, in dirhams through French Franc A r ea Accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, be low); certain noncommercial settlements with A lge r ia, how­ ever, are made in dirhams or A lger ian dinars through special accounts at the two central banks, and all settle­ ments with Tunisia are made through accounts denomi­ nated in convertible dirhams or Tunisian convertible dinars. Settlements with the payments agreement group are made by debiting or crediting the payments agree­ ment accounts established for this purpose. Imports originating in countries in the area of convertibility may be paid for only in "convertible currencies" negotiated by the Bank of M o r o c c o .5 Other settlements with coun­ tries in the area of convertibility may be made only in "convertible currencies" negotiated by the Bank of Morocco or through Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams. Nonresident Accounts The various types of nonresident accounts are as follows: 1. French Franc Area Accounts are held in Mo ro c­ can currency in the names of residents of countries of the French Franc A rea. These accounts may be used for settlements with residents of countries in the French Franc A rea, except for the payment for imports (and :J Since February 1967, France has applied to Morocco its controls on foreign investments in France and on French investments abroad. Not for Redistribution M O R O C CO related invisibles) from those countries.0 They may be freely credited with and debited for sales or purchases of French francs (except banknotes) sold to or bought from the Bank of Mo rocco. Transfers between French Franc A rea Accounts may be made freely. 2. Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams are reserved for residents of countries in the area of con­ vertibility. These accounts may be credited freely with authorized payments due to residents of countries in the area of convertibility (but not in respect of imports or related invisibles) and with dirhams obtained from the sale to the Bank of Morocco of "convertible currencies" negotiated by it, excluding banknotes. They may be debited freely for payments in Mo rocco and for pur­ chases from the Bank of Mo rocco of the "convertible currencies" negotiated by it. Transfers between Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams may be made freely. 3. Payments Agreement Accounts are held by the Bank of Mo rocco for central banks (or similar institu­ tions) of the countries with which Mo rocco maintains bilateral payments agreements (see footnote 4 ); they are used only for settlements with these countries, includ­ ing settlements for imports and exports. 4. Capital Accounts, which may be held by any non­ resident, are credited with funds that may not be trans­ ferred abroad. These include the proceeds from the sale on the Casablanca stock exchange of Moroccan securi­ ties held under foreign dossier and proceeds from the contractual or accelerated redemption of such securities. Transfers between Capital Accounts related to (1) coun­ tries either in the area of convertibility or the French Franc A rea or (2) the same country in the payments agreement group, are permitted freely. Capital Accounts may be debited freely for (1) pur­ chases of specified 5Vi per cent, seven-year government bonds; interest and redemption proceeds are transfer­ able, and the bonds are freely negotiable between non­ residents; and (2) personal expenses of the account holder and his immediate relatives during visits to Mo rocco, up to DH 150 a person a day, subject to a l im it of DH 5,000 a year for each account. A ll other operations through Cap i tal Accounts require individual approval. These include purchases on the Casablanca stock exchange of Moroccan and non-Moroccan securi­ ties; purchases of Moroccan securities not quoted in Casablanca or of participation in a Moroccan firm; sub­ scriptions to either; investments of any k ind, including purchases of businesses or office buildings; lending to resi­ dents; payment of local expenses in excess of DH 5,000 during the account holder's stay in Mo rocco; any such payments to beneficiaries other than the holder of the account or a close relative of his; any such payments from an account held by a foreign jur id ical person; gifts to social, cultural, or religious institutions; subscriptions to capital increases of Mo roccan companies whose shares are quoted on the Casablanca stock exchange; subscrip­ tions at the time of issue to long-term or short-term securities w i th a fixed yield issued by a Moroccan public entity; custody charges and commissions on securities; and payment of the costs of maintenance, repairs, real estate taxes, and insurance on real estate located in Mo rocco. Subject to approval, Cap i tal Accounts may also be debited for investments in Mo rocco, within the framework of the 1973 Investment Code, provided that the amounts debited do not exceed 50 per cent of the investment undertaken by the nonresident and 25 per cent of the company's total capital. Moreover, balances held in "o r ig ina l" Capital Accounts by nonresident natural persons of foreign nationality and not exceeding DH 10,000 on May 31, 1975 have been declared transferable abroad as follows, subject to prior authorization by the Exchange Office: balances not exceeding DH 3,000, during 1976; those between DH 3,001 and DH 7,000, during the first half of 1977; and those between DH 7,001 and DH 10,000, during the second half of 1977. 5. Suspense Accounts are used for holding nonresi­ dent funds not available for credit to any of the accounts mentioned above. Balances on these accounts may be used freely to pay taxes due to the Moroccan authorities, but all other debits to these accounts require approval. 6. Two Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams are held by the Bank of Mo rocco for the Central Bank of A lge r ia and the Central Bank of Tun is ia. Only cer­ tain noncommercial transactions between Morocco and A lger ia are settled through the account opened in the name of the Central Bank of A lge r ia. Imports and Import Payments Imports are admitted in accordance with an annual General Import Program. Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Imports are divided into three categories applicable to all countries. Goods in L ist A are liberal­ ized. Goods in L ist B are restricted, in some cases by a global quota, or are subject to state trading; for a large number of L ist B items, no quotas are established, and imports are approved according to need, licenses usually being issued upon application (SB items). In principle, the importation of goods in L ist C is not permitted; among the items on this list are certain motor vehicles, certain precious metals, and gold jewelry. To import goods in L ist A, the importer signs an import commitment (engagement a"importation), which does not require administrative approval unless the goods are imported from a country other than that of origin or are purchased on a c.i.f. basis,7 but for goods in List B, an import license (autorisation d'importation or certificat a"importation) must be obtained. Wheat, sugar, tea, and fertilizers are imported by official agencies. 6 Imports from the French Franc A r e a, unless covered by special credit arrangements, must be paid for with French francs purchased from the Bank of Morocco. 7 C.i.f. approval. imports of List A goods require prior exchange control 320 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution For all imports the import title —import certificate or import commitment —must be domiciled (registered) with an authorized bank, which may make payments upon submission of the required documents. Import certificates require the visa of the Exchange Office before the foreign exchange is made available. Import commit­ ments require this visa only when the country of origin and the country of shipment of the goods concerned differ or when imports are contracted for on a c.i.f. basis. Import certificates must be domiciled within 15 days from the date that the Exchange Office approves the license. Import commitments must be domiciled at the time of their subscription. Special procedures are appli­ cable to specified imports financed by foreign aid or loans. Most imports from countries in the payments agree­ ment group are made in accordance with the quotas established in the respective trade agreements. Imports can also be licensed under compensation transactions. Payments for Invisibles Payments for most current invisibles require the approval of the Exchange Office upon presentation of the necessary justification; in several instances the approval authority has been delegated to the banks. The authorized banks are permitted to make payments and settle expenses incidental to the commercial transaction covered by the relevant import or export documents. Earnings after tax on approved nonresident investments in Morocco are transferable to the investor's country of residence. The transfer of dividends on nonresident- owned shares of Moroccan companies having their main office in Mo rocco requires the approval of the Exchange Office. Undistributed profits relating to the financial year 1968 or later remain transferable indefinitely. Some payments are subject to limitations. A foreign employee may transfer to his country of origin, subject to the initial approval of the Exchange Office, 50 per cent of his monthly wages or salary if his family does not reside in Mo rocco, or 30 per cent if he is single or his family lives in M o r o c c o .8 The same percentages of their monthly earnings may be transferred by foreign nationals engaged in professions; except for the medical and paramedical professions, such transfers are subject to a limit of DH 1,000 a month. Subject to a monthly limit of DH 300, the same percentages of earnings may also be transferred by foreign nationals engaged in agricultural, industrial, or commercial activities, or in skilled crafts. Foreign nationals employed in the hotel sector or the mining sector are authorized to transfer between 60 and 80 per cent of their monthly salaries or wages. An allocation of foreign exchange equivalent to DH 100 a person a year is granted to residents of any nationality for travel abroad, provided that they do 8 For all wages and salaries of the private sector, monthly transfers which exceed by more than DH 100 the amount transferred in June 1976 require prior authorization by the Exchange Office. M O R O C CO not make periodic transfers abroad. There is a special allocation for pilgrimages. Residents of foreign nation­ ality may acquire exchange for tourist travel up to the equivalent of DH 2,500 for each passport a year by selling to an authorized bank a corresponding amount in foreign exchange (other than banknotes) from their own foreign assets not subject to surrender requirements. F or business travel by persons other than exporters a standard allowance of the equivalent of DH 250 a day is granted, up to DH 5,000 a person a trip and within an annual ceiling fixed individually by the Exchange Office; exporters may obtain up to DH 300 a day, up to DH 7,500 a person a trip, within a ceiling of 3 per cent of the foreign exchange repatriated during the pre­ ceding calendar year. The allocation issued for business travel may be added to the allocation issued for tourist travel. F or study abroad, a monthly allocation of for­ eign exchange up to DH 834 is granted, provided that no comparable educational facilities are available in Mo rocco; Mo roccan students taking college or univer­ sity level courses abroad are entitled to an annual instal­ lation allowance equivalent to DH 1,000. F or family maintenance, the Exchange Office grants a monthly allo­ cation generally of DH 300. The export of Moroccan banknotes is prohibited. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most exports may be made freely, although export licenses are required for a few items. A ll fruits, fresh vegetables, canned goods, raw cotton, and cotton by-products may be exported only by a state trading agency, the Office of Marke t ing and Export (Office de Commercialisation et d 'Expo r t a t ion —OCE ). That Office also is in charge of wine exports. A ll exporters must sign an undertaking to repatriate and surrender the foreign exchange proceeds of their exports. The surrender of the proceeds to the exporter's bank must take place w i th in one month from the date the payment is due. The date on which the payment is due is the maturity date fixed in the commercial con­ tract; this date must not be set, in principle, more than 90 days after the date of arrival of the merchandise at the place of destination. When the bank receiving the funds that represent the proceeds from exports receives the advice of credit in foreign currency from abroad, it must surrender the foreign exchange immediately to the Bank of Mo rocco. Proceeds from Invisibles Residents of Moroccan nationality and Moroccan companies must repatriate exchange receipts accruing from all their noncommercial claims and surrender them to an authorized bank. Other residents must surrender noncommercial receipts only if the receipts result from current transactions, and only when they accrue in for­ eign currencies other than those of the French F ranc 321 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution M O R O C CO A rea. Moroccans working abroad must surrender such currencies within one month of re-entry, but are per­ mitted, when leaving again, to repurchase 15 per cent of the amount surrendered (the currencies so purchased may also include French francs); they are entitled to a bonus of 5 per cent on the dirham equivalent of any foreign exchange repatriated in the form of transfers to a bank or a postal account. The importation of Mo ro c­ can banknotes is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may bring in freely foreign banknotes; foreign exchange brought in in excess of the equivalent of DH 5,000 must be declared to the customs authorities. Resident travel­ ers also may bring in any amount in foreign banknotes, but these must be surrendered within 30 days of re-entry. Capital Residents of Moroccan nationality, as well as compa­ nies established in Mo rocco, are obliged to declare to the Exchange Office all foreign-held assets exceeding DH 250, and to repatriate and surrender certain of these assets. The disposal of other foreign-held assets requires permission. The transfer of capital abroad by residents must be approved. Remittances in respect of the assets of emigrants and transfers of gifts are not normally approved, nor is investment by private individuals in foreign securities or real estate. Exchange allocations for the transfer of inheritances are limited to DH 35,000 a beneficiary. Those for the transfer of their assets by repatriates vary with the length of their stay in Mo rocco, from DH 35,000 a family with family residence of 3 to 5 years to DH 250,000 a family where the period of residence has been 15 years or more. New foreign investments in specified sectors of the economy may benefit from the provisions of the Invest­ ment Code of August 15, 1973. The Code consists of six laws and several implementing decrees providing various tax concessions and other incentives. It guar­ antees the transfer of dividends distributed to nonresi­ dents and of proceeds from the liquidation of the capital brought in by the foreign investor. Investments financed with funds held in Capital Accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above) also are eligible for the benefits of the Code; proceeds from the liquidation of investments financed in this manner become transferable after a minimum investment period of 5 years. Foreign investments approved under the previous Investment Code (of February 10, 1961) continue to benefit from the retransfer guarantee for the liquidation proceeds. Proceeds from the liquidation of other invest­ ments are credited to Capital Accounts. Certain government bonds acquired with funds from Cap i tal Accounts are freely negotiable between nonresi­ dents. A ll other transactions in securities involving non­ resident interests, as well as the import and export of securities, require approval. Banks are permitted to engage in short-term borrowing abroad within the frame­ work of Dah ir N o. 1-74-385 of August 5, 1974 and the 322 Orders issued for its implementation. Under this facility, they may accept convertible currency funds from non­ residents for credit to Special Deposit Accounts, pro­ vided that these funds are reinvested abroad in the same currency and for the same maturity period; the rate of interest paid by banks on deposits received must not exceed that received by them on the placing made for their account. Gold A commemorative gold coin w i th a face value of DH 250 has been issued, which is legal tender. Resi­ dents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Mo rocco for numismatic or investment purposes. Ten different types of foreign gold coins are traded on the Casablanca stock exchange, wh ich does not, however, deal in gold bars. Imports of gold are subject to authori­ zation by the Directorate of Customs and Indirect Taxes, to which the M in i s t ry of Finance has delegated its approval authority. Every year the M in is t ry fixes a quota for the importation of gold ingots, which is then allocated among jewelers and industrial users of precious metals. G o ld jewelry is included in import List C. Exports of gold are prohibited. Changes during 1976 January 1. However, until further notice 40 per cent of the value of imports from Egypt had to be settled through the bilateral account, and 60 per cent in convertible currencies. M O R O C CO 323 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NE PAL (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0808408 gram of fine gold per Nepalese Rupee. On February 20, 1973 a central rate was established of N Rs 12.7390 = SDR 1, correspond­ ing at the time to N Rs 10.56 = U S $ 1, and Nepal avails itself of wider margins. Since October 9, 1975, however, the Nepal Rastra Bank (the central bank) has maintained fixed buying and selling rates for U . S. do l­ lars of N Rs 12.45 buying, and N Rs 12.55 selling, per US$1. The Bank also quotes fixed rates for the Indian rupee, at N Rs 139.00 buying, and N Rs 139.15 selling, per 100 Indian rupees. Da i ly buying and selling rates are quoted for Australian dollars, Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Japanese yen, pounds sterling, and Swiss francs and only buying rates are quoted for Austrian schillings, Italian lire, and Swedish kronor. Different effective exchange rates arise from the operation of an Exporters' Exchange Entitlement Scheme. Most of Nepal's foreign exchange transactions are in terms of Indian rupees. Residents may freely pur­ chase Indian rupees from Nepalese banks and they may hold any amount of Indian notes and coins, but the Indian rupee is not legal tender. Administration of Control A Foreign Exchange Committee, consisting of rep­ resentatives from the Nepal Rastra Bank and the Ministries of Finance, Foreign Affairs, and Industry and Commerce, prepares an annual foreign exchange budget for foreign currencies other than the Indian rupee and excluding transactions with the countries with which clearing arrangements exist. Permission is required from the M in i s t ry of Finance for all foreign pay­ ments, except for certain specified payments that require authorization from the Nepal Rastra Bank. Import and export licensing is the responsibility of the M in is t ry of Industry and Commerce. A ll exchange transactions with countries other than India must be settled through authorized dealers, i.e., the Nepal Bank L t d. and the Rastriya Banijya Bank. W i th in Nepal there are 95 additional authorized dealers licensed to purchase for­ eign currencies; any sale of such currencies other than Indian rupees is subject to the prior approval of the Nepal Rastra Bank. A ll import and export transactions with payments agreement countries, as we ll as all barter trade, are conducted through a state trading agency, the Na t ional Trad ing L t d. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements apply to outgoing payments to countries with which no payments agreement is in force and these may be made in the foreign currency supplied by the Nepal Rastra Bank. 324 Payments to, and receipts from, other member countries of the As ian C lear ing Un ion except India (Bangladesh, Iran, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka) in respect of current transactions (other than those relating to petroleum, natural gas, and their products) may, but need not, be effected in As ian monetary units through the Asian C lear ing U n i o n. Payments for imports from India normally are settled in Indian rupees, but the Nepal Rastra Bank sometimes makes convertible currencies available for such imports at the recommendation of the M in is t ry of Finance. The proceeds of exports to India are obtained in Indian or Nepalese rupees; the proceeds of exports to other countries must be received in any of the convertible currencies quoted by the Nepal Rastra Bank. Nepal .has bilateral payments agreements with Bulgaria, the People's Republic of Ch ina, Pakistan, and Po land; payments between Nepal and these countries must be made through special accounts. The agree­ ment w i th Pakistan is inoperative. Nonresident Accounts The Nepal Rastra Bank permits nonresidents upon request to open "convertible rupee accounts" with Nepalese banks, the balances of wh ich may be freely transferred abroad. Indian nationals are allowed to open current accounts in Indian rupees w i th Nepalese banks. Foreign currencies brought into or received in Nepal by nonresidents, which are converted into Nepalese rupees and deposited w i th a Nepalese bank, may be reconverted for transfer out of the country, subject to prior permission of the Nepal Rastra Bank. Imports and Import Payments A ll imports of goods except those originating in India require import licenses from the M in is t ry of Industry and Commerce. Imports of vegetable o i l, margarine, animal fat, beef, woolen carpets, arms and ammunition, explosives, chemicals to be used for explosives, and wireless transmitters are prohibited. Under the Trade and Transit Treaty of August 15, 1971, Nepal and India agreed to freedom of trade between themselves in Nepalese and Indian goods; Indian goods may in principle be imported freely (although some are subject to a permit system in order to prevent their reexportation and certain others are subject to export ceilings in Ind ia ), and reimbursement of tax is made by the Gov­ ernment of India to the Government of Nepal on direct imports from Indian manufacturers of commodities subject to excise duty in India. W i th the exception noted below, applications to the M in i s t ry of Finance for foreign exchange to pay for imports from countries other than India are considered on their merits; any application must, however, be in ©International Monetary Fund.
