For travel to countries other than India for medical treatment, foreign exchange is allowed as recommended by a panel of doctors; students studying at their own expense in these countries are allowed up to US$2 ,160 a year for board and lodging, while payments for tuition fees are allowed as required. Payments for other invisibles depend on the essentiality of the transaction and the availability of foreign exchange. Nepalese and Indian currencies may be taken out freely to India by Nepalese and Indian nationals only; the export of these currencies to countries other than India is pro­ hibited. Foreign banknotes other than Indian banknotes may not be taken out by residents without permission. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of old coins, gold and silver, and coins and jewelry made of these metals, cows, buffaloes, and rhinoceros horns are prohibited. There is also a tem­ porary prohibition on exports of oilseeds and edible oils. The re-export to India of non-Nepalese goods is not permitted, and re-exports to any destination of goods imported from India are proh ib i ted .2 A ll other goods, except rice, may be exported freely to India. The exchange proceeds of exports, except Indian rupees, must be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or an authorized bank at the official buying rate of exchange, within six months of shipment. The exporter receives from the Nepal Rastra Bank an exporters' exchange entitlement corresponding to a specified pro­ portion of his export proceeds in foreign currencies other than Indian rupees; the entitlement may be used to obtain exchange at the official rate for the import of goods specified by the M in is t ry of Industry and Commerce. Entitlements are negotiable. Exporters engaged in bilateral trade (i.e., the Na t ional Trad ing L t d. when selling to countries w i th which Nepal maintains payments agreements) are granted entitle­ ments corresponding to 100 per cent of their export earnings; in principle, 40 per cent of these earnings may be used for imports of their choice from the partner country concerned, while the remaining 60 per cent must be used to import specified commodities from the partner country concerned. For virtually all exports to convertible currency countries, exchange entitlements are granted at ratios of 45 per cent or 60 per cent. At least 10 per cent of the entitlement must be used to purchase goods on a list of development goods, up to 70 per cent may be used to purchase consumer goods, and up to 20 per cent may be spent on any type of goods including luxuries. Proceeds from Invisibles W i th the exception of Indian rupees, foreign exchange proceeds derived from transactions in invisibles must be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or an autho­ rized bank at the official rate of exchange. Nonresidents other than Indian nationals are not allowed to bring in Nepalese or Indian bank­ notes. Other foreign banknotes may be brought in freely by residents and nonresidents, but residents and Indian nationals must declare any foreign banknotes they bring in. Capital No conditions are laid down concerning receipts and remittances in respect of capital transactions, but offi­ c ial exchange is not normally provided for capital remit­ tances by Nepalese nationals. Foreign investors who obtain an investment guarantee may remit yearly profits of up to 25 per cent of the total profit on the foreign capital invested and, in any one year, up to 10 per cent of the pr inc ipa l; if the exchange situation permits, profits in excess of 25 per cent are remittable. Gold Residents may freely purchase, ho ld, and sell gold in any form in Nepa l. No import licenses for gold are issued under the Exporters' Exchange Entitlement Scheme. Imports of gold from any country other than India require a license and are subject to an import duty of N Rs 6.65 a troy ounce; such imports are not normally allowed. Exports of gold may be made only by the monetary authorities and require prior approval by the M in is t ry of Finance. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.245489 gram of fine gold per Netherlands Gu i lde r. On September 17, 1973, the Netherlands established a central rate of f. 3.35507 = SDR 1, corresponding at the time to 0.264874 gram of fine gold per Netherlands guilder. The Netherlands avails itself of wider margins. A maximum margin of 2!4 per cent is maintained for exchange rates in the official market between the Netherlands guilder and the Belgian franc, the Dan ish krone, the deutsche mark, the Luxembourg franc, the Norwegian krone, and the Swedish krona. No announced margins are maintained for other currencies.1 The authorized banks' buying and selling rates for the U . S. dollar on December 31, 1976 were f. 2.45575 and f. 2.45825, respectively, per US $ 1. Authorized banks are freely permitted to buy and sell convertible and inconvertible currencies, both spot and forward, against convertible currencies, including guilders on Convertible Gu i lder Accounts, and incon­ vertible currencies; they are free to deal w i th residents and nonresidents, whether banks or nonbanks. Fo rwa rd exchange contracts are not limited as to delivery period nor is an underlying transaction required. Residents are permitted to conclude spot transactions with other resi­ dents, including authorized banks, and they may con­ clude forward transactions for any period with autho­ rized banks. Nonbank residents are free to hold foreign currency accounts at home and on application are per­ mitted to hold accounts (normally demand deposits only) in their own names with banks abroad; over­ drafts on the latter accounts are not allowed. The K ingdom of the Netherlands formally accepted the obligations of A r t ic le V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Exchange Control Territory Transactions with the Netherlands Antilles are sub­ ject to the same exchange controls as transactions with other countries. Vis-a-vis any third countries w i th which payments agreements might be in force, the Netherlands and the Netherlands An t i l les constitute the Netherlands Monetary A r e a. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Netherlands Bank on behalf of the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Finance, Economic Affairs, and Agr icu l ture. Import and export licensing are handled by the Central Import- Export Agency ( C D I U) and the delegated offices, under directives from the Directorate-General for Foreign Economic Relations. Invisibles and capital transactions are licensed by the Netherlands Bank, as are transit trade transactions, except those in strategic goods and scrap, which are licensed by the C D I U .2 A ll commer­ c ial banks of any importance are authorized to handle foreign exchange transactions within the scope of general and special licenses granted by the licensing authorities. F or a ll payments to, or receipts from, nonresidents exceeding f. 3,000, nonbank residents as well as non- authorized banks have to indicate, by submitting an exchange control form, the nature of the underlying transaction as well as the currency and amount paid or received. Prescription of Currency Payments to nonresidents, if eligible for transfer abroad, must be made through an authorized bank, either in guilders to the credit of a nonresident guilder account held with an authorized bank in the Netherlands or to the debit of the authorized bank's currency holdings abroad. There are special regulations, however, for pay­ ments in respect of certain direct imports from Egyp t .3 A ll payments and credits, whether direct or indirect, from the Netherlands to Rhodesia are prohibited unless a license is granted by the Netherlands Bank. Since there are no bilateral payments agreements, a ll foreign countries are included in the "convertible guilder area." Payments to countries in the convertible guilder area may be made in any foreign currency or in guilders to the credit of any nonresident account. Receipts from countries in the convertible guilder area may be obtained in any convertible currency or in guilders to the debit of a Convertible Gu i lder Account (see section on Nonresident Accounts, be low ); however, receipts may also be collected in other currencies, provided that the amounts received are deposited w i th an authorized bank or held in a permitted foreign account. Payments between residents may be made freely in any foreign currency, provided that the amount involved is debited to a foreign currency account in the Nether­ lands or abroad and is credited to a foreign currency account in the name of the beneficiary w i th an autho­ rized bank in the Netherlands. Nonresident Accounts The principal nonresident guilder accounts are Con­ vertible Guilder Accounts. These accounts may be held by any nonresident. Imports and Import Payments Imports from the Belgian-Luxembourg Economic U n i on are free from import licenses. V i r tua l ly all imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Import licenses are required for imports originating in Hong K o n g, Japan, and state trading countries, and for the import of goods of unknown origin. In addition, import licenses are required for a limited number of products, mainly in the agricultural and textile sectors, when not of E EC origin. Except for imports from Rhodesia, practically all imports that require an import license are free from quantitative restriction. Most imports from Eastern European countries are formally liberalized. C om­ modities corresponding to some 19 tariff headings or subheadings are subject to quantitative restriction when originating in Japan. Imports from n o n -EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Ag r icu l tu ral Po l icy of the E EC are subject to import levies that have replaced all previous barriers to imports; common E EC regulations are also applied to imports from n o n -EEC countries of most other agricultural and livestock products. Imports of cattle and beef from " th i rd" countries are in pr in­ ciple suspended. Payments for imports may be made freely, provided that the method of payment conforms with the general prescription of currency regulations. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of imports of commodities,4 but they require prior approval from the Netherlands Bank to accept credit for periods in excess of those traditional in the trade concerned; such permission is not normally granted. Payments for Invisibles Payments abroad for invisibles are permitted freely. Exchange for travel is provided in any currency and up to any amount, and the entire amount may be taken, 4 Commodities are so defined as to exclude gold. 328 if the traveler wishes, in Netherlands banknotes. A resident traveling abroad may in addition have any further amounts remitted to h im through banking channels. Exchange purchased for travel purposes must not be spent for other purposes; it may be used for purchases for personal use, however. Payments for interest, dividends, and contractual amortization due to nonresidents are permitted freely by crediting the appropriate nonresident account. The export of domestic or foreign banknotes by resi­ dent travelers is not subject to limitation. Nonresidents may export a ll unutilized negotiable instruments and foreign and Netherlands banknotes and coins which they have imported or have obtained in the Netherlands by drawing on their accounts or exchanging other currencies. Exports and Export Proceeds V i r tua l ly a ll exports to Rhodesia are prohibited; those wh ich are permitted require an export license. For exports to other countries, export licenses are required only for a few commodities, mostly of a strategic char­ acter, and for some agricultural products, scrap of iron and steel, and certain nonferrous metals. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of exports of commodities,4 but they require prior permission from the Netherlands Bank to accept payment in advance of delivery where such advance payments are not tradi­ tional in the trade concerned; such permission is not normally granted. The surrender of export proceeds is not obligatory, but any surrender that is made must be at the official rate. The collection of export proceeds through an authorized bank is obligatory. A license may be obtained, however, to hold a bank account abroad, to which export proceeds may be credited and import payments debited; in most cases, balances in excess of a stipulated maximum amount must be trans­ ferred periodically to the Netherlands. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles must be collected through an authorized bank but need not be surrendered and may instead be credited to foreign currency accounts. A license may be obtained on application to hold a foreign currency account w i th a bank abroad, to which account proceeds from invisibles may be credited. Nonresidents may bring into the Netherlands unlim­ ited amounts in Netherlands banknotes, foreign bank­ notes, and negotiable instruments. These may be sold only to an authorized bank, to an authorized exchange office, or, in the case of foreign banknotes, to an autho­ rized depository, or they may be used to pay tourist expenses in the Netherlands. Residents are obliged to bring back to the Netherlands any unutilized portion of the banknotes and coins that they took with them on their outward journey; there is no limitation on the amount in Netherlands or foreign banknotes and coins that they may bring in. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Capital Most external capital transactions by nonbank resi­ dents, whether involving foreign or domestic capital, require a specific license from the Netherlands Bank. The main transactions permitted by general licenses are (1) purchases and sales (except issues) of officially listed stocks and bonds, (2) loans granted or received that do not exceed f. 100,000, provided that the resi­ dent does not lend or borrow more than f. 100,000 a year to or from the same nonresident, and (3) suppliers' and customers' credits granted or received, subject to certain limitations (see sections on Imports and Import Payments and Exports and Export Proceeds, above). At the end of 1976, borrowing abroad by nonbank residents continued to be restricted for reasons of mone­ tary, credit, and exchange rate policy, while capital exports continued to be stimulated. In general, the inward transfer of foreign capital (other than for portfolio investment or the purchase of real estate, see below) is permitted only if the capital constitutes a direct investment. In addition to foreign participation in the capital of newly founded or existing companies, direct investment is considered to include intercompany financial loans with a fixed term of at least five years from the foreign parent company. Under certain con­ ditions, loans from other affiliated foreign companies (i.e., sister companies or subsidiaries) are also being licensed. Other financial borrowing —whether by way of issuing bonds and notes abroad or by way of borrowing from foreign banks —is, in principle, not allowed unless the proceeds are kept abroad and used for investments abroad (which are considered to include purchases of ships and a ircraf t). However, companies work ing on the Netherlands' part of the Continental Shelf, whether foreign owned or resident owned, are allowed to take up foreign bank loans (with a fixed term of at least five years) up to two thirds of their financing requirements. Resident units of international companies are permitted upon request to maintain current accounts with their head offices or subsidiaries abroad, mainly for the stipulated purpose of intercompany commercial credit (which is subject to the same rules as suppliers' and customers' cred i t). Short-term foreign bank credit for the financing of imports is licensed (when there is no domestic credit restriction in force) if it is directly con­ nected w i th a specific import transaction; for long-term financing, importers are referred to the domestic credit market. Sales to nonresidents, including central banks, of Netherlands treasury paper and bank acceptances denominated in guilders are prohibited. Most lending by nonbank residents to nonresidents (whether affiliated companies or others) is liberally per­ mitted on application. Requested public issues on the domestic capital market on behalf of nonresidents are scheduled, and if necessary limited, by the Netherlands Bank in accordance with the market's capacity to absorb issues. In the private placement sector of the capital N E T H E R L A N DS market (the market for debt certificates or onderhandse leningen), nonresidents are in principle allowed to take up loans from institutional investors, but their access to such loans has been suspended since June 1976.5 Nonbank residents are not normally allowed to purchase foreign treasury bills or other foreign short-term nego­ tiable instruments. Outward direct investment by resi­ dents is authorized on application. The inward or outward transfer of proceeds from the sale or liquidation of direct investments is free under general license. Repayment of licensed loans may be made or received freely, provided that any relevant stipulations in the license are complied with. Transactions between residents and nonresidents in a ll stocks and bonds listed on the Amsterdam stock exchange take place at official market exchange rates and are unrestricted. Residents may freely purchase offi­ cially listed securities abroad. Transactions between residents and nonresidents in unlisted stocks are gov­ erned by the rules applicable to direct investment and require a special license. Residents are not allowed to purchase unlisted fixed-interest securities (such as notes) on the Euromarket if denominated in guilders and issued by nonresidents. Nonbank residents are licensed to issue bonds and notes abroad only if the proceeds are not brought into the Netherlands (see above). The proceeds of securities sold in the Netherlands by non­ residents (except Rhodesians) are transferable in any currency, irrespective of the seller's country of domicile or residence. Nonresidents may have their securities, domestic or foreign, exported to them; for the exporta­ tion of listed guilder bonds, residents need a license, which is granted upon application. Domestic and for­ eign securities held abroad by a resident are subject to a deposit requirement, but the Netherlands Bank grants exemptions on application; securities held in the Ne th­ erlands are not subject to deposit. Nonresidents may freely purchase real estate in the Netherlands for personal use or investment, and resi­ dents may freely purchase real estate abroad. Mortgage loans between residents and nonresidents in connection with these real estate transactions are mostly free under general license or licensed on application. Gifts and donations to nonresidents are free.c> Em i­ grants may export any amount in foreign and domestic currency. They acquire nonresident status upon leaving the Netherlands, provided that they have declared their intention to settle abroad for more than three years, and may upon departure have remitted to them their total assets in the Netherlands. The maximum size of each loan was set at f. 75 million and the minimum largest maturity at ten years, with repayment to take place in at least five equal installments. Not for Redistribution N E T H E R L A N DS estates in the Netherlands may have the proceeds trans­ ferred to them freely. The curtailment of external borrowing is also applied to the authorized banks. A ny net foreign indebtedness on their part is restricted by the "five m i l l ion regulation," which prescribes that the total of each bank's spot for­ eign liabilities (regardless of denomination or maturity) must not at any time exceed its total spot foreign assets by more than f. 5 m i l l ion. Banks are required to report to the Netherlands Bank twice a month the totals of their spot assets and liabilities, broken down into guilders and a ll foreign currencies combined. In addition, banks must maintain a balanced total position (i.e., spot plus forward position) in each foreign currency. They are required to report their spot position, as well as their forward position with residents and nonresidents, respec­ tively, in each foreign currency at the end of each month; for deutsche mark, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U . S. dollars, the same data must also be reported at mid-month. Moreover, copies of all forward exchange contracts with nonresidents are forwarded to the Ne th­ erlands Bank. Banks are free, under general licenses, in their lending to foreign banks and, for maturities up to one year, to foreign nonbanks; longer-term lending is usually permitted on request. Banks are free to pay customary rates of interest on nonresident-held guilder demand deposits, and to establish guilder time or savings deposits on their books in the names of nonresidents. Thus, their freedom to accept deposits from nonresidents (including foreign currency demand or time deposits) and to borrow abroad is unrestricted, provided the l im it set by the "five m i l l ion regulation" is observed. A ll capital transfers in excess of f. 3,000 by nonbank residents, whether permitted under general license or specific license, must be notified to the Balance of Pay­ ments Department of the Netherlands Bank. This includes suppliers' credits granted or received for periods in excess of one year; prepayments exceeding f. 250,000 received for exports must be reported as such. Totals of security transactions must be reported periodically by securities brokers and authorized banks or, if trans­ actions take place through a foreign bank account, by the resident parties concerned. Authorized banks must report their own investments and loans. Resulting totals of foreign exchange dealings and deposit transactions are reported periodically. Gold Certain prewar gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. The Netherlands Bank engages in gold trans­ actions only with monetary authorities and international financial institutions. Neither the Bank nor any govern­ ment agency imports or markets gold for industrial use. Authorized banks and nonbank residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold (fine gold, gold coin, and gold alloys) in the Netherlands or abroad; gold held abroad, however, must be kept on deposit with the for­ eign correspondent of an authorized depository. Imports 330 and exports of gold require neither exchange licenses nor import and export licenses. There is a free gold market in Amsterdam. Domestic sales of gold coins, if legal tender in the country of issue, are free of value-added tax; those that are not legal tender are subject to value- added tax at 4 per cent. The value-added tax on medal­ lions and commemorative coins is 18 per cent; sales of gold bars and nuggets are exempt. Commercial imports of gold jewelry and of articles containing minor quan­ tities of gold, such as watches, require import licenses only when originating in Hong K o n g, Japan, or state trading countries. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS ANTILLES (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.471230 gram of fine gold per Netherland Antilles Gu i lde r .1 The gold content of the currency has been established at 0.411543 gram of fine gold. The central rate is An t. f. 1.7900 per U S $ 1, and the Netherlands Antilles avails itself of wider margins. The intervention currency is the U . S. dollar. Exchange transactions between commercial banks and the public take place at An t. f. 1.79 buying, and An t. f. 1.81 selling, per US $ 1, plus a tax of %o of 1 per cent on sales of exchange, making the effective selling rate for the U . S. dollar An t. f. 1.8245 per U S $ 1 .2 The official buying and selling rates for certain other cur­ rencies are set daily on the basis of rates for the U . S. dollar abroad. The Bank of the Netherlands Antilles (the central bank) deals with commercial banks at interbank rates. It does not normally deal with the public. Commercial banks require the approval of the central bank to invest or hold foreign currency balances,3 but authorized banks have been granted general permissions for these purposes. Administration of Control Exchange licenses, where required, are issued by the central bank. Import licenses are issued by the Department of Economic Affairs. The commercial banks are permitted by the central bank to provide foreign exchange for most current transactions without prior approval. The central bank may grant an exemp­ tion from the obligation of surrendering foreign exchange, insofar as the assets or moneys concerned were acquired from nonresidents and are not being held in favor of, or on behalf of, or for the account of, third parties who are residents; the foreign exchange may then be held or used freely until further notice or until revocation by the central bank. Prescription of Currency Payments may be made in any currency except Netherlands Antilles guilders. Receipts may be accepted in any convertible currency except Netherlands Antilles guilders. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain items, such as narcotics and explo­ sives, are subject to license for public policy reasons. Imports into the islands of A rub a, Bonaire, and Curacao of a number of commodities, including edible oils and certain domestic appliances, are subject to licensing by the Department of Econom ic Affairs, while commercial imports of passenger automobiles built prior to the production year November 1, 1975-October 31, 1976 are prohibited. Payments for permitted imports may be made freely. Companies w i th nonresident status normally finance their imports with their own foreign exchange. Certain commodities are subject to import surcharges in A rub a, Bonaire, and Curacao. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles are not restricted. For most types of current invisibles remittances may be made freely through the authorized banks. Licenses are required mainly for the purchase of travel exchange in excess of A n t. f. 180 a person for each day to be spent abroad and for certain personal remittances in excess of A n t. f. 5,000 each or in excess of An t. f. 25,000 a person a year. Such licenses are freely granted when no illegal capital transfer seems to be involved. Nonresidents may take w i th them on departure any foreign currency which they brought in on arrival. The export of Netherlands An t i l les banknotes is limited to A n t. f. 200 a person. Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports require licenses, wh ich are usually granted. Exchange proceeds must be surrendered to an authorized bank within six months of shipment, with the exception of export proceeds received by companies with nonresident status. Capital Foreign investment in the Netherlands Antilles requires a license, which is, in general, granted if the investment is in the economic and social interest of the islands; the Investment Incentives Program, as amended, provides for duty-free entry of many com­ modities as well as tax facilities. New industrial com­ panies primarily engaged in exporting may be granted nonresident status by the central bank, which confers on the company concerned exemption from exchange control (except in its transactions with residents), includ­ ing exemption from the requirement of surrendering their foreign currency receipts. Such exemption may also be granted to investment companies, patent holding companies, shipping companies, and insurance com­ panies. Outward flows of resident-owned capital are subject to control, and certain capital transactions by or on behalf of residents are restricted. L i fe insurance con­ tracts in foreign currency between residents and foreign insurance companies for a minimum term of ten years are licensed freely up to an amount which is fixed annually, depending on the foreign exchange position, but outward transfers of capital by life insurance com­ panies are not restricted; contracts expressed in domestic currency are freely permitted in any amount by virtue of general permissions granted to individual foreign insurers. Investment by residents in real estate situated abroad requires a license. Investment in officially listed foreign securities (i.e., securities issued outside the Ne th­ erlands An t i l les or payable or optionally payable in the currency of a country other than the Netherlands Antilles) is freely allowed by a general permission; purchases of mutual fund shares are prohibited. Authorized banks may freely borrow foreign cur­ rency abroad from nonresidents (including residents with nonresident status), or accept foreign currency deposits from nonresidents, for relending to nonresidents or redeposit abroad; their borrowing from nonresidents for relending to residents is restricted for monetary policy reasons and banks require central bank approval to incur a net foreign l iab i l i ty position. Nonresidents are not normally permitted to acquire balances in Nether­ lands An t i l les guilders. L o c al borrowing in domestic currency by nonresidents (including resident companies N E T H E R L A N DS A N T I L L ES regarded as nonresidents for exchange control purposes) is restricted. Gold A commemorative gold coin of A n t. f. 200 is legal tender. Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in the Netherlands Antilles for numismatic and investment purposes; authorized banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents. Resi­ dents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed without special permis­ sion to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry or coins, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the central bank; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports of coins by authorized banks, and for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and indus­ tr ial users. Not for Redistribution NEW ZEALAND (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.99531 gram of fine gold per New Zealand Do l la r, corresponding to $NZ 0.892857 = SDR 1, and New Zealand avails itself of wider margins. Since July 9, 1973 no announced margins have been observed. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand adjusts the exchange rate for the U . S. dollar daily so as to maintain the effective relationship between the New Zealand dollar and the currencies of the main trading partners as at December 19, 1976. Except for the Aus­ tralian dollar and the pound sterling, the rates for spot transactions in currencies quoted by the New Zealand trading (commercial) banks are based on the closing buying and selling rates of the previous day in London. The rate for the pound sterling is derived by crossing the U .S .-London rate quoted in New Y o rk with the New Zealand-U.S. rate. The outer limits for the banks' buy­ ing and selling rates for the U . S. dollar on December 31, 1976 were US$0.9550 and US$0.9450, respectively, per $NZ 1. The trading banks are permitted to conclude with their customers forward exchange contracts for up to 12 months to cover both import and export transactions but can do so only within ten banking days of the exchange risk arising. Cover is not available for goods imported on consignment and nonresidents are not per­ mitted to obtain forward exchange cover. Forward transactions in Canadian dollars and pounds sterling take place at rates of exchange determined daily by the Reserve Bank and based on the closing buying and selling forward quotations of the previous day in L o n­ don. Forward exchange contracts written in U .S. dollars are concluded at the relative spot rates, adjusted in the case of contracts covering imports with a loading of US$0.0050 a month on the spot rate. The Reserve Bank provides a facility whereby trading banks may obtain day-to-day cover for their net positions in Canadian dollars, pounds sterling, and U .S. dollars, spot and for­ ward. Contracts in other currencies may be covered through the London or New Y o rk foreign exchange markets, against sterling or U .S. dollars. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand. The Reserve Bank has given discre­ tionary authority to the trading banks in New Zealand to approve applications for certain remittances of funds overseas. The Overseas Investment Commission admin­ isters the regulations governing foreign direct invest­ ment in New Zealand. Export and import licensing is the responsibility of the Customs Department and the Department of Trade and Industry, respectively. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from residents of countries other than New Zealand may generally be made or received in any foreign currency.1 Payment to and from the accounts in New Zealand currency held w i th banks in New Zealand by banks not domiciled in New Zealand or Rhodesia also is a generally acceptable form of payment. Nonresident Accounts The Reserve Bank supervises certain specified accounts in New Zealand of residents of other countries ("controlled accounts"). The accounts in New Zealand dollars of overseas banks may be used for the settlement of transactions with other countries, but they may only be funded from overseas or by amounts which would otherwise be remittable from New Zealand. Imports and Import Payments Imports are controlled through an annual Import Licensing Schedule, which groups imports into different categories to which various import procedures are applied. On a value basis, about 70 per cent of all private imports are exempt from licensing. The import categories included in the annual Schedule are as fol­ lows: Category " E" (exempt) includes petroleum, lub r i­ cating oils, certain other raw materials, green coffee, cocoa beans, jute, many textiles, specified sporting goods, tires, and printed books which may be imported without license. In addition, certain imports of Australian origin are exempt from licensing, irrespective of the licensing category to which they belong.2 A "Bas ic" category comprises items for which licenses are granted by refer­ ence to qualifying licenses issued or actual imports in a previous licensing period. Category " C" licenses are granted on an individual basis on such criteria as essen­ tiality, availability, and price; for some " C" items, how­ ever, an initial allocation based on a previous period is provided, while applications for further licenses are considered individually. "Administrative basic licenses" are issued automatically to ensure continuity of impor­ tation for certain regularly required goods that corre­ spond to only part of an item code. Imports of com­ pletely knocked-down automobiles are subject to special arrangements. In order to assure continuity of imports of specific items (mainly raw materials and consumer goods), in the 1974/75 program, the Government under­ took that over a three-year period importers would receive licenses at least equal in value to the basic allo­ cation for 1974/75; existing commitments are honored 1 Foreign currencies are defined as all currencies other than New Zealand currency. - Under the terms of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agree­ ment that came into force on January 1, 1966. 335 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution N EW Z E A L A ND but the scheme w i ll be allowed to lapse at the end of the initial three-year period. A ll licenses issued may be used for imports from any source at the applicant's discretion, except Rhodesia. Imports from Rhodesia require the consent of the Minister of Foreign Affairs. A degree of flexibility in the application of the Licensing Schedule is achieved through the use of G roup Schemes (for Industry and Interchangeability Groups) that enable importers to transfer individual entitlements to a composite license, instead of holding licenses for separate items, and to import, up to the total amount, any item or combina­ tion of items in the group. "No-remittance licenses" for imports outside the Import Licensing Schedule may be issued in special circumstances, v iz ., for advertising material supplied free of charge; gifts, passengers' baggage, replacement of faulty or damaged goods; trade samples supplied free of charge; and temporary imports. The trading banks have authority to make foreign exchange in an appropriate currency available for pay­ ments in respect of all licensed imports and all imports that do not require a license. An import deposit scheme was introduced on Febru­ ary 2, 1976 and w i ll remain in force until August 2, 1977. It applied to a range of finished consumer goods representing about 7 per cent of the value of total imports, until July 30, 1976 when the coverage of the scheme was reduced to about 5 per cent of total imports. Under the scheme importers are required to pay a deposit of one third of the value of their proposed imports. The deposit is held by the Reserve Bank for six months and repaid without interest. Payments for Invisibles The trading banks are permitted to sell exchange for overseas payments up to established limits for many categories of invisibles, subject in appropriate cases to the submission of justifying documents. Payments beyond the established limits, and for categories not included in the commercial banks' permitted list, require the specific approval of the Reserve Bank; applications must be supported, where appropriate, by justifying documents. Banks are authorized to sell foreign exchange for genuine foreign travel purposes without prior reference to the Reserve Bank up to $NZ 1,000 a person a month or part thereof, with a maximum of $NZ 4,000 a person in any 12-month period. Requests for amounts in excess of $NZ 1,000 a month or for a total of more than $NZ 4,000 in any 12-month period must be referred to the Reserve Bank. Larger amounts of exchange for any type of travel are authorized at the discretion of the Reserve Bank, which meets all reason­ able requests for genuine travel purposes. In addition to the above allocations, banks in New Zealand and their branches or agents in London and Aus tra l ia may sell foreign currencies, without l im it as to amount, to New 336 Zealand travelers against these persons' privately held foreign funds. A 10 per cent tax is payable on all tickets for overseas travel, except for travel to a few Pacific islands. The remittance abroad of dividends, interest, and profits due to nonresidents is approved, subject to formal authentication; for dividends and interest, the approval authority up to $NZ 1,500 in any 12-month period to any one remittee has been delegated to the authorized banks. Most contractual obligations incurred in the ordinary course of business also are normally approved, but each remittance requires approval and new commit­ ments such as royalty agreements with overseas licensors or overseas borrowing require the prior consent of the Reserve Bank. Allocations for remittances on account of mainte­ nance and /or gifts are made on a yearly basis without discrimination. Remittances by recognized New Zealand religious and charitable organizations or individuals operating as members of such an organization are not subject to any limitation. Allocations to individuals for religious and charitable remittances, other than of the type specified above, are approved by the Reserve Bank up to $NZ 500 a remitter, and applications for larger amounts are considered on their merits. A ny resident may freely make personal remittances up to a total of $NZ 100 a year to any destination overseas except Rho­ desia, for any purpose except gambling or building up assets in the remitter's name, provided that no individual remittance exceeds $NZ 20. Travelers may take with them up to $NZ 50 in New Zealand currency, regardless of destination. Banknotes taken out may not be in denominations larger than $NZ 5. Up to $NZ 4 of the permitted total may be in coins. Exports and Export Proceeds W i th minor exceptions, a ll exports require export licenses. These are issued by the Customs Department and carry the condition that the net export proceeds must be surrendered to a trading bank in accordance with the prescription of currency regulations. General export licenses va l id until December 31, 1982 are issued to regular exporters. Payments for exports must, unless prior consent is obtained, be received w i th in six months from the date of shipment. Exports to Rhodesia require the consent of the Minister of Foreign Affairs. Certain items classified as strategic goods may only be exported when particular requirements have been met and subse­ quent to the issue of a permit to export. Temporary restrictions have been imposed on exports of tallow and specified types of mutton. Exports of beef and veal to the United States and cheddar-type cheese to the United K ingdom are subject to annual quantitative restraint. Under an export bonus scheme, manufacturers sub­ mitting evidence of exportation may receive a replace­ ment import license of the same value as the imported raw material or components still subject to import con- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution trol that are incorporated in the exported goods, as well as, subject to certain conditions being met, an additional bonus license; goods imported against the bonus license may be used for the manufacture of goods for the home market or for export. The bonus license must not exceed the difference between the f.o.b. value of the goods exported and the c.i.f. value of imported materials and/or components used in manufacture by the exporter. Exports of lamb receive a subsidy. Proceeds from Invisibles When remuneration for services provided or to be provided in New Zealand for overseas residents by New Zealand residents (including corporate bodies ordinarily resident in New Zealand) is paid in the form of foreign assets,8 their foreign currency proceeds must be sold to the New Zealand banking system; interest and dividends earned overseas from portfolio investment are excluded from this surrender requirement. If the remuneration is in a form other than a foreign currency or a balance with an overseas bank, it must be converted into foreign currency before the surrender takes place. The disposal overseas by New Zealand residents of foreign income from other invisibles such as interest and dividends is permitted, but such income is not e l i­ gible for sale in exchange for New Zealand currency, except that the foreign currency proceeds may be sold to a New Zealand bank. Travelers may bring into the country unlimited amounts of foreign and domestic banknotes and coins, provided that any New Zealand banknotes brought in are in denominations not exceeding $NZ 5. Capital With the exception of certain capital issues outside New Zealand and certain overseas borrowings, consents are not required in respect of capital receipts. Wh i le overseas borrowing by financial institutions is controlled, consents are usually granted where the funds are required for industrial development purposes. To be eligible for repatriation, capital must have been initially transferred to New Zealand through normal banking channels or in some other way approved by the authorities, e.g., as imports of plant or machinery. Cap i tal so transferred, including capital gains and capitalized profits, may be repatriated, after the formal approval of the Reserve Bank has been obtained. In the case of overseas bor­ rowing, repayments are not permitted until the expiry of the term for which the funds were borrowed and in any case not within 12 months of the receipt of the proceeds. Overseas companies seeking to commence business in New Zealand require the approval of the * The kinds of remuneration that are involved are (1) the pay­ ment or provision of any money; (2) the crediting of any sum in any account at any bank or with any person; (3) the acquisition or provision of any securities, or any real or personal property, or of any right thereto or interest therein (whether actual or contingent); and (4) any benefit, whether by way of doing work or the performance of services, or otherwise, under any contract agreement, scheme, or transaction of any k ind (whether or not it is enforceable or intended to be enforceable by legal proceedings). N EW Z E A L A ND Overseas Investment Commission, under the terms of the Overseas Investment Regulations, 1974. Cap i tal issues outside New Zealand by companies incorporated in New Zealand require the approval of the Overseas Investment Commission; overseas borrow­ ing by such companies also requires prior approval. Forward exchange facilities are available to cover bor­ rowings abroad by New Zealand companies in cases where the borrowings relate to specific approved projects which w i ll develop industries based on the extraction or processing of indigenous raw materials. A ny such forward exchange cover would be for the amount of the capital sum only and is normally limited to not less than $NZ 50,000 and not more than $NZ 1 m i l l ion for each project. New Zealand subsidiaries and branches of overseas companies must obtain the consent of the Overseas Investment Commission if they wish to borrow in New Zealand, whether for long-term or short-term finance. Local borrowing by companies which are more than 75 per cent overseas owned is normally restricted to 10 per cent of the turnover in the previous financial year, with a special allowance in respect of any export turn­ over. Companies which are predominantly but less than 75 per cent overseas owned may borrow locally, in addi­ tion, an amount in proportion to the level of their bor­ rowings from overseas, based on the ratio of New Zealand and overseas equity holdings. Nonresident persons or companies desiring to make a direct investment in a New Zealand company through the purchase or exchange of shares are required to give notice to, and seek the consent of, the Overseas Investment Commission in respect of any proposed offer for such shares whenever the investment would result in the control by the offeror of 25 per cent or more of the New Zealand company's voting capital. Emigrants to any destination other than Rhodesia may upon designation as nonresidents transfer the whole of their assets to their new country of residence. A p p l i­ cations for the remittance abroad of legacies from the estate of a New Zealand resident are normally approved in fu l l. The authorities do not normally make exchange avail­ able to private persons or firms for the purchase of over­ seas securities for portfolio investment. New Zealand Government bonds purchased overseas by New Zealand residents after September 5, 1969 may not be trans­ ferred from the Un i ted K ingdom to the New Zealand register. A New Zealand resident owning overseas securities is free to sell them to overseas residents for any foreign currency, which may be reinvested in other overseas securities, surrendered, or retained at the dis­ posal of the New Zealand resident. W i th limited excep­ tions, sales of overseas securities by one New Zealand resident to another may be made only in exchange for other overseas securities or for any overseas currency. The only overseas securities that may be traded between New Zealand residents in exchange for New Zealand 337 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution N EW Z E A L A ND currency are those of any overseas country which were registered in the names of New Zealand residents on June 16, 1966 and for which scrip or other documents evidencing title were issued; the purchaser must lodge the share scrip with an approved depository (i.e., the Reserve Bank of New Zea land). These securities may also be sold for any overseas currency, in which case the proceeds must immediately be remitted to New Zealand through the banking system or reinvested in other overseas securities within three months and the resulting scrip deposited. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in New Zealand for numismatic purposes. Since the revocation in 1954 of the G o ld Acqu is i t ion No t ice, 1948, it is no longer necessary to offer gold to the Reserve Bank, and sales within New Zealand do not require Reserve Bank approval. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the Customs Depart­ ment; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Commercial imports of gold jewelry are licensed restrictively, but the importa­ tion of gold coins is exempt from license. Changes during 1976 February 2. An import deposit scheme was intro­ duced on a range of finished consumer goods for a 12-month period. The items affected would represent some 7 per cent of the value of total imports. Under the scheme, importers were required to pay a deposit of one third of the value of their proposed imports. This deposit would be held by the Reserve Bank for 6 months and repaid without interest. March 3. Hire-purchase restrictions were tightened by abolishing credit buying of new cars and by further restricting credit buying of secondhand cars and color television receivers. March 23. It was announced that the import deposit requirement was to be waived with retroactive effect for all goods used for repair purposes (spares and service parts but not components for assembly). April 1. The timetable for the tariff review was brought forward. In order that the new tariff structure could be introduced as planned on July 1, 1978 all final submissions to the Review Committee were to be received by the end of October 1976, instead of by the end of February 1977, as originally indicated. April 2. The import licensing arrangements for the year July 1, 1976 to June 30, 1977 provided for basic allocations to be generally 100 per cent by value of the 1975/76 basic licenses. However, taking into account the devaluation of the New Zealand dollar and the increases in import prices, the volume of goods imported in 1976/77 was expected to be considerably less than in the preceding period. 338 The allocation for bicycles, Manchester goods, and canned pineapple was reduced to 75 per cent of 1975/76 licenses; maize, corn flour, and tires and tubes were allocated 50 per cent of 1975/76 licenses. April 4. The emergency action of A p r il 1975 with respect to imports of certain polyester fabrics was extended for 12 months. May 3. Several changes were introduced in the con­ ditions under wh ich forward exchange cover was made available. Exporters and importers wishing to cover their exchange risks could do so only within ten banking days of the risk arising. A ny risk not covered within that period ceased to be eligible for cover. The purpose of this change was to ensure that the facility was avail­ able to traders genuinely seeking to eliminate their risks, while reducing opportunities for speculative use of the system. The maximum period of cover for importers was extended from 6 to 12 months in line with the present export cover facility. Cover ceased to be available for goods imported on consignment and nonresidents were no longer able to obtain forward exchange cover. June 4. New Zealand and the Un i ted States formally signed the 1976 voluntary restraint agreement on beef imports to the Un i ted States. July 29. It was announced that with effect from A p r il 1, 1977, nonresident companies w i ll be subject to a company tax of 50 per cent, replacing the progressive scale now in effect. July 29. The terminating date for all existing export incentive schemes was extended to M a r ch 31, 1980. A range of new selective investment incentives was intro­ duced, including a 20 per cent investment allowance for new export-oriented plant and machinery. July 30. A 10 per cent tax was introduced on all overseas travel except a few Pacific islands, including F i j i, Tonga, and Western Samoa. The tax was payable on all tickets supplied in New Zealand. A ll vendors of foreign travel were required to be licensed and the tax was payable to them in New Zealand dollars at the time of purchase. As a general rule, only payments for overseas travel were taxable, which meant that in package tours payments for components representing accommodation and other known travel items were not taxable. July 30. The coverage of the import deposit scheme was reduced to approximately 5 per cent of total imports when a number of import categories became exempt. These included alcoholic beverages, marine outboard engines, and certain types of machinery. September 1. An entry tax was introduced on all foreign fishing vessels using New Zealand ports. The tax was graded according to the size of the vessel with a maximum of $NZ 5,000 charged to vessels of 5,000 tons and over. November 18. Restrictions on exports and re-exports of sugar were revoked. November 29. It was announced that the New ©International Monetary Fund. The Reserve Bank stated its intention to continue to adjust the rate so as to maintain the new average overall relationship with the currencies of New Zealand's main trading partners. December 9. Not for Redistribution NICARAGUA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.105237 gram of fine gold per Nicaraguan Cordoba. The parity for the U . S. dollar is C$7 .00 = US $ 1. The Central Bank of Nicaragua deals with the commercial banks in U . S. dollars, the interven­ tion currency, at C$7.00 per US $ 1, buying and selling, and sells exchange to the Government at C$7.0525 per US $ 1. A ll exchange transactions between commercial banks and the public take place at the official rates of C$7 .00 buying, and C$7.0525 selling, per US $ 1. Nicaragua accepted the obligations of A r t ic le V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from July 20, 1964. Administration of Control The exchange control system is administered by the Central Bank, which by law has the sole authority to buy and sell foreign exchange. This authority has been dele­ gated to the commercial banks, and the Central Bank deals with the public only to the extent that it accepts deposits in foreign currency, and for purposes of mone­ tary control. Certain agencies are also authorized to buy and sell foreign exchange, but they may sell exchange only for payments for invisibles. The Central Bank is responsible for classifying imports and deter­ mining any advance deposits required; no advance deposit requirements are in force at present. Prescription of Currency There is no prescription of currency, but the customs authorities have the power to prohibit an export if the currency stipulated for payment is not readily converti­ ble into U . S. dollars in international markets. Payments to Costa R i c a, El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras in respect of trade and invisibles may be settled in Nicaraguan cordobas through the Camara de Compen­ sation Centroamericana, a clearinghouse established by the central banks of Central Ame r ica to foster the process of economic integration of their countries. The Central Bank does not accept banknotes of El Salvador for compensation through the clearinghouse in excess of 400,000 Salvadoran colones a month. Imports and Import Payments A ll commercial and industrial importers are required to be registered. There are two broad categories of registered importers: those who are permitted to import any k ind of merchandise and those who may import only for their own industrial needs. Unregistered ind i­ viduals may import for their own personal consumption. Commercial and industrial imports from a ll countries, except the other Central Amer ican countries, must be consigned to persons or firms holding a commercial 340 license from the M in is t ry of Economy. Import licenses are not required, but import transactions must be regis­ tered with the Central Bank by means of import declara­ tions. A ll imports on credit and all prepayments for imports require approval by the Central Bank, which is normally granted only for capital goods, industrial mate­ rials, and other essential goods; when payment is not being made on sight of documents, an application for registration of the order must be submitted to the Central Bank. Payments for imports must be made with exchange purchased from banks.1 Payments are usually made by sight drafts. Letters of credit are mostly confined to imports from Japan. Central Bank approval is not required to open an import letter of credit. The banks are not permitted to sell exchange for import payments in advance of the arrival of the documents. The Cen­ tral Bank may authorize deferred payment or payment with funds derived from properly authenticated credits obtained abroad, provided that the imports are capital goods intended for development or production or for basic works complementary to production; such per­ mission is at present limited mainly to industrial and agricultural machinery and, for certain industries, raw materials. Imports are not released from customs unless evidence is submitted either that payment has been made through a bank (constancia de pago) or that acceptance has been made through a bank (constancia de acepta- cion). In the latter case, the Central Bank must also approve the importation on credit terms; this require­ ment does not apply to duty-free imports from member countries of the Central Ame r ican Common Market. Most imports originating outside the Central Ameri­ can Common Market are subject to an import surcharge of 30 per cent of the applicable import duty. Certain commodities are subject to a compensatory (selective) consumption tax irrespective of their origin. Further­ more, most commodities are subject to a 6 per cent general sales tax, whether they are imported or domes­ tically produced, and there is an additional 2 per cent consumption tax levied for the benefit of the National Welfare Board. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are not subject to license and may be made freely. Persons purchasing foreign cur­ rency to make payments for invisibles are required, for statistical purposes, to complete a declaration specifying the purpose for wh ich the foreign currency obtained 1 However, by virtue of Decree N o. 1-L (effective March 1, 1963) the exchange proceeds from bananas, coconuts, copra, and coconut by-products exported through the ports of the region of El Cabo and the department of Zelaya may be used by the exporters to pay for commodities not produced in Nicaragua which they themselves import for the exclusive use of or consumption by the inhabitants of those areas. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution w i ll be used. Domestic and foreign currency notes may be exported freely. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are not required, but a declaration to the customs authorities must be completed for statistical purposes. The exchange proceeds of exports do not have to be surrendered; however, they may not be used to pay for imports (exchange for which must be pur­ chased from a bank, with the exception stated in foot­ note 1 ). F or certain agricultural exports (live cattle, beans, rice, corn, and cottonseed), the M in is t ry of Economy can fix minimum export prices or tempo­ rarily prohibit their export in order to avoid domestic shortages. Proceeds from Invisibles The surrender of foreign exchange derived from invisibles is not required. Domestic and foreign currency notes may be imported freely. Capital Remittances on account of foreign capital and capital transfers by residents and nonresidents may be made freely under the general provisions of the Exchange Law of M a r ch 1, 1963 or under the Law on Foreign Investments of February 26, 1955 (effective M a r ch 11, 1955). Under the 1955 law, foreign investments approved by the Central Bank and registered are guaran­ teed the following privileges, provided that the foreign currency is converted in the banking system: repatriation N I C A R A G UA of the registered capital; transfer of earnings, profits, or interest on the capital; and re-exportation of goods imported for investment. Commercial banks and private investment companies require the prior approval of the Central Bank for a ll borrowing abroad. Gold Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Nicaragua. Producers of gold sell their newly mined gold at free market prices to buyers abroad. The Central Bank purchases gold abroad for resale to domestic industrial and other users. Nonmonetary imports and exports of gold do not require import or export licenses but must be registered with the Central Bank and require prior government authorization. Commemorative gold coins were issued in 1967 and commemorative gold and silver coins were issued in 1975. Changes during 1976 March 23. A decree authorized the establishment of duty-free zones for export industries. Businesses set up within the zones w i ll be exempt from customs duties, while export receipts w i ll be exempt from income tax. A new agency, the Au to r idad de las Zonas Francas w i ll be in charge of the establishment and management of the duty-free zones. May 16. A temporary ban on imports of iron rods imposed on M ay 6, 1975 was lifted. September 7. The arrangement whereby payments to Mex ico might be settled in cordobas through the clear­ inghouse was suspended. 341 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NIGER (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange System No par value or central rate for the currency of Niger has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the C FA Franc 3 which is officially main­ tained at the rate of C F AF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transactions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de l'Afr ique de l'Ouest ( B C E A O) and commercial banks take place at the rate of C F AF 1 = F 0.02, subject to a commission from which transactions for the account of the public Treasury and transactions in banknotes and travelers checks are exempt; the commission is Mo of 1 per m i ll for transfers to other countries of the West A f r ican Monetary U n i on and 2.50 per m i ll for transfers to countries outside the U n i o n. Exchange rates for foreign currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned, and include a commission. Banks levy a commission on transfers to all countries outside the West A f r ican Monetary U n i o n, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. A fixed exchange rate is applied in certain transactions with N iger ia. W i th the exception of those relating to gold, Niger's exchange control measures do not apply to (1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories, except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Benin, Cameroon, the Central Afr ican Empire, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Ivory Coast, M a l i, Senegal, Togo, and Upper V o l t a ). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. A ll other countries, except Niger itself, are con­ sidered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only with foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the External Finance Office in the M in is t ry of Finance which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in N iger, and inward and outward investment. The B C E AO is author­ ized to collect, either direct or through the intermediary of banks, financial institutions, the Postal Adm in is tra­ tion, and notaries public, any information necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics. A ll exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through the B C E AO or authorized banks. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of External 1 The C FA franc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de l'Afrique de l'Ouest ( B C E A O) and is the common currency in Benin, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper V o l t a. 342 Trade in the M in is t ry of Economic Affairs, Commerce, and Industry, subject to the visa of the External Finance Office in the M in i s t ry of Finance, except those for gold, wh ich are granted by the M in is t ry of Finance. Import certificates for liberalized commodities are made out by the importer himself and are first approved by the External Finance Office. Prescription of Currency N iger is an Operations Account country of the French Franc A r e a, since the B C E AO maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settlements with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in C FA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Settlements with The Gamb ia, Ghana, L ibe r ia, N ige r ia, and Sierra Leone normally are made through the West A f r ican Clearing House. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in foreign currencies or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. B C E AO banknotes may be credited to Foreign Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the B C E AO agency in Niamey by authorized banks' foreign correspondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of B C E AO banknotes, French banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments A ll imports of commodities originating in Rhodesia or South A f r ica are prohibited. Imports of soap, cement, and certain printed cotton fabrics are prohibited, irre­ spective of origin, unless a special authorization is issued by the M in is t ry of Economic Affairs, Commerce, and Industry. The import from any source of rice, paddy, hulled rice, wheat flour, butane gas, many types of fabric, certain footwear, and certain plastic goods requires prior authorization, irrespective of whether an import license or import certificate is also required. A similar regime applies to imports of sugar, except from member countries of the Common Organization of A f r ican and Mau r i t ian States, and to imports of matches, except from countries of the West A f r ican Customs U n i o n. Imports from France and the Operations Account countries in the French Franc A rea of all goods other than those mentioned above may be made freely without ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution a license or certificate. Imports from other countries require either a license or an import certificate. Imports of virtually all goods from A lge r ia, Mo rocco, Tun is ia, and the six original member states of the E E C, many goods from other former O E EC countries and their past or present dependent territories, and a smaller number of items from the Un i ted States and Canada are liberal­ ized and require only an import certificate. Imports of nonliberalized goods from n o n -EEC countries outside the F rench F ranc A r ea are made under global quotas in accordance w i th an annual program that is determined each year by the M in i s t ry of Economic Affairs, C om­ merce, and Industry. Licenses for certain cotton fabrics are conditional upon purchases of the corresponding domestic product. Goods not subject to quantitative restriction may be imported on an import certificate, i.e., a declaration made out by the importer. The Societe Nationale de Commerce et de Production du N iger (COPRONIGER) has a monopoly over the import of specified commodities. These include wheat, wheat flour, green tea, and certain textiles. A ll import transactions with foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when valued at more than C F AF 25,000 c.i.f. Nigerien border. The import licenses or import certificates entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, provided that the authorized bank is satisfied that the import transaction is genuine and in accordance with the import title. Import certificates require the visa of the External Finance Office. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc A rea are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to the approval of the Exter­ nal Finance Office, wh ich for certain transactions has delegated its powers to the authorized banks. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted freely when the basic trans­ action has been approved. Residents traveling on tourist trips to countries other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc A rea may obtain an exchange allo­ cation of an amount equivalent to C F AF 100,000 a per­ son a trip ( C F AF 50,000 for children under ten), which may be taken up twice a year; any foreign exchange in excess of C F AF 5,000 remaining after return to N iger must be surrendered within eight days by sale to an authorized bank. The transfer of salaries of foreigners working in N iger is subject to prior approval by the External Finance Office and is normally limited to 50 per cent of net pay. Resident travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to a maximum of C F AF 25,000 in B C E AO bank­ N IG ER notes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries, in addition to their travel allocation. Resident travelers to other countries of the French Franc A r ea may take out any amount in B C E AO banknotes but, when traveling to a French Franc A r ea country outside the West A f r ican Monetary U n i o n, must declare these if they exceed C F AF 150,000. Nonres i­ dent travelers may freely take out up to C F AF 25,000 in B C E AO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries, and foreign notes up to the amount declared upon entry,2 or, if no declaration was made, up to C F AF 25,000; they may also take out freely any amount of foreign currency travelers checks, etc., issued abroad in their name. Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports to Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are pro­ hibited. A ll exports of rice and paddy require the prior authorization of the M in is t ry of Economic Affairs, Commerce, and Industry. Exports of millet and sorghum are prohibited unless covered by a shipping document in the name of the Office des Produits V ivr iers du N iger ( O P V N ). G um arabic may be exported only by COPRONIGER. W i th the exception of peanuts, peanut o i l, peanut cakes, sisal, cotton, cottonseed, and certain imported commodities, all of which require a license, a ll other exports to France (as defined above) and the Operations Account countries in the French Franc A rea may be made freely. Exports to all other countries of domestic products and imported commodities require a license and an exchange commitment. The due date of payments for exports to foreign countries must not, in principle, be later than 180 days after arrival of the goods at their destination. The proceeds must be co l­ lected and, if the contract is denominated in a non- Franc A rea currency, surrendered by sale on the exchange market, within two months after the due date. A ll export transactions w i th foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their total value exceeds C F AF 100,000. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc A r ea may be retained. A ll amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services, and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets, must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date or the date of receipt. Capital Cap i tal movements between N iger and France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc A rea are free of exchange control; capital transfers to a ll other countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward and outward invest­ ment, and over the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in N ige r; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to payments or receipts. W i th the exception of those over foreign securities in N iger, these control measures do not apply to relations w i th France (as defined above), Monaco, the other member countries of the West A f r i c an Mone­ tary U n i o n, and those other countries whose bank of issue is linked w i th the French Treasury by an Opera­ tions Accoun t. Special controls are maintained also over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and institutions, and over all publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate building operations abroad; these special controls do apply also to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. A ll investments abroad by residents of N iger require prior authorization by the M in is ter of F inance .3 Foreign direct investments in N iger 4 must be declared to the Minister of Finance before they are made. The M in is ter has a period of two months from receipt of the declara­ tion during wh ich he may request the postponement of the projects submitted to h im. The full or partial liquidation of investments, whether direct or not, also requires prior declaration. Bo th the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Nigerien investments abroad or foreign investments in N iger, must be reported to the M in is ter of Finance and the B C E AO within 20 days following each operation. D irect investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. 3 Including those made through the intermediary of foreign com­ panies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Niger and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Niger. 4 Including those made by companies in Niger that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or sub­ sidiaries in Niger of foreign companies. 344 The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in N iger requires prior authorization by the M in is ter of Finance. Exempt from authorization, how­ ever, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the N iger ien Government, and (2) shares that are similar to or may be substituted for securities whose issuing or offering for sale in Niger has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the M in is ter of Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constituting a direct investment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans contracted by authorized banks; and (3) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount outstanding of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed C F AF 2 m i l l ion for any one borrower, provided that the annual rate does not exceed the "no rma l" market rate and that the proceeds of the loan are immediately sold on the exchange market or debited to a Foreign Account in Francs. The repay­ ment of a foreign borrowing constituting a direct invest­ ment is subject to the same formalities as the liquidation of a direct investment; the repayment of other borrow­ ings requires authorization only to the extent that the borrowing itself was subject to prior authorization. Lend ing abroad is subject to prior authorization by the M in is ter of Finance. Foreign investments in N iger may be granted certain guarantees and facilities under the Investment Code of July 31, 1968 (Law N o. 68-24), as amended by L aw N o. 71-2 of January 29, 1971 and Law N o. 74-18 of M a r ch 11, 1974. Ex is t ing benefits accorded under the previous Investment Code (Law N o. 61-21 of July 12, 1961) have been maintained. The new Investment Code provides for privileged or regular treatment. The latter provides assurances, for both new and existing enterprises, with respect to indemnities in the event of expropriation and concerning nondiscrimination between Nigerien nationals and for­ eign nationals; tax exemptions may be granted to new investments. Privileged treatment is reserved for enter­ prises deemed to be of special importance to national economic development and falling w i th in specified categories of industrial activities. Such treatment may be accorded under two different regimes, the approval regime and the agreement regime. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in N ige r. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the M in is ter of Finance, wh ich is seldom granted. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Treasury or the B C E A O; (2) imports and exports of manufactured articles con­ taining a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution N IG ER gold-plated articles); and (3) articles of gold up to a combined weight of 500 grams when carried by a traveler.
