Not for Redistribution P ERU (Position on January 7, 1977) Exchange Rate System On December 18, 1946, a par value for the Peruvian Sol was established by Peru with the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. There is a dual exchange market with a single exchange rate, which is adjusted from time to time; on December 31, 1976 the rate for the U . S. dollar was S /. 69.37 per US$1, buying and selling. The exchange certificate market rate applies to all trade transactions and specified nontrade transactions, inc lud­ ing the principal capital movements, and the draft mar­ ket rate to services and most other nontrade transac­ tions. The foreign exchange requirements of the public sector are met entirely through the certificate market. Export proceeds must be converted into exchange certificates, which are valid for three days and are issued by the Central Reserve Bank of Peru in U . S. dollars only. These exchange certificates may be used, only through the intermediary of commercial banks, to pay for imports (f.o.b.) and for certain nontrade transac­ tions. Generally, no exchange certificates are issued against export proceeds surrendered by the public sec­ tor, nor are certificates used to cover foreign payments of the public sector, since normally the Central Reserve Bank buys and sells foreign exchange direct from and to government agencies at the certificate rate. When approved applications for certificates exceed the supply, the Central Reserve Bank sells foreign exchange at the certificate market rate without any delay. A ll foreign exchange receipts that are not required to be surrend­ ered at the certificate rate must be sold in the draft market, in which only the government-owned Banco de la Nac ion and its authorized agents operate. Access to the draft market is controlled and purchases of for­ eign exchange are permitted only for specified payments not eligible for exchange at the certificate rate. The banks are required to quote a single rate for buying and selling certificates, but they may charge a commission of V4 of 1 per cent on sales of certificates (none on purchases of certificates); they may charge a commission of VA of 1 per cent, buying and selling, on transactions in the draft market. A stamp tax of 1 per cent is payable on most outward remittances. Peru formally accepted the obligations of A r t ic le V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Administration of Control Export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Fo r­ eign Trade in the M in is t ry of Commerce. The Central Reserve Bank controls the use of certificates for import payments. It also authorizes the use of certificates for nontrade transactions; for profit remittances by branches of foreign companies, prior approval by the M in is t ry of 366 Economy and Finance must be obtained in addition. A ll imports require the approval, within the framework of an annual import plan, of the competent sectoral ministry. In addition, a specific import license issued by the M in is t ry of Commerce is required for each import transaction of the private sector, and foreign exchange for imports is allocated to each importer by the Central Reserve Bank on the basis of the approved annual import program. Pub l ic sector imports require the approval of the Board for External Transactions of the Pub l ic Sector. Borrow ing abroad by the public sector as well as bor­ rowing abroad by the private sector with a government guarantee are subject to prior approval by Supreme Decree, upon favorable recommendation by the High Committee of the External Debt, the Na t ional Planning Institute, and the Permanent Commission on External Credit in the M in is t ry of Economy and Finance. The External Office for Foreign Investment in the Commer­ (OIESCO) supervises foreign commercial cial Sector investment in Peru, the use of foreign trademarks, patents, and licenses, as well as thj related royalty payments. Prescription of Currency In principle, all export proceeds must be received in convertible currencies; 1 exchange certificates at present are only issued in U . S. dollars, but the Central Reserve Bank is empowered to issue certificates denominated in any convertible currency. Settlements in respect of trade transactions with Hungary and Poland must be made through special accounts denominated in U . S. dollars, which have been established under bilateral payments agreements. No other prescription of currency require­ ments are in force. Payments between Peru and Argen­ tina, Bo l iv i a, B r a z i l, Ch i le, Co lomb ia, Ecuador, Mexico, Paraguay, Uruguay, and Venezuela may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the Central Reserve Bank of Peru and the other central banks concerned, w i th in the framework of the LAFTA multilateral clearing system. Imports and Import Payments Goods not included in the List of Permitted Imports may not be imported (with the exception of goods from Andean G roup countries and gifts). Moreover, the import of a large number of manufactures included in the Na t ional Register of Manufactured Products requires the approval of the M in is t ry of Industry and Tourism and of the customs authorities, which is granted only in 1 The proceeds must be received in the currency in which the con­ tract is expressed if it is one of the following currencies: Belgian francs, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, or U .S. dollars. Otherwise, export proceeds must be received in U . S. dollars. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution exceptional circumstances unless the goods originate in a country of the Andean G roup. F or goods on the L ist of Permitted Imports that are also on the Na t ional Register of Manufactured Products, the importer must show that local production is insufficient in quantity or quality. Each year a Na t ional Annual Import Program and an Annual Import Exchange Budget are approved by a Supreme Decree of the Counc il of Ministers. The former specifies the permitted annual import level by sector and, within each sector, by private and public importers. On the basis of this plan, the relevant sec­ toral ministries approve annual import programs for each importer, with each program specifying item-by- item the approved volume and estimated U . S. dollar value. In accordance with these approved programs, private sector importers are provided by the Central Reserve Bank with four quarterly exchange allocation cards. The corresponding amount of exchange is sub­ tracted from the card each time import documents are registered. In addition, each import transaction requires a specific import license which is issued by the M in is t ry of Commerce after the verification that the items to be imported are included in the importer's annual program. Imports from countries of the Andean G roup, however, do not require an import license and need only be registered with the M in is t ry of Commerce. Certain agri­ cultural commodities, such as rice and wheat, may be imported only by the F ish Meal Marke t ing Agency (EPCHAP), and crude petroleum and petroleum deriva­ tives only by PETROPERU, a government agency. Cer­ tain industrial raw materials and fertilizers may be imported only by the Na t ional Enterprise for Industrial Marketing ( E N C I ). Payments for the f.o.b. value of private sector imports, whether under documentary letters of credit or on a documentary collection basis, and for interest charges on foreign import credits, may be made at the certificate exchange rate; however, payments for freight and import-related banking charges other than interest must be made at the draft market rate. Transport insurance contracts for imported goods must be placed with national insurance companies unless a specific exemp­ tion from this requirement is obtained from the Banco de la Nac ion, in which case premium payments are made at the draft market rate. The full c.i.f. value of public sector imports may be paid with certificates. The use of certificates for import payments requires the prior authorization of the Central Reserve Bank, which provides the foreign exchange to the commercial banks against delivery of the certificates. The commer­ cial banks must present evidence that the entire amount represented by the certificates w i ll be used for the importation of merchandise. The relevant shipping documents and the b i ll of lading, together with the com­ mercial invoice and the remittance letter issued by the exporter, must be forwarded to a commercial bank and P E RU presented to the Central Reserve Bank for registration and validation. Submission of import contracts or other evidence sup­ porting the transaction is required for advance import payments when the shipping documents are not avail­ able; in addition, the intermediary bank must provide a guarantee equal to the sol value of the advance payment. If the shipping documents are not presented within 30 days after the utilization of the foreign exchange, the Central Reserve Bank w i ll collect the guarantee and refund this sum only when the required documents have been presented. M i n im um credit terms have been pre­ scribed for many imports. F or imports of capital goods valued at over US$10,000 f.o.b., at least 80 per cent of the value must be financed abroad through loans either from suppliers or other foreign creditors or from the Peruvian state development banks, to be repaid in accordance with prescribed m in i­ mum credit terms. The state development banks may only provide such financing for national enterprises; these loans are repayable at the exchange rate prevailing at the time of repayment. The Central Reserve Bank may authorize the sale of exchange certificates only for partial advance payments of up to 20 per cent of the f.o.b. value for imports of capital goods by the private sector (20 per cent of the c.i.f. value for public sector imports). These imports of capital goods must be cov­ ered by irrevocable documentary credits and the inter­ mediary bank must guarantee refunding of the foreign currency if the import is not effected by the time the relevant documentary credit expires. F or private sector imports of goods other than capital goods from countries outside the Andean G roup, the minimum external financing terms at the end of 1976 were as follows: (1) foodstuffs and pharmaceutical products were exempt; (2) a credit period of at least 90 days from the date of shipment was prescribed for certain intermediate and finished goods; (3) the corre­ sponding minimum period for all other goods was 120 days; and (4) import shipments valued at up to US$5,000 (c. & f.) were exempt, up to a total value of US$50,000 a year for each importer. A ll goods, whether imported or produced domes­ tically, are subject to a sales tax imposed by Decree- Law N o. 21497. The tax is levied at a general rate of 20 per cent, a maximum rate of 40 per cent, preferential rates of between 2 per cent and 7 per cent, and reduced rates corresponding to effective rates of between 10 per cent and 16 per cent; there is also a list of exempted items. A maritime freight tax of 4 per cent of the ocean freight charges is levied on goods imported by sea other than certain agricultural and medical products, books, and coins. Pub l ic sector imports must, in principle, be shipped in Peruvian vessels. Payments for Invisibles Au thor iza t ion is required in order to pay for invisibles with certificates or at the certificate rate. The transac- 367 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution P E RU tions in invisibles that are eligible for the certificate mar­ ket include government payments, profit remittances by branches of foreign companies operating in Peru, d iv i­ dend remittances to foreign shareholders (provided that the original investment took place at the certificate rate), and interest payments on those loans for which amortiza­ tion may be transferred through the certificate market. Remittances of net profits, including depletion and depreciation allowances, require a resolution of the M i n­ istry of Economy and Finance, a prior tax clearance, and the visa of the Central Reserve Bank. Moreover, in compliance with the foreign investment regime approved by the countries of the Andean G roup, new foreign investments must be authorized and registered with the competent agency. Access to the certificate market or the draft market for profit remittances is determined according to the market through which the investment is made. Remittances of profits on foreign capital invested in Peru are limited to 20 per cent a year, although a higher percentage may be permitted in exceptional cases;2 foreign-owned enterprises may not pay royalties under new contracts to a foreign parent company or its affiliates; and the effective interest rate on a new loan from a foreign parent company or its foreign affiliate may not exceed by more than 3 per cent the prevailing interest rate for first-class assets in the money market of the country in whose currency the transaction is denominated. Exchange for payments that are not eligible for exchange certificates must be obtained in the draft mar­ ket, subject to the prior authorization of the Banco de la Nac ion. For private sector payments in respect of a large number of current invisibles the sale of foreign exchange is authorized freely, either by the Banco de la Nac ion or its agents, provided evidence is presented that genuine current payments are involved. These cate­ gories include insurance premiums, the remuneration of technicians hired abroad, interest on loans for which amortization payments are permitted to be transferred through the draft market, rental income, pensions, and commissions. Payments for royalties, patents, and trade­ marks require the prior approval of the contract by the competent agency. F or certain other payments of the private sector basic allocations have been established up to which foreign exchange is sold freely through the draft market by the Banco de la Nac ion. These cate­ gories include expenses abroad connected with tourist and business travel, study, and family maintenance. The basic l im it up to which foreign exchange for tourist travel may be sold is the equivalent of S /. 1,200 a person a day for travel in the Amer ican continent and S /. 1,350 a person a day for travel elsewhere. The corresponding limits for business travel range from S /. 2,600 to S /. 3,900 a person a day, plus representa­ tion expenses of up to S /. 26,000 a trip. There is a travel tax, which takes the form of a tax on a traveler's acquisition of goods and services abroad (including the cost of passages and fares) of 30 per cent for tourist travel and business travel on amounts up to the daily limits specified above, and of 50 per cent on any amounts in excess of these limits; the minimum amount payable is S /. 200 a day for each day spent abroad. Exempt are residents traveling on official business and foreign diplomats. Travel for medical treatment or study abroad also is exempt. The tax is paid prior to departure on the basis of a sworn declaration specifying separately the amount of the fare, the value of anticipated services to be received, and daily expenses. A ir and sea passages are in addition subject to a 15 per cent ad valorem tax (9 per cent for economy class fares). Foreign nationals resident in Peru must obtain a special travel permit for business travel abroad (permiso especial de salida y reingreso). Such permits cost S /. 1,000 and are valid for six months. The export of domestic currency in excess of S /. 1,000 by travelers is prohibited, but the Central Reserve Bank may grant exemptions in special circumstances. Exports and Export Proceeds The Banco M ine ro del Peru has a monopoly over the export of uncut precious stones and pearls, and MINEROPERU and the Banco M ine ro over exports of gold and silver. EPCHAP has a monopoly over exports of fish meal, fish o i l, coffee, and cotton, and E P SEP over exports of fish for human consumption. A ll exports are subject to license to assure the necessary supply of export proceeds to the certificate market. Traditional exports must be sold against an irrevocable letter of credit confirmed by a bank established in Peru; the latter must surrender the foreign exchange proceeds within ten working days of payment. In special cases, and with the authorization of the Central Reserve Bank and the Directorate of Foreign Trade, exports may be sold against sight drafts, provided that payment is received within 180 days of shipment. Exporters of nontraditional exports or local handi­ craft articles are granted transferable tax credit certifi­ cates (certificados de reintegro tributario or CERTEX) equivalent to 30 per cent of the c. & f. value (the f.o.b. value is used when the goods are shipped in foreign ves­ se l s ) .8 These certificates may be used by the exporter in payment of his tax obligations or may be sold to other taxpayers, who may use them for the same purpose. The Banco de la Nac ion administers an export credit guarantee program and the Industrial Bank provides or arranges export finance for nontraditional exports. Trad i t ional exports are subject to a tax of 15 per cent. Proceeds from Invisibles Most public sector entities other than the state banks must surrender their fu ll receipts at the certificate rate; 2 Companies exporting at least 80 per cent of their production to countries outside the Andean Group and mining companies are exempt. 3 An additional 2 per cent is allowed for new exports and an addi­ tional 10 per cent for exports from outside the L ima -Ca l lao area. 368 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution the exceptions are earnings from services provided by the Peruvian Shipping Company ( C P V) and the Peru­ vian A i r l i ne Company (A ERO P ERU ), which are eligible for the draft market rate. A ll other receipts from invisibles must be sold in the draft market. Travelers may not bring in more than S /. 1,000 in Peruvian cur­ rency, but the Central Reserve Bank may grant exemp­ tions in special circumstances. Capital A ll outward capital transfers require prior approval. In addition to government payments, certain capital pay­ ments on private account may be effected through the certificate market. The use of exchange certificates may be authorized for the amortization of foreign loans con­ tracted by the private sector, provided that the foreign exchange proceeds of the loan have been surrendered to the Central Reserve Bank. Where such debt was contracted before October 9, 1967, certificate exchange may be allotted by the Central Reserve Bank only to public utility enterprises, to earners of foreign exchange, for payment of debts to international organizations, and for payment of debts guaranteed by the State. Payments in connection with all loans received before June 17, 1971 and not channeled through the certificate market must be transferred through the draft market. The proceeds of all foreign loans received after June 17, 1971 must be converted in the certificate market; amor­ tization and service payments in respect of these loans are also settled through the certificate market. A ll exchange receipts that are not required to be sold in the certificate market must be sold in the draft market. On ly the Banco de la Nac ion may receive funds orig­ inating abroad for deposit to foreign currency accounts maintained in the name of nonresidents; these funds and the accrued interest thereon may be freely disposed of by the depositor and are exempt from income and inheritance taxes until December 31, 1978. Foreign investment in Peru is governed by Decree- Law N o. 18900 of June 30, 1971, which ratified the Andean Common Market's policy on the treatment of foreign capital, by Decree-Law N o. 18999 of Octo­ ber 19, 1971, and by Decree-Law N o. 19232, Decree- Law N o. 19307, Decree-Law N o. 19971, and the legis­ lation ruling the Peruvian exchange system. A ll foreign investments in Peru require the prior approval of the competent authorities with a view to channeling such investments to projects considered essential for the coun­ try's development. If they wished to enjoy for their products the advantages deriving from the duty-free program of the Cartagena Agreement, foreign companies incorporated in Peru as at July 1, 1971 had to agree, by June 30, 1974, to the gradual acquisition by national investors of shares in such companies so as to transform them into mixed or national companies during a maxi­ mum period of 15 years following the entering into effect of this regime. F or this purpose, mixed compa­ P E RU nies are defined as those in which national investors hold between 51 per cent and 80 per cent of the capital, while national companies are those in which at least 80 per cent of the capital is owned by national investors. After June 30, 1974, the participation of national investors in the capital of an enterprise had to amount to not less than 15 per cent; this participation must increase to at least 45 per cent after 10 years and to at least 51 per cent at the end of the 15-year period. In the case of foreign companies established in Peru after June 30, 1971, the 15 per cent participation by national investors must be secured at the time of the initiation of production. Foreign investments in firms engaged in basic industries or in mining activities (including petro­ leum production) and in firms which export at least 80 per cent of their production to countries outside the Andean Common Market are exempt from the require­ ment of gradual transformation into mixed companies; however, these enterprises do not benefit from the duty­ free program of the Cartagena Agreement. A ll insurance and reinsurance companies that were not branches of foreign firms had to become national enterprises by June 30, 1974, and all insurance and reinsurance companies established in Peru after July 17, 1973, had to be completely owned by national investors. Investment in the mining sector is governed by the General M i n i ng Law (Decree-Law N o. 18880) of June 8, 1971, which replaced the M i n i ng Code of M ay 12, 1950. Companies holding mining concessions may enter into mining contracts with the Government providing for special incentives and guarantees or may constitute mixed enterprises with government participa­ tion of at least 25 per cent. Under the regime of mining contracts, the Government may grant to mining con­ cessionaires initiating large-scale investment programs tax incentives and guaranteed availability of foreign exchange for transfers of (1) recovery of investment; (2) interest payments if the rate does not exceed the prevailing rate for similar loans in the financial market from which the loans originate; (3) payments for justi­ fied services; and (4) reasonable profit remittances, together with guaranteed access to the most favorable exchange rate. M i x ed mining enterprises may receive all the benefits and incentives which may be granted by special contract and, in addition, special tax reductions. Gold The marketing of precious metals and their import and export are governed by Decree-Law N o. 18882 of June 15, 1971 and Supreme Decree N o. 065-71-EF of the same date. The export of gold and silver in the form of agglomerated or native metals is the monopoly of M INEROPERU, while their export in the form of pre­ cious metals is the monopoly of the Banco M ine ro del Peru. A ll imports and exports of gold are settled in the certificate market. The authorities do not make foreign exchange available for imports of gold other than by or 369 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution P E RU on behalf of the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users. Domestic sales and purchases of gold may be carried out by industrial and professional users, provided that they hold licenses issued by the Banco M ine ro del Peru, but only MINEROPERU is authorized to make the initial purchase of newly mined gold and other precious metals. Residents traveling abroad may not take out jewelry valued at over S /. 50,000 unless it has been registered with the customs ( S /. 15,000 for trips to bordering countries). Decree-Law N o. 21496 provided for the introduction of a general import and foreign exchange allocation regime. This system was meant to unify the existing import and exchange allocation systems. The M in is t ry of Commerce would be in charge of import guidelines, which would be implemented by the sectoral ministries. Each ministry would establish annual import programs for individual importers; on the basis of these programs, the M in i s t ry of Commerce and the Ministry of Economy and Finance, in conjunction with the Plan­ ning Institute, would draw up the foreign exchange allo­ cation program. The M in is t ry of Commerce would issue import licenses and the M in is t ry of Economy and Finance would authorize the use of the necessary foreign exchange. This system took effect from January 1, 1977. Under the previous system, private sector imports required the prior authorization of the sectoral ministry concerned on the basis of an annual import forecast, but there was no national import program and specific import licenses were not required. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.227864 gram of fine gold per Philippine Peso. A ll exchange transactions take place in a free market. The Bankers' Association establishes daily a "guiding rate"; on December 31, 1976 this rate was about P 7.43 per U .S. dollar. In spot transactions with their customers, commercial banks are required by the Association to observe certain margins. The maxi­ mum and minimum spot buying rates are Vi of 1 per cent and 1 per cent below the guiding rate, respectively. The minimum and maximum spot selling rates are 3A of 1 per cent and WA per cent above the guiding rate, respectively. The Central Bank of the Philippines, which is not governed by the Association's trading rules, makes its own purchases and sales of foreign exchange within the above margins required by the Association. Neither the Central Bank nor the commercial banks quote cur­ rencies other than the U . S. dollar. Interbank trading takes place at the Foreign Exchange Trading Center ( F O R E X), where the Central Bank from time to time acts as a buyer or supplier. Administration of Control Exchange regulations are administered by the Central Bank, which issues circulars and memoranda to the authorized agent banks on the basis of policy decisions reached by the Monetary Board. Certain new foreign direct or portfolio investment in the Philippines requires the prior approval of the Board of Investments ( B O I ). Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency requirements for outgoing payments, but all exchange proceeds from exports and invisibles must be obtained in Austrian schillings, Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, or U . S. dollars. Most pay­ ments and transfers to Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Bank accounts denominated in pesos may be opened in the name of nonresidents, whether individual or cor­ porate, without prior approval of the Central Bank. Nonresident accounts are permitted to be credited only with the proceeds from inward remittances of foreign exchange or convertible foreign currencies and with peso income from, or peso proceeds of, conversion of prop­ erties (real or personal) located in the Philippines belonging to nonresidents. Nonresident accounts may be freely debited for peso withdrawals. However, with­ drawals from nonresident accounts for transfer abroad are subject to individual application with supporting 372 evidence, and to established limits where applicable, such as in the case of emigrants. Both residents and nonresidents may under certain circumstances maintain foreign currency accounts with authorized agent banks in the Philippines (see section on Proceeds from Invisibles, be low). Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are pro­ hibited. Imports of certain commodities are prohibited on grounds of health, morals, and national security and those of certain others, mostly agricultural commodities, for protective purposes. There are no other quantitative restrictions on imports (other than imports of gold); however, foreign exchange sales for imports of specified commodities are subject to prior approval of the Central B a n k .12 Such approval is granted on a case-by-case basis for commodities classified under three consumer goods categories (unclassified, semiunclassified, and non­ essential consumer goods) or for completely knocked- down parts for automobile assembly plants. Payments for imports of certain other commodities (wheat, raw cotton, and leaf tobacco) are permitted only if they are financed through certain official credit arrangements. A ny importation of plant, machinery, equipment, and spare parts under deferred payments arrangements with maturity periods longer than 360 days is subject to prior approval by the Central Bank. If payment terms are cash or within 360 days, prior approval by the Central Bank is necessary for importation by any single importer of nonagricultural machinery and equipment with an aggregate value in excess of US$50,000 within a calen­ dar month, with the exception of (1) certified export- oriented firms, and (2) other importers who have obtained prescribed certification from the BO I. Imports from socialist or communist countries must be effected through the Philippine International Trading Corporation. As a method of payment, commodities may be imported against letters of credit, on a document against acceptance ( D / A) basis, or under open account ( O / A) arrangements. The use of the D /A and O /A pro­ cedures is limited mainly to firms with a history of importing under these arrangements prior to Febru­ ary 21, 1970; to producer firms established after that date and expressly authorized by the Monetary Board to import under these arrangements; to producer firms that are export oriented, are registered with the BO I, or 1 Authorized agent banks have been instructed not to accept appli­ cations for letters of credit or foreign exchange in respect of specified textile products that are subject to a moratorium. 2 Central Bank approval is required for payments for imports of certain synthetic fibers; certain synthetic yarns; all textile machinery and equipment; beef; ships and appurtenances thereto; and steel billets, ingots, hot-rolled coils and sheets, and other steel products listed under Commodity G r oup 681. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution are franchisee! utility concerns; and to such others as may be approved by the Central Bank. The use of these procedures by producer firms normally is restricted to commodities in the Essential Producer Goods category. Unless arrangements for such terms of credit are made, imports in excess of US$100 (US$500 for books and supplementary readers) must be covered by letters of credit opened on or before the day of shipment. Imports financed by importers' own foreign exchange or not involving payments from the Philippines (so-called no-dollar imports) are allowed subject to prescribed conditions. Such permissible no-dollar imports are exempt from the requirement of opening letters of credit. At the request of an authorized agent bank or other financial institution, a firm may be "watch listed" by the Central Bank for arrears on its loan repayment commitments. A firm thus "watch listed" may not open import letters of credit without the approval of the Central Bank, which w i ll allow the opening of letters of credit only after a schedule for the repayment of over­ due obligations has been agreed upon. Furthermore, it is the practice of certain authorized agent banks to require 100 per cent deposit against the opening of letters of credit for such firms, compared with 25 per cent or 50 per cent in normal cases. Imports into border regions by barter traders are governed by Presidential Decree N o. 93. Payments for Invisibles V i r tua l ly all payments to Rhodesia and South A f r ica are prohibited. In principle, a ll other payments are permitted, without prior approval of the Central Bank, provided that amounts of more than US$100 are sub­ stantiated by documentary evidence regarding the pur­ pose and the amount applied for. However, there are certain limits and regulations established by the Central Bank for purchases of foreign exchange for travel abroad by residents, remittances for educational expen­ ses, maintenance and expenses of dependents abroad of residents, remittances of profits, dividends, and interest, royalties, and film and other rentals (see be low). Exchange for travel abroad is made available by autho­ rized agent banks as follows: (1) US$25 a day, up to a maximum of US$750 a trip (for exporters an addi­ tional representation allowance of US$500) for each person for business or professional travel; (2) US$500 a year for each adult resident for nonbusiness travel to A f r i c a, No r th and South Ame r ica, Aus tra l ia, Europe, Japan, the M idd le East, and New Zealand; and (3) US$200 a year for each adult resident for nonbusiness travel to Guam, Hong K o n g, Okinawa, the Republic of Ch ina, or any other neighboring country. Foreign tourist travel by Philippine citizens, however, is not normally permitted. The following limits apply to exchange for educational expenses abroad: for studies in the Un i ted States, PHILIPPINES US$250 a month for living and other out-of-school expenses, plus the cost of tuition, books, laboratory fees, and other school charges; for studies in Aus tra l ia, Europe, Japan, and New Zealand, US$200 a month; and for studies in other areas, US$150 a month. A ny scholarship allowances are deducted from these amounts. Remittances for educational expenses and student main­ tenance abroad are allowed only to students working for a degree at duly accredited colleges or universities. The following limits apply for remittances to depen­ dents of residents: US$250 a month for each dependent living in the Un i ted States; US$200 a month for each dependent living in Australia, Europe, Japan, and New Zealand; and US$100 a month for each dependent l iv ing in other areas. The maintenance allowances for depen­ dents are allowed only for close relatives under certain conditions prescribed by the Central Bank. Remittances of profits and dividends (net of taxes) accruing to nonresidents out of net profits realized beginning January 1, 1973, are permitted in fu l l, pro­ vided that remittances are not financed from domestic credit resources. Profits earned and dividends declared before January 1, 1973 (which had been unremittable for some time) may be remitted over a period of two years. Remittances of royalties or rentals on patents, trademarks, and copyrights are freely permitted (net of taxes) for contracts registered with the Central Bank, provided that (1) the royalties do not exceed 5 per cent of the wholesale price of the commodity which is manu­ factured locally under the royalty contract (2 per cent in the case of marketing service contracts), and (2) contracts do not exceed five-year terms and do not include restrictions on the export of the product. Remit­ tances of the producer's shares of earnings made on motion-picture films and rentals on television films are freely permitted, provided generally that the shares or rentals do not exceed 60 per cent of net proceeds from films. Foreign exchange within the above limits may be purchased from authorized agent banks, without prior approval of the Central Bank, for current payments for invisibles administratively withheld prior to Novem­ ber 26, 1969. Applications for certain invisibles for which no basic allowance has been set are considered on their merits by the Central Bank. No person may take out or export from the Ph i l ip­ pines foreign currency or any other foreign exchange except as authorized by the Central Bank. Residents may take out, as part of their travel allowance, up to US$100 in foreign banknotes. Nonresident travelers may take out any amount of foreign currency that they had previously brought in and declared, minus any amounts converted into pesos. Resident and nonresident travelers require prior authorization from the Central Bank to take out more than P 500 in domestic notes and coins or checks, money orders, and other bills of exchange drawn in pesos. Citizens of the Philippines 373 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES and permanent resident aliens, when traveling abroad, must pay a travel tax of P 400 for first-class ship or airplane tickets or P 300 for any other ticket. Exempt are, among others, foreign diplomatic staff and F i l ip ino Muslims making their first pilgrimage to Mecca. Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports to Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are pro­ hibited. Exports of certain strategic materials and items deemed essential for industrialization and economic development are also prohibited. Otherwise, exports are generally not restricted, but they are regulated to ensure that the foreign exchange proceeds are surrendered to an authorized agent of the Central Bank. Authorized agent banks issue the necessary export permits upon registration of the exporter's report of foreign sales (except export permits for gold, which are issued by the Central B a n k ); reports of foreign sales for copra, coconut o i l, and sugar-based commodities, however, are approved for registration only by the Central Bank. Registration of sales of sugar-based commodities requires .pr ior clearance by the Department of Trade. As a general rule, no commodity may be exported unless it is covered by a draft drawn in one of the prescribed currencies and unless collection of the pro­ ceeds w i ll be undertaken by an authorized agent bank; however, payment by means of telegraphic transfer, check, or mail transfer may be allowed. Payments for exports on a cash, collection, or consignment basis must be arranged through an authorized agent bank, which must specifically contract with the exporter to buy the exchange proceeds. No shipment of exports w i ll be allowed by the customs unless a certificate is issued by a bank stating that payment has been received or arranged by the bank. Proceeds from exports must be received in the prescribed currencies within 60 days from the date of shipment (or within such period as may be established in special cases) and surrendered to the agent bank within 3 business days of receipt. An irre­ vocable letter of credit is required for all exports of scrap metals, copra, and coconut o i l, and for all exports to Guam, Hong Kong, the Republic of Ch ina, Indonesia, and Japan. Exports of perishable commodities to Hong Kong require prepayment. Under an "export deduction" scheme, export-oriented industries are allowed, subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank, to use a part of their export proceeds for the repayment of the loans obtained for their imports of machinery, equipment, raw materials, and other requirements. An export tax is levied on the f.o.b. value of major exports. The rate is 6 per cent for copra and centrifugal sugar; 4 per cent for gold, molasses, coconut o i l, dessi- cated coconut, iron ore and concentrates, chromite ore and concentrates, copra meal or cake, unmanufactured abaca, unmanufactured tobacco, canned pineapples, shrimps and prawns, bunker fuel o i l, bananas, cement 374 clinker, portland cement, and petroleum pitch and resi­ dues; and 2 per cent for copper ore and copper concen­ trates. However, the export taxes on copper ore and copper concentrates and cement are suspended. Certain traditional export commodities are subject to premium export duties; those on copper ore, copper concentrates, and cement are suspended. The Philippine Exchange Company has a monopoly over the export of sugar. Export trade with socialist and communist countries authorized under Executive Order N o. 384 is handled through the Philippine International Trad ing Corporation. Exports from border regions by barter traders are governed by Presidential Decree N o. 93. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles must be sold within three business days by the recipient to an authorized agent bank. Philippine nationals employed abroad are per­ mitted to open U .S. dollar deposit accounts with the Central Bank or authorized agent banks, in which they may retain any U . S. dollars they remit to the Philip­ pines. To be eligible for credit to such accounts at the Central Bank, earnings must be transferred through Philippine diplomatic or consular establishments. Under a foreign currency deposit scheme, inward remittances by residents or nonresidents of foreign currencies for deposit in numbered foreign currency accounts are exempt from surrender requirements, provided that the remittances represent neither current earnings or income of residents nor payments by nonresidents pursuant to contractual obligations. Balances in such accounts are freely transferable abroad. Philippine nationals working abroad are required to repatriate specified minimum shares of their foreign earnings, ranging from 30 per cent to 70 per cent of earnings. Travelers may freely bring in any amount of foreign currency and up to P 500 in domestic notes and coins and checks, money orders, and other bills of exchange drawn in pesos, of which not more than P 50 may consist of Philippine coins. The "1,500-Peso I M F - I B R D" gold coins and the "A ng Bangong L ipunan" are exempt from these requirements. Capital A ll inward and outward capital movements, with the exception of certain banking operations and certain transactions related to financing of international trade (see below), are subject to the prior and specific approval of the Central Bank. V i r tua l ly a ll payments and transfers to Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are pro­ hibited. F or the purpose of the approval of new inward foreign investments (in k ind or in cash) as well as new foreign borrowings, preference is given to projects approved by the BO I, export-oriented industries, and other (nonexport-oriented) industries not utilizing domestic credit resources. The law guarantees full repatriation of cash investments made after March 15, ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 1973 in (a) export-oriented industries that have been certified by the Central Bank (b) enterprises registered with the BO I, and (c) securities certified by the Central Bank and traded on the M an i la and M ak a ti stock exchanges. M i n im um repatriation periods, however, are prescribed; thus, foreign investors must hold securities for at least 90 days before the proceeds become eligible for repatriation. Foreign direct cash investments made after M a r ch 15, 1973 and registered with the Central Bank are freely repatriable, except investments in domestic commercial banks, which if made after M a r ch 31, 1973, are freely repatriable and if made before that date are repatriable according to the schedule in (4) below. There are cer­ tain restrictions on sales of foreign exchange for the repatriation of foreign direct cash investments made before M a r ch 16, 1973 and noncash investments made after M a r ch 15, 1973, depending on the category of industry where the investment is made, as follows: (1) investments in export-oriented industries certified by the Central Bank are repatriable in full but no annual installment may exceed the applicant's share in the net foreign exchange earnings of the firm in the preceding year; (2) investments in enterprises registered with the BO I, producing import substitutes or exports, are repa­ triable in three equal annual installments starting one year after the liquidation of the investment, but no annual installment may exceed the total net foreign exchange earnings in the preceding year; (3) invest­ ments in enterprises registered with the BOI (not included in (2) above and not u t i l iz ing domestic credit resources) are repatriable in four equal annual install­ ments starting one year after the liquidation of the investment; (4) for investments in the remaining indus­ tries, repatriation is allowed according to the following schedule: for amounts of US$0.25 m i l l ion or less, five equal installments after liquidation; US$0 .25 -0 .5 m i l­ l ion, seven equal annual installments after liquidation; and over US$0 .5 m i l l ion, nine equal annual installments after liquidation. Du r ing the period between the date of the investment and repatriation, liquidation proceeds may be reinvested, subject to approval by the Central Bank, in foreign currency deposits under C i rcu lar N o. 343, in government securities, or in shares of stock in export-oriented industries registered with the BOI or certified by the Central Bank. Without prior Central Bank approval, commercial banks may not receive credit from abroad other than credit arising from normal international trade transac­ tions. They may, however, freely accept from non­ residents of foreign nationality deposits in nine scheduled currencies (Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U . S. do l la rs ); such deposits are freely repatriable at the prevailing exchange rate and are exempt from the 35 per cent withholding tax. Nonbank residents may obtain suppliers' credits PHILIPPINES from abroad provided that repayment terms are within the limits prescribed by the Central Bank. The maturity may not be less than 5 years for amounts up to US$250,000 (with certain exceptions), not less than 8 years for amounts between US$250,000 and US$500,000, and not less than 12 years for amounts greater than US$500,000. F or export industries, amounts exceeding US$500,000 are approved if the credit has a maturity of at least 8 years, inclusive of a 3-year grace period on repayment of principal; and for amounts less than US$150,000, 3-year or 4-year maturities may be permitted, depending on the amount of credit and the type of export industry. Interest rates may not be more than 1 Vi per cent above the prime rate of the lending country. Applications are not approved if the proposed project expands capacity in an industry deemed to be overcrowded, or for firms which are in arrears with government financial institutions. Sales of foreign exchange for amortization of loans are permitted in accordance with the terms of loan contracts approved by the Central Bank. The same applies for loan con­ tracts registered with the Central Bank prior to Novem­ ber 26, 1969. F or those not falling under these two categories, prior approval by the Central Bank is required for sales of foreign exchange for repayment of loans. The Management of External Debt and Invest­ ment Accounts Department in the Central Bank main­ tains a comprehensive record of credit taken up abroad by the public and private sectors. Emigrants may repatriate up to US$5,000, subject to verification by the Central Bank. The remaining l iqu id assets may be withdrawn in five years beginning one year from emigration. Except as otherwise specifically authorized, resident persons, firms, or corporations may not enter into any contract or transaction which may involve settlement in foreign exchange, or involving any assets belonging to them expressed in foreign currencies or payable or deliverable abroad. This restriction also applies to con­ tracts or transactions involving assets within the Ph i l ip­ pines belonging to a nonresident person, firm, or corpo­ ration, and to their exportation or importation. Detailed regulations are in force concerning transactions in securities between residents and nonresidents. Under the Investment Incentives A ct of 1967, a ll investors in enterprises registered with the BOI are guar­ anteed the right to repatriate their investments, and to remit earnings thereon and sums needed to meet pay­ ments of principal and interest on foreign loans; they are also guaranteed freedom from expropriation and requisite . i. There are different arrangements for "pioneer investments" and "preferred investments"; the former are granted certain incentives over and above those given to preferred investments. No rma l ly, enterprises owned or controlled by foreign­ ers are permitted to operate only in "pioneer areas of investment," and normally at least 60 per cent of the 375 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES outstanding voting capital stock of registered enterprises in "preferred areas of investment" (mainly investments related to the exploitation of export-oriented natural resources and the manufacturing of import substitutes) must be owned by Philippine nationals. By virtue of the Laurel-Langley Agreement, U .S. citizens, corporations, and associations were given the same status for this purpose as Philippine citizens until July 1974. Under the Foreign Investment Law of 1968, new enterprises in which investment by non-Filipinos exceeds 30 per cent and which are not covered by the Investment Incentives A ct must obtain prior authority from the BOI in order to engage in any economic activity in the Philippines. If purchases of shares of common stock by foreign nationals would reduce Philippine ownership in a firm to less than 70 per cent, permission from the BOI must first be obtained. Gold Producers of gold may be eligible for assistance under the G o ld Industry Assistance A ct (Republic A ct N o. 3089, as amended by Republic A ct N o. 6364 of August 5, 1971), irrespective of whether this gold is a by-product or the principal or only product of their operations. However, gold producers who wish to take advantage oi the floating exchange rate (the "guiding rate") in lieu of the subsidy must export their gold production. Exports of gold (as principal product) are subject to an export tax of 4 per cent. Primary gold producers may sell their production, in the form of refined standard bars, to authorized gold dealers of the Central Bank or retain it abroad for their own account for sale either to other authorized gold dealers or in the free market abroad. Purchases by authorized gold dealers from primary producers are based on current London market prices (as quoted in U .S. dollars, multiplied by the interbank guiding rate on the date of sale); sales by authorized gold dealers or primary producers in the free market abroad must be settled in "acceptable" foreign currencies. Residents other than the monetary authorities, authorized gold dealers, and authorized industrial users are not allowed to purchase gold abroad in any form other than jewelry. A gold coin with a face value of P 1,000 has been issued which is legal tender; another gold coin valued at P 1,500 was issued in connection with the 1976 Annual Meetings of the I MF and the I B RD in M an i l a. These coins may be imported freely by travelers as well as resident physical or juridical persons. W i th this exception, imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Central Bank; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Not for Redistribution PORTUGAL (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0309103 gram of fine gold per Portuguese Escudo. A central rate of Esc 25.50 = US$1 has been established, and Portugal avails itself of wider margins. Since M a r ch 19, 1973, however, no announced margins have been observed and all spot transactions between the escudo and foreign currencies take place at fluctuating rates.1 On December 31, 1976 the authorized banks' buying and selling rates for the U .S. dollar were Esc 31.435 and Esc 31.663, respec­ tively, per US $ 1. Neither the Bank of Portugal nor the commercial banks charge buying and selling commis­ sions but there is a tax of 0.15 per cent on all sales of foreign exchange.2 F or settlements with countries with which Portugal has bilateral payments agreements,8 the U .S. dollar rate applies to transactions in "agreement dollars." On December 31, 1976 the parity for the Macao pataca was Esc 5.015 = P 1.4 Authorized banks may deal in foreign exchange with the Bank of Portugal. They are also normally allowed to deal in foreign exchange with banks abroad at the rates prevailing in the Portuguese foreign exchange market, but they are not expected to solicit such trans­ actions in foreign markets and may be required to justify the amounts of their sales of escudos to non­ residents. They are not allowed to buy and sell foreign exchange among themselves, or to enter into arbitrage operations in foreign markets. In dealing with their customers, the authorized banks buy and sell foreign exchange in convertible currencies for their own account; their purchases and sales of bilateral agreement currencies are made for the account of the Bank of Portugal. Purchases and sales of unquoted currencies can only be made through an authorized bank acting on a commission basis. Banks are required to obtain the prior approval of the Bank of Portugal to accept deposits in foreign currencies from residents or nonresidents and to obtain short-term credits abroad. The banks may use their foreign exchange holdings for all authorized pur­ poses, but the M in is t ry of Finance may set limits on their foreign exchange resources and in certain circum­ stances may require that foreign exchange assets be sold to the Bank of Portugal; since December 31, 1971, the x On February 25, 1977, the escudo was depreciated by 15 per cent in effective terms and pegged against a basket of currencies weighted by the proportion of Portugal's receipts from trade and invisibles accounted for by these currencies. 2 The currencies dealt with in the official exchange market and quoted by the Bank of Portugal are Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Finnish markkaa, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, N o r­ wegian kroner, pounds sterling, South A fr ican rand, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U . S. dollars. :i The only bilateral payments agreement is maintained with Israel. Settlements with Greece and Turkey, however, are also channeled through special accounts denominated in U . S. dollars. 4 On A p r il 9, 1977 the Macao pataca became linked to the Hong K ong dollar on the basis of P 107.50 = HK$100.00. 378 net foreign asset positions of the authorized banks have been subject to ceilings, and since M ay 31, 1972 their gross foreign exchange holdings have been subject to ceilings. Cap i tal held abroad by residents in the form of foreign exchange that is not subject to surrender require­ ments may be transferred to other residents through authorized commercial banks at official rates of exchange. Decree-Law N o. 44699 of 1963 forbids direct transactions in foreign exchange between residents other than authorized banks. There is no forward exchange market, but authorized banks may enter into forward transactions with indi­ vidual customers; the exchange rates may not be higher than the spot buying rate or lower than the spot selling rate of the same date, but the size of the commission is not prescribed. Administration of Control Exchange controls are administered by the Bank of Portugal on behalf of the M in is t ry of Finance, with the assistance of the commercial banks authorized for this purpose. Trade control policy is formulated by the Directorate- General of Foreign Commerce in the M in is t ry of For­ eign Trade. This Directorate-General also administers the trade controls; import and export licenses ("bulle­ tins") are issued by its Foreign Trade D iv i s ion, or by other executive departments duly authorized. A ll imports valued at over Esc 5 m i l l ion and all exports valued at over Esc 2.5 m i l l ion are subject to prior autho­ rization by the Foreign Trade Con t rol Committee; this screening is intended only to prevent overinvoicing and underinvoicing. Practically all foreign trade transactions are subject to registration with the M in is t ry of Foreign T rade .5 Prescription of Currency Transactions with Greece, Israel, and Turkey are settled through clearing accounts maintained in U .S. dollars. Export transactions with countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements may be settled in Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, or U . S. dollars, and import transactions may be settled in any of the above currencies or in escudos. In addition, transactions with Canada, F in land, Japan, South A f r i c a, and Spain may be settled in the currencies of those countries. Payments to nonresidents may be made by crediting 3 In February 1977 it was announced that state agencies undertaking export or import activities would require an authorization to charter Portuguese vessels for that purpose. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution escudos to a nonresident account, the opening of which is subject to prior approval by the Bank of Portugal. Nonresident Accounts The main categories of nonresident accounts are described below. "Foreign Accounts in Escudos" in the name of per­ sons resident or domiciled in countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements or arrangements: These accounts are divided into (1) "T ime Foreign Accounts in Escudos," for which the opening, debiting, and crediting are subject to special advance authorization of the Bank of Portugal, and (2) "Demand Foreign Accounts in Escudos," which may be opened, debited, and credited without prior authorization of the Bank of Portugal for (a) payments for transactions expressed in escudos and duly authorized in that cur­ rency, and for imports and exports of goods, services, and capital between metropolitan Portugal and foreign countries and (b) transfers between such accounts. F or all other debit and credit operations, authorization of the Bank of Portugal is required. The granting of credit in the form of overdrafts on the above accounts requires the authorization of the Bank of Portugal. "Foreign Accounts in Escudos" in the name of per­ sons resident or domiciled in countries with which Portugal has bilateral payments agreements or arrange­ ments: These accounts are opened, debited, and credited according to instructions issued by the Bank of Portugal. Special accounts in escudos have been established to which must be credited those Portuguese banknotes that have been presented by foreign correspondents and are in excess of the amounts that may be credited to Demand Foreign Accounts in Escudos. These accounts may be debited only for payments in escudos to resi­ dents, subject to the prior authorization of the Bank of Portugal. There are also provisions for resident and nonresident accounts in foreign currencies. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain products are prohibited or are allowed only under specific conditions, mainly for rea­ sons of health, public order, and the prevention of commercial fraud. A ny physical or juridical entity may be an importer; importers must have an import entitle­ ment and must pay income taxes regularly. P r ior regis­ tration (in the form of a "bulletin") is required for all imports valued at over Esc 5,000. Almost all imports from all sources are effected on the basis of "bulletins." F or imports free of quantitative restriction, the bulletin serves a statistical purpose and enables the importer to obtain the necessary foreign exchange as specified in the bulletin. For imports subject to restriction, the bulletin is equivalent to an import license (but for imports valued at over Esc 5 m i l l ion prior authorization must be obtained from the Foreign Trade Con t rol Comm i t tee). The validity of the bulletin P O R T U G AL is normally 90 days, but extensions are often granted. Baggage and imports of merchandise whose value does not exceed Esc 25,000 do not require a bulletin, pro­ vided they are not expressly excluded from this exemp­ tion. Payments for imports already cleared through cus­ toms require the approval of the Bank of Portugal when made after the validity of the bulletin. Payments beyond one year after customs clearance always require the approval of the Bank of Portugal. Goods not on the negative list may be imported freely from most coun­ tries that are members of the G A T T .0 The negative list includes certain foodstuffs and other agricultural prod­ ucts, certain natural or manufactured raw materials, some textile fibers, and a small number of finished prod­ ucts, including motor vehicles; the items on the list are subject to quantitative restrictions for protective reasons or under special regimes. A somewhat more extensive negative list applies to Japan. The G A TT liberalization does not apply to Ghana and N ige r ia; imports from these G A TT members of goods liberalized if imported from other G A TT countries are subject to individual authorization, which is granted on the merits of the case. Nonliberalized imports from countries that are G A TT members are admitted either under global or bilateral quotas or under individual authorization. A ll imports from countries that are not members of the G A TT are based on individual authorizations; imports from some Eastern European countries are generally licensed in accordance with bilateral agreements. There are a few bilateral quotas for specified agricul­ tural imports from certain E F TA countries. Imports of nonliberalized industrial products, except for certain pro­ tected steel products and automobiles, are free of quan­ titative restriction when originating in E F TA or E EC countries. Special legislation provides that automobiles must be assembled in Portugal, subject to the use of certain minimum percentages of domestic components. Imports of passenger automobiles of E F TA origin are allowed up to 150 units a year for each producer, while those of n o n - E F TA origin are allowed up to 15 units a producer a year for those makes not assembled in Portu­ gal and, for other makes, up to 2 per cent of the number of passenger automobiles of the same make that were assembled in Portugal in the preceding year. Imports of some makes of E EC origin are allowed up to 150 units a year for each producer. Imports of commercial vehicles for special purposes are free of restrictions. Imports of completely knocked-down vehicles from E F TA and E EC countries are free of restrictions, and allocations for imports from other G A TT countries are available under special open licenses. Many imports are subject to a temporary import surcharge of 30 per cent or 60 per cent of the customs value, irrespective of origin. In addition, among the surcharged items some 7.5 per cent of total imports are fi However, in February 1977 quantitative limitations in value terms were introduced for a number of imports, mainly automobile parts, household appliances, coffee, and bananas. 379 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution P O R T U G AL subject to an advance import deposit requirement of 50 per cent which is blocked for 180 days. Payments for Invisibles Payments to foreign countries for current invisibles must be made through authorized banks and are gener­ ally free of quantitative restrictions, but for most trans­ actions ceilings are specified for the amounts of foreign exchange that authorized banks may grant freely. F or payments to countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements, the authorized banks may grant foreign exchange up to the equivalent of Esc 30,000 a transaction for most types of invisibles, including income on imported capital, and the regional licensing centers (established in Portugal, Made ira, and the Azores) of those banks may grant up to the equiva­ lent of Esc 60,000. F or tourism and other private travel they may grant to persons 1 8 years of age or over the equivalent of Esc 7,000 a person a year; in addition, tourists may take Esc 1,000 out of the country in local currency for each trip. The foreign exchange allowance is the equivalent of Esc 4,000 for persons between 1 2 and 18, and of Esc 2,000 for children under 12. The export of higher amounts of domestic or foreign cur­ rency requires the prior authorization of the Bank of Portugal. F or payments to countries with which Portu­ gal has bilateral payments agreements, the authorized banks may effect freely payments for other current invisibles listed in the respective payments agreements. App l ica t ion must be made to the Bank of Portugal for exchange for payments of items not referred to above and for payments in excess of the above-mentioned limits. Exports and Export Proceeds P r ior registration is required for all exports valued at over Esc 5,000. Exports and re-exports are effected on the basis of "bulletins" (similar to the import bulle­ t ins). Exports valued at over Esc 2.5 m i l l ion require prior authorization by the Foreign Trade Con trol C om­ mittee. Export bulletins are issued freely, with few exceptions; the primary purpose of this procedure is to enforce the prescription of currency and surrender regu­ lations. The export of a few commodities is restricted, mainly to assure adequate supplies to domestic indus­ tries and to avoid depletion of local resources. Baggage and exports and re-exports of merchandise whose value does not exceed Esc 5,000 do not require a bulletin, provided they are not expressly excluded from this exemption. Exporters are required to sell to an authorized bank, within the period stipulated in the export bulletin, the total amount of the export proceeds, in the foreign cur­ rency indicated in the bulletin. The Bank of Portugal may, however, authorize the deduction of commission expenses abroad, and freight, insurance, or other charges pertaining to exports, from the total amount of the export proceeds subject to surrender. 380 Proceeds from Invisibles Portuguese residents may receive freely payments in foreign currency for invisibles from residents of coun­ tries with which Portugal does not have bilateral pay­ ments agreements. A l so, payments from residents of countries with which Portugal does have payments agreements may be received freely for invisibles listed in the payments agreements. Receipts on account of all other invisibles require authorization by the Bank of Portugal, which is granted without restriction once the proposed operation proves to be real and l ic i t. Receipts from invisibles must be surrendered. Nonresident travelers may bring in freely up to Esc 1,000 in domestic banknotes and any amount in banknotes, coins, and checks denominated in foreign currency for their travel expenses; imports of notes and coins by nonresidents for other purposes require autho­ rization by the Bank of Portugal, and the re-export by nonresident travelers of foreign currency in excess of Esc 20,000 requires proof of prior importation of an equal or larger amount. Returning residents may also bring in any amount up to Esc 1,000 in domestic bank­ notes and any amount in foreign banknotes and coins. Au thor ized banks are not permitted to receive or to pay domestic or foreign banknotes or coins for the settle­ ment of external transactions. Capital A ll private capital transactions between Portugal and foreign countries are subject to prior authorization by the Bank of Portugal, and for transactions exceeding Esc 50 m i l l ion and with a maturity of more than one year, the approval of the Minister of Finance also is required. Foreign direct investments in Portugal are authorized on the basis of the Foreign Investment Code. Projects are assessed according to the following criteria: job creation, transformation of natural resources, use of national goods and services, regional development, pro­ duction of goods not produced in Portugal, introduction of advanced technologies, high value added, little use of domestic credit, professional training of Portuguese workers, and reduced industrial pollution. Foreign direct investment is permitted in a ll sectors except those con­ cerned with defense and public services, i.e., water, sanitation, electricity, gas, telephone, ma i l, telecom­ munications, internal transport, monetary and financial institutions, insurance, advertising, and sectors national­ ized on A p r il 6, 1976. In the last case, the Counc il of Ministers may permit a minor participation of foreign capital when advisable in the interests of the national economy.7 The transfer abroad of the proceeds from the liquida­ tion of foreign investments is authorized after five years, but guaranteed only up to a maximum of 20 per cent 7 An Exchange Risk Guarantee Fund was established in Febru­ ary 1977 to reduce the risks associated with external borrowing. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution of the total amount in each year. Larger amounts are subject to special authorization, as in the case of interest and dividends. Foreign loans and their repayments are authorized as necessary. Emigrants leaving Portugal are subject to the same limits as resident travelers, unless they can prove the importation of foreign exchange exceeding the limits, or the receipt of such foreign exchange, within 30 days before departure. Transfers by foreigners resident in Portugal who emigrate to any other O E CD country are authorized automatically up to Esc 100,000 annually for a family and larger amounts may be granted on the merits of each case. Transfers by foreign nationals who have been residents in Portugal are authorized on the merits of each case when they return to their country of origin. Transfers to O E CD countries in respect of life insurance policies due from Portuguese insurers are authorized in favor of the beneficiary when their value does not exceed Esc 500,000. Capital movements and transfers of assets not mentioned above are authorized on the merits of each case. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold in any form in Portugal. The purchase or sale of coined or uncoined gold, when carried out between Portugal and foreign countries, is subject to special advance authorization from the Bank of Portugal whenever a resident of Portu­ gal takes part in the transaction or has an interest in it. The import, export, or re-export of coined or uncoined gold is also subject to special advance authorization from the Bank of Portugal. Import authorizations for industrial gold are granted only to commercial banks and the Association of Industrial Users of G o l d. Domes­ tic sales of gold and of gold coins that are not legal tender are subject to a transaction tax of 40 per cent.8 There is a free market for gold in Macao, in which both residents of Macao and nonresidents who are not resident in Portugal may freely trade among themselves in bars, leaves, and coins; settlement must take place in patacas or U . S. dollars. In Macao, the Government sets overall limits for imports of gold in any form other than jewelry; authority to carry out such imports is delegated to a concessionary enterprise for a two-year period. Imports and exports of gold, unless made by or on behalf of the Macao monetary authorities, require licenses issued by the Commissioner for Economy. Changes during 1976 March 1. On M a r ch 19, 1975 the currency was pegged to the SDR at QR 4.76190 = SDR 1; subsequently, Qatar applied margins wider than 214 per cent. The Qatar Monetary Agency buys and sells U .S. dollars with a spread of 3 per m i ll around the middle rate of QR 3.94945 set on M a r ch 13, 1976; the Agency also sets buying and selling rates for the pound sterling. The commercial banks' exchange rates for other currencies are based on the Monetary Agency's rates for the U . S. dollar and market rates for the currencies concerned against the U .S. dollar; on December 31, 1976, their buying and selling rates for the U .S. dollar were QR 3.9392 and QR 3.9597, respectively, per U S $ 1 .1 Qatar formally accepted the obligations of A r t i­ cle V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, with effect from June 4, 1973. Administration of Control The Qatar Monetary Agency is the exchange control authority, but there is at present no exchange control legislation in Qatar. Import licenses are issued by the M in is try of Economy and Commerce. Prescription of Currency A ll settlements with Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica are prohibited. No other prescription of currency requirements are in force. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by residents and those held by nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments A ll imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica are prohibited, and alcoholic beverages, firearms, ammu­ nition, and certain drugs are subject to licensing for rea­ sons of health, morals, or security. Otherwise, imports are not restricted. There are no restrictions on payments for permitted imports. 1 There are fixed rates of QR 1 — Dh 1 for U . A . E. dirhams and QR 10 = BD 1 for Bahrain dinars brought in by travelers from the United A r ab Emirates and Bahrain, up to limits of Dh 5,000 and BD 500, respectively. Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica are prohibited. Otherwise, all commodities may be exported freely. There are no requirements attached to receipts from exports or re-exports; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surrendered, and they may be disposed of freely regardless of the currency involved. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments must not be made to or received from Israel, Rhodesia, or South A f r i c a. Otherwise there are no limitations on payments for and proceeds from invisibles. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents, although payments must not be made to or received from Israel, Rhodesia, or South A f r i c a. Foreign participa­ tion in certain industrial enterprises is prohibited unless Qatar nationals control at least 51 per cent of the shares. Gold The monetary authorities and all other residents and nonresidents, including private persons, may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. They may also, without a license and without payment of customs duty or tax, import and export gold in any form. Transactions involving Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i c a, however, are prohibited. Changes during 1976 January 15. Not for Redistribution ROMANIA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Romanian Leu has been estab­ lished with the F u n d. The leu is officially defined as equivalent to 0.148112 gram of fine gold, yielding offi­ cial rates as at December 31, 1976 of lei 4.97 per U . S. dollar and lei 6.67 per ruble. There is no exchange market. The National Bank of the Socialist Republic of Romania quotes official rates also for certain other currencies. Quotations for the 16 currencies defined as "freely convertible" 1 (except those for the U . S. dollar itself) and for the F inn ish markka, the Greek drachma, the Spanish peseta, and the Yugoslav dinar are based on their rates against the U . S. dollar in the countries con­ cerned; for the U . S. dollar and for inconvertible curren­ cies, exchange rates are based either on the gold content against the leu or on the ratio between the currency concerned and the leu through the official rate against a third currency. For exchange rate purposes, payments for insurance and transportation connected with trade are considered as trade transactions. W i th the exception of capital transactions, nontrade transactions with countries other than the socialist countries listed in footnote 2 are car­ ried out at the official rate plus a premium of 141.45 per cent, resulting in a rate of lei 12.00 per U S $ 1; the sale of exchange at this rate to Romanian citizens for private use is subject to an additional service charge. Some trade transactions are subject to a price equali­ zation system. Excluded from this system are imports of machinery and equipment, complex equipment, assem­ blies and subassemblies, and spare parts, the domestic delivery prices of which are determined by converting the foreign price into lei at a customs valuation coeffi­ cient, to which customs duties are added. F or consumer goods a similar calculation is made; their domestic prices are fixed, and any difference between these prices and those resulting from the calculation is reflected in the profits of the importing enterprise. For all other imports (basic raw materials, materials and assemblies, subassem­ blies, spare parts for production) and for all exports, the price equalization system applies. The equalization system is designed to eliminate the effect on the earn­ ings of exporters and importers of the differences between domestic prices and foreign prices converted into lei at a uniform settlement coefficient of lei 20 per US$1. For nontrade transactions with some socialist coun­ tries 2 exchange rates are established by special agree- 1 Australian dollars.
