S. dollar is used for the payment and repayment of foreign loans taken up or granted by the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade, other official bodies, and Romanian enterprises. Administration of Control Foreign trade is a state monopoly. Import and export transactions are effected by authorized industrial cen­ trals, producing enterprises, and foreign trade enter­ prises. Foreign trade units have autonomy in selecting their foreign partners and operate on a trade criteria basis, taking into account prices, quality, delivery and payment conditions, etc. Import and export transactions are subject to authorizations granted by the M in is t ry of Foreign Trade and International Economic Cooperation. In the issuing of authorizations, both the provisions of existing trade agreements and criteria of economic effi­ ciency are taken into account. Foreign currency pro­ ceeds from exports are sold to the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade; foreign currency required for import payments is purchased from that Bank. Exchange con­ trol is administered by the Na t ional Bank and the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from countries with which Romania has bilateral payments agreements are made in curren­ cies and in accordance with the procedures set forth in those agreements.3 If no agreement exists, settlement is usually made in a convertible currency. Permitted foreign payments may not be made in le i, and the import and export in any form of Romanian notes and coins are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Foreign juridical and physical persons may maintain accounts with the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade or with the Na t ional Bank. Neither justification nor autho­ rization is required to open such accounts, except for foreign economic organizations and agencies, which have to show evidence of permission to operate in Romania. These accounts are of three kinds: A-Accoun ts are maintained in convertible currency or in lei obtained for convertible currencies, gold, or other precious metals (except s i lve r ); B-Accounts are maintained in noncon- 3 The countries with which bilateral payment's arrangements were in force as of December 31, 1976 were listed as A lban ia, Bangladesh, Brazil, People's Republic of Ch ina, Co lomb ia, Cyprus, Ecuador, F in land, Ghana, Greece, India, Iran, D . P . R. of K o r e a, Lebanon, M a l i, and Socialist Republic of Viet N am. Settlements with Bulgaria, Czecho­ slovakia, Cuba, D . R. of Germany, Hungary, Mongo l ia, Poland, and the U . S . S .R. took place through the multilateral payments system within the International Bank for Econom ic Cooperation. Further­ more, certain settlements with Singapore also took place through special accounts. 383 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution R O M A N IA vertible currencies quoted by the Na t ional Bank, in clearing currency, or in lei received from the conversion of such currencies. Transactions in any individual B-Account may be effected in only one such currency. C-Accounts are maintained in lei received from legal sources. A-Accoun ts may be debited for payments abroad in any currency, for payments within the country, and for transfers to any other A, B, or C-Accoun t. B-Accounts may be debited for all payments abroad in the curren­ cies from which the funds were derived and for pay­ ments w i th in Romania. C-Accounts may be debited only for domestic transactions. The transactions per­ mitted for the different accounts do not require any further authorization. Nonresidents may also keep accounts with the Savings and Consignment Bank. In addition, any bank may accept from nonresident cus­ tomers time deposits in convertible foreign currencies, on which interest is paid at rates prevailing in interna­ tional markets. Romanian citizens, including Romanians working abroad who transfer their savings to Romania, may open foreign currency accounts with the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade or the Na t ional Bank. The deposits may be used for payments at home or abroad, or for exchange into lei at the official rate plus pre­ mium (lei 12 per U . S. do l la r ). Receipts from abroad for special purposes for the benefit of Romanian c i t i­ zens (such as the building of a house, the purchase of an automobile, the purchase of other goods or services whose prices are expressed in foreign currency, travel abroad, and education) are paid out entirely in foreign currency. In the case of certain other foreign exchange receipts from abroad, such as donations, assistance, or family maintenance, a proportion may be deposited in a foreign currency account and the rest must be con­ verted at the official rate plus premium. Imports and Exports The general policy targets for foreign trade are set at the central level, in accordance with the priority interests for the development of the national economy. Import and export plans are drawn up by the basic economic units, producing enterprises, and industrial centrals on the basis of current and long-term needs. After their elaboration, the plans are correlated and integrated into the single national plan, which is a synthesis of the effective production and export possi­ bilities and of the needs for imported goods. The foreign trade plan specifies only a limited num­ ber of goods considered of particular importance for the national economy, especially raw materials. The major part of the plan is set forth as a lump sum, without being divided by importer or exporter countries but only dis­ tinguishing, according to the manner of settlement of exchange payments and receipts, between the clearing area and the convertible currency area. 384 Import and export transactions are carried out on the basis of authorizations issued by the M in is t ry of Foreign Trade and International Economic Cooperation, for each commodity or group of commodities. The authori­ zations are not restrictive or discriminatory and are issued, at the request of foreign trade units, for all types of goods, regardless of origin. The M in is t ry may take measures with a view to equilibrating the balance of payments, for the protection of the public health, for reasons of national defense and the security of the State, etc., in accordance with the provisions of the G A T T. As a rule, annual import authorizations expressed in value terms are issued to individual importing enter­ prises as a lump sum, or for a single k ind of product. The authorization stipulates whether import payments are to be made in convertible currency or under bilat­ eral payments agreements, and in the latter case the country also is specified. Export proceeds must be sold to the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade. Invisibles A ll transactions in invisibles not connected with for­ eign trade transactions require general or individual authorization given by either the M in i s t ry of Finance or the competent ministry. For most categories of pay­ ments in respect of invisibles, foreign exchange is made available automatically once the transaction has been authorized. F or travel outside socialist countries an exchange allocation is provided up to the equivalent of US$70 a trip for each adult person for one trip a year. In addition, tourist agencies may organize group or individual trips payable in lei in amounts the equivalent of which may exceed the maximum allocations of for­ eign exchange. Receipts from transactions in invisibles must be sold to the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade, and the foreign currency required for payments in respect of such transactions is bought from the same bank. Receipts in foreign currencies from travelers are converted at lei 12.00 per U S $ 1. Travelers with perma­ nent residence in nonsocialist countries or Yugoslavia must convert at least US$10 a person a day (or the equivalent in other "acceptable" cu r r en c i e s )4 during their stay in Roman ia. Foreign diplomats and tourists, as well as Romanian citizens legally holding foreign curren­ cies, may purchase certain domestically produced or imported consumer goods in COMTURIST shops, against payment in convertible currencies. The import and export of Romanian notes and coins by travelers are prohibited. Capital A ll inward and outward transfers of foreign exchange must be authorized by the M in is t ry of Finance. Out­ ward transfers of funds belonging to resident physical persons are not normally permitted. For certain estab­ lished categories, such as inheritances, reciprocal agree­ ments have been concluded with a number of countries providing for automatic authorization of transfers of specified amounts to and from Romania. The Foreign Trade Law (Law N o. 1 of M a r ch 1971) provides for the possibility of the establishment of joint ventures in Romania and abroad by Romanian economic organizations; under this law and enabling Decrees Nos. 424 and 425 of 1972, foreigners are also allowed to invest capital in joint ventures in Romania, up to 49 per cent of the total capital of the company con­ cerned. The law and the decrees guarantee the repatria­ tion in foreign currency of the capital and the transfer in foreign currency of profits after taxes. By agreement the accounts of joint ventures may be kept in an agreed currency. Foreign physical and juridical persons may keep in bank accounts in Romania their legally owned foreign currency or lei funds; balances in foreign exchange accounts are transferable abroad. Romanian nationals working abroad may hold their foreign currency savings in accounts opened with Romanian banks and use these funds for payments in Romania or abroad (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). R O M A N IA Gold Only the Na t ional Bank has authority to purchase or sell gold in any manner, at home or abroad. The Bank, in turn, authorizes certain juridical persons to hold gold, to use it, and to engage in gold transactions, in accor­ dance with the law. The ownership by physical persons, for domestic and personal use, of jewelry and of artistic and cultural objects of gold is not restricted. Changes during 1976 January 1. Not for Redistribution RWANDA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.00888671 gram of fine gold per Rwanda Franc. On January 7, 1974 Rwanda established a central rate of RF 112 = SDR 1, and since that date the Na t ional Bank of Rwanda (the central bank) has maintained a middle rate for the U . S. dollar of RF 92.84 = US$1. The Bank also quotes certain other currencies.1 The National Bank levies a fee (droit de dossier) for the validation of import and export licenses as well as transfer authorizations; the fee is RF 350 for import and export licenses or 2 per cent of the amount approved for transfers other than import payments. Payments by the Government and public sector agencies are exempt. Administration of Control Con trol over foreign exchange transactions and for­ eign trade is vested in the National Bank; authority to carry out some of these transactions is delegated to authorized banks. Exchange policy and foreign trade policy are, in principle, to be determined by the General Foreign Exchange and Licensing Committee, which comprises the Minister of Finance and Economy, the Governor of the Na t ional Bank, and five other members, but is inoperative. Prescription of Currency Settlements with Burund i, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zaire are made through special accounts. Otherwise, the following applies. Payments for imports must be made in the currency approved by the Na t ional Bank, which in principle is the currency of the country of origin. Payments from any country may be received in Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U . S. dollars. A ll foreign payments, except in border trade, must be made by bank transfer; for import payments, however, payment by check made out in the name of the creditor is also permitted. Exchange transactions with Rhodesia and South A f r ica are prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia and South A f r ica are pro­ hibited. Imports of a few types of goods, such as nar­ cotics, are prohibited from all sources for reasons of public policy. A ll imports except baggage and household effects of travelers and merchandise valued up to RF 100,000 (when settled in Rwanda francs) require licenses if payment is to take place in foreign exchange; 1 Belgian francs, Burundi francs, Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Kenya shillings, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, Tanzania shillings, Uganda shillings, and zaires. 386 these are issued freely and serve statistical and price comparison purposes only. Before orders are placed, applications for import licenses for all other goods must be submitted to the Na t ional Bank through an autho­ rized bank on a form entitled Import License and Pay­ ments Authorization (Model I ). The approval of an import license application constitutes an authorization also to obtain foreign exchange. The Na t ional Bank grants global import licenses for certain essential commodities and for specified amounts to individual firms in order to ensure their continuous operation. Licenses are examined at the Na t ional Bank only to avoid capital exports through overinvoicing and to ensure that importers (unless exceptionally authorized to do so) do not have recourse to domestic bank credit. Except as stated above, there are no restrictions as to currency of payments or permitted origin or place of shipment, but control is exercised to ensure that pay­ ments are made to the supplier or the shipper. Import licenses must be presented to the customs officials when the goods are cleared through customs. The number and date of expiration must be entered on the customs clear­ ance form, a copy of which is then sent to the National Bank by the customs authorities. In practice, certain goods are imported mainly or exclusively from the Peo­ ple's Republic of Ch ina. Importers are authorized to pay by means of docu­ mentary credits upon shipment. A ll imports are subject to a license validation fee (droit de dossier), which is RF 350 a license. Payments for Invisibles The prior approval of the Na t ional Bank is required for all payments for invisibles. Foreign exchange is sold by the Na t ional Bank, through the authorized banks, for transport and other expenses (except insurance) con­ nected with imports and exports; for transfers of the salaries or wages—after income tax and social security contributions and after deduction of 40 per cent of net income or RF 35,000 a month, whichever is higher— of foreign nationals employed in Rwanda under con­ tract; for transfers of the net earned income of foreign nationals who are self-employed or are engaged in a profession or established as independent traders; and for salaries of foreigners traveling abroad on leave. Pay­ ments in respect of transport charges on imports cannot be made until imported goods have been cleared through customs (unless a documentary credit has been opened). Insurance on imports and exports must be taken out locally, with the Societe Nationale d'Assurance (SONARWA). Net profits and dividends due to non­ residents may in principle be remitted abroad in full, subject to the right of the Na t ional Bank to prescribe their transfer in installments. Nonresidents and resident ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution expatriates may not transfer their net income from rents, except after the sale of the real estate. The purchase of tickets for travel abroad requires the prior approval of the Na t ional Bank. Purchases of foreign exchange for travel purposes are authorized on an ad hoc basis. Remittances for payments for certain other invisibles may also be authorized on an ad hoc basis. Travelers may take out domestic banknotes up to RF 5,000. Residents require authorization by the National Bank to take out foreign banknotes. Nonres i­ dent travelers may take out any amount in foreign bank­ notes declared upon entry minus the amount of their expenditures in Rwanda. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are prohibited. A ll exports, except trade samples, baggage and house­ hold effects of travelers, and merchandise valued at less than RF 20,000, are subject to a prior declaration entitled Declaration of Co l lec t ion of Foreign Exchange (Model E ). Declarations for all exports must be pre­ sented to the Na t ional Bank through an authorized bank for certification. A declaration is va l id for a period of three months, but extensions may be granted by the National Bank, which also reserves the right to deter­ mine the conditions for certification. F or exports to Burundi, Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zaire, pay­ ment must be collected not later than 30 days after the goods have left the country; for exports to all other countries, this period is 120 days, except for minerals shipped abroad for refining, for which the period is 180 days. A ll exchange proceeds from exports must be sur­ rendered to an authorized bank within 8 days from their collection. R W A N DA Proceeds from Invisibles A ll receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to the authorized banks w i th in 8 days from their collection. The collection of claims resulting from services per­ formed for nonresidents must take place within 30 days of the date on which the claim falls due. Travelers may bring in up to RF 5,000 in domestic banknotes and any amount in foreign banknotes. Capital A ll outward transfers of capital require the prior approval of the Na t ional Bank. Such approval is rarely given unless the transfer relates to a foreign investment in Rwanda that is covered by the Investment Law of May 4, 1964 or to the personal effects of a foreign national returning to his own country. Retransfer guar­ antees, as well as an exchange rate guarantee, may be given by the Na t ional Bank in respect of short-term capital inflows remaining in Rwanda for at least two months; such inflows result mainly from financial transactions between Rwandese banks and their foreign correspondents. Commercial banks are not permitted to import or export domestic banknotes. Gold Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Rwanda for numismatic purposes only. W i th this excep­ tion, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry. Imports and exports of gold require licenses and are normally made only by the monetary authorities. Changes during 1976 August 1. Not for Redistribution SAUDI ARABIA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System On August 11, 1973, Saudi A rab ia established a par value of 0.207510 gram of fine gold per Saudi A rab ian R i y a l, corresponding at the time to SRls 4.28255 = SDR 1 or SRls 3.55001 = US$1. Saudi A r ab ia avails itself of wider margins. Since M a r ch 15, 1975 Saudi A rab ia has maintained exchange rates for the r iyal on the basis of the parity of SRls 4.28255 = S DR 1; since September 9, 1975 rates have been permitted w i th in margins somewhat wider than 2\A per cent but not exceeding llA per cent. On December 31, 1976, the Saudi A rab ian Monetary Agency's middle rate for the U . S. dollar was SRls 3.53; it sold U . S. dollars to banks at SRls 3.535 per US$1 and bought from banks and the principal producer of petroleum at SRls 3.525 per U S $ 1; these rates served as the basis for exchange quotations in the market, the banks being permitted to charge up to lA of 1 per cent above and below the Monetary Agency's buying and selling rates. The Monetary Agency also sells sterling to banks. A ll settlements with Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited; there are no other restric­ tions on foreign payments. Saudi A r ab ia formally accepted the obligations of A r t ic le V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agree­ ment, as from M a r ch 22, 1961. Prescription of Currency The use of the currencies of Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca is prohibited. No other prescription of currency requirements are in force. Imports and Import Payments Import licenses are not required, and exchange for payments abroad may be obtained freely. A ll imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Imports of a few commodities are prohibited from all sources for reasons of health or security. Certain con­ sumer goods are imported by a state trading company. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are not required, and no control is exercised over export proceeds. A ll exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca and the re-export of certain imported items benefiting from government subsidy are prohibited. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted, except that payments must not be made to, or received from, Israel, Rhodesia, or South A f r i c a. Travelers may freely import and export Saudi A rab ian banknotes and coins. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents, but payments must not be made to, or received from, Israel, Rhodesia, or South A f r i c a. The Foreign Capital Investment Law (Royal Decree N o. 35 of February 24, 1964) provides for specified benefits to be extended to approved foreign investments in Saudi A r ab i a. Gold The monetary authorities and all other residents, including private persons, may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. They may also, without a license and without payment of any customs duty or tax, import and export gold in any form. Transactions involving Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Changes during 1976 July 12. A Royal Decree promulgated the establish­ ment of the Saudi Supply Company. This state trading company would import, store, transport, and distribute foodstuffs and other goods to complement the activities of the private sector, with the objective of making adequate supplies regularly available at the lowest possible prices. December 17. Vessels more than 15 years o ld were prohibited from discharging cargo at Saudi Arabian ports unless a condition survey established their cargo- worthiness. 388 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SENEGAL (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange System No par value or central rate for the currency of Senegal has been established with the Fund. The unit of its currency is the C FA F ranc ,1 which is officially maintained at the rate of C F AF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transactions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de rAfrique de l'Ouest ( B C E A O) and commercial banks take place at the rate of C F AF 1 = F 0.02; the B C E AO levies a commission of 1io of 1 per m i ll for transfers from countries outside the West A f r ican Monetary Union and a commission of 2.50 per m i ll for transfers to countries outside the U n i o n. Exchange rates for for­ eign currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the Paris exchange market rate for the cur­ rency concerned, and include a commission. Banks levy a commission on transfers to all countries outside the West Afr ican Monetary Un ion, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. With the exception of those relating to gold, Senegal's exchange control measures do not apply to (1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories, except the French Territory of the Afars and the Tssas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Benin, Cameroon, the Central A f r ican Emp ire, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Ivory Coast, M a l i, Niger, Togo, and Upper V o l t a ). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. A ll other countries, except Senegal itself, are considered for­ eign countries, and in principle financial relations only with foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Directorate of Money and Credit in the M in is t ry of Finance and Economic Affairs, which also supervises borrowing and lending abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Senegal, inward direct invest­ ment, and all outward investments. Part of the approval authority in respect of exchange control has been dele­ gated to authorized banks. The B C E AO is authorized to collect, either directly or through the intermediary of banks, other financial institutions, the Postal Adm in is tra­ tion, and notaries public, any information necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics. A ll exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks or the Postal Adm in is tra t ion. Import and export licenses are issued by the M in is t ry of Finance and Economic Affairs (Directorate of Fo r­ eign T rade ), including those for gold. Import certificates ^ he C FA franc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de l'Afrique de l'Ouest ( B C E A O) and is the common currency in Benin, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Vo l ta. for liberalized commodities are made out by the importer himself. Prescription of Currency Senegal is an Operations Account country of the French Franc A rea, since the B C E AO maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settle­ ments with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc A rea are made in C FA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Cer­ tain settlements with Guinea are made through bilateral accounts established under a payments agreement. Set­ tlements with The Gamb ia, Ghana, L ibe r ia, N ige r ia, and Sierra Leone normally are made through the West Afr ican Clearing House. Settlements with all other coun­ tries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. A ll settlements with Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. The crediting to non­ resident accounts of C FA banknotes, French banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the French Trea­ sury is not permitted, except for B C E AO banknotes mailed direct to the B C E AO agency in Dakar by autho­ rized banks' foreign correspondents; such banknotes may be credited to Foreign Accounts opened by the latter with authorized banks in Senegal. Imports and Import Payments Imports of Rhodesian and South A f r ican origin and /or provenance are prohibited from any source, and the import of certain other goods is prohibited from all countries except member states of the West A f r ican Economic Community. The import from any source of a number of other commodities is subject to individual licensing. Imports from countries in the French F ranc Area are generally free of license and quantitative restriction; some goods, although free from import license, require prior authorization by the M in is t ry of Finance and Economic Affairs. Imports of virtually all goods from E EC countries (the six original member states) and imports of some goods from all former O E EC countries, the United States, and Canada are free of quantitative restriction; such liberalized imports require only an import certificate made out by the importer himself. There is an annual program with global quotas for imports from a ll n o n -EEC countries outside the French Franc A r e a. The import program 389 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution S E N E G AL is put into effect through individual licenses, wh ich are required for most commodities. Licenses are issued only to authorized traders and to industrial and agricultural producers. A ll import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds C F AF 25,000 (c.i.f. or delivered at the border). The import licenses or import certificates entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before shipment if a documentary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodities have already been imported ( if no documentary credit has been opened, on presentation of the b i ll of lad ing). Furthermore, pay­ ments for imports cannot be made prior to customs clearance. Payments for Invisibles A ll payments to Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are pro­ hibited. Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc A rea are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to approval. Pay­ ments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Furthermore, authorized banks have been empowered to effect freely any payment abroad up to C F AF 15,000 on behalf of residents. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also per­ mitted. F or tourist travel, residents traveling to countries other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc A rea may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to C F AF 150,000 a year for each person ( C F AF 75,000 for children under ten); any foreign exchange remaining after return to Senegal must be surrendered. Applications for additional amounts of foreign exchange may also be approved. For business travel, there is a special allocation of the equivalent of C F AF 7,500 a day, subject to a maximum of C F AF 150,000 a person a trip, but not more than the equivalent of C F AF 15,000 may be taken out in foreign notes. The transfer of the full net salary of a foreigner working in Senegal is permitted upon presentation of the appropriate pay voucher, provided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period; how­ ever, for Mauritanian nationals working in Senegal the transferable portion is limited to 50 per cent or 80 per cent, depending on family status and residence, except for leave salaries, which are transferable in fu l l. Resident and nonresident travelers going to foreign countries may take out, in addition to any foreign exchange allocation, up to C F AF 15,000 in B C E AO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries. Resident travelers to other countries of the French Franc A rea may take 390 out any amount in B C E AO banknotes, but if going to a country that is not a member of the West African Monetary U n i o n, they must declare to the customs the amount taken out if it exceeds C F AF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign bank­ notes and coins up to the amount declared by them on entry (minus the amount converted in Senegal plus any amount up to C F AF 50,000 reconverted by purchase of foreign banknotes), or if no declaration has been made, up to the equivalent of C F AF 50,000; other banknotes as stated above; and any means of payment, such as travelers checks, established abroad in their name. Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports to Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are pro­ hibited. W i th a few exceptions (e.g., gold, diamonds, tunny), exports to countries in the French Franc Area are free of license. Most exports to other countries require licenses, mainly in order to assure adequate supplies for the domestic needs of Senegal and to pre­ vent certain re-exports. Proceeds from exports to for­ eign countries must normally be collected within 120 days of the arrival of the goods at their destination. They must be surrendered by sale on the exchange market not later than one month after collection when received in a non-Franc A rea currency. A ll export transactions relating to foreign countries must be domi­ ciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds C F AF 50,000. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be retained. A ll amounts due from residents of other coun­ tries in respect of services, and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets, must be collected, and surrendered, if received in foreign currency, within one month of the due date or the date of receipt. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue maintaining an Operations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc A r e a; residents bringing in foreign banknotes must declare them to the customs upon entry and sell them to an authorized bank within eight days. Capital A ll settlements between Senegal and Rhodesia and South A f r ica are prohibited. Cap i tal movements between Senegal and France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc A rea are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, and over the issuing, adver­ tising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Sene­ gal; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to payments or receipts. W i th the exception of those over foreign securities, these control measures do not apply to relations w i th France (as defined above), Monaco, the other member countries of the West A f r i­ can Monetary U n i o n, and those other countries whose bank of issue is linked w i th the F rench Treasury by an Operations Accoun t. Special controls are maintained also over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and institutions, and over all publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate building operations abroad; these special controls do apply also to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. A ll investment abroad by residents of Senegal requires prior authorization by the M in is ter of Finance and Eco­ nomic A f fa i rs .2 Foreign direct investments in Senegal;{ must be declared to the M in is ter of Finance and Eco­ nomic Affairs before such investments are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the post­ ponement of the projects submitted to h im. Both the making and the liquidating of direct and other invest­ ments, whether these are Senegalese investments abroad or foreign investments in Senegal, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs and the B C E AO within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Senegal requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Senega­ lese Government and (2) shares that are similar to or may be substituted for securities whose issue, offering, or sale in Senegal has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the M in is ter of Finance and Eco­ nomic Affairs. The following are, however, exempt from 2 Including investments made through the intermediary of foreign companies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Senegal and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of com­ panies in Senegal. 3 Including those made by companies in Senegal that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or sub­ sidiaries in Senegal of foreign companies. S E N E G AL this authorization: (1) loans constituting a direct invest­ ment, which are subject to prior declaration, as ind i­ cated above; (2) loans contracted by authorized banks; (3) loans other than those mentioned above, subject to certain conditions, when the total amount outstanding of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed C F AF 40 m i l l ion for any one borrower. The repayment of loans not constituting a direct investment requires the special authorization of the M in is ter if the loan itself was subject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Lending abroad requires prior authorization by the M in is try of Finance and Economic Affairs. The Investment Code of June 12, 1972 (Law N o. 72-43) provides various facilities and benefits for approved foreign investments in Senegal. Law N o. 74-6 of A p r il 22, 1974 provides special facilities for export industries established in the Industrial Free Trade Zone. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Senegal. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authori­ zation by the Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by the Treasury or the B C E A O; (2) imports and exports of manufactured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated arti­ c les ); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold articles up to a combined weight of 200 grams. By virtue of Ordinance N o. 60-21 of October 1, 1960, brokers in precious metals require an authorization from the Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs to con­ duct their business. Both licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Purchases abroad of nonmonetary gold are subject to a tax of 25 per cent. Commercial imports of gold jewelry require prior authorization (Decree N o. 65-794 of Novem­ ber 19, 1965). Furthermore, imports of ornaments require the prior advice of the Senegal Office for Hand i­ crafts (Office Senegalais de l'Artisanat) and the D irec­ torate of Mines and Geology (Notice to Importers of M ay 17, 1971). Changes during 1976 February 14. Decree N o. 76-195 made the importa­ tion of secondhand automobiles subject to prior autho­ rization. March 15. France suspended its participation in the European common margins arrangement; the parity between the C FA franc and the French franc remained unchanged. July 1. Not for Redistribution S E Y CH E L L E S1 (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange and Trade System The currency of Seychelles is the Seychelles Rupee, the value of which is officially maintained at Sey Re 1 = <£ stg. 0.075. Exchange rates for currencies other than the pound sterling are determined by the commercial banks on the basis of London market rates. There is no exchange control. Settlements with Rho­ desia are prohibited. Otherwise, inward and outward payments, whether on current or capital account, are unrestricted, and export proceeds need not be repatriated or surrendered. Residents may freely hold, purchase, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. A gold coin with a face value of Sey Rs 1,000 is legal tender. Trade with Rhodesia is prohibited. W i th this excep­ tion, most goods may be imported freely from any 1 Seychelles is not a member of the International Monetary Fund. source under open general license. Other imports require a specific license. Exports do not normally require licenses. Changes during 1976 May 3. Not for Redistribution SIERRA L EO NE (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.06641 grams of fine gold per Leone. W i th effect from June 27, 1972, however, the leone was allowed to float w i th sterling. The Bank of Sierra Leone deals in sterling only and stands ready in transactions with commercial banks to buy and sell leones in exchange for sterling at the rate of Le 1 = £. stg. 0.50, subject to a maximum commission of 1 per cent on either side. The authorized banks in Sierra Leone base their rates for other currencies on the cur­ rent London market rates. On December 31, 1976, the banks' buying and selling rates for the U . S. dollar were US$0,859 and US$0 ,842, respectively, per Le 1. Sierra Leone avails itself of wider margins. Administration of Control Exchange control policy is made by the M in is t ry of Finance. The day-to-day administration of exchange control is carried out by the Bank of Sierra Leone. Authorized commercial banks are permitted to sell exchange for permitted imports and, in small amounts, for travel expenses. The Bank of Sierra Leone has power to direct payments into B locked Accounts. Import and export licenses are issued by the M in is t ry of Trade and Industry. Prescription of Currency Transactions w i th all countries are subject to exchange control. Certain settlements with the People's Republic of Ch ina must be channeled through clearing accounts established under the terms of a bilateral payments agreement.1 Payments for imports from other countries may be made in leones to the credit of an External Account or a Sterling A rea Account in Sierra Leone, in the currency of the exporting country, in sterling to the credit of an External Account in the Un i ted K i n g­ dom, or in U . S. dollars. Settlements with the Central Bank of West A f r ican States (for Benin, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Vo l ta) and The G am­ bia, Ghana, M a l i, L ibe r ia, and N iger ia are normally made through the West Afr ican C lear ing House. Receipts from exports other than diamonds to countries other than the People's Republic of Ch ina and Rhodesia may be obtained in leones from an External Account or a Sterling Area Account in Sierra Leone, in the currency of the importing country, or in any specified currency .2 Receipts from exports of diamonds and all other m in­ erals must be obtained in the currency of the importing country or in any other specified currency, through the 1 A payments agreement concluded with Gu inea in 1964 tive. 2 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, Spanish pesetas, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U . S. dollars. inopera­ is account of the Bank of Sierra Leone in the importing country. Settlements with Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in leones held with authorized banks in Sierra Leone by residents of countries outside Sierra Leone other than residents of Rhodesia may be desig­ nated External Accounts. Residents of former Sterling A rea countries 3 may maintain Sterling A rea Accounts denominated in leones. Rhodesian Accounts are accounts with banks in Sierra Leone conducted in the name of persons resident in Rhodesia. In addition, there are Blocked Accounts, to which are credited amounts that may not be remitted abroad and that are due to nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments A ll imports from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica are prohibited. Certain goods may be imported under open general license from a wide range of coun­ tries. Otherwise, all imports require individual import licenses. Imports of rice can be made only by the Rice Corporation. Authorized banks have limited authority to grant foreign exchange for import payments; for imports under specific import licenses, the approval of the Bank of Sierra Leone is required where the payment exceeds Le 10,000 for each individual license, and for imports under open general license the Bank's approval must be obtained where the payment for an individual item of import exceeds Le 5,000. The Bank of Sierra Leone takes the foreign exchange availability into account in considering applications. A ll imports not specifically exempted by the Minister of Finance are subject to an invoice entry tax of W2 per cent of the c.i.f. value. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to nonresidents require approval, which for many current transactions is given freely. Remittances of earnings by foreign nationals are limited in principle to Le 8,000 or 40 per cent of gross taxable annual wages and salaries, whichever is lower, but the Bank of Sierra Leone may permit the transfer of higher amounts. Insurance on imported goods must be taken out with insurance companies incorporated in Sierra Leone, buying commission is not normally per­ mitted to exceed 2 per cent, and bank charges, financing commission, and other financial charges on imports also are not normally allowed. Certain current payments are in arrears. F or travel abroad, residents are entitled to a basic exchange allowance of Le 500 a person a calendar year. • Sierra Leone's regulations still provide a definition of the Sterling A r e a; the definition includes Sierra Leone and excludes South A f r i c a. 393 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution S IERRA L E O NE Applications for larger amounts are considered on an individual basis. In addition to the basic exchange allow­ ance, travelers may take out, regardless of destination, Le 20 in leone notes and the equivalent of Le 50 in foreign currency notes. Nonresident travelers may take out any foreign currency banknotes, including sterling notes, declared by them when entering Sierra Leone. Travel abroad is subject to a travel tax of 5 per cent of the price of the ticket, payable at the time of pur­ chase of the ticket. Exports and Export Proceeds Except for a few commodities sold to certain destina­ tions, exports require individual export licenses. Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. The proceeds of exports other than diamonds and other minerals must be received in the currency of the import­ ing country or any other specified currency agreed to by the Bank of Sierra Leone; they must be transferred to Sierra Leone within a month of receipt and sold to an authorized bank in Sierra Leone within three months from the date of export, unless permission to do other­ wise is obtained. The proceeds from exports of dia­ monds and all other minerals must be obtained in the currency of the importing country or in any other speci­ fied currency, through the account of the Bank of Sierra Leone in the importing country, within six months of shipment or such shorter period as may be specified. The buying and exporting of diamonds is carried out by five locally licensed firms and by several foreign companies. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in specified currencies (see footnote 2) must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Subject to declaration upon entry, persons enter­ ing Sierra Leone may bring in any amount of foreign banknotes. The importation of domestic banknotes is limited to Le 20 per traveler. Capital Capital payments to nonresidents of Sierra Leone are subject to exchange control. Residents of Sierra Leone require permission from the Bank of Sierra Leone to purchase foreign currency securities or real estate situ­ ated outside Sierra Leone. Investments by nonresidents other than residents of Rhodesia may be repatriated at any time, together with profits, provided that exchange control permission was obtained initially for the invest­ ment. The Sierra Leone Exchange Con trol A ct of 1954 imposes control on the issue and transfer of securities. The placing of an issue in Sierra Leone requires permis­ sion if either the person acquiring the securities or the person for whom he is nominee is resident outside Sierra Leone. Permission must also be obtained before a security registered in Sierra Leone may be transferred 394 to a person resident outside Sierra Leone. Capital in respect of securities registered in Sierra Leone may not be transferred outside Sierra Leone without permission. Where permission has been given for securities registered in Sierra Leone to be sold to persons resident outside Sierra Leone, the company is usually required to obtain bank certification of the funds brought into Sierra Leone to ensure that permission w i ll not be given later for taking out appreciably more than was brought in. The Develop­ ment Ordinance of 1960 provides for income tax and customs duty concessions to foreign and domestic com­ panies undertaking industrial or agricultural activities that are needed for the development of the country. Noncitizens are prohibited from owning or controlling certain types of business. By virtue of Pub l ic Notice N o. 50 of October 11, 1974, residents of Sierra Leone must sell to an autho­ rized dealer in Sierra Leone their holdings of gold and specified currency. Exemption is made for authorized dealers, diplomats, and those exempt sterling assets held prior to June 24, 1972 for which exemption has been claimed and granted by the Bank of Sierra Leone. Exempted securities may be sold outside the former Sterling A rea (see footnote 3) and any income there­ from may be retained in the former Sterling Area or reinvested in other Sterling A rea securities. A ny certifi­ cate of security purchased with the proceeds of the sale of securities exempted under this permission is exempt from deposit requirements. A ny assets held outside the former Sterling A rea by any foreign national tempo­ rarily resident in Sierra Leone also are exempt from surrender and deposit requirements, provided exemption has been claimed and granted by an authorized dealer or by the Bank of Sierra Leone. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Sierra Leone for numismatic purposes. Also, residents and nonresidents may freely purchase, hold, sell, or export certain Sierra Leonean gold coins issued for commemorative purposes. W i th these exceptions, residents other than the monetary authorities, gold pro­ ducers, and authorized industrial users are not allowed to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad; residents have been directed to declare and make available to the Government all gold held in the form of bars or coins. Imports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require individual import licenses which are not normally granted. Exports of gold in any form require licenses issued by the Ch ief Inspector of M ines; such licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and local gold producers. Travelers, however, do not require a license to take out personal jewelry if the value of the total gold and platinum content does not exceed Le 200. Exports of unworked gold are not subject to export tax. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Changes during 1976 March 18. Government No t ice N o. 264 of M a r ch 15 was gazetted notifying a ll importers that for importa­ tion under the open general license for 1976 (Notice No. 1310 of December 11, 1975), they were required to apply to the Bank of Sierra Leone, through their bankers, for foreign currency before placing orders. The Bank would give priority to essential imports; therefore, some applications might not be met in full and others not at a l l. March 18. Government No t ice N o. 267 of M a r ch 5 was gazetted. Further to Government Notices Nos. 1309 and 1310 of December 1 1, 1975, it rescinded the Bank's Notice of November 17, 1975 (which had revoked the authority of commercial banks to make payments for imports on production of shipping documents) and laid down new conditions and procedures to be followed for payments for goods imported under specific import licenses and under the open general license. Applications for payment for goods imported under specific import licenses issued in 1976 had to be forwarded to the com­ mercial banks, who would either remit the amounts under their own authority or forward the applications to the Bank of Sierra Leone. Applications for payment for goods imported under the open general license for 1976 also had to be forwarded to the importers' bankers, before orders were placed, together with supporting documentary evidence of the actual level of these goods received by the importer concerned in 1975. In addi­ tion, all orders above Le 5,000 for goods under open general license must be referred to the Bank of Sierra Leone, together with supporting pro forma invoices indicating the payment terms, and approval had to be obtained before orders were placed. The remittance of buying commissions would no longer be permitted unless it proved to be absolutely necessary. F inanc ing commissions and other such finan­ cial charges also would not be permitted, while payment of interest would only be allowed on usance bills. March 24. The Bank of Sierra Leone issued a Notice to Banks containing guidelines for payment for imports. The main ones were: (1) Imports were normally to be invoiced in the currency of the exporting country, and payments were to be made in that currency, but payments could in all instances (except under bilateral agreements) be made in sterling or U . S. dollars. (2) Goods should normally be imported direct from the country of origin so as to avoid buying commissions. The use of confirm­ ing houses and establishment of letters of credit abroad S IERRA L E O NE should be avoided, and applications for both had to be referred to the Bank of Sierra Leone. (3) Requests for the establishment of outward letters of credit must be declined if the amounts included charges for insurance, buying commissions of over 2 per cent, examination fees, financing commissions or other financial charges, cost of cables or postage, or bank charges. (4) Payment of air freight required the prior approval of the Bank of Sierra Leone. (5) U n t il further notice, payment for orders under specific import licenses could be effected by authorized dealers up to only Le 10,000 for each individual license, while payments for orders above that amount had to be referred to the Bank of Sierra Leone; payment for goods under the open general license must be restricted to Le 5,000 for each item of import and all orders above this amount required the prior approval of the Bank of Sierra Leone. (6) A ny appli­ cation to remit foreign currency wh ich could not be executed within these guidelines had to be referred to the Bank of Sierra Leone. June 10. Not for Redistribution SINGAPORE (Position on January 7, 7977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.290299 gram of fine gold per Singapore Do l la r, and Singapore avails itself of wider margins. Since June 20, 1973, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate within announced margins. The closing selling and buying rates in the Singapore foreign exchange market for the U .S. dollar on Decem­ ber 31, 1976 were S$2.4545 and S$2.4555 per US $ 1, respectively, for telegraphic transfers. The authorized banks are free to deal spot and for­ ward in a ll currencies. Forward cover on transactions of residents in the As ian currency market requires the prior approval of the Monetary Au thor i ty of Singapore. App roval is not required for forward cover for any period in respect of import or export transactions. Singapore and Brunei currency notes and coins are freely interchangeable, at par and without charge, in the two countries concerned, at the commercial banks and with the monetary authorities. Singapore formally accepted the obligations of A r t i­ cle V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from November 9, 1968. Administration of Control The Monetary Au thor i ty of Singapore administers exchange control. M u ch of the authority for approving normal current payments as well as certain capital pay­ ments is delegated to commercial banks authorized for this purpose. The Trade Department of the M in is try of Finance administers import and export controls; the power to approve imports and exports has been dele­ gated to the Controller and Registrar of Imports and Exports. Prescription of Currency Singapore has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U . K. Exchange Con trol A c t, 1947 but under current U . K. exchange control regulations con­ tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling A r e a. Singapore has made no changes in the list of Scheduled Territories (covering Singapore and a ll other former Sterling A rea territories) which appears in the first schedule to the Singapore Exchange Con trol A c t, other than adding Indonesia, the Philippines, and Tha i land. A ll payments to and from the Scheduled Territories may be made in either a Scheduled Territory currency or a foreign currency.1 Certain payments to Romania must be made through special accounts. Pay­ ments to other countries outside the Scheduled T e r r i­ tories except Rhodesia may be made in Singapore dollars or another currency of the Scheduled Territories through an External Account, or in any foreign currency other 1 Foreign currencies are all currencies of countries outside Scheduled Territories. the 396 than Rhodesian currency. Receipts from exports to other countries outside the Scheduled Territories except Rho­ desia must be obtained in either Singapore dollars or another currency of the Scheduled Territories through an External Accoun t, or in any specified currency .2 Special regulations apply to settlements with Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts The accounts of residents of other Scheduled Terri­ tories are treated as resident accounts. The accounts of residents of countries outside the Scheduled Terri­ tories are treated as nonresident accounts and, unless specially restricted, are designated External Accounts: the latter may be denominated in Singapore dollars or other Scheduled Territory currencies. External Accounts may be credited with (1) approved payments by resi­ dents of Singapore and residents of other Scheduled Territories; (2) interest on the accounts; (3) payments from other External Accounts; (4) proceeds from sales of gold and foreign currencies; and (5) payments, including cash, up to S$50,000 or its equivalent in any of the Scheduled Territory currencies. External Accounts may be debited with (1) payments to residents of Singapore and residents of other Scheduled Territories; (2) payments to other External Accounts; (3) the cost of purchases of foreign currencies and gold; and (4) withdrawals in cash. Accounts of residents of Rhodesia are designated Rhodesian Accounts. A ll debits and credits to such accounts require prior approval. Imports and Import Payments V i r tua l ly all imports are permitted freely under open general license or specific licenses, depending on the nature and origin of the goods. A few imports are con­ trolled for health or security reasons. A ll imports originating in Rhodesia, South A f r i c a, or any territory administered by either are prohibited. Specific licenses are required for (1) rice (excluding bran) and refined sugar, irrespective of or ig in; (2) textile fabrics, when originating in Japan; and (3) all goods originating in, wholly or mainly manufactured in, or consigned from A lban ia, the People's Republic of Ch ina, Cuba, Czecho­ slovakia, the German Democratic Republic, the Mon­ golian People's Republic, and V iet N am. License appli­ cations for goods under (3) must be submitted through the intermediary of Intraco L t d ., which levies a sur­ charge of 0.5 per cent on the c.i.f. value of imports from these countries (except the People's Republic of C h i n a ). Permission to make payments for permitted imports is readily given, provided that the prescription of cur- 2 The specified currencies are Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U . S. dollars. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution rency regulations are observed; for imports of Bulgarian, Hungarian, No r th Ko rean, and Romanian origin this permission must be obtained from the exchange control authorities. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to residents of the Scheduled Territories may be made freely. Payments related to commercial transactions and personal payments of a current nature to other countries, except Rhodesia, are also permitted freely. Au thor ized banks are permitted to approve applications for payments in respect of many categories of current invisibles, either without limitation or up to established limits. Applications for payments in excess of these limits, or for purposes for which no dele­ gation of authority has been granted, are approved by the Monetary Au thor i ty of Singapore, provided that no unauthorized capital outflow is involved. Payments up to S$50,000 are not subject to exchange control formalities. There are no restrictions on the amount of foreign exchange made available for travel abroad; there is a basic foreign exchange allowance equivalent to S$50,000 a person a year, and available in any currency, for travel outside the Scheduled Territories and amounts in excess of this figure are allowed on application; the same allocation is available only in foreign currencies for travel in the Scheduled Territories other than Japan. Remittances to nonresidents of dividends, interest, and agreed profits on all bona fide investments are freely permitted; authorized banks are allowed to approve the applications. Resident and nonresident travelers may freely take out any amount in foreign and Scheduled Territory banknotes and coins, including Singapore gold coins. Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Exports of certain textiles to Aus tr ia, Belgium, Denmark, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxem­ bourg, the Netherlands, No rway, Sweden, the Un i ted K ingdom, and the Un i ted States are subject to quantita­ tive restriction. Exports of a few other items are restricted irrespective of destination. Other commodi­ ties do not require an export license. Exchange control approval is required only for exports exceeding S$50,000 in value to countries outside the Scheduled Territories; this requirement serves to ensure that the proceeds are obtained in specified currencies and are sold to an authorized bank, normally within six months of ship­ ment. F or exports to Bulgaria, No r th Ko rea, Hungary, and Romania, exchange control approval is required irrespective of the value of the goods. Export proceeds in specified currencies up to S$3 m i l l ion for each recipi­ ent may be retained and may be used to make commer­ cial current payments and any other approved payments to residents and nonresidents of Singapore. S INGA PORE Proceeds from Invisibles The exchange con t rol requirements govern ing exchange receipts from invisibles are, in general, the same as those for export proceeds, including the facility for the retention and use of up to S$3 m i l l ion in specified currencies for each recipient. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign and Scheduled Territory banknotes and coins, including Singapore gold coins. Capital There are no restrictions on capital transfers to and from other Scheduled Territories. Capital transfers from Singapore to countries outside the Scheduled Territories require exchange control approval. Inward transfers of capital from such countries (with the exception of borrowing from residents of such countries) do not require approval and the subsequent utilization of nonresident-owned funds in Singapore for investment purposes also is exempt from individual exchange con­ trol approval; however, government approval is required for investment in most residential property and in any vacant land other than land already designated prior to September 1 1, 1973 for industrial or commercial use. Investment by residents of countries outside the Sched­ uled Territories (other than Rhodesia) in Singapore stocks and bonds, whether quoted or not, is freely per­ mitted in any currency, including Singapore dollars from an External Account. Proceeds from sales of Singapore securities held in Singapore and of other investments may be freely repatriated by residents of countries out­ side the Scheduled Territories; the approval authority for such transfers has been delegated to authorized banks. Borrowing from local banks by nonresident- controlled companies is not restricted. Investments by Singapore residents in countries out­ side the Scheduled Territories normally may be made only upon approval of the exchange control authorities; however, residents are permitted to invest without limit in certain prescribed external bonds, and up to certain prescribed limits in securities denominated in foreign currencies, in deposits in foreign currencies with autho­ rized banks or with As ian Currency Un i ts, in properties outside the Scheduled Territories, and in foreign cur­ rency life and endowment policies. The exchange allow­ ance for cash gifts and loans by individuals and charitable organizations resident in Singapore to ind i­ viduals and charitable organizations resident outside the Scheduled Territories is S$50,000 a remitter a calendar year, available in any currency; the same allocation is available in foreign currencies where the beneficiaries are resident in the Scheduled Territories other than Singa­ pore. Negotiable certificates of deposit in any currency that have been issued in Singapore, as well as other bearer securities prescribed by the Monetary Au thor i ty, must be deposited with an authorized depositary. 397 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution S INGA PORE Singapore banks that have been licensed to operate an As ian Currency Un i t, and thus to operate in the As ian dollar market, may freely accept deposits in currencies other than Singapore dollars from nonresidents of Singapore and, up to certain prescribed limits, deposits in foreign currencies from residents of Singapore. As ian Currency Units are required to obtain specific exchange control approval for granting loans to residents of Singa­ pore, except loans to finance outstanding export bills. A ll transactions must be conducted over accounts held in the Asian Currency Units of the banks concerned. The spot and forward foreign exchange positions of banks are supervised by the Monetary Authority. Gold There is a free gold market in Singapore, to which residents and nonresidents have free access; payments by residents to nonresidents must take place in a Sched­ uled Territory currency to an External Account or in any foreign currency, while receipts from nonresidents may be accepted in any currency, including by debit to an External Account. Both resident and nonresident individuals and companies are permitted to import, hold, negotiate, and export gold freely; imports and exports require neither exchange control approval nor import or export licenses, and gold can be dealt with freely by any person in Singapore. A S$150 commemorative gold coin issued by the Board of Commissioners of Currency, Singapore, is legal tender; this coin is treated for exchange control purposes as gold rather than local currency and its export and import is dealt with in the same way as that of gold so that it may be freely imported and exported by travelers. A few other legal tender gold coins issued subsequently by the Board of Commissioners of Currency are also treated as gold for exchange control purposes. The price of gold used for the manufacture of orna­ ments is fixed by the Singapore-Chinese G o ld and Silver Merchants Association. On December 31, 1976, this price was about S$490 per tael for 24-karat gold and S$450 per tael for 22-karat gold. Changes during 1976 January 16. Import licenses were no longer required for aluminum sheets, certain machinery, and sewing machines from Japan. Export licenses were no longer required for round steel bars and cement. February 4. Three non-Scheduled Territory member countries of the Association of South East As ian Nations —Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines— were included in the list of Scheduled Territories. Transfers to and from these countries could henceforth be made freely. In addition, the permission for residents to make such investments was extended to foreign currency deposits, foreign currency securities, and properties outside the Scheduled Territories. The basic exchange allocation for Singapore residents for tourist and business travel out­ side the Scheduled Territories was increased to S$50,000 a person a calendar year; this allowance could be made available in foreign currency notes. February 4. Not for Redistribution SOMALIA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.118193 gram of fine gold per Somali Sh i l l ing, and Somalia avails itself of wider mar­ gins. The Central Bank of Somalia carries out exchange transactions in some of the "convertible" currencies 1 with authorized dealers at fixed rates, taking into con­ sideration those in leading exchange markets in Europe; on December 31, 1976, the Bank's buying and selling rates for the U . S. dollar were So. Sh. 6.2327 and So. Sh. 6.3573, unchanged since 1973. The exchange market in Somalia comprises the Central Bank and the sole commercial bank, which operates as the authorized exchange dealer in respect of transactions in foreign cur­ rencies. There is a foreign exchange commission (includ­ ing banking commission) of 0.7 per cent for all exchange transactions other than purchases and sales of banknotes. The authorized exchange dealer generally does not con­ duct forward exchange transactions on behalf of the public, although this is not prohibited. Administration of Control The M in is t ry of Commerce is the principal govern­ ment agency concerned with the implementation and operation of trade and exchange controls. It has been given the authority to regulate and control all foreign economic transactions and to establish policy for the licensing of imports, exports, and exchange. The Central Bank is authorized to determine the rates at which for­ eign currencies are to be negotiated, to establish a list of "convertible" currencies,1 and to appoint authorized exchange dealers. The sole commercial bank has been appointed as authorized exchange dealer. The Central Bank may also implement the trade and exchange con­ trols on behalf of the M in is t ry of Commerce. An Adv isory Commission, consisting of nine members, representing various ministries, the Central Bank, the Customs Au thor i ty, and the police, advises the M in is try of Commerce on policy questions relating to the regula­ tions and control of foreign economic transactions. The National and Lo c al Licensing Committees, usually con­ sisting of members representing the M in is t ry of C om­ merce, the M in is t ry of Finance, the Central Bank, the Customs Au thor i ty, and the police, decide on applica­ tions for licenses for imports and exports and for trans­ fers in respect of services. The Central Bank grants licenses for certain routine invisibles. Transfers in respect of capital are authorized by the Na t ional Licens­ ing Committee in Mogadiscio, unless they are governed by the provisions of Law N o. 10 of February 18, 1960 on foreign investments, as extended and amended by 1 The "convertible" currencies are listed as Dj ibouti francs, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U . S. dollars. 400 Decree-Law N o. 3 of M a r ch 3, 1968 and Law N o. 17 of June 15, 1968. Prescription of Currency Settlements with the People's Republic of Ch ina and the U .S .S .R. are made through bilateral clearing accounts denominated in pounds sterling. Settlements with all other countries must be made in Somali shillings or in "convertible" currencies (see footnote 1 ); however, resi­ dents are not permitted to make settlements with Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, or South A f r i c a. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts in Somali shillings may be opened with the authorized exchange dealer by Somali nationals residing abroad, by foreign nationals and foreign institutions enjoying diplomatic status in Somalia, and by foreign companies engaged in mineral prospecting or consultancy services. Imports and Import Payments Imports of goods originating in or shipped from Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. The import of a few commodities from all sources is temporarily prohibited for balance of payments reasons.2 Individual licenses are required for a ll other commodi­ ties. Some of these commodities may be imported only from specified sources.3 Certain other commodities are liberalized when originating in E EC countries. State agencies are responsible for all commodity imports. The state trading organization, the Na t ional Agency for Trade (Ente Nazionale per il Commercio or E N C ), is responsible, inter alia, for the import and /or distribution of certain commodities received under aid programs. It also is the sole agent for the importation of animal and vegetable oils and fats, corn, rice, wheat flour, coffee, tea, sugar, pasta, cement, and certain other commodities; some are not being imported at present (e.g., soaps and detergents, rubber and plastic footwear, and bleached or unbleached cotton c lo th ). The Somali Petroleum Agency and the Na t ional Petroleum Agency are the only importers of fuel and fuel products, batteries, rubber tubes and tires, and fire extinguishers and related mate­ rials. The Pharmaceutical Agency is the only agency entitled to import medicines, while the Agency for Construction Materials is the sole importer of construc­ tion materials. 2 Butter, cheese, tomatoes, nonalcoholic beverages, ready-made cloth­ ing, textiles and related materials, electrical appliances and parts, and small passenger automobiles. nT he permitted origin varies from commodity to commodity; the specified sources of supply generally are Egypt and /or the U .S .S .R.
