S . S .R. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution If goods imported differ in weight, quantity, or value by more than 10 per cent from the specifications in the import license, a new import license must be obtained. A ll imports other than those made by the Government, diplomatic and consular agencies, and international organizations are subject to a statistical and administra­ tive tax of 10 per cent. Payments for imports are authorized by the Central Bank or the authorized exchange dealer on the basis of the import license and other documentation relating to the import transaction (bills, bills of lading, shipping notices, etc .). Provided that the Central Bank or the authorized exchange dealer is satisfied that the transac­ tion meets the legal requirements, permission to make payment for imports is granted to the applicant not later than the third business day following the receipt of the application or on such other subsequent day as may be specified by the applicant. The Central Bank or the authorized exchange dealer may also permit advance payments for imports (i.e., payment for merchandise not actually passed through customs at the time of pay­ ment) provided that documentary evidence of actual shipment is produced. Advance payments for imports without documentary evidence of actual shipment are not permitted. Payments for imports from neighboring areas 4 are permitted only by letter of credit and by cash against documentation. Payments for Invisibles Payments to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. Payments for current invisibles are subject to licensing, mainly to prevent unauthorized capital movements; provided that balance of payments considerations permit, genuine requirements are met. Transfers of salaries, wages, gratuities, and allowances paid in Somalia to their foreign personnel by enterprises registered under the Foreign Investment Law are nor­ mally allowed up to 50 per cent. The Central Bank may grant licenses for exchange for travel purposes up to specified limits. Applications for all other invisibles are considered on their merits by the Licensing Comm i t­ tees in Mogadiscio, Hargeisa, and Burao. F or tourist travel by residents, there is an allowance of the equiva­ lent of So. Sh. 1,000 a person a year, which is applicable to all countries, except Canada, Japan, and the Un i ted States; for these three countries, the allowance is So. Sh. 1,400 a person a year. Nonresident travelers may take out without authoriza­ tion any foreign exchange which they brought in and up to So. Sh. 200 in Somali notes and coins. Resident travelers may take out without authorization So. Sh. 200 in Somali notes and coins and up to the equivalent of So. Sh. 200 in foreign banknotes and coins. A currency declaration is required by all persons leaving the country. 4 Ad en, Dj ibout i, Muk a l l a, E th iop ia, and Kenya. S OM A L IA Exports and Export Proceeds Exports and re-exports to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. The export of a few commodities to any destination may be prohibited for reasons of public policy. An export license is required for all other commodities. Bananas are exported only by the Banana Marketing Board. The E NC is the sole agent for the exportation of incense, myrrh, gum arabic, and charcoal. The export of salt, dried fish, and hides and skins also is a public sector monopoly. A ll export proceeds must be repatriated, declared, and offered for sale to the Central Bank or to the authorized exchange dealer within five business days after their receipt. The Central Bank may exempt exporters from the surrender obligation in respect of their export pro­ ceeds. Where no banks are operating, an advance pay­ ment deposit of 50 per cent of the value of livestock exports and 15 per cent of the value of other exports is required. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be repatriated, declared, and offered for sale to the Central Bank or to the autho­ rized dealer within five business days after their receipt. The Central Bank may grant exemptions from the sur­ render requirement. Nonresidents may bring in freely with them any amount in foreign exchange and up to So. Sh. 200 in Somali banknotes and coins; they must make a currency declaration when entering the country. Resident travelers may bring in up to So. Sh. 200 in Somali banknotes and coins and are obliged, upon arrival, to declare and offer to surrender any foreign exchange or gold they bring in. Capital Payments to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica are prohibited. Cap i tal transactions are subject to licensing unless they are authorized by the Foreign Investment Law of February 1960 (as amended in M a r ch and June 1968). In accordance with the provi­ sions of that law, foreign enterprises must be registered with the M in is try of Planning and Coordination. F or "productive" enterprises (i.e., those that engage in irrigation, improvement of land, establishment of fac­ tories, construction of aqueducts, and testing, analyzing, and d r i l l ing activities in connection with o il and mineral exploration), profits may be transferred abroad freely up to a limit of 15 per cent per annum of the capital invested; the unused portion of this transfer right is cumulative for three years. Should profits in any one year be less than 15 per cent, the transfer right for the succeeding three years is correspondingly increased. The capital itself may be transferred abroad beginning five years after the date of registration. Profits resulting from other foreign investments may be transferred abroad up to a l im it of 10 per cent per annum of the capital invested, and the capital itself may be transferred 401 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution S OM A L IA abroad over a minimum period of three years, beginning seven years after the date of registration. The M in is t ry of Finance, upon the recommendation of other ministries concerned, may extend total or par­ tial exemption to any enterprise from import and export taxes, excise duty, income tax, and municipal tax for a period not exceeding five years. For investments regis­ tered prior to M a r ch 1968, the fiscal exemptions may be granted for up to ten years. Enterprises registered in or after M a r ch 1968 must, to the largest possible extent, employ residents; a program for the substitution of resi­ dent employees for nonresidents is to be submitted, for the record, to the Committee on Foreign Investments. Gold Residents may hold and acquire in Somalia, for numis­ matic purposes only, gold coins that are not legal tender in any country. W i th this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require permis­ sions issued by the Central Bank; such permissions are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. G o ld imported by jewelers must be melted down to a fineness of not more than 22 karats within one month. Imports of gold are exempt from customs duty when originating in E EC countries and are subject to a 10 per cent duty when of other or ig in. Not for Redistribution SOUTH AFRICA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.04550 grams of fine gold per South A f r ican Rand. On June 24, 1974 South A f r i ca began an exchange rate policy of independent managed float­ ing, but since June 27, 1975 a policy has been followed of keeping the buying and selling rates for the U . S. do l­ lar constant for longer periods at a time. As at Decem­ ber 31, 1976 the South A f r ican Reserve Bank quoted a middle exchange rate for the U . S. dollar of US$1.1500 per R 1, unchanged since September 22, 1975. Exchange rates for other currencies are based on the Reserve Bank's rates for the U . S. dollar against rand and the London market rates for the currencies concerned against the U . S. dollar. The commercial banks' spot public rates for the U . S. dollar on December 31, 1976 were US$1.1529 buying, and US$1.1471 selling, per R 1. Subject to certain limitations, authorized dealers are permitted to conduct forward exchange operations among themselves and w i th overseas banks. The Reserve Bank provides forward cover for private sector transac­ tions in U . S. dollars only; such cover is given to autho­ rized dealers at a charge of 1 per cent per annum, for import and export transactions and for foreign loans raised in their own names. There is also a market in which securities rand (the local sale and redemption proceeds of South A f r ican securities and other investments in South A f r i ca owned by nonresidents other than former residents of South Afr ica) may be negotiated at freely determined rates, usually incurring a discount on the official market rate; at the end of 1976, that discount was about 40 per cent, the middle closing rate on December 31 being R 1 = US$0.66. South A f r i ca formally accepted the obligations of Ar t ic le V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agree­ ment, as of September 15, 1973. Exchange Control Territory There are virtually no exchange or trade restrictions between the Republic of South A f r i ca (defined for exchange control purposes as including South West A f r i c a ), Lesotho, and Swaziland, and these, as well as Transkei, are regarded as forming, with the Republic of South A f r i c a, a single exchange control territory, the Rand Monetary A r e a. Administration of Control Import and export licenses are issued by the Director of Imports and Exports acting on behalf of the Secre­ tary for Commerce. Exchange licensing is the responsi­ bility of the Treasury, which has delegated this authority to the South A f r i c an Reserve Bank; in turn, the Reserve Bank has delegated to the authorized dealers much of its licensing power. Appropriate exchange for licensed imports is made available by the authorized dealers upon proof of shipment or, where advance payment is pro­ posed, upon presentation of other suitable documentary evidence, which must include the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Prescription of Currency A ll countries outside the Rand Monetary A r ea con­ stitute the Nonresident A rea. Settlements within the Rand Monetary A r ea take place in rand on ly .1 Swazi banknotes and coins are convertible into rand at par without restriction, but they are not legal tender in South A f r i c a. Settlements by residents of the Rand Monetary A rea with residents of the Nonresident A rea, except Botswana and Rhodesia, may be made in rand to and from a Nonresident Account and in any specified cur­ r e n c y2 and, for outgoing payments only, in any other foreign currency.3 Settlements with Botswana may be made in rand to or from a local Botswana Account, in Botswana currency, in rand from a local Nonresident Account to a Botswana Account (for outgoing payments on ly ), in rand from a local Nonresident Account (for inward payments o n l y ), or in any specified currency (for inward payments o n l y ). Settlements with Rhodesia may be made in rand to and from a local Rhodesian or other nonresident account, in Rhodesian currency and, for inward payments only, in any specified currency. Nonresident Accounts The rand accounts of persons resident outside the Rand Monetary A rea are divided into Botswana Accounts, Rhodesian Accounts, Nonresident Accounts, Securities Rand Accounts, and Blocked Accounts. Botswana Accounts are held by persons, firms, or companies (including banks) resident, domiciled, or registered in Botswana. They may be credited with all authorized payments by South A f r ican residents, with the proceeds of sales to authorized dealers in South A f r i ca of Botswana currency and of any specified cur­ rency, and with payments from local Nonresident or Botswana Accounts. They may be debited for payments for exports to Botswana and other payments due by Botswana residents to South Afr ican residents, for pay- 1 In September 1974 Swaziland issued its own currency, the lilangeni (plural emalangeni), to replace the rand. Lilangeni banknotes are freely convertible into rand, at par, at the Monetary Authority of Swaziland, but they are not legal tender in South A f r i c a. Checks and other bills of exchange drawn by Swazi residents for payment in South A fr ica and Lesotho must be denominated in rand. 2 Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, F i ji dollars, French francs, Hong K ong dollars, Indian rupees, Italian lire, Japanese yen, "«'enya shillings, Malagasy francs, Ma lawi kwacha, Netherlands guilders, New Zealand dollars, Norwegian kroner, Pakistan rupees, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Seychelles rupees, Spanish pesetas, Sri Lanka rupees, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, Uganda shillings, U . S. dollars, za'ires, and Zambian kwacha. 3 Foreign currency is any currency other than currency that is legal tender in South A f r i c a. 403 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution S O U TH A F R I CA merits to the account holder while temporarily resident in South A f r i ca for short periods, for payments to other local Botswana Accounts, and for the cost of purchases of Botswana currency. Rhodesian Accounts are held by persons, firms, or companies (including banks) resident, domiciled, or registered in Rhodesia. They may be credited with all authorized payments by South A f r ican residents, with the proceeds of sales to authorized dealers in South A f r ica of Rhodesian currency and of any specified cur­ rency, and with payments from local Nonresident or Rhodesian Accounts. They may be debited for payments for exports to Rhodesia and other payments due by Rhodesian residents to South Afr ican residents, for pay­ ments to the account holder while he is temporarily resident in South A f r ica for short periods, for payments to other local Rhodesian Accounts, and for the cost of purchases of Rhodesian currency. Nonresident Accounts are held by persons, firms, or companies (including banks) resident, domiciled, or registered outside Botswana, Rhodesia, and the Rand Monetary A rea. They may be credited with all autho­ rized payments by South Afr ican residents, with the proceeds of sales to authorized dealers in South A f r ica of specified currency, and with payments from other Nonresident Accounts in South A f r i c a. They may be debited for payments to South Afr ican residents for any purpose; for payments to nonresidents for any purpose, i.e., by transfer to a local Nonresident, Botswana, or Rhodesian Account or for remittance to any country outside the Rand Monetary A rea; for the cost of pur­ chases of any foreign currency; and for payments to the account holder while he is temporarily resident in South A f r ica for short periods. Securities Rand Accounts are the accounts of nonresi­ dents of the Rand Monetary A rea, other than emigrants from that A rea, to which exchange control restrictions have been applied. Such accounts are maintained with authorized banks. They must be credited with the local sale and redemption proceeds of South A f r ican securi­ ties and other investments in South A f r i c a, owned by nonresidents, excluding former residents of South A f r i c a, and by immigrants within three years of arrival. Johan­ nesburg Stock Exchange dealers are permitted to quote prices for securities rand and its members are permitted to buy and sell securities rand as agents, acting on behalf of nonresidents. Authorized banks are freely permitted to transfer securities rand balances from one Securities Rand Account in their books to another, in their own books or in the books of another authorized bank. In addition to transfer to another Securities Rand Account, funds in these accounts may be used freely for reinvest­ ment in locally quoted securities (which may be exported and sold abroad); to acquire central government, municipal, or public utility stock with a maturity of five years or more (the redemption proceeds of which are transferable abroad when held for a continuous period 404 of at least five years to redemption); and to tender for five-year nonresident bonds issued by the Treasury (the redemption proceeds of which are also transferable). The proceeds of South A f r ican securities held by immi­ grants prior to their arrival in South A f r ica or acquired abroad within three years of their arr iva l, are also credited to Securities Rand Accounts, with the excep­ tion of funds of persons who had been South African residents. Blocked Accounts are the accounts of emigrants from the Rand Monetary Area to which exchange control restrictions have been applied .4 They must be credited with that part of an emigrant's assets which exceeds the amount that is transferable on departure. Such funds may not be transferred from South A f r ica or to another Blocked Account in South A f r i c a, but may be retained on deposit with an authorized dealer, used within cer­ tain limits for the holder's l iv ing expenses while visiting South A f r i c a, or invested in any securities which are quoted locally; such securities may not, however, be exported and sold abroad. Blocked rand may also be used, within a limit of R 30,000 for each emigrant family unit, to subscribe to a special issue, made available by the Government to nonresidents of South A f r ica only, of five-year nonresident bonds offered by tender on a discount basis and repayable at face value. The redemp­ tion proceeds are transferable in the foreign currency of the monetary area in which the holder is resident. Imports and Import Payments A ll importers of goods requiring import licenses must be registered with the Director of Imports and Exports. Most licenses allow the importation of a range of com­ modities, but they are, in general, to be used for goods as prescribed on the relevant import permit. Import licenses are valid for imports from any country. Imports free of license include (1) all goods imported from Botswana, Lesotho, or Swaziland and (2) all goods imported from Rhodesia, Ma law i, and Zambia that were grown, produced, or manufactured in those countries. The Import Con t rol Regulations for 1977, as announced in December 1976, distinguish generally between the following broad categories of imports: (1) Goods which may be imported without an import permit. This free list contains 583 tariff headings or subheadings and corresponds to some 27.3 per cent of 1976 imports. (2) Goods which may be imported only under per­ mit but subject to automatic licensing for bona fide merchants and manufacturers. These fall under an unspecified number of tariff headings or subheadings and correspond on a value basis to 59.6 per cent of 1976 imports. (3) Goods which may be imported only under permit and for which global quotas are determined from time 4 The local sale proceeds of South A fr ican assets, including South A fr ican securities, owned by residents of Botswana must be credited to a Securities Rand Account. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution to time. These account for about 4.6 per cent in value of 1976 imports. (4) Goods which may be imported only under permit and for which specific permits authorizing the import of these goods individually are issued. They cover some 8.5 per cent of 1976 imports. Since August 2, 1976 most imports for home con­ sumption are subject to a rand deposit of 20 per cent of the f.o.b. price, payable to the Controller of Customs and Excise at the time of customs clearance.1 The deposit, which may be financed abroad, is transferred to the Reserve Bank and is refunded, without interest, by the Bank six months after it is lodged. Exemptions include crude petroleum and certain petroleum products, government imports, certain goods imported for use in exports, goods exempted by the Secretary for Industries as essential capital goods for new projects, goods imported exclusively for re-export in their original form to a country other than Botswana, Lesotho, and Swazi­ land, and goods valued at R 100 or less. Provided that licensing regulations are respected and upon presentation to his bank of the necessary consign­ ment documents (proof of importation), an importer is automatically granted exchange to pay for the import. Payments prior to the date of shipment or dispatch are not normally allowed except for certain capital goods, and provided that the terms are normal in the trade concerned. Payments for Invisibles There are no restrictions on payments and transfers for current international transactions. A ll payments to nonresidents of the Rand Monetary A rea for current invisibles require exchange licenses. Au thor i ty is, how­ ever, delegated to the authorized dealers to approve cer­ tain payments without limitation and others up to estab­ lished limits. F or current income payments, such as declared dividends, profits, royalties, etc., that accrue in South A f r i c a, approval is given by the authorized dealers without reference to the Reserve Bank, provided that the relative royalty agreement was approved by the Department of Industries and the Reserve Bank and the profits or dividends to be remitted by nonresident- owned branches and subsidiaries are based on profits earned since December 31, 1959 and their remittance does not involve the use of local credit facilities. Favor­ able consideration is, however, given by the Reserve Bank to such transfers where the use of local credit facilities is not regarded as excessive. Income derived from securities acquired with blocked funds or securities rand or otherwise held by nonresidents is freely trans­ ferable at the official market rate of exchange to the owner's country of residence. L im i ted amounts of exchange to pay for membership fees, family mainte­ nance, etc., are authorized. 5 The import deposit scheme was discontinued on February 2, 1977. S O U TH A F R I CA The basic allowance for tourist travel in a year is R 2,000 for an adult and R 800 for a ch i ld under the age of 12. Separately, there is another annual basic exchange allocation of R 500 for an adult (R 200 for a child under 12) for travel to Ango la, Botswana, M a l aw i, Mozambique, Rhodesia, Zaire, and Zambia. Applications for larger amounts are considered on their merits by the Reserve Bank. In addition to the tourist allowances, authorized dealers may grant allowances for business trips overseas at a rate not exceeding R 100 a day, with a maximum of R 3,000 in a calendar year. The applicable allowance for business trips to the neigh­ boring territories mentioned above is R 500 a year. Residents leaving South A f r i ca for destinations outside the Rand Monetary A rea may take out not more than the equivalent of R 200 in banknotes. South A f r ican Reserve Bank notes, however, may not exceed R 50 but are not regarded as being part of the basic travel allow­ ance. Foreign visitors leaving South A f r ica within 12 months after arrival may take with them up to R 50 in Reserve Bank notes and any amount of foreign notes which they brought into the country or obtained from the disposal of instruments of exchange that they brought to and exchanged in South A f r i c a. These l im i­ tations on the export of Reserve Bank notes do not apply in the case of Bantu returning to neighboring countries, who are permitted to take with them reason­ able amounts in the form of banknotes representing their earnings in South A f r i c a. There are no limitations on the export of domestic currency to Lesotho and Swaziland. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of commodities considered as being in rela­ tively short supply, or for which domestic prices are substantially lower than those obtainable overseas, require licenses irrespective of destination (with the exception of exports to Botswana, Lesotho, and Swazi­ land ). Certain other goods are controlled for strategic reasons only, and permits are required for their export to a ll destinations but no import certificate is required where the goods are exported to the Un i ted K ingdom, any Commonwealth country, any Br i t ish colony, pro­ tectorate, or trust territory, or the Un i ted States. The re-export of imported goods to countries outside the Rand Monetary A rea other than Botswana is controlled to prevent commodity and exchange arbitrage. Unless otherwise permitted, all export proceeds must be remitted to South A f r i ca and surrendered within six months from the date of shipment and seven days from the date of collection. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered within seven days from the date of their acquisition, unless exemption is obtained. Upon entry from countries out­ side the Rand Monetary A r e a, residents and nonresidents may bring in R 50 in South A f r ican Reserve Bank notes. 405 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution S O U TH A F R I CA There are no limitations on the import of domestic cur­ rency from Lesotho and Swaziland. Capital6 A ll inward loan transfers require specific approva l ,7 while inward transfers in respect of equity capital are freely permitted. Foreign exchange accruing to residents from capital transfers and transactions must be surren­ dered. Outward transfers of capital by residents to destinations outside the Rand Monetary A rea require the approval of the South A f r ican Reserve Bank and are usually not allowed; transfers to Lesotho and Swaziland do not require prior approval. Local borrowing by nonresident-owned or nonresident-controlled firms is subject to limitation. Transfers by residents for the pur­ chase of South A f r ican (or other) shares on external stock exchanges are generally not permitted (except in amounts not exceeding R 2,000 for each shareholder, to allow South A f r ican residents to exercise rights arising from existing holdings of shares in foreign companies quoted only on foreign stock exchanges), although South A f r ican stockbrokers may engage in arbitrage transactions in securities, subject to certain conditions designed to prevent any net outflow of exchange. A p p l i­ cations by South A f r ican residents to retain in, or transfer to, neighboring territories (this term excludes Lesotho, Swaziland, and Transkei) funds for bona fide long-term investment in specific development projects or for the expansion of existing projects that are owned or controlled by South Africans are considered by the South A f r ican Reserve Bank and the Treasury on their merits. Authorized dealers may allow their customers to transfer monetary gifts and loans up to R 100 for each applicant during a calendar year to persons nor­ mally resident outside South A f r ica or to South Afr ican residents temporarily overseas for the sole purpose of study. For three years after their arrival in South A f r i c a, immigrants (excluding former South Afr ican residents) may dispose of their foreign assets (including foreign cash funds) held outside the Rand Monetary Area or otherwise invest them (including by purchase of South Afr ican securities abroad). The proceeds from the sale of all South Afr ican securities brought in by immigrants must be credited to Securities Rand Accounts; the restriction on the free use of such funds locally is nor­ mally for the first three years of the immigrant's resi- For exchange control purposes, a nonresident is defined as a person whose normal place of residence or domicile is outside the Rand Mone­ tary A r ea. Securities are defined as including not only quoted stocks, shares, debentures, and rights, but also unquoted shares in public com­ panies, shares in private companies, government, municipal, and public utility stocks, nonresident-owned mortgage bonds and /or participations in mortgage bonds, and National Savings Certificates. The terms scrip and share certificates include any temporary or substitute documents of title, such as letters of allotment, option certificates, balance receipts, and any other receipts for scrip. 7 Approval is generally given for borrowing abroad with a maturity of at least six months by domestic entrepreneurs, except for property development, speculation, or consumer credit. Authorized dealers gen­ erally are permitted to raise funds abroad in their own names for the financing of South A fr ican foreign trade and other approved purposes. 406 dence, but may be removed freely (except for former South A f r ican residents) on amounts up to R 20,000 or, subject to Reserve Bank approval, on additional amounts, to enable the immigrant to set up a home and to meet current l iv ing expenses. The proceeds of the sale of South Afr ican securities by nonresidents of South A f r ica to residents must be credited to Securities Rand Accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). The following payments related to nonresident capital may be carried out by the authorized dealers without reference to the South A f r i­ can Reserve Bank: transfers to nonresidents of South A f r ica of the proceeds on maturity of government, municipal, and public utility bonds and national savings certificates (except those issued on October 1, 1974), provided that they were registered in the name of the nonresident transferee (who was not an emigrant) on June 16, 1961, or, if the stocks were acquired after June 16, 1961, provided that they were registered con­ tinuously in the beneficial owner's name for a period of not less than five years to redemption: normal capital repayments to nonresidents of South A f r ica by certain "dy ing" mines in regular periodic installments not exceed­ ing in any one year 10 per cent of the nominal value per share: transfers to nonresident owners of any balance of up to R 50 left over from the reinvestment of securities rand balances; and transfers of up to R 20,000 to a non­ resident beneficiary from the proceeds of legacies from estates in South A f r ica that hold no foreign assets. Emigrant families whose net assets do not exceed R 20,000 may have R 10,000 transferred outside South A f r ica as a settling-in allowance, and those with greater assets may have 50 per cent of their assets, up to R 30,000, transferred; any balance exceeding the permis­ sible transferable amount must be credited to a Blocked Account, and the value of any foreign assets is deducted from the applicable settling-in allowance. Emigrants may, however, utilize such blocked funds up to an amount of R 30,000 a family unit to subscribe to the five-year nonresident bonds issued by the Government on a tender basis (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). The South A f r ican Reserve Bank approves transfers of repayments at maturity to nonresident holders of mort­ gage bonds registered in their names on or before June 16, 1961. Favorable consideration is given for the transfer by nonresident-owned branches and subsidiaries of open or approved loan account balances or undis­ tributed current profits, or for the transfer of any divi­ dends by them, provided that the remittance does not involve the excessive use of local credit facilities. The physical export from South A f r ica of nonresident-owned securities is permitted, except by emigrants in excess of their settling-in allowance. Gold Residents of South A f r i ca may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in South A f r ica for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents of South A f r i ca other than the monetary authorities, authorized dealers, registered gold producers, and authorized industrial and profes­ sional users are not allowed to purchase, ho ld, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. A ll exports of gold require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank; the approval authority has been delegated to authorized dealers in respect of exports of jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler (subject to a written declaration to the effect that the jewelry w i ll be brought back to South A f r i ca on the traveler's return) and in respect of exports of gold jewelry by manufacturing jewelers (except for exports to Botswana, Malawi, Rhodesia, and Zambia) subject to a written declaration that the articles are in fully manufactured form and that the gold content of each does not exceed 75 per cent of the selling price to the ultimate consignee. Furthermore, authorized dealers may, without reference to the Reserve Bank, allow residents to export for numis­ matic purposes currency coins, including gold coins, up to R 300 for each applicant during a calendar year; they may also allow residents to export one Krugerrand coin during a calendar year to a nonresident in lieu of a monetary gift. The gold mining industry must sell its output to the Reserve Bank, within one month of produc­ tion, except for sales effected on the industry's behalf in the free market. The M i nt from time to time strikes gold coins without a face value (Krugerrand) that are legal tender but do not circulate freely in South A f r i ca as currency; these are made available in limited numbers to resident co l­ lectors, while the bulk is sold abroad. Imports of gold are confined mainly to coins for numismatic purposes and to certain types of jewelry. Changes during 1976 February 2. The Minister of Finance and the Minister of Economic Affairs issued a joint statement announcing the imposition of a temporary import deposit scheme, with effect from August 2. Acco rd ing to a proclamation gazetted on July 23, a deposit of 20 per cent, calculated to the nearest rand of the f.o.b. price, was payable on all goods imported into the Republic of South A f r ica and cleared with effect from August 2, 1976, except in respect of those categories of goods specifically exempted. The deposit was payable to the Controller of Customs and Excise at the time of direct entry of the goods for home consumption or entry for storage in a customs and excise warehouse. No interest was paid on such deposits, which would be repaid to the importer after a period of six months by the Reserve Bank. The exemptions were as follows: (1) M ine ral fuels, mineral oils and products of their distillation, bituminous substances, and mineral waxes; (2) state importations and certain other goods specified in the proclamation and entered in terms of Schedule N o. 4 to the Customs and Excise A c t, 1964; (3) any goods the f.o.b. price of which exceeded R 10,000 and in respect of which there was at the time of entry furnished to the Controller a certificate, issued by the Secretary for Industries, declaring that the goods were essential capital goods or equipment required in connection with the carrying out of a development project for purposes other than replacement of existing goods or equipment; (4) goods imported exclusively for re-export in their original form to a country other than Botswana, Lesotho, or Swaziland; (5) goods the f.o.b. 408 price of which amounted to R 100 or less; and (6) goods imported into or destined for Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland, on the presentation of a certificate issued by the responsible authorities in those countries. August 2. Authorized dealers were permitted, without reference to the Reserve Bank, to allow those of their import customers who were unable to raise the necessary finance locally, to borrow funds abroad to enable them to meet their commitments under the import deposit scheme. The loans had to be for a minimum period of six months and the interest rates had to be reasonable in relation to the current market rates; the Reserve Bank would not approve early repayment or the provision of forward exchange cover (Exchange Con t rol Circular N o. B .175 ). August 12. Residents of Lesotho and Swaziland ceased to be regarded as nonresidents for purposes of securities control. Accord ing ly, authorized banks could, upon application to them, cancel the restrictive endorse­ ment on South A f r ican securities owned on August 12, 1976 by residents of Lesotho and Swaziland, provided that they satisfied themselves that the securities were not acquired outside the Rand Monetary A rea after June 16, 1961. Subject to the same conditions, securities rand balances held by residents of Lesotho and Swaziland could be released (Exchange Con t rol C i rcu lar N o. B.176). August 12. Fo l low ing the announcement by Botswana of its withdrawal from the Rand Monetary Area and the introduction on August 23 of its own national currency, authorized dealers were advised that, with effect from August 23, a ll currency transactions between residents of the Republic of South A f r i ca and residents of Bo­ tswana would be governed by the South A f r ican exchange control rulings. Certain amendments to the rulings would become effective on that date. The definition of the Rand Monetary A rea was modified by the deletion of Botswana. A new type of rand account, Botswana Accounts, was introduced; these were defined as the accounts of persons, firms, or companies (including banks) resident, domiciled, or registered in Botswana. A new definition of securities was provided. It was stated that numerous further alterations to the rulings would be necessary. It was announced that authorized dealers had to com­ ply with the following procedures with effect from August 23: (1) Accounts of residents of Botswana with authorized dealers and building societies had to be redesignated as Botswana Accounts; while balances on the latter would be transferable to Botswana, they would not be convertible into any foreign currency other than the pula. (2) The local sale proceeds of South African assets (including South A f r ican securities) owned by residents of Botswana must be credited to Securities Rand Accounts. (3) Au thor ized dealers would be advised in due course of arrangements regarding the repatriation of South A f r ican Reserve Bank notes and pula notes. Not for Redistribution SPAIN (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0126953 gram of fine gold per Spanish Peseta. Spain avails itself of wider margins. The official intervention limits for the U . S. dollar have been suspended since January 22, 1974. The official buying and selling rates of the Bank of Spain on Decem­ ber 30, 1976 were Ptas 68.188 and Ptas 68.388, respec­ tively, per US $ 1. Official buying and selling rates for specified curren­ cies 1 are fixed daily by the Bank of Spain acting in con­ sultation w i th the authorized banks. Purchases and sales of clearing currencies are centralized in the Bank of Spain, which publishes the rates at which it settles the transactions it carries out direct. These rates are the same as the prevailing rates for the U . S. dollar. The Bank of Spain also quotes buying and selling rates for banknotes in specified foreign currencies on a weekly basis. Au thor ized banks are allowed to operate in foreign markets for spot and forward transactions related to commercial operations for up to 360 days; forward transactions with customers are restricted to currencies admitted to the M a d r id foreign exchange market and to permitted import and export transactions with a maturity up to 360 days. Exchange Control Territory The Peninsular Territories of the Spanish State, the Canary Islands, the Balearic Islands, Ceuta, and M e l i l la constitute a single exchange control territory. Administration of Control The guidelines on foreign exchange policy are formu­ lated by an interministerial commission. The M in is try of Commerce is in charge of all administrative functions connected with exchange control. The Bank of Spain is in charge of the operative functions (basically, the handling of the external reserves). It is also responsible for the authorization of foreign currency loans to resi­ dents for nontrade purposes. Trade controls are administered by the M in is try of Commerce. The M in is t ry also is in charge of the con­ trols over Spanish investment abroad, private Spanish lending abroad, foreign financing of trade, and the regis­ tration of foreign investments in Spain. Contracts deal­ ing with technology must be registered with the M in is t ry of Industry. Prescription of Currency Settlements on account of merchandise transactions and invisibles other than those with bilateral payments 1 Austr ian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Dan ish kroner, deutsche mark, F inn ish markkaa, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U . S. dollars. 4 10 agreement countries may be made in any specified cur­ rency ,1 but in practice they are usually made in the currency of the country of origin or destination. Settle­ ments w i th bilateral payments agreement countries2 are made through agreement accounts expressed in U .S. dollars. Nonresident Accounts There are six types of nonresident accounts: Foreign Accounts in Pesetas for Payments in Spain (A Accounts), Foreign Accounts in Convertible Pesetas (B Accounts), External Accounts in Internal Pesetas, Nonresident Accounts in Convertible Foreign Currencies, Bank Accounts in Pesetas w i th Ando r ra, and Emigrants' Accounts. A Accounts may freely be credited with (1) the countervalue in pesetas of convertible currencies sold on the Spanish foreign exchange market; (2) amounts transferred from other A Accounts; (3) amounts trans­ ferred from B Accounts; and (4) any interest payable on the account concerned. These accounts may freely be debited for (1) any payment in pesetas in favor of Spanish jur id ical persons and Spanish or foreign physical persons legally resident in Spain (including payments relating to foreign investment in Spa in); and (2) trans­ fers to other A Accounts. Debits for the purchase of foreign currency for remittance abroad are not per­ mitted. B Accounts may freely be credited with (1) any peseta collections generated in Spain that under existing rules are transferable abroad under powers delegated to authorized banks; (2) amounts transferred from other B Accounts; and (3) any interest payable on the account concerned. The crediting of amounts originating from A Accounts is prohibited. B Accounts may be freely debited for (1) the countervalue in pesetas of foreign currency acquired on the Spanish foreign exchange market; (2) any payments in pesetas in favor of Spanish juridical persons and Spanish or foreign physical persons legally resident in Spain, including those relating to foreign investment in Spain; (3) transfers to other B Accounts; and (4) transfers to A Accounts. A ll other entries on A or B Accounts require the prior authorization of the M in is t ry of Commerce. Private banks are required to make special noninterest- bearing deposits in cash at the Bank of Spain, in an amount equivalent to 100 per cent of the increases after October 18, 1971 in nonresident-held deposits in A and B Accounts (demand deposits, savings account deposits, or time deposits at less than three months' notice), and in an amount equivalent to 50 per cent of the increases in such deposits when held for three months or more (100 per cent of any increase after February 7, 1973). 2 Co lomb ia and Equator ial Gu inea. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Furthermore, banks are prohibited from paying inter­ est on any nonresident-held peseta deposits in A or B Accounts, whether demand, time, or savings deposits. External Accounts in Internal Pesetas are designed to hold funds accruing in Spain to nonresidents that are not transferable abroad ("blocked pesetas"). Balances are freely negotiable between nonresidents holding such accounts; if the recipient of pesetas does not hold an account of this type, he needs prior approval to open one. These accounts may be credited freely with (1) the full proceeds of the sale by a nonresident to a resident of Spanish real estate originally acquired with pesetas from an External Account in Internal Pesetas; (2) the full proceeds of the sale by a nonresident to a resident of Spanish shares and fixed-interest securities that have been acquired w i th pesetas from an External Account in Internal Pesetas and have been held for less than three years consecutively by the same owner;0' (3) with receipts from the Na t ional Lottery; (4) with any non­ transferable wages, salaries, pensions, rents, or dividends accruing to the account holder; (5) with interest received on balances held in these accounts; and (6) with trans­ fers from any other External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. They may be debited freely for (1) payments of any amount of personal expenses in Spain of the account holder and his close relatives (managers' per­ sonal expenses if the account is opened in the name of a juridical person); (2) the purchase of shares quoted on the stock exchange and of Spanish fixed-interest securities; (3) the purchase for the use of the account holder (provided that the account holder is a nonresi­ dent physical person) of urban and rural properties that do not represent investment for commercial, industrial, or agricultural purposes (applicable to rural properties only if the account holder is of Spanish nationality); (4) the purchase of Na t ional Lottery tickets; and (5) transfers to any other External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. A ll other entries on these accounts require prior authorization and the accounts may not be over­ drawn. Nonresident Accounts in Convertible Foreign Curren­ cies may be held by nonresident foreign nationals, non­ resident Spanish nationals, and nonresident firms or banks: resident foreign nationals may maintain such accounts only if opened before January 1, 1968. The deposits may be either sight or time. The accounts may be credited with convertible currencies quoted in the Spanish exchange market and with any amount of interest. They may be debited freely for reconversion into the currency in i t ia l ly deposited, for the purchase of other convertible currencies quoted in the Spanish exchange market, and for conversion into pesetas, including the transfer to an A Account. Overdrafts are prohibited except for mail credits in favor of foreign banks. ;! The proceeds of such securities that have been held for at least three years consecutively are transferable abroad. SPAIN Emigrants' Accounts—Since October 29, 1970, com­ mercial banks have been authorized to open savings accounts in convertible pesetas for Spaniards working abroad. Imports and Import Payments A ll imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Most imports are admitted under the following arrangements: (1) free imports, (2) global quotas, (3) state trading, and (4) individual licensing, also referred to as the "bilateral import regime." A ll imports require either an import license or an "import declaration" issued by the Directorate-General of Tariff Po l icy and Imports. P ro­ vided that import prices are not considered abnormal, import declarations are issued freely for a large number of goods (mostly foodstuffs not under state trading, raw materials, capital goods, and spare parts, but also some consumer goods) included in an import free list that applies to most countries with which Spain has no bilateral payments agreements; the free list also applies to specified imports from Iran and Japan .4 A ll other imports require licenses. There are global quotas for specified imports from countries to which the free list applies, but licenses are usually granted for larger amounts.5 W i th certain excep­ tions, the global quota regime also applies to goods of Japanese origin. Licenses for imports from Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Po land, Romania, and the U .S .S .R. are issued freely. Imports of raw cotton, cer­ tain other agricultural products, some raw materials, petroleum products, and tobacco are state traded; some goods formally listed as being subject to state trading, such as feedgrains, may in fact be freely imported by private traders. Imports of certain agricultural products that are free of quantitative restriction and previously were state traded are subject to variable import levies. Import subsidies are paid on certain foodstuffs and speci­ fied other essential commodities. Exchange in the appro­ priate currency to pay for authorized imports is granted freely. Except for capital goods, suppliers' credit for imports is not normally permitted to exceed 90 days. A ll import transactions must be domiciled with an autho­ rized bank, and the import payment must be made through the intermediary of the bank of domiciliation; exempt from domiciliation are transactions whose value is less than Ptas 500,000 provided that payment is to be made within one year. F or a large proportion of invisibles, the banks are autho­ rized to sell foreign exchange freely, provided that the request is supported by appropriate documents. F or certain services, transfers may be made freely up to a pre-established amount; for transfers which exceed that amount licenses are required which are granted at the discretion of the Government. Holders of Spanish securities (excluding securities issued by private companies and acquired through direct subscription) may freely transfer abroad accrued inter­ est, dividends, and proceeds from the disposal of sub­ scription rights; the securities must have been purchased w i th convertible pesetas, with pesetas resulting from the sale of foreign exchange quoted in the Spanish foreign exchange market, or with pesetas released from External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. Profits and dividends on direct investments are also transferable abroad without restriction. Rents on nonresident-owned real estate are transferable, provided the purchase price has been paid in full and the owner has no outstanding tax liabilities applicable to the property concerned. A general license permits the reinsurance abroad of risks insured in Spain with Spanish firms or with foreign insurance companies operating in Spain. Insurance contracts abroad may not be concluded, except where they concern exports and imports of goods. There is a basic tourist exchange allowance of Ptas 50,000 a person a year; however, amounts in excess of this limit are approved freely for bona fide tourist expenses. The authorized banks are also permitted to sell the equivalent of Ptas 2,000 a day for business trips, up to the equivalent of Ptas 100,000 a person for each trip. F or larger amounts, the banks must apply for approval, which may be granted. Travelers may take with them Ptas 3,000 in notes of the Bank of Spain (Ptas 10,000 for persons going to A n d o r r a ). Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports are subject to prior licensing by the Directorate-General of Exportation. A ll export proceeds must be sold in the exchange market or to the Bank of Spain through authorized banks. Certain agricultural exports are subject to an export tax. Proceeds from Invisibles A ll exchange proceeds from invisibles must be sold in the exchange market or to the Bank of Spain through authorized banks. Travelers may bring in a maximum of Ptas 50,000 in notes of the Bank of Spain. Capital Foreign capital participation in Spanish industries of up to 50 per cent of the capital of the enterprise is exempt from authorization, while investment that exceeds 50 per cent requires the authorization of the 412 Coun c il of Ministers; for participation in public service companies in general, the former ratio is 25 per cent. Special ratios and regulations apply for a number of specific activities.0 Foreign investment in Spanish com­ panies manufacturing capital goods that are listed in the Appendix List of the Customs Code requires registra­ tion only; within 30 days the registration may be deemed an authorization if no notification to the contrary has been received. Foreign investment is not permitted in Spanish enterprises whose activity is directly connected with national defense, while investment in firms dealing with public information and in certain public services is subject to specific regulations. Foreign investment for the purpose of modernizing, expanding, and establishing Spanish enterprises may be effected by transferring currencies that are negotiable in the M ad r id exchange market, by using convertible pesetas, by bringing in capital goods, by reinvesting profits or capital transferable under the Foreign Invest­ ment Law, or by providing know-how, patents, or licenses. A ll contracts dealing with technology require prior registration with the M in is t ry of Industry. Proceeds, including capital appreciation, from the liquidation of foreign direct investments made for the purpose of establishing, modernizing, and expanding Spanish enterprises may be transferred freely. Purchases by nonresidents of shares in most Spanish companies are permitted freely up to the percentages applicable to direct investment. This applies to shares acquired by Spaniards resident abroad, as well as by resident or nonresident foreigners, either with con­ vertible pesetas or with pesetas resulting from the con­ version of foreign currencies negotiable in the Spanish exchange market. Proceeds, including capital gains, from the liquidation of such shares may be transferred abroad at any time, or used for further purchases of shares.7 Purchases by nonresidents of bonds and other fixed-income securities representing debts of either Span­ ish companies or the Spanish Government and its agen­ cies are unrestricted when financed as indicated in this paragraph, and the full sales proceeds are transferable. Investment in Spanish real estate by nonresidents is, within certain l im i t s ,8 freely permitted if financed with <! The foreign content of investment by Spanish companies with for­ eign participation (inversion de cascada) is determined in the follow­ ing manner: (1) if foreign participation exceeds 50 per cent, the investment is considered 100 per cent foreign; (2) if foreign partici­ pation is over 25 per cent but equal to or less than 50 per cent, the investment is considered foreign to the extent of such participation; nevertheless, if foreign investors enjoy a position of dominance, the investment is considered 100 per cent foreign; and (3) if foreign participation is 25 per cent or less or if there is Spanish Government participation, the investment is considered as domestic. 7 However, if the purchase was made with internal pesetas, the owner of the shares must hold them for three years, after which he may transfer the liquidation proceeds abroad. s Purchases of real estate by nonresident physical persons of foreign nationality are freely permitted by a general authorization as follows, if financed with funds imported from abroad: (1) one plot not exceeding 5,000 square meters for one single-family dwelling for per­ sonal use, (2) the land needed for the construction of an apartment building, and (3) up to three apartments in a single apartment build­ ing. There are separate regulations for the purchase of business premises. ©International Monetary Fund. The M in is t ry of Commerce has empowered authorized banks to provide the investor with a document certifying that he owns such pesetas; this is the only requirement for official registration of the change in ownership. Cer­ tain investments in real estate may also be financed from External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. Irrespective of the method of financing, rural properties purchased may not exceed 4 hectares of irrigated land or 20 hectares of unirrigated land. When Spanish real estate is sold to a resident, the full sales proceeds are transferable if the initial purchase was financed with convertible foreign currency or with pesetas from an External Account in Convertible Pesetas, an A Account, or a B Account. If the initial purchase was financed with pesetas from an External Account in Internal Pesetas, no part of the sale proceeds is transferable. Outward capital transfers by residents require approval. Requests by firms to invest abroad in the same line of business are granted rather liberally, pro­ vided that the investment contributes to the expansion of Spanish exports; this includes participation in foreign enterprises. No formal authorization is required for such investments when undertaken by Spanish firms which have been granted an individual "export card" and have net assets in Spain of at least Ptas 100 m i l l ion, provided that the firm's total foreign investments do not exceed 40 per cent of its assets in Spain. Other direct investments are subject to more severe restric­ tions. Portfolio investments by all residents and pur­ chases of real estate abroad by private persons are severely restricted. However, registered investment funds with assets of at least Ptas 1 b i l l ion are permitted to place up to 10 per cent of their assets in foreign securi­ ties that are officially quoted on specified stock exchanges abroad. Approval of requests by nonbank resident firms to grant loans to nonresidents is based on criteria similar to those applied to residents' requests to make direct investments abroad. Suppliers' credits from Spanish residents to nonresidents require authorization by the Ministry of Commerce; such authorization accompanies the export license. There has been no experience with the issuing of bonds in the Spanish capital market by nonresidents, nor with short-term credits granted by Spanish banks to nonresidents other than certain export credits granted directly to foreign importers. Credits to nonresidents for transactions w i th Spain may, however, be authorized by the M in is t ry of Commerce. A l so, authorized banks may extend various types of credit to nonresidents, pro­ vided that this credit is financed with funds deposited in Spain in nonresident convertible currency accounts; some forms of such credit do not require prior approval by the M in i s t ry of Commerce. Local bank credit extended at medium-term or long-term to Spanish firms with foreign participation in excess of 25 per cent is SPAIN subject to special directives, but domestic bank credit for up to 18 months may be granted, irrespective of the degree of foreign participation, on the same conditions as to wholly Spanish-owned firms. For transfers abroad of bona fide inheritances and dowries, authorizations are granted liberally. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Spain for numismatic purposes. W i th this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. By law, only the Bank of Spain is allowed to import or export gold; industrial requirements are met by imports effected by the Bank of Spain. Not for Redistribution SRI LANKA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.149297 gram of fine gold per Sri Lanka Rupee. Since M ay 24, 1976 the official exchange rate for the Sri Lanka rupee has been maintained in terms of a weighted average of currencies. The inter­ vention currency is the pound sterling and the Central Bank of Cey lon fixes the buying and selling rates for the pound sterling from time to time in accordance with this policy. On December 31, 1976, the spot buying and selling rates were SL Rs 14.60875 and SL Rs 14.62375, respectively, per <£ stg. 1. The official exchange rate is applicable to receipts from major exports and to pay­ ments for "A category" imports (rice, wheat flour, fertilizers, Western pharmaceuticals, and certain other imports classified as essential), a well as some invisibles. There is another effective rate which is maintained at a 65 per cent premium over the official rate and for which the spot buying and selling rates on Decem­ ber 31, 1976 were SL Rs 24.10444 and SL Rs 24.12919, respectively, per £ stg. 1. This arises from transac­ tions in Foreign Exchange Entitlement Certificates (henceforth called certificates), which exporters of nontraditional exports (i.e., exports other than black tea, rubber, and major coconut products) and most other earners or recipients of foreign exchange are entitled to receive upon surrender of foreign exchange earned. Nonresident travelers, when converting foreign exchange into Sri Lanka rupees at the official rate, may also receive either corresponding certificates or their cash value in rupees. The certificates are denominated in Sri Lanka rupees and are issued with a face value equivalent at the official rate to the foreign exchange surrendered; they are not transferable and must be surrendered to authorized dealers within 30 days of the date of issue for encashment at a price of SL Rs 65 per SL Rs 100 in certificates. Add i t ional certificates are sold by commercial banks on behalf of the Central Bank upon demand and at the same price; such certificates also are not transferable. Certificates with a face value corresponding at the official rate to the amount of for­ eign exchange required must be surrendered when pur­ chasing foreign exchange for payments in respect of most imports and most invisibles. The commercial banks deal in certificates for up to four months for­ ward with the option to extend a further two months at the discretion of the Ch ief Accountant of the Central Bank at SL Rs 66 selling, and SL Rs 64 buying, per SL Rs 100 certificate; transactions are permitted only when relating to anticipated genuine payments and receipts in foreign exchange to which the certificate requirements or privileges are applicable. The Central Bank deals in U . S. dollars, sterling, and Indian rupees only. Wh i le its spot rates for sterling are fixed, the Central Bank determines exchange parities for some 20 other foreign currencies, including the U . S. dollar, from time to time on the basis of London market rates for those currencies. Rates for other foreign cur­ rencies are determined by commercial banks, also on the basis of London market rates. On December 31, 1976 the Central Bank's spot buying and selling rates for the U .S. dollar were SL Rs 8.7160 and SL Rs 8.7185, respectively, per US $ 1. The Central Bank stands ready to provide forward cover to commercial banks (1) in U . S. dollars, sterling, and Indian rupees, buying and selling; and (2) under the Asian Clearing Un ion arrangements, in Bangladesh taka, Indian rupees, Iranian rials, Nepalese rupees, Pakistan rupees, and Asian monetary units, buying and selling. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Department of Exchange Con trol of the Central Bank as agent of the Government. A foreign exchange budget, including an import program, is drawn up annually by the M in i s­ try of Planning and Economic Affairs. This M in is try is responsible for the exchange allocations for government departments and public corporations. W i th in a block allocation to private sector importers, licenses for the industrial sector are issued by the Ac tual Users D iv is ion of the M in is t ry of Industries and Scientific Affairs. Otherwise, import and export licensing is handled by the Controller of Imports and Exports. A ll remittances of foreign exchange in Sri Lanka must normally be made through commercial banks authorized to carry out operations in foreign currencies in accordance with the exchange control procedures prescribed by the C o n­ troller of Exchange. Remittances may also be made through post offices, under permits issued by the Con­ troller of Exchange. Prescription of Currency Settlements with countries with which Sri Lanka has bilateral payments agreements 1 and with Egypt must be made through the relevant special accounts. Pay­ ments in respect of trade with Pakistan also are effected through special accounts. Payments to, and receipts from, member countries of the As ian Clearing Un ion other than Pakistan (i.e., Bangladesh, India, Iran, and Nepa l) in respect of current transactions (other than those relating to petroleum, natural gas, and their prod­ ucts) must be effected in As ian monetary units or in the currency of a member of the As ian Clearing U n i o n; for settlements with Pakistan, this is applicable to invisi­ bles only. 1 People's Republic of Ch ina, Syrian A r ab Republic, and U . S . S .R. 415 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SRI L A N KA For settlements with all other countries (except Rho­ desia) the following applies. Payments for imports may be made in any foreign currency, i.e., any currency other than the Sri Lanka rupee. Other payments may be made either in the currency of the country to which the pay­ ment is due or by crediting Sri Lanka rupees to an External Rupee Account. Proceeds from exports must be received in designated foreign currencies.2 Other receipts may be accepted in Sri Lanka rupees from an External Rupee Account or in any designated foreign currency .2 Transactions involving deviations from the general procedures require the prior approval of the Controller of Exchange. Special procedures apply to settlements with Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident Accounts may be held in Sri Lanka by banks, corporations, or persons residing abroad. The remittance abroad of balances in these accounts requires approval by the Controller of Exchange. Blocked Accounts are used for holding funds that have not been permitted to be transferred abroad, usually funds owned by nonresidents, repatriates, and emigrants. Such funds, unless they originate from payments for imports, may be used in Sri Lanka for certain invest­ ments, subject to the prior approval of the Controller of Exchange. Proceeds from the liquidation of such invest­ ments must be credited to Blocked Accounts. A l so retained in Blocked Accounts is a proportion of local currency earnings, derived from the exhibition of foreign-owned films, if the takings exceed the amount specified in the import license; such retained funds may be used by the owner for certain specified purposes, including the making of films in Sri Lanka. Special Accounts may be maintained in Sri Lanka by nationals of Sri Lanka working abroad. Credits to the accounts are limited to the proceeds of remittances from abroad (inclusive of the value of the certificates to which the holder is entitled) but the accounts may be freely debited for payments within Sri Lanka. Balances in such accounts are exempt from wealth tax, and income arising from investments made out of such balances with the approval of the Controller of Exchange is exempt from income tax; the value of such investments is also exempt from wealth tax. Imports and Import Payments A ll imports of goods originating in or shipped from Rhodesia are prohibited. Except for imports by the Food Commissioner's Department and certain minor imports (such as trade samples, gifts of up to SL Rs 750, and books up to certain specified amounts for each con­ signment), all imports require individual licenses. 2 Australian dollars, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Japanese yen,. Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U . S. dollars. 416 A ll trade imports are subject to quota restrictions. They are divided into two groups—the A category and the B category. Imports in the A category broadly com­ prise basic necessities, Western pharmaceuticals, fertil­ izers, books and periodicals, and two-wheeled tractors. The B category includes all remaining imports. The value and composition of imports are established by an annual import program. Imports of many nonessential items or goods similar to locally produced items are either not permitted or considerably restricted. The right to import is restricted to government depart­ ments, government-sponsored corporations, and regis­ tered importers, although private individuals are allowed to import certain commodities for their own use, subject to special authorization. Imports of specified commodi­ ties ,0> are restricted to government or state corporations or the Cooperative Wholesale Establishment; these com­ modities are referred to as "reserved items." In order to allocate foreign exchange, applicants for import licenses are divided into three groups: (1) actual users of indus­ trial raw materials, machinery, etc., (2) those who import other goods for their own use and not for resale, and (3) established importers who import goods for trading purposes. Public sector imports shipped or transshipped from places served by vessels of the Ceylon Shipping Corporation must be carried in vessels owned or chartered by the Corporation, whenever such ship­ ping space is available. Holders of funds in Convertible Rupee Accounts may use these for certain imports, including items otherwise not permitted, subject to approval by the Controller of Imports and Exports. An authorized dealer may approve an application to remit foreign exchange or to credit a Nonresident Account when the applicant furnishes or undertakes to furnish evidence of importation and the cost of the goods and produces a valid importer's copy and an exchange control copy of the import license. Payment for imports in the B category requires, in addition to the rupee equivalent of the foreign exchange involved, surrender of certificates with a face value equal to the rupee pay­ ment; imports in the A category do not require the sur­ render of certificates. Import licenses for certain imports (primarily food products, industrial raw materials, and machinery) may be subject to a minimum deferred payment term. Letters of credit against such licenses may be opened provided that drafts are drawn payable either not earlier than 6 months after shipment or 12 months after shipment, in accordance with the terms of the import license. :! These include mainly rice, wheat flour (except corn flour), un­ refined sugar, refined sugar, "Ma ld ive fish," dried fish, cumin seed, masoor dhal, dried chilies, coriander, pulses, yeast and baking powder, garlic, fennel seed, mathe seed, turmeric, dates, sultanas and raisins, cement, fish meal, corn, caustic soda, cotton yarn, newsprint and other paper products, petroleum products, and textiles and manufactures of textile materials. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Payments for Invisibles A ll payments for invisibles require exchange control permission and, with certain exceptions, require sur­ render of certificates corresponding to the full amount of the foreign payment. Exempt from surrender of certificates are (1) expenditures for certain approved courses of study abroad; (2) remittances abroad by nonnationals for family maintenance, up to certain limits; (3) provident fund contributions and life insur­ ance premiums which commenced prior to the introduc­ tion on May 6, 1968 of the certificate scheme; (4) pen­ sions and the final remittance, on retirement, of pension and provident funds, contributions to which commenced prior to M ay 6, 1968; (5) expenditures of foreign embassies, official international organizations, and for­ eign diplomatic personnel; and (6) other expenditures abroad specifically exempted from the certificate sur­ render requirement by the Controller of Exchange. The remittance of life insurance premiums on policies in foreign currencies purchased by nonnationals resid­ ing temporarily in Sri Lanka is permitted, and such policies are considered as part of the assets available to them on repatriation. Foreign exchange for personal travel abroad is granted only for emigration, the taking up of employment abroad, and furloughs of nonnationals. Business travel is generally limited to travel for the promotion of exports and of tourism, and exchange up to a maximum of £ stg. 15 a day for persons of the rank of chairman or director of a firm or corporation ( SL Rs 150 a day for travel to the As ian G roup of Countries) 4 and of £ stg. 10 a day for other executives ( SL Rs 100 a day for the A s ian G roup of Countries) for a maximum period of 30 days is allowed in such cases. Exchange for educational expenses is allocated only for certain courses of study that w i ll be of positive value to the country and that are not available in Sri Lanka; allocations are subject to the approval of the Minister of Finance, acting on the personal recommendation of the Minister of Education. F or study in educational institutions in the As ian G r o u p ,4 exchange up to a maxi­ mum of SL Rs 250 a month for undergraduate studies or up to SL Rs 450 a month for postgraduate studies is allowed, as well as SL Rs 250 a year for books plus actual fees. For study in the United K ingdom, foreign exchange is made available at £ stg. 45 a month for undergraduate studies, and at £ stg. 60 a month for post­ graduate studies, plus actual fees, and <£ stg. 25 a year for the cost of books. Fo l low ing the devaluation of the pound sterling in November 1967, students in countries whose currencies were not devalued were allowed supplementary remit­ tances to enable them to receive the same amount as 4 The A s ian Group is listed as Ad en, Afghanistan, the East A fr ican region, Brunei, Burma, Egypt, Hong Kong, India, Indochina, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Ma lays ia, Pakistan, Persian Gu lf Sheikdoms, Sabah, Sarawak, Saudi Arab ia, Syrian A r ab Republic, Thailand, and Turkey.
