F or study in such countries (other than the United States and Canada), the maximum allowable is £ stg. 53 a month for under­ graduate studies and £ stg. 70 a month for postgraduate studies; the maximum for the United States and Canada is US$225 a month and US$240 a month for under­ graduate and postgraduate studies, respectively (in addi­ tion to an annual book allowance and actual fees). For travel (and other expenses) for medical reasons, exchange is authorized if a certificate is produced from a medical specialist in Sri Lanka and supported by the Director of Health Services that equally effective treat­ ment cannot be obtained in Sri Lanka; the amount authorized w i ll depend on the estimated cost, as certified by the specialist. Indian and Pakistani nationals are permitted to remit for family maintenance a maximum of SL Rs 750 a month or one third of their gross monthly income, whichever is less. Other foreign nationals are permitted to remit £ stg. 85 a month for a wife, £ stg. 145 for a boy in a senior school, £ stg. 131 for a girl in a senior school, £ stg. 75 for a boy in a junior school, and £ stg. 90 for a girl in a junior school, up to a maxi­ mum of two thirds of the gross monthly income of the parent; any excess of the total of such remittances over one third of gross monthly income is treated as an antici­ patory transfer against the nonnational's entitlement to remit assets at the time of repatriation. For other depen­ dents, this ceiling is one third of the gross monthly income. When the amount claimed on this basis exceeds one third of the gross monthly income, the excess w i ll be treated as an anticipatory transfer to be set off against the amount the repatriate is entitled to remit upon departure. Temporary residents on short-term contracts are allowed to remit up to two thirds of their gross monthly income. Nationals of Sri Lanka are not granted exchange for family remittances. Commissions up to 5 per cent of the c.i.f. value are allowed on export orders secured through agents abroad. No remittances for insurance on exports are permitted; these must be covered with the Insurance Corporation of Sri Lanka. Holders of funds in Convertible Rupee Accounts may use these funds for travel expenditures and other current invisibles, subject to approval by the Controller of Exchange. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign exchange declared to the customs at the time of entry; they may not take out Sri Lanka currency notes and coins. Resi­ dents may take out foreign currency notes and coins not exceeding the equivalent of SL Rs 50 a person ( S L R s 25 for children under 12) once in 12 months, provided that they have been granted exchange for travel. Subject to the approval of the Controller of Exchange, residents may also export domestic currency notes of a value not exceeding SL Rs 50 a person ( SL Rs 25 for children under 12). 417 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SRI L A N KA Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Permits issued by the Controller of Exchange are required for all com­ mercial exports, and exports to countries with which Sri Lanka maintains bilateral payments agreements are subject to the approval of the Director of Commerce. Furthermore, most exports require an export license issued by the Controller of Imports and Exports; licenses for tea are issued by the Commissioner of Tea Exports and those for coconut products by the Coconut Market­ ing Board. Rubber exports to the People's Republic of Ch ina, Poland, Romania, and the U .S .S .R. are under state trading. The State Gem Corporation has the exclusive right to export gems and jewelry. Private sector exports have to be made with the permission of and through the State Gem Corporation. The Corpora­ tion also handles exports in the names of gem miners who wish to export gems. Re-exports of nonmonetary gold, silver, and diamonds are allowed only in special circumstances. The Controller of Exchange issues a permit for a com­ mercial export when he is satisfied that payment repre­ senting fair value for the goods has been or w i ll be received in Sri Lanka by approved methods of payment and, usually, within six months from the date of ship­ ment. Foreign exchange proceeds from exports must be surrendered. There are special arrangements, however, for gems and nontraditional exports. Exporters may main­ tain accounts, designated Convertible Rupee Accounts, with authorized dealers in Sri Lanka. These may be credited with 20 per cent of the f.o.b. Sri Lanka rupee value (inclusive of certificates) of the net export pro­ ceeds of gems and craftsmanship of jewelry; with 5 per cent of the f.o.b. value in Sri Lanka rupees (inclusive of certificates where applicable) of nontraditional exports; and with 20 per cent of the f.o.b. value in Sri Lanka rupees (inclusive of certificates) of net export proceeds of original and individual works of art. Debits to the accounts are permitted for imports, travel and study abroad, other payments which are not of a capital nature, and transfers to any other Convertible Rupee Accounts of the same holder. Exporters of all goods other than black tea in bulk and in packets, rubber (excluding sponge rubber), coco­ nut o i l, copra, desiccated coconut, and fresh coconuts are entitled to receive certificates with a face value in Sri Lanka rupees equal to the f.o.b. value of exports, upon surrender to an authorized bank of the foreign exchange actually earned. Exporters who hold certifi­ cates are entitled to purchase foreign exchange to effect payments abroad which come within those categories for which exchange is released and require the surrender of certificates. Certificates have to be deposited or lodged with an authorized bank within 30 days of issue. The holders can use them for making foreign exchange payments within six months from the date of issue; at 418 the end of the six-month period, the validity of the certificate lapses. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered. Receipts under the following headings entitle the recipient to obtain certificates with a face value equivalent to the value of the foreign exchange surrendered to an authorized bank: (1) travel receipts; (2) insurance receipts; (3) investment income; (4) pri­ vate transfers and donations; (5) small savings remitted to Sri Lanka by workers abroad; and (6) miscellaneous other inward remittances as determined, on a case-by- case basis, by the Ch ief Accountant of the Central Bank. Nonresident travelers are eligible to receive certificates corresponding to the amount of foreign exchange converted with authorized dealers; alterna­ tively, the latter may pay the traveler the cash value of the certificate in addition to the rupee equivalent of the foreign exchange sold. Part of the Sri Lanka rupee equivalent of certain proceeds from invisibles may be credited to Convertible Rupee Accounts; this proportion is 5 per cent of gross foreign exchange earnings from tourism, 20 per cent of foreign exchange earnings by individuals from the sale of their original and individual works of art to tourists in Sri Lanka and from the publication abroad of scien­ tific and literary works, 20 per cent of foreign exchange earnings from professional and consultancy services per­ formed abroad by individuals, and 5 per cent of the proceeds from such services performed by firms, com­ panies, etc. A traveler entering Sri Lanka must declare his hold­ ings, including currency notes and coins. The amount of foreign funds that may be carried into Sri Lanka in the form of travel credit instruments is not restricted. The import of Sri Lanka, Indian, and Pakistan currency is not permitted; however, Sri Lanka notes in denomina­ tions of SL Rs 10 or less may be imported up to SL Rs 50, provided that evidence of prior export of such notes by the same traveler is produced. Other currency notes and coins may be taken in without restriction. Capital Investments of foreign capital are permitted in projects which are specifically approved by the Government, or, where the capital is drawn from a Blocked Account in Sri Lanka, in certain investments in Sri Lanka that have been approved by the Controller of Exchange, including shares of public companies incorporated in Sri Lanka; capital transfers for direct investment in Sri Lanka are entitled to receive certificates upon conversion of the foreign exchange into rupees. Proceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments in approved projects other than investments made from Blocked Accounts may be repatriated, along with capital appreciation; transfers require the surrender of certificates. Proceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments not approved by the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Government may not be transferred abroad, but they may be reinvested with the approval of the Controller of Exchange; the current income thereon may be remitted abroad. New foreign investments in Sri Lanka that are considered and approved by the Foreign Investment Advisory Committee of the M in is t ry of Planning and Economic Affairs are also granted special facilities in respect of remittances and taxation. Investments abroad by residents are not normally permitted. Resident-owned securities on which the principal, interest, or dividends are payable (either contractually or at the option of the holder) in any foreign currency must be declared to the Controller of Exchange, and the sale or transfer of such securities is allowed only with the permission of the Controller of Exchange. Emigrants are allowed to purchase foreign exchange up to the equivalent of £ stg. 100 a family for the cost of passage, freight, and other charges, subject to a limit of 25 per cent of the cost of passage and subject to reimbursement within three years; in most cases the purchase of the exchange is subject to surrender of cer­ tificates. They may also export their personal and household effects up to SL Rs 5,000, and their personal jewelry up to SL Rs 7,500. Emigrants over 60 years of age are also permitted remittances of pensions or other income accruing in Sri Lanka up to £ stg. 25 a month. Otherwise, emigrants are not permitted capital remittances except on grounds of dire hardship, nor generally, remittances of income (including pensions) accruing in Sri Lanka. However, certain remittances of income may be approved to persons over 55 who emigrated before June 26, 1973, and pension payments to persons pensioned by government bodies of Sri Lanka who emigrated before 1964 have been continued without interruption, irrespective of the beneficiary's age or income abroad. Repatriates leaving Sri Lanka for residence in the country of their permanent domicile are permitted, at the time of their departure, to transfer assets represent­ ing their retirement funds and a reasonable amount of savings as determined by the Government from time to time. Persons who have been in business in Sri Lanka are allowed to transfer the capital they originally brought into the country plus a reasonable amount of savings, subject to certain limits. The transfer of personal assets and of income thereon requires the surrender of certifi­ cates; exempt are (1) balances on provident and pension funds held abroad and representing contributions in respect of contractual obligations entered into before May 6, 1968, (2) provident and pension funds held in rupees in Sri Lanka, and (3) the value of insurance policies held abroad and taken out before M ay 6, 1968. Special provisions, governed by an agreement between Sri Lanka and India, apply to Indian families returning to India. SRI L A N KA Gold Imports and exports of gold in any form require licenses issued by the Controller of Imports and Exports w i th the approval of the Central Bank. Such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities. The Peo­ ple's Bank is the sole importer of gold; it has not imported any nonmonetary gold since July 1972. It sells gold in small quantities to licensed craftsmen and jewelers and also to hospitals. Commercial imports of jewelry and of other articles containing gold are severely restricted. No credits to Convertible Rupee Accounts are allowed for the gold or silver content of commercial exports of jewelry. Changes during 1976 January J. May 24. The official pegging of the Sri Lanka rupee to the pound sterling was terminated. For the future the exchange rate for the Sri Lanka rupee was to be main­ tained in terms of an appropriately weighted basket of currencies. The intervention currency continued to be the pound sterling. The Central Bank would fix the buying and selling rates for the pound sterling from time to time in accordance with the new policy. The certifi­ cate market rate continued to be at a premium of 65 per cent over the official market rate. June 17. Not for Redistribution SUDAN (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.55187 grams of fine gold per Sudanese Pound. The Sudanese pound is defined by law as having a gold content of 2.115368 grams of fine gold. The effective parity relationship for the U . S. dollar is L Sd 1 = US$2.87156. F ixed official rates for transactions in U . S. dollars are quoted by the Bank of Sudan (the central bank) whose rates for trans­ actions with authorized banks and the government on December 31, 1976 were US$2.867268 buying, and US$2.875877 selling, per L Sd 1. An effective exchange rate of L Sd 1 = US$2 .50 is applied to all exchange transactions other than the purchase of proceeds from exports of cotton, to which the exchange rate of LSd 1 = US$2.87156 continues to apply, as a result of the application of exchange taxes and subsidies of 5.18 piastres per U . S. dollar (i.e., 15 per cent) to the rate of LSd 1 = US$2 .87. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Sudan, much of the detail being carried out by author­ ized banks. The issuance of registration forms and the licensing of imports and exports (except those of gold) are the responsibility of the M in is try of Commerce and Supply, but all registration forms and licenses must be validated by the exchange control authorities (Bank of Sudan). Import payments and other foreign payments are approved within the framework of an annual foreign exchange budget that is drawn up by the M in is t ry of Finance and Na t ional Economy and approved by the Economic Counc il of the Cabinet. Prescription of Currency Transactions with bilateral countries 1 are normally settled through the relevant bilateral account in Sudanese pounds or pounds sterling; however, most noncom­ mercial invisibles except those payable to j i g y p t2 have to be settled outside these accounts. Payments to all other countries and monetary areas (the "convertible area") may be made in Sudanese pounds to the credit of any nonresident account or in any foreign currency, while receipts from the "convertible area" may be accepted in Sudanese pounds from any nonresident account or in any convertible currency. 1 At the end of 1976 the Sudan had bilateral payments agreements with Egypt and India. The agreement with India, however, expired on December 31, and with effect from January 1, 1977 settlements were placed on a convertible currency basis. - Payments to Egypt for gasoline and Suez Canal dues must be made in convertible currencies. A ll other payments are settled through the bilateral account. 420 Nonresident Accounts Foreign diplomats are allowed to maintain accounts in Sudanese pounds designated as nonresident accounts. These accounts must be credited with convertible cur­ rencies. Other foreign personnel working in the Sudan under certain contracts, as well as foreign nationals residing in the Sudan, may maintain resident current or savings accounts in Sudanese pounds. Blocked Accounts are maintained by former residents; earnings accruing to these accounts may be used within the Sudan by the account holder for his personal expen­ ses up to limits established in each case by the exchange control authorities. Except for the crediting of interest, a ll debits and credits to Blocked Accounts require approval. Imports and Import Payments Certain imports are prohibited for protective reasons and others are not being licensed. Imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca also are prohibited. Per­ mitted imports generally are licensed or accepted for registration in accordance with allocations under the foreign exchange budget. Imports of certain consumer goods and commercial trucks are eligible for importa­ tion on a barter basis. Certain imports are permitted only when acceptable foreign financing is obtained. Sugar and wheat are imported by a state agency only. F or goods that require individual licensing, import licenses must be obtained from the M in is t ry of Finance and Na t ional Economy and validated (franked) by the Exchange Con t rol Department of the central bank. " N i l" licenses, wh ich also require franking, are issued for certain imports financed with foreign exchange held abroad by residents and by Sudanese expatriates or officials stationed abroad. Import insurance normally must be taken out with local companies. Most private sector imports are subject to an advance deposit of 2 per cent of the c. & f. value, payable before validation, and a surcharge of 5 per cent is levied on the c.i.f. value of a ll imports; capital goods, heavy trucks, tires and tubes, medicines, spare parts, raw materials for factories, and commodities imported either for government units or on behalf of government departments are exempt from advance deposits. Goods otherwise subject to the advance deposit requirement are exempt when financed with suppliers' credit of at least two years' maturity, provided that the amount of the transaction is at least L Sd 500,000. If a letter of credit is opened, the author­ ized bank usually requires a cash margin of 10 per cent to 30 per cent. In practice, for many goods whose importation the banks are not allowed to finance, a 100 per cent margin deposit must be made. A stamp duty of L Sd 5 is levied on the application form for ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution each remittance in respect of private sector imports. Most imports are subject to a development tax of 3 per cent ad valorem. Payments for Invisibles A ll payments for invisibles require exchange control approval. Remittances are permitted for family main­ tenance (up to L Sd 360 a person a year), educational expenses (up to L Sd 1,200 a student a year for Western Europe, in addition to tuition fees; study in the Un i ted States is exempt from this ce i l ing ), and for certain other purposes. Allowances for tourist travel to countries other than Egypt are authorized by the commercial banks up to a maximum of £ stg. 60 every other year for each adult traveling to Western Europe and the United States, and <£ stg. 40 every other year for travel to other areas. Allowances for nonbusiness travel to Egypt, however, are the equivalent of £ stg. 80 an adult, and £ stg. 30 a ch i ld, a year, and are also authorized by the commercial banks. Exchange for travel must be purchased at an effective exchange rate of LSd 1 = US$2 .50. Sudanese nationals resident abroad who remit foreign exchange to the Sudan for conversion at the rate of LSd 1 = US$2 .50 may at the same rate obtain foreign exchange equivalent to the full amount converted in any one year and use this exchange to make personal remittances abroad. Sudanese Government officials (other than seconded staff) and students receiving educational allowances at the official rate are not entitled to avail themselves of this arrangement. Salaried foreign nationals not permanently resident in the Sudan, except Egyptian nationals, are permitted to remit their bona fide current savings to any country other than Israel, Rhodesia, or South A f r i c a. Shipping charges, insurance premiums, profits, interest, and d iv i­ dends earned by nonresidents may be remitted freely upon presentation of the required documents. The remittance of income accruing from blocked assets in the Sudan (including income from Blocked Accounts) is prohibited, except for earnings from investments in government securities made before 1970. The exporta­ tion of Sudanese currency is prohibited. Stamp duties are payable on the application forms for virtually a ll payments for invisibles. The duty is LSd 5 on applica­ tions for remittances of profits and dividends, for other transfers, and for foreign exchange for business travel, LSd 2 on applications for foreign exchange for tourism, and from L Sd 1 to L Sd 0.25 on applications for remittances for other purposes; government remittances and those by diplomats are exempt. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. W i th the exception of cotton and gum arabic, a ll exports require a license. Exporters must submit an export form to an authorized bank. Except for hides and skins, authorized banks may approve S U D AN these forms only if payment is in the form of cash against documents or against sight letters of credit or if payment takes place in advance; exports on credit require the approval of the Bank of Sudan. A ll com­ modities are subject to minimum export prices. The proceeds of exports must be repatriated and surrendered through an authorized bank. When the terms of pay­ ment are cash against documents or sight letter of credit, proceeds must be surrendered on delivery of the shipping documents; in other cases a surrender date is usually specified. Some major export com­ modities are exported solely by public sector entities. At the end of 1976, the export of some commodities (including durra) was prohibited for supply reasons, and the export of certain others was permitted only when the proceeds were to be received in convertible cur­ rencies. Certain minor exports may be sold on a barter basis or on consignment. Most exports are subject to a development tax of 3 per cent ad valorem. Proceeds from Invisibles Sudanese nationals resident abroad other than govern­ ment officials or students may remit foreign exchange in convertible currencies to the Sudan for conversion at the rate of LSd 1 = US$2 .50, and receive an incentive bonus of 100 per cent per annum which is paid on amounts so transferred to the Sudan and kept in a special account for at least six months;:] the full amount of the remittances so received may be repatriated at the end of the six-month period but in that case the bonus is forfeited and the remittance becomes subject to the prevailing exchange tax. Receipts from abroad in respect of invisibles must be surrendered to authorized banks and are subject to the general prescription of currency requirements. Travelers entering the Sudan may bring in any amount in notes and coins of other countries permitted by their regulations to be taken out of those countries. However, the importation of Sudanese currency is forbidden. Emigrants of Sudanese nationality may on departure transfer up to the equiva­ lent of L Sd 1,500 to their new country. Not for Redistribution SUR INAM1 (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The currency of Surinam is the Surinam Gu i lde r. The fixed official rates for the U . S. dollar are Sur. f. 1.77 buying, and Sur. f. 1.80 selling, per U S $ 1. There are also fixed official buying and selling rates of Sur. f. 1.75 and Sur. f. 1.80 for U . S. banknotes. The rates for other foreign currencies,2 are set daily by the Central Bank of Surinam on the basis of the market quotations for the U .S. dollar and those currencies in Amsterdam and the fixed buying and selling rates for the U . S. dollar in Surinam, net of any commissions. There is no exchange market in Surinam. Administration of Control In principle, a ll foreign exchange dealings are subject to license, as are dealings between residents and non­ residents in domestic currency and other domestic assets. The authority to grant exchange licenses is vested in the Foreign Exchange Board, which has delegated much of this authority and issues licenses mainly for capital transactions and certain invisibles. The Board has authorized the D irec tor of Econom ic Affairs (or, on his behalf, the Head of the Import, Export, and Foreign Exchange D iv is ion of the M in i s t ry of Econom ic Affairs) to issue import and export licenses, and has empowered the Central Bank of Surinam to provide foreign exchange for import payments (subject to presentation of an import license); the latter authority is exercised through the commercial banks, which have all been appointed as authorized banks by the Foreign Exchange Board. The authorized banks are empowered to provide foreign exchange for specified current payments without requir­ ing an exchange license. They may also accept free of license those inward transfers of foreign exchange that do not result from borrowing abroad; the taking up of foreign loans is subject to Foreign Exchange Board approval. Except in the circumstances specified above, the authorized banks are not permitted to sell foreign exchange without requiring the submission of an exchange license by the remitter. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents, whether banks or nonbanks, may freely open accounts in U . S. dollars w i th domestic banks; no overdrafts are permitted. Nonresidents other than banks may freely open accounts in Surinam guilders with domestic banks; certain debits and credits are covered by a general license, while a ll others are subject to a specific license. These accounts must not be overdrawn, and debits for certain specified purposes must not exceed a total of Sur. f. 3,000 a month. Au thor ized banks have also been granted a general license permitting them to open nonresident accounts in Surinam guilders in the name of nonresident banks; these accounts also must not be overdrawn. Nonresident guilders or foreign currency accounts may not be credited w i th Surinam banknotes mailed from abroad or with the foreign currency equivalent. Imports and Import Payments Import licenses are required for a ll imports.4 Some items, such as specified explosives and narcotics, are prohibited for reasons of public policy or health. Imports of a few other commodities are prohibited from n o n -EEC sources for protective reasons and are subject to quota when originating in E EC countries; they include coffee (roasted and unroasted), sugar, powdered m i lk, butter (in packs of 500 grams or less), most worked and unworked wood, and certain metal furniture. The import of pro­ hibited goods may be allowed when there is a need for them, provided that they cannot be obtained in Surinam. Another group of commodities are subject to quota, irrespective of or ig in; these include matches, pre­ fabricated wooden houses, certain women's wear, certain footwear, and certain wooden or cane furniture. Special conditions are attached to the import of copra, rice, butter (in packs of over 500 grams), wheat flour (in packs of over 1,000 grams), veneer, and furniture that is on neither the prohibited nor the restricted list; the import of these commodities also is restricted for protec­ tive reasons but the issuance of licenses is subject to administrative decision rather than to quota. A govern­ ment agency, the Surinam Central Import Service, acts as the sole importer of certain staple foodstuffs. A ll other imports are licensed freely from any source. The import license serves as a payment license, exchange being made available upon presentation of the license. Most licenses have a validity of six months, 4 However, two specified mining companies do not need licenses for their own import requirements. Similar exemptions may be granted to foreign companies for their industrial activities in Surinam, provided that they pay for their imports from their own foreign exchange holdings. 423 ©International Monetary Fund. The commercial banks and the General Post Office have authority to provide foreign exchange up to Sur. f. 150 an item a month on account of certain services (bank charges, legal fees, membership dues, copy and patent rights, and so for th); up to Sur. f. 150 an item a month for advertising expenses and payments for books; up to Sur. f. 300 a year from each remitter in respect of gifts, subject to a l im it of Sur. f. 300 a year on any beneficiary's receipt of gifts from Surinamese residents; and up to Sur. f. 200-300 a month for the support of each member of the remitter's own family in the Netherlands An t i l les or the Netherlands, subject to a l im it of Sur. f. 600-900 a month for a family unit (family remittances up to the same amounts to other countries require a license, which is granted upon application). The basic exchange allowance to residents for travel is Sur. f. 750-2,500 a person for each trip (50 per cent of these amounts for children under 14), depending on the destination; 5 the authorized bank must enter on the travel ticket the amount of foreign exchange sold and the date, the purchase of travel exchange not being permitted until three days before departure. Travelers may take out Sur. f. 100 in Surinam currency. The export by resident travelers of foreign banknotes (includ­ ing Netherlands currency) is limited to the amount of their travel allowance. Nonresident travelers may freely purchase and take out foreign currency up to the equiva­ lent of Sur. f. 250. Nonresident travelers may also freely take out any foreign banknotes they brought in, provided that amounts in excess of Sur. f. 5,000 were declared upon entry. Payments due as interest on loans and as net income from other investments, and payments of moderate amounts for amortization of loans or depreciation of direct investments, may be made if an application sup­ ported by an auditor's report is duly presented to the Foreign Exchange Board for verification. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports require export licenses, which for most com­ modities are issued freely, provided that the exporter undertakes to surrender the foreign currency proceeds to an authorized bank within six months of shipment. Export licenses for cattle and pigs, fresh beef and pork, and planting materials are granted only after favorable advice of the Director of Agriculture, A n im al Husbandry, and Fisheries. The export of baboonwood is restricted and that of rice is subject to special regulations. Certain exporting companies have received special permission from the Foreign Exchange Board to maintain current accounts in foreign currency with their parent com­ panies abroad and to use these for specified payments and receipts (including export proceeds). Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to an authorized bank. Travelers may bring in foreign currency without l im i t, and up to Sur. f. 100 in domestic currency; resident travelers must surrender any foreign currency in excess of the equivalent of Sur. f. 500. Capital A decision of September 21, 1960 of the Foreign Exchange Board provides for the transfer abroad of capital proceeds from the sale to residents or the liquida­ tion of fully or partly foreign-owned companies or other forms of enterprise. The decision covers investments made by nonresidents with foreign capital after July 31, 1953. It also provides for the annual transfer of profits and for the transfer at any time of the foreign exchange (including loans) imported by the nonresident entre­ preneur for the company's use. Profits must be trans­ ferred within a period of three years; otherwise, they are considered to have become part of the firm's working capital or to have been lent to the firm, and may only be transferred in annual quotas of 20 per cent. An Investment Law passed on February 3, 1960 provides for additional incentives to private investment in Surinam. The Foreign Exchange Board grants licenses on application for transfers abroad from a deceased's estate, up to a maximum of Sur. f. 25,000. F or estates of more than Sur. f. 25,000, further annual transfers are per­ mitted so as to spread them over a period not exceeding ten years. The Board allows emigrants (heads of family) to transfer in foreign exchange the equivalent of Sur. f. 5,000 in a lump sum, and subsequently Sur. f. 5,000 a year. The head of a repatriating family is permitted to transfer the equivalent of Sur. f. 10,000 plus 10 per cent of his total taxable earnings in Surinam accrued during his period of residence; if his Surinamese assets exceed the sum thus calculated, the excess may be transferred at a rate of Sur. f. 10,000 a year, or at a higher rate when this is necessary to ensure that the entire balance is released w i th in ten years. Subject to certain requirements, residents may pur­ chase or sell in specified countries 0 Surinamese cor­ porate shares that have been designated as negotiable by the Foreign Exchange Board. Loca l ly produced gold must be surrendered to the Foreign Exchange Board by sale to the Central Bank at Sur. f. 2,110 a kilogram fine for bars of at least 10 kilograms or at Sur. f. 1.80 a gram for unworked gold with an average smelting loss of 6 per cent and an average gold content of 9 4 (M o o o .7 Au thor ized gold buyers are permitted, however, to sell nuggets at freely agreed prices to the public for industrial and artistic purposes; dealings between residents in gold bars and other forms of unworked gold, with the exception of nuggets, are prohibited. As local production does not meet demand for industrial purposes, the Central Bank imports some gold, which it sells to authorized gold buyers. A gold coin w i th a face value of Sur. f. 100 is legal tender. Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Surinam for numismatic and investment purposes; authorized banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents. Residents other than the monetary authorities, producers of gold, and authorized industrial and dental users are not allowed without special permission to hold or acquire gold in any form other than nuggets, jewelry, or coins, at home S U R I N AM or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require exchange licenses 8 issued by the Foreign Exchange Boa rd; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports of coins by authorized banks, and for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities, producers of gold, and industrial users. Residents arriving from abroad, however, may freely bring in gold, subject to declaration, and provided that they surrender it to the Central Bank within 20 days. Nonresident travelers also may freely bring in gold, subject to declaration; they may re-export the declared amount freely. Imports of gold coins are duty free and those of unworked gold are subject to a duty of Sur. f. 0.0375 a gram, irrespective of origin. The general tariff for gold ornaments is 60 per cent ad valorem, but those of E EC origin are subject to duty at 50 per cent ad valorem. Imports of a ll forms of gold are subject to a statistical fee of 1.5 per cent and a licensing fee of 0.5 per cent. Changes during 1976 July 16. Surinam acceded to the Lome Convention. October 1. Not for Redistribution SWAZILAND (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange and Trade System No par value has been established for the currency of Swaziland, the Lilangeni (plural emalangeni), but a central rate of E 1.00 = R 1.00 has been established. On December 31, 1976, the Monetary Au thor i ty of Swaziland quoted a middle exchange rate for the U . S. dollar of US$1.1500 per E 1 and buying and selling rates are held within a range of VA of 1 per cent on either side of that middle rate although Swaziland avails itself of wider margins. Exchange rates for other currencies are based on the fixed rate for the U . S. dollar against emalangeni which is identical with the South A f r ican Reserve Bank's rate for the U . S. dollar against the rand, and the London market rates for the currencies concerned against the U .S. dollar. Swaziland forms part of the Rand Monetary A rea which is a single exchange control territory comprising Lesotho, South A f r i c a, and Swaziland. The Monetary Au thor i ty of Swaziland, on behalf of the M in is t ry of Finance and Economic Planning, controls all external currency transactions; transactions with residents of Rhodesia, or involving Rhodesian currency, are pro­ hibited. No restrictions are applied to payments within the Rand Monetary A r e a, and in principle these are un­ controlled. In relation to countries outside the Rand Monetary A rea, Swaziland applies exchange controls that are generally similar to those of South A f r i c a, although Swaziland's treatment of certain capital trans­ fers to countries outside the Rand Monetary A rea may be more liberal. Payments to nonresidents for current transactions, while subject to control, are not normally restricted, but applications for most outward transfers of capital are considered on their merits. The rulings on applications for inward and outward capital transfers may depend on whether the applicant is a temporarily resident foreign national, a nonresident, or a resident. Au tho r i ty to approve some types of current payments is delegated to authorized dealers up to established limits; this is true, for example, of the basic exchange allowance for tourist travel (the equivalent of R 2,000 in a calendar year for an adult and R 800 for a child) and a smaller annual allocation for travel to neighboring countries. There are no bilateral payments arrange­ ments. Holders of blocked emalangeni may purchase five-year nonresident bonds, the maturity proceeds of which are transferable, five years after purchase, to the currency area of which the holder is a resident. Swaziland is a member of a customs union with Botswana, Lesotho, and South A f r i c a, and there are no import restrictions on goods originating in any country of the customs union. Imports from South A f r ica do not require licenses and include an unknown quantity of goods originating outside the customs union. Insofar as Swaziland imports goods direct from countries outside the customs union, such imports are usually licensed in conformity with South Afr ica's import regulations. Import licenses are va l id for a ll countries and entitle the holder to buy the foreign exchange required to make the import payment. Certain exports are subject to licensing, mainly for revenue and similar reasons, but most exports are in the first instance shipped free of license to or through South A f r i c a. Changes during 1976 August 12. South A f r i ca ceased to regard residents of Lesotho and Swaziland as nonresidents for purposes of securities control. 426 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SWEDEN (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.171783 gram of fine gold per Swedish K r o n a. Sweden avails itself of wider margins. Margins of 2lA per cent are maintained for spot rates in the official exchange market between the Swedish krona and the Belgian franc, the Danish krone, the deutsche mark, the Luxembourg franc, the Netherlands guilder, and the Norwegian krone; the Sveriges R iks- bank's official buying and selling rates for these curren­ cies correspond to a central rate of S Kr 5.55651 = SDR 1. No announced margins are maintained for other currencies. On December 30, 1976 the buying and sell­ ing rates of the authorized banks for the U . S. dollar were S Kr 4.113A and S Kr 4.13^4, respectively, per US $ 1. Authorized banks may buy from and sell to other authorized banks any foreign currency on a spot basis against another foreign currency or Swedish kronor. Also, they may purchase, spot, from foreign banks and other nonresident foreign currencies against any foreign currency or Swedish kronor credited to a Regular Account (see section on Nonresident Accounts, be low). They may sell to foreign banks and other nonresidents foreign currencies spot against any other foreign cur­ rency or Swedish kronor debited to a Regular Account. The acquisition by foreign banks or banking firms of kronor on Regular Accounts is subject to limitation. Authorized banks may conclude with residents other than banks forward exchange transactions covering cur­ rent payments and authorized payments for periods not exceeding (1) 24 months in respect of receipts for exports, freight, and charter services; (2) 24 months in respect of payments for imports, freight, and charter services; (3) 12 months in respect of repayment of loans abroad for refinancing of credits granted in Swedish kronor in connection with Swedish exports; and (4) 6 months in respect of other receipts and payments. Forward exchange transactions covering payments under (1) and (2) above may be allowed for periods exceed­ ing 24 months if a purchase and a sale in the same cur­ rency correspond as regards amount and approximate value date. Authorized banks may under certain condi­ tions conclude forward transactions for a period not exceeding 12 months with foreign banks. Such transac­ tions between banks may, however, be for periods exceeding 12 months if made in cover of forward trans­ actions with residents. Fo rwa rd market rates are left to the interplay of market forces. Sweden formally accepted the obligations of A r t i­ cle V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Board's decisions may be appealed to the Board of Directors of the Riksbank. Authorized banks and some other authorized agencies implement the exchange con­ trol regulations. A ll current payments (as defined in Sweden's exchange control legislation) are exempt from exchange control, provided that they are made through the intermediary of an authorized bank in accordance with the currency prescriptions issued by the Riksbank. The authorized banks have been granted general licenses giving them power to approve various payments that are subject to exchange control. Import and export licenses, when required, are issued by the Board of Commerce, except those for foodstuffs, which are issued by the National Agr icu l tural Marke t ing Board, and those for gold and gold alloys, which are issued by the Riksbank. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from foreign countries may be made in any foreign currency or in Swedish kronor through any Regular Account (see section on Nonresident Accounts, be low). Nonresident Accounts There are two main types of nonresident accounts held in Swedish kronor with authorized banks in Sweden: Regular Accounts and Restricted Accounts. Other non­ resident accounts are Foreign Exchange Accounts and K ronor Accounts for Nonresidents Dom ic i led in Sweden. Regular Accounts may be held by residents of all countries. These accounts may be credited with trans­ fers from other Regular Accounts, with authorized payments to foreign countries by residents of Sweden, and with sales of any foreign currency. They may be debited for transfers to any other Regular Account and for authorized payments to residents of Sweden, and they may be exchanged into any foreign currency. The credit­ ing of Regular Accounts with proceeds from sales of foreign currencies or with transfers from other Regular Accounts may not result in the creation of abnormal balances. Regular Accounts do not normally bear interest. Restricted Accounts are held mainly by persons who had been residents of Sweden but became nonresidents after emigrating. The accounts may be credited with interest accrued to, and earnings from, assets in Sweden, proceeds from sales of assets in Sweden owned by the account holders, and funds transferred from abroad. Balances in Restricted Accounts may be used for pay- Administration of Control Exchange controls are administered by the Sveriges Riksbank through its Exchange Con t rol Bo a rd .1 The 1 The Exchange Control Board has 7 members, except when matters affecting direct investment abroad are to be dealt with, in which case it has 11 members. Foreign Exchange Accounts2 are held in foreign currencies. Such accounts may be credited with autho­ rized payments in foreign currencies due to the account holder and with accrued interest. Balances on such accounts may be used for making authorized payments in foreign currencies to a resident. A Foreign Exchange Account may also be credited with transfers from abroad of foreign currencies, or transfers from Regular Accounts or from other Foreign Exchange Accounts. A Foreign Exchange Account may be debited for transfers to any nonresident account. Balances on Foreign Exchange Accounts may be sold to an authorized bank against any other foreign currency or Swedish kronor. Kronor Accounts for Nonresidents Domiciled in Swe­ den may be maintained by banks and may be credited with payments in Sweden in favor of an account holder and with accrued interest; they may be used for with­ drawals in kronor in Sweden. Imports and Import Payments A ll imports are prohibited when originating in or shipped from Rhodesia. W i th the exception of a few agricultural and fishery products and of specified types of footwear, practically all goods are free from quantita­ tive restriction and import licensing when imported from countries other than (1) Japan and (2) A lban ia, B u l­ garia, the People's Republic of Ch ina, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, No r th Ko rea, Mongo l ia, Poland, Romania, the U .S .S .R ., and V iet N am. Most imports from countries in the second group are also liberalized. Some imports from Japan require licenses. Imports from the Republic of Ch ina of certain textiles are subject to specific licensing arrange­ ments. Imports from some countries and territories (Hong Kong, India, the Republic of Ko rea, Macao, Ma lays ia, M a l t a, Pakistan, Portugal, Singapore, and Thailand) of certain textile products are regulated through special arrangements. In addition, imports of certain footwear are subject to global quota restrictions. Imports from all sources of specified textiles and garments are subject to import licensing for surveillance purposes. Payments for imports, including normal advance payments, may, as current payments, be made without permission through authorized banks and without the formality of presenting an import license. If the condi- - Residents may also maintain Foreign Exchange Accounts in foreign currencies. Such accounts may be credited with authorized receipts in foreign currencies and with interest and debited for authorized pay­ ments in foreign currencies. However, deposits made and interest accrued after June 18, 1974 must be credited to noninterest-bearing accounts. 428 tions specified for current payments (see section on Payments for Invisibles, below) are not met, an exchange control permit is required. Importers are permitted to utilize foreign commercial credits, provided that these do not exceed what is regarded as customary in the trade. Payments for Invisibles The exchange control regulations define and list those categories of payments abroad which are considered as current payments. Persons domiciled in Sweden may make such payments without restriction in favor of per­ sons domiciled abroad. The payments must be made through authorized banks in order to ensure that capital payments are not made in the guise of current payments. Payments not exceeding the equivalent of SKr 1,000 that are made abroad for any purpose do not have to be verified by authorized banks; however, if they constitute partial payments of a capital nature, the approval of the Riksbank is required. L ife insurance premiums in excess of S Kr 1,000 a person a calendar year require the approval of the Riksbank; such approval is normally given freely in respect of both existing and new insurance policies. F or tourism, recreational travel, or study abroad, resi­ dents may acquire and take out freely up to SKr 6,000 a trip in Swedish and foreign banknotes and coins and other means of payment; applications for additional amounts must be submitted to the Riksbank and are given liberal treatment. Authorized banks and other authorized agencies may allocate to residents, without restriction, exchange for business travel abroad. The export by travelers of Swedish banknotes in denominations larger than S Kr 100 is prohibited. With this exception, nonresidents leaving Sweden may export freely Swedish and foreign banknotes and other means of payment which they brought into, or duly acquired in, the country. No traveler may, however, without specific permission take out of Sweden more than S Kr 6,000 in Swedish banknotes and coins. Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports except ships, scrap metals, and arms are exempt from license if payment is to be received in conformity with the general regulations (see section on Prescription of Currency, above); however, all exports to Rhodesia are prohibited, and exports of specialty steel to the Un i ted States are subject to license. Proceeds from exports of goods do not have to be surrendered; they may be kept in a foreign currency account with a Swedish authorized bank and used by the holder to make authorized payments abroad, or they may be sold to an authorized bank against Swedish kronor. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles are subject to the same treat­ ment as those from exports (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, above). ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Each person entering Sweden may bring in up to SKr 6,000 in Swedish banknotes ( in denominations of SKr 100 or less) and coins and unlimited amounts of other means of payment. Capital Direct investment abroad by Swedish residents requires individual authorization, which normally is granted only if the investment is considered to promote exports or otherwise to be favorable from a balance of payments point of view. Au thor iza t ion may be conditional on foreign financing with an average maturity of at least five years. F inanc ing abroad is, however, as a rule not required for investments in sales companies and other companies which give rise to exports from Sweden, investments involving relatively small amounts, or invest­ ments in countries that are the main recipients of Swedish development assistance. Residents may, on application, transfer capital abroad to purchase, for recreational purposes, real estate valued at no more than S Kr 125,000 for each family, subject to certain limitations regarding the cost of the lot, and the time allowed for building on it. A Swedish resident when emigrating is permitted to transfer up to S Kr 100,000, subject to verification by the Riksbank; after one calendar year (beyond the year of emigration), he w i ll normally be permitted to transfer the remainder of his assets. When Swedish residents emigrate to engage abroad in activities of limited dura­ tion, applications for transfers in excess of the initial SKr 100,000 are considered in a restrictive manner. Transfers on account of inheritances that are due to nonresidents are permitted. Au thor ized banks may freely approve payments abroad in respect of various cate­ gories of remittances, including those in respect of gifts and support payments up to S Kr 2,000 for each transfer. Residents are permitted to accept capital receipts from abroad on account of life, pension, and annuity con­ tracts; contractual amortization of their investments; the sale of foreign securities, real estate abroad, and personal property held by them abroad; and gifts and inheritances. Residents may accept other kinds of capital receipts from abroad only upon approval from the Riksbank. Residents who wish to receive loans or credits other than normal suppliers' credit from nonresidents must receive authorization to do so; each case is considered on its merits. Borrowing abroad for periods of at least five years to finance industrial investments in Sweden that are considered to be favorable from a balance of payments point of view is normally permitted. The Riksbank also permits exporters to cover their normal suppliers' credits through foreign borrowing. Suppliers' credit granted by Swedish shipyards may be refinanced abroad even if it serves to finance sales of ships to Swedish shipowners. Swedish importers can also be granted permission to take up credit abroad to finance contemplated imports. Borrowing by way of suppliers' SW E D EN credit is not controlled, and other borrowing to finance imports is approved where the borrowing itself and the repayment terms are in conformity with commercial practice in the trade concerned. In this context, autho­ rized banks are upon application permitted to extend to the foreign counterpart of a Swedish exporter or importer credit intended to finance certain specified import and export transactions, and to refinance such credit through a corresponding foreign borrowing. Permission for the financing of the export and import transactions men­ tioned above requires that the credits conform to normal commercial practice. Residents are not normally per­ mitted to extend financial loans to nonresidents. Under certain conditions, authorized banks may be granted permission to borrow abroad at long term for purposes of on-lending to residents who have received permission to borrow abroad. Foreign-owned companies in Sweden usually are per­ mitted to borrow at long term from the parent com­ panies. Generally, the repayment of foreign credits at any date other than that specified in the contract requires a new authorization from the Riksbank; such authoriza­ tions are granted restrictively. Permission is needed for the issuance of bonds and shares in Sweden by non­ residents; bond issues in favor of other Scandinavian countries and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development have been admitted when the state of the Swedish capital market and the balance of payments were considered to allow them. Foreign direct investments in Sweden require authori­ zation, which normally is given, provided that not more than 50 per cent of each individual investment (minor investments excepted) is financed with domestic credit. The transfer of the liquidation proceeds of such invest­ ments, including appreciation, requires authorization, which is always given. Nonresidents' purchases of real estate in Sweden for recreational purposes are to some extent exempt from the restrictions on foreign direct investments. In such cases a resident may, without authorization, both receive payment from and grant credit to a nonresident. Ex is t ing loans connected with the estate may, when older than one year, be transferred to the nonresident. Furthermore, banks are permitted to assist in the financing of the purchase with a new loan of up to S Kr 25,000. Investment by nonresidents in Swedish real estate always requires approval according to regulations other than exchange control regulations. Residents do not need authorization to sell portfolio holdings of foreign securities to nonresidents. The pur­ chase of listed, as well as unlisted, foreign securities by residents from nonresidents, requires authorization. As a rule, such authorization is not granted. However, authorized banks and stockbrokers may by virtue of a general license purchase from nonresidents, on behalf of residents, listed foreign securities and listed Swedish securities denominated in foreign currencies with the proceeds from sales to nonresidents of Swedish-held 429 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SW E D EN securities denominated in foreign currencies, provided that the purchase is made within six months of the corresponding sale. Residents may without authorization buy foreign securities and Swedish securities denomi­ nated in foreign currencies from other residents. A general license permits the repurchase abroad of listed Swedish securities expressed in Swedish kronor, provided that an affidavit can be produced showing either (1) that at no time during the last five calendar years have the securities been owned by a person domi­ ciled in Sweden, or (2) that the securities have been acquired with the permission of the Swedish exchange authorities from a person domiciled in Sweden. The affidavit is not required when the securities are registered with the Securities Register Center. The authorized banks and stockbrokers may, by virtue of a general license, handle purchases by nonresidents of listed Swedish securities expressed in Swedish kronor when payment is to be made in the form of other similar securities (switches), provided that (1) the foreign seller and buyer is the same person in each case; (2) the afore-mentioned affidavit requirements are met or the securities are registered with the Securities Register Center; (3) foreign holdings of bonds are not exchanged for shares; and (4) not more than three months pass between the date of the purchase from and the date of the sale to the foreign party. The export of securities owned by nonresidents other than Swedish emigrants is not restricted. Ceilings are placed on the net foreign exchange hold­ ings of each authorized bank and the types of assets have been listed which the banks may hold within their foreign exchange limits. The ceilings for commercial banks have been fixed so as to enable them to carry out their foreign business. Banks may grant only normal overdrafts to nonresidents. They may incur foreign exchange l iab i l i­ ties, but may not maintain a net liability in any one cur­ rency. Th is, together with the permission to pay interest on foreign exchange deposits held by nonresidents, enables the banks to borrow foreign currency from non­ residents for on-lending (but not in the form of kronor) to foreign banks. Swedish banks may not borrow abroad freely in order to sell the proceeds against Swedish kronor in the market, but under certain conditions they may be granted permission to borrow abroad to relend in Sweden (see above). Nonresidents' holdings of kronor in Regular Accounts must not be "abnormal," and, with minor exceptions, they cannot earn interest. Gold G o ld in any form may be held, purchased, and sold within Sweden. Imports and exports of gold and gold alloys require licenses issued by the Riksbank; the types of gold affected are unmanufactured gold, most types of semimanufactured gold, and gold coins (except coins imported by or on behalf of collectors or collections). 430 Import licenses are normally granted to jewelers, dental laboratories, and users of gold for industrial and scien­ tific purposes, as we ll as to persons and firms importing for resale to these categories of users. As a general rule, no licenses are issued for the import of gold to be held on private account. Commercial imports and exports of articles containing gold, such as jewelry, may be made freely without a license. The same applies to imports and exports of gold coins of numismatic value and intended for collectors or collections. Changes during 1976 January 1. Not for Redistribution SW ITZERLAND1 (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The gold content of the Swiss Franc as established by Decree of the Federal Counc il on M ay 9, 1971 is 4% io (= 0.21759) gram of fine gold. The "central rate" for the U . S. dollar fixed on December 20, 1971 was Sw F 3.84 = US $ 1. The gold parity of the Swiss franc has not been altered accordingly. On January 23, 1973, the Swiss Na t ional Bank suspended until further notice its intervention in the exchange market and no announced margins have since been maintained in the market for any currency, although intervention occurs from time to time. The market rate for the U . S. dollar on December 31, 1976 was Sw F 2.4505 per US $ 1. A ll settlements may be made freely at free market rates. Foreign banknotes are negotiated freely in Switzerland at rates determined by the interplay of supply and demand. Exchange Control Territory F or a ll purposes of import and export the Pr inc ipa l i ty of Liechtenstein is included in the Swiss customs terri­ tory for the duration of the treaty of M a r ch 29, 1923 between Switzerland and the Pr inc ipa l i ty of L i e ch­ tenstein concerning the union of the Pr inc ipa l i ty of Liechtenstein with the Swiss customs territory. F or purposes of capital control, natural or juridical persons (including banks) domiciled in the Pr inc ipa l i ty of Liechtenstein are generally considered by Switzerland as residents,2 except in respect of the acquisition of Swiss real estate. F or purposes of the Federal Law on Banks and Savings Institutions, however Liechtenstein is considered a foreign country. Administration of Control The authority to impose measures for the control of imports, exports, and payments is vested in the Swiss Federal Counc il acting, as a rule, on the proposals of the Federal Department of Pub l ic Economy or the Federal Po l i t ical Department. The Swiss Na t ional Bank is the executive authority in matters of currency. Prescription of Currency Settlements may be made or received in any cur­ rency. Imports and Import Payments A ll imports from Rhodesia require a license; licenses are not granted in excess of the average volume of imports for 1964, 1965, and 1966. W i th minor excep­ tions, imports into Switzerland from other countries may be made freely. The only commodities subject to license irrespective of their origin are certain agri­ cultural products and certain fuels. Import permits for goods still under license are, in general, granted freely, but global quotas are established for certain agricultural products. Imports of textiles from specified countries are subject to price surveillance or price certification. Payments for imports from all countries may be made freely through the free market. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles may be made freely. The export of Swiss and foreign banknotes is free. Exports and Export Proceeds The export (including re-export) of some goods is subject to export control through individual licenses. This export licensing system is operated in part with the assistance of appropriate trade organizations. Export proceeds are freely disposable. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles are freely disposable. The import of Swiss banknotes is free while that of foreign banknotes is restricted to the equivalent of Sw F 20,000 a person for each period of three months.3 Capital Transfers of capital may be made freely, with the exception mainly that bank credits and other bank lend­ ing to nonresidents, when exceeding Sw F 10 million each and w i th a maturity of 12 months or more, require permission. This applies, inter alia, to foreign issues in Switzerland of bonds and to direct participations by Swiss banks in Eurobond issues. Furthermore, all proposed first placings of medium-term negotiable paper (notes, certificates of deposit, etc.) in amounts of Sw F 3 m i l l ion or more must be submitted to the Na t ional Bank for examination. In addition, issues in Switzerland of foreign bonds (but not the issue of notes) denominated in Swiss francs are subject to a ceiling. A ll capital exports denominated in Swiss francs and licensed by the Na t ional Bank (bond issues, placings of notes, and other loans and credits, except export credit) must be converted into foreign currency at the Na t ional Bank. Issues by foreign issuers of debt instru­ ments expressed in Swiss francs and having a maturity of less than 12 months are discouraged. The same applies to foreign bond issues denominated in Swiss francs in amounts below Sw F 10 m i l l i o n .4 1 Switzerland is not a member of the International Monetary Fund. 2 For details see the Federal Ordinance on the application of the Measures for the Protection of the Currency in respect of the Prin­ cipality of Liechtenstein. 3 This restriction was terminated with effect from May 1, 1977. 4 Liechtenstein is considered a foreign country for the application of some regulations, namely, those based on the Law on Banks and Savings Institutions, which does not extend to banks in Liechtenstein. 432 ©International Monetary Fund. Na tural or jur id ical persons having their domicile or registered office in Liechtenstein are considered nonresidents for purposes of the acquisi­ tion of Swiss real estate. The definition of the terms ''foreigner" and "foreign funds" is not the same under all types of capital control regulations. The physical importation and exportation of Swiss and foreign securities are unrestricted. Borrowing from nonresidents, whether in domestic or foreign currency, by resident natural and jur id ical persons other than banks requires the prior approval of the Na t ional Bank, wh ich is not normally granted. The principal exemptions from this licensing require­ ment are for borrowing corresponding to customary credit terms for current commercial transactions and for credits up to Sw F 1 m i l l ion, if taken up in foreign currency, used entirely abroad, and not con­ verted into Swiss francs. In addition, approval is normally granted for borrowing from relatives abroad. Banks are subject to reserve requirements against the growth and the level of external liabilities (liabilities both in Swiss francs and in foreign currencies); the reserve requirements are different for, on the one hand, deposits made between July 31, 1971 and October 31, 1974, and on the other hand, deposits made after the latter date.0 Banks are not permitted to pay interest on Swiss franc deposits (including "fiduciary" or "trustee" funds) received from nonresidents; however, savings accounts and similar accounts are subject to preferential treat­ ment. Banks must charge a commission ("negative interest") of 10 per cent a calendar quarter on a ll net increases after October 31, 1974 in nonresident-held Swiss franc deposits, irrespective of maturity; increases up to Sw F 100,000 are exempt from this commission .7 The banks have agreed to inform the Swiss Na t ional Bank of spot and forward transactions exceeding US$5 million; they must report their foreign exchange turn­ over involving Swiss francs (except when the daily turnover is less than S w F 15 m i l l i o n ). They are required to at least balance daily their overall foreign exchange position, as well as their position in each currency separately, short positions in foreign currency being prohibited. Banks are required to report monthly their forward positions. The Na t ional Bank is empowered to block in noninterest-bearing deposits, for an indefinite period of time, the Swiss franc counterpart of its spot purchases in the exchange market; these powers have not been invoked. Banks and finance companies must report monthly their "dealer positions" in foreign cur­ rencies (their own assets and liabilities in foreign currencies, spot and forward). Internationally active firms in Switzerland have agreed to report monthly to the Na t ional Bank their expected transfers of earnings and capital during the following month and may be required to report once a year their repatriation poten­ tial (i.e., their foreign currency placements with maturities of up to six months). Purchases of real estate in Switzerland by or on behalf of persons or firms of foreign nationality who are domiciled or resident abroad require approval by the canton where the property is situated. Such per­ mission is also required for the acquisition of real estate by foreign natural persons who have been resident in Switzerland for less than five consecutive years, unless they have been granted a residence permit. The approvals of the cantons are subject to supervision and appeal by the Confederation. Gold Swiss gold coins are not legal tender. Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form at home or abroad; domestic transactions are not subject to any sales or turnover tax. There is a free gold market in Zu r ich. Imports and exports of gold in any form by residents and nonresidents are unrestricted and free of license; however, the import of gold known or suspected to come from Cambodia or V iet N am is prohibited. No customs duties or other charges are levied on exports of gold.
