However, unless specifically included among the permitted debits to Rhodesian Accounts, all commercial payments, except those in respect of exports, due from persons resident in Rhodesia to residents of the Un i ted K ingdom must be received either in a foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) or, with the specific permission of the Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Accoun t; authorized payments for exports from the Un i ted K ingdom to Rhodesia must be received in advance of shipment in a foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency, or, w i th the specific approval of the Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Accoun t. Persons normally resident in Rhodesia who are l iv ing temporarily in the Un i ted K ingdom as students or workers may open Temporary Resident Accounts in sterling with authorized banks in the Un i ted K ingdom; debits to such accounts are generally permit­ ted only for living expenses within the United K ingdom. Nonresident Accounts The sterling accounts of residents of other Scheduled Territories are treated in the same way as those of resi­ dents of the Un i ted K ingdom. Thus, for transfers between Scheduled Territories no U . K. exchange control permission is required; for payments to other countries by residents of any Scheduled Territory, the authorized banks are required to ensure that the payment has the approval of the exchange control authority in the terri­ tory concerned. External Accounts. W i th the exception of Rhodesian Accounts and the Rhodesian Special Account (see be low), the sterling accounts of nonresidents with authorized banks in the Un i ted K ingdom, i.e., those of residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories, are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with authorized payments by residents of Scheduled Territories, with transfers from other External Accounts, with the proceeds from sales of gold or for­ eign currency other than Rhodesian currency (including banknotes), and with sterling banknotes mailed from outside the Scheduled Territories. External Accounts may be debited, subject to general or special permission, for payments to residents of the Scheduled Territories, for transfers to other External Accounts, for transfers to Rhodesian Accounts other than in payment for certain goods exported from Rhodesia, for payments in cash in the Un i ted K ingdom, and for purchases of any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency (including banknotes) or gold. Rhodesian Accounts. These accounts are applicable to residents of Rhodesia only. Permitted credits include transfers from External Accounts, provided that the bank has no reason to believe that the payment is for a purpose prohibited by the Southern Rhodesia (Un i ted U N I T ED K I N G D OM Nations Sanctions) (N o. 2) Order 1968; payments by residents of Scheduled Territories other than the Un i ted K ingdom to residents of Rhodesia, subject to the approval of the exchange control authority in the terri­ tory concerned; and payments by U . K. residents to residents of Rhodesia in respect of (1) the sale of foreign currencies other than Rhodesian currency, (2) the dis­ count or maturity proceeds of U . K. treasury bills, (3) permitted imports from Rhodesia which have entered customs in the Un i ted K ingdom, (4) insurance and freight charges resulting from permitted trade between Rhodesia and any Scheduled Territory, (5) insurance claims directly related to such permitted trade, (6) pen­ sions and widows' annuities where associated with the deceased husband's employment, (7) charges and fees relating to patents, designs, and trademarks registered in Rhodesia, Zambia, or M a l aw i, (8) maturity proceeds of certain endowment insurance policies, and (9) expen­ diture in gathering news material. Permitted debits include transfers to the Rhodesian Special Account in respect of pensions and widows' annuities; payments for l iv ing expenses in the Un i ted K ingdom of persons resident in Rhodesia and their families; authorized purchases of U . K. sterling securities to be held for the account holder; purchases in the United K ingdom of treasury bills to be held for the account holder; payments to residents of the Scheduled Territories for (1) interest on and repayment of outstand­ ing personal loans, advances, and overdrafts granted before November 11, 1965, (2) patents, designs, trade­ marks, and royalties, (3) distributions from Rhodesian estates and trusts, and (4) subscriptions to newspapers and other periodicals; and payments to U . K. residents for (a) expenses arising out of property in the Un i ted K ingdom owned on or before November 11, 1965, (b) taxes, (c) l iv ing expenses, educational fees, and incidental expenses, (d) insurance premiums and capital and annuity payments on personal policies taken out on or before November 11, 1965, (e) medical fees, (f) gifts and maintenance not exceeding £ 2 50 for any one pay­ ment, to individuals and religious, medical, educational, and charitable organizations, and subscriptions to such organizations, (g) contributions to pension funds pro­ vided the person was a member of the fund before November 1 1, 1965 or before taking up residence in Rhodesia after that date, and (h) bank and safe custody charges. Payments in respect of educational and medical expenses in Rhodesia also are permitted. Transfers between Rhodesian Accounts and from Rhodesian Accounts to External Accounts are not normally allowed. Suspense Accounts. Unless eligible for credit to Rhodesian Accounts or to the Rhodesian Special Account, payments to persons resident in Rhodesia must be withheld unless the Bank of England directs otherwise; the funds may be placed on Suspense Accounts and, except with specific permission, may only be (1) used to meet U . K. tax payments and safe custody 469 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U N I T ED K I N G D OM charges due on the monies in question, (2) used within specified limits for l iv ing expenses in the Un i ted K i n g­ dom of residents of Rhodesia and certain other personal payments, or (3) placed on deposit with banks or other financial institutions in the name of the U . K. resident by whom they are held. Permission is given for residents of Rhodesia to use Suspense Account monies to pur­ chase U . K. sterling securities on a recognized stock exchange in the Un i ted K ingdom and to purchase U . K. treasury bills and savings bonds and certificates. Permis­ sion is only given for them to purchase Rhodesian or foreign currency securities, however, when the funds for the purchase are derived from the immediate sale pro­ ceeds of other Rhodesian or foreign currency securities, respectively. The Rhodesian Special Account. This is an account operated by the Rhodesia Pensions Office staff in L o n­ don and maintained with the Standard Bank, London. Pensions and associated payments due to beneficiaries in Rhodesia from residents of the Scheduled Territories and the O SA, and pensions due from Rhodesia to resi­ dents of the United K ingdom, the Republic of Ireland, and most parts of the OSA are normally settled through this account. Corresponding transfers from Rhodesian Accounts in the names of individuals to the Rhodesian Special Account are freely permitted. Permission is not normally given for payments of any other nature to be credited to the Rhodesian Special Account. Subject to specific approval by the Bank of England, any balance on the Special Account may be used to meet educational payments in the United K ingdom, the cost of permitted exports to Rhodesia from the Scheduled Territories and the O SA, and of services provided by residents of the Scheduled Territories and the OSA for account of per­ sons resident in Rhodesia. Imports from countries other than Rhodesia are admitted under an Open General Import License with­ out restriction, w i th the following exceptions as at the end of 1976: (1) from all other countries, seven com­ modities or groups of commod i t i e s ;15 (2) from the Do l lar A rea only, two commodities or groups of com­ modities; (3) from Japan only, certain textiles; (4) from the n o n - C E F TA countries only, one commodity; (5) from Romania only, one group of commodities; (6) from the Republic of Ch ina, one commodity; and (7) from the State Trading A rea only, ten com­ modities or groups of commodities. Individual import licenses are required where goods cannot be imported under the authority of the Open General Import License; a number of items are subject to surveillance licensing under which import licenses are issued freely on demand to applicants providing certain information. Most articles subject to specific import licensing can be imported in limited quantities under bilateral or global quotas. A few articles may be imported under open individual licenses, i.e., without l im it as to quantity or value. Imports of cereals and cereal products, beef and veal, mutton and lamb, poultry meat, and dairy products other than butter and cheese are subject to minimum import prices enforced through autonomously imposed variable import levies. Imports of many other agricultural, horticultural, and livestock products are subject to E EC regulations. Not for Redistribution or are to be dispatched immediately on receipt of pay­ ment. Advance payments for imports are approved by the Bank of England where the payment is considered necessary or in accordance with the traditions of the trade and the continuance of the practice is considered to be essential. Current administrative practice is not to allow advance payments for consumer goods. Exchange control forms are not required for payments to residents of the Scheduled Territories; neither are they required for payments to residents of other coun­ tries, unless the payment represents part or final settle­ ment for goods for wh ich the total amount payable exceeds £ 5 , 0 0 0, and evidence of importation cannot be presented to the bank before making the remittance. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to residents of other Sched­ uled Territories may be made freely. Payments to residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories require exchange control authorization, which (except for payments to residents of R h o d e s i a )10 is granted freely for all purposes, subject to the presentation of supporting evidence. The completion of an exchange control form is required for payments exceeding £ 1,000 or its equivalent. Au thor ized banks are per­ mitted to approve applications for transfers on account of many categories of current invisibles without any limitation, and for other categories up to established limits. Applications for payments in excess of these limits or for purposes for wh ich no delegation of authority has been granted are approved by the Bank of England, provided that no unauthorized capital outflow is involved. Au thor ized banks may dispatch sterling banknotes to nonresidents except residents of Rhodesia against pay­ ment in sterling from an External Account or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. F or any type of travel outside the Scheduled T e r r i­ tories (except to Rhodesia), U . K. residents can obtain on demand from banks and authorized travel agents foreign exchange up to the equivalent of £ 3 00 a person a trip; for travel for business or professional reasons, an allowance of £ 75 a day up to a maximum of £ 3 , 0 00 for any one journey can be authorized by banks and certain authorized travel agents. Applications for additional amounts are .approved by the Bank of England unless there is reason to suspect that the exchange is to be used for purposes other than genuine travel expenditure. The cost of accommodation, fares, etc., can be paid for without limit in the Un i ted K ingdom. Travel exchange purchased in the Un i ted K ingdom must normally be recorded in the traveler's passport. 1 ,5 F or security reasons, virtually all current payments to Rhodesia are prohibited, except when these result from permitted trade in goods. Consideration is, however, given to remittances on a limited basis to relieve hardship and to remittances of a continuing nature by chari­ table, religious, medical, and educational organizations for both cur­ rent purposes or to meet capital expenditure in the educational and medical fields. Small personal gifts are also permitted where humani­ tarian grounds exist. U N I T ED K I N G D OM Under arrangements agreed with certain banks, per­ sonal checks may be cashed abroad for travel purposes, up to £ 30 a check, if backed by check cards. Credit cards may be used freely to settle travel expenses. Resident travelers may take out up to £ 3 00 in foreign currency notes. A ny unused travel exchange expressed in foreign currency may be retained for a period of one month from the date of return to the Un i ted K ingdom. Banks have authority to approve applications by U . K. residents who wish to open foreign currency accounts outside the Scheduled Territories for the receipt of travel funds for use during their stay abroad. Travel facilities expressed in sterling may be held for six months from the date of issue or for one month from the date of return to the Un i ted K ingdom, if later. In addition, resident travelers may take with them up to £ 25 in U . K. and other Scheduled Territory bank­ notes, which may be exchanged or spent abroad only for travel expenditure; but those traveling direct to the Republic of Ireland, the Channel Islands, or the Isle of M an may take out any amount. Visitors to the United K ingdom are, in addition, allowed to take out any notes that they brought in w i th them, other than notes in excess of £ 25 expressed in the currencies of the Un i ted K ingdom or the Republic of Ireland. Authorized banks are permitted to approve, within certain limits and subject to the submission of appro­ priate documentary evidence of the amounts due, appli­ cations to pay fees, accommodation charges, and a ll incidental expenses arising from the education of U . K. residents outside the Scheduled Territories. Special regulations apply to all travel to Rhodesia. F or approved official and essential business journeys the Bank of England w i ll authorize the issue of foreign currency at a rate of up to £ 10 a day with a maximum of £ 3 0 0. Facilities for private travel are authorized only where there are compassionate grounds. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are subject to licensing control and licenses are normally issued only for the permitted exceptions (medical and educational supplies, foodstuffs where these are special medical preparations, newsfilm and photographs, and documentary and printed matter not more than 70 years old) and for equipment for the essential replacement needs of the Rhodesian Railways and the Central A f r ican Power Corporation. V i r tua l ly all exports to other destinations are free of export control and no exchange control forms are normally required. Exporters to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia must normally obtain appropriate payment within six months of shipment; special exchange control permission to collect at a later date is required only where the exporter extends credit for more than six months without cover from the Export Credits Guarantee Department ( E C G D ). Receipts in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an author- 471 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U N I T ED K I N G D OM ized bank unless the recipient has obtained specific permission to credit them to a retained currency account (subject to supervision) or permission has been given for them to be used for some other purpose. Permitted exports to Rhodesia must be paid for prior to shipment in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency or, if specific permission is granted by the Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Accoun t. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts in foreign currencies on account of invisibles must be offered for sale to an authorized bank, unless recipients of such currencies have permission to credit them to a retained currency account or to use them for some other purpose. British and other banknotes may be brought into the Un i ted K ingdom freely. Capital Residents of the United K ingdom who receive foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency from certain capital account sources (mainly the sale or redemption of foreign currency securities held for portfolio invest­ ment purposes and the sale of personal residential property situated outside the Scheduled Territories) may, in certain circumstances and with permission, use the exchange (which is regarded as investment currency once permission has been given) for the purchase of marketable foreign currency securities, the purchase of personal residential property outside the Scheduled Territories, or the making of approved direct invest­ ments outside the Scheduled Territories; they may also sell the exchange for sterling to other residents to be used for the same purposes. If permission is not forth­ coming, the foreign currency must be offered for sale at the rates ruling in the official market to an authorized bank in the Un i ted K ingdom. If permission is granted, however, the equivalent in foreign currency of 25 per cent of the proceeds must normally be sold to an autho­ rized bank for sterling at the official market rate of exchange.17- 18 In certain circumstances, residents of the Un i ted K ingdom who possess the nationality or citizenship of a country outside the Scheduled Te r r i­ tories or, in some cases, who are former residents of O SA countries but do not possess such nationality or citizenship may be granted exemption from certain of their obligations under the Exchange Con t rol A ct in respect of assets denominated in a foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. There are no restrictions on capital transfers by resi­ dents of the Un i ted K ingdom into the beneficial owner­ ship of residents of other Scheduled Territories. 17 Where currency is received from the sale of residential real estate by residents of other Scheduled Territories, permission may also be given for such funds to be regarded as investment currency. 18 The full amount of the foreign currency proceeds is normally per­ mitted to be sold as investment currency when the whole of a resi­ dential property is sold which has been held for private use; when it has been held as an investment, however, the proceeds are not nor­ mally eligible to be treated as investment currency. 472 A ll capital transfers by residents to countries outside the Scheduled Territories require approval. Each indi­ vidual resident of the Un i ted K ingdom may, from his own resources, make cash gifts or personal loans not exceeding a total of £ 1 , 0 0 0, or the equivalent in foreign currency, during each calendar year to residents of the O SA, as well as a further £ 3 00 or the equivalent to residents of other countries outside the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesia; additional amounts may be allowed under appropriate circumstances. The cash gifts allowance is noncumulative and is not transferable from one resident to another. A resident of the United K ingdom with dependents who are established residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia may make payments from his own resources not exceeding £ 2 , 0 00 a year to support those dependents. Such payments, which may be gifts or loans, are outside the cash gifts scheme and do not prejudice the normal cash gift allowances. F or security reasons, no capital transfers are allowed to Rhodesia, whether in the form of direct investment or of the purchase of Rhodesian securities, or by any other means, except to relatives, or other Rhodesian residents where humanitarian reasons are given, to the extent of £ 75 during any period of two years. F or direct investments in non-Scheduled Territories, official exchange is normally made available only for certain projects directly concerned with promoting exports of goods and services where the prospective benefit to the U . K. balance of payments is expected to equal or exceed the total cost of the investment within 18 months and to continue thereafter; this benefit will normally occur by way of additional export receipts, but may also arise from profits and other foreign cur­ rency receipts that would not take place without the investment. F or such projects ("super-criterion,, proj­ ects), official exchange may be made available up to £ 2 5 0 , 0 00 or 50 per cent of the total investment, which­ ever is larger; any balance must be financed by foreign currency borrowing, the use of investment currency, the export free of payment of capital equipment and stock-in-trade forming an integral part of the invest­ ment, by the issue or transfer of shares to nonresidents on appropriate terms, by the capitalization of an over­ seas subsidiary's current account indebtedness to the U . K. parent company on appropriate terms, by approved profit retention, or with foreign currency proceeds of dis­ investment in the context of a group reorganization. Direct investment other than for super-criterion projects is considered on the basis that its capital cost should not fall directly upon the U . K. official foreign exchange reserves at least un t il an equivalent amount has been received in the Un i ted K ingdom by way of benefits arising from the investments; such investments can normally be financed by foreign currency borrow­ ing, the use of investment currency, the export free of payment of capital equipment and stock-in-trade forming ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution an integral part of the investment, by the issue or transfer of shares to nonresidents on appropriate terms, by the capitalization of an overseas subsidiary's current account indebtedness to the U . K. parent company on appropriate terms, by approved profit retention, or with foreign currency proceeds of disinvestment in the context of a group reorganization. The permitted pro­ portion of retained foreign currency earnings normally is one third of net earnings after taxes, applied, if desired, on a global basis where more than one sub­ sidiary is i n v o l v e d .19 The purchase outside the Scheduled Territories of marketable foreign currency securities for portfolio investment must be financed either with investment currency or w i th foreign currency borrowing. Such borrowing is freely permitted when undertaken by or through U . K. professional security managers, and the resale of foreign currency securities acquired in this manner is exempt from the "25 per cent requirement" (see above) until the loan portfolio is liquidated and the profit repatriated. Purchases of marketable foreign currency securities with investment currency are freely permitted by virtue of certain general permissions granted to banks, stockbrokers, and other authorized depositaries. Purchases from other residents may also be effected w i th sterling on The Stock Exchange (sterling prices reflect the prevailing investment currency pre­ m ium ). The purchase by U . K. residents of a house or an apartment for personal use in countries outside the Scheduled Territories requires specific approval and must be made either from another Scheduled Territory resident for sterling or another Scheduled Territory currency, or from a nonresident of the Scheduled Territories w i th investment currency or borrowed for­ eign currency; payment for attendant expenses and improvements, but not maintenance, must also be made w i th investment currency. (As an exception to this rule, residents temporarily employed in member countries of the E EC may be authorized to purchase necessary accommodation at current official market rates of exchange.) App roval is normally limited to one property a family; purchases of investment currency are normally limited to reasonable amounts and may be made before exchange control approval is received provided that the funds are held by an authorized depositary and that a formal application is lodged to purchase the property w i th in six months. The approval authority for amounts up to <£ 30,000 for a residential property has been delegated to authorized banks. 19 W i th effect from February 11, 1977 applicants for permission to make an outward direct investment were required to provide details of estimated benefits over the 18 months following the proposed invest­ ment and estimates of the benefits expected thereafter in all cases. In addition, investors seeking permission to repay foreign currency bor­ rowings taken to finance outward direct investments had to give an explanation if the benefits received fell short of those originally esti­ mated; the Bank of England also expected the investor to show, where possible, that these benefits derived from the particular injection of capital financed by the foreign currency borrowing being repaid. U N I T ED K I N G D OM A ll proceeds from the realization, redemption, or maturity of sterling capital assets (including direct investments) owned by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories other than residents of Rhodesia are remit­ table at the official market rate of exchange. Pay­ ments to nonresident beneficiaries are authorized freely in respect of inheritances due from the estates of deceased residents; capital payments under life and other insurance policies taken up by nonresidents with resident insurance companies are also authorized freely. Residents of the Un i ted K ingdom who leave with the intention of residing for at least three years in a country outside the Scheduled Territories and apply to transfer their assets are, on their departure from the United K ingdom, regarded for exchange control purposes as nonresidents, and, with the following exceptions, their assets are treated accordingly. Repatriates (non- Scheduled Territory nationals or citizens, other than Rhodesians, who having been resident in the United K ingdom return to take up residence in any country outside the Scheduled Territories) may normally trans­ fer all their sterling assets abroad at the official market rate of exchange. Other residents leaving to take up residence in countries outside the Scheduled Territories and the OSA except Rhodesia are allowed on departure to transfer for a family unit up to <£5,000 through the official foreign exchange market (<£ 20,000 for older persons) and may export any foreign currency securities they hold; the remaining declared assets in excess of <£ 5,000 are restricted for a four-year period from the date of the departing person's redesignation as a non­ resident. U . K. residents taking up residence and employ­ ment in member countries of the E E C, however, may, with specific approval, transfer sterling assets at the official market rate of exchange in excess of the £ 5 , 0 00 limit where this is necessary in order to ensure their freedom to take up the employment in question. F or emigration to the O SA, the basic settling-in allowance is £ 2 0 , 0 00 also available at the official market rate of exchange, and holdings of foreign currency securities are exportable. Du r ing the four-year period the restricted funds may be disposed of for foreign currencies other than Rhode­ sian currency through the investment currency market, may be invested in sterling securities which are quoted on The Stock Exchange, the income therefrom being freely remittable through the official exchange market, or may be used, with general or specific permission, to meet certain expenses in the Un i ted K ingdom. After the four-year period any remaining assets are trans­ ferable in accordance with the rules then applicable to the assets of a nonresident; at present, the transfer at the official market rate of exchange is normally allowed. The participation of foreign capital as a direct invest­ ment in the Un i ted K ingdom is subject to individual authorization, wh ich is normally granted, provided that adequate capital for the project is supplied in an 473 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U N I T ED K I N G D OM approved manner of payment (see section on Prescrip­ tion of Currency, above) or by the import of goods and services; the foreign currency received must be surrendered at rates ruling in the official market unless permission has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Cases involving the take-over of existing companies that by their size or nature con­ stitute a vital part of Br i t ish industry are considered on their merits. Permissions given for direct invest­ ment in the Un i ted K ingdom by nonresidents are normally, unless otherwise agreed with the Bank of England, conditional on the consideration being paid in sterling from an External Account or in foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) and, in certain circumstances, on any subsequent finance being provided in foreign currency or External Account sterling at least in proportion to the nonresident interest in the equity of the company. The acquisition in any manner by any person not resident in the United K ingdom of 10 per cent or more of the outstanding shares of a company registered in the United K ingdom requires prior exchange control approval. Nonresident firms and individuals must obtain per­ mission from the Treasury in order to raise capital in the United K ingdom, and all U . K. resident companies are required to obtain consent before issuing shares or other securities to nonresidents. U . K. residents also need permission to lend to U . K. companies controlled by nonresidents. Such permission is normally given for sterling lending for the purpose of financing the com­ pany's day-to-day business, provided that the level of nonresident funds in the company is at all times suffi­ cient to cover the percentage of the fixed and other noncurrent assets attributable to the nonresident stake, but is not normally given for any expansion of manu­ facturing capacity except for companies whose activities are regarded as bringing special advantages to the U . K. economy. There are three important exceptions to these principles: (1) Un l im i ted sterling finance in the United K ingdom is normally allowed to U . K. companies in which any nonresidents have less than a controlling interest, except to companies which are purely vehicles for portfolio investment in securities or property. (2) U . K. companies controlled by residents of the E EC or the OSA that are not purely vehicles for portfolio invest­ ment are normally allowed unlimited sterling finance for their operations anywhere in the United K ingdom. (3) U . K. companies controlled by residents of any non -EEC country ouside both the Scheduled Territories and the O SA are upon application allowed similar facilities in respect of expenditure on new manufacturing capacity in the areas of the Un i ted K ingdom which qualify for special government assistance (the assisted areas), while their requests in respect of such new expenditure in other areas of the Un i ted K ingdom are considered on their me r i ts .20 U . K. banks are prohibited from providing sterling 474 loans or overdrafts to persons resident outside the Sched­ uled Territories for the purpose of financing trade between non-Scheduled Territories. S im i lar ly, U . K. merchants, except certain commodity traders, may not finance such trade in sterling. They are, however, allowed to do so w i th foreign currency borrowed for the purpose. Borrowing by U . K. residents from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories to finance expenditure in the United K ingdom is subject to restrictions. Private sector U . K. residents other than authorized banks nor­ mally are not permitted to borrow foreign currency from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories for conversion into sterling for use in the Un i ted K ingdom, or to finance current payments to nonresidents of the Sched­ uled Territories, unless the term of borrowing is at least two years; exporters, merchants, and certain commodity traders are, however, permitted to borrow foreign cur­ rency for shorter periods from authorized banks or from nonresidents to finance their sales or, in some cases, stockholdings. Pub l ic sector bodies normally are not permitted to borrow foreign currency unless the term of the foreign borrowing is at least five years; for permitted foreign currency borrowing they may avail themselves of exchange cover provided by the Treasury. Authorized banks must not lend foreign currency to U . K. residents (other than authorized banks) for any other purpose without prior reference to the Bank of England. U . K. companies normally are not permitted to borrow External Account sterling from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories unless the term of the borrowing is at least two years. Under certain permissions delegated to authorized depositaries, transactions in securities of most types may generally be carried out freely between residents of the United K ingdom, except that transactions wh ich involve loss of U . K. voting control of a company because the purchaser is itself nonresident-controlled require Bank of England consent and transactions in Rhodesian securities may only be effected on The Stock Exchange. Residents are normally permitted, subject to certain conditions, to sell foreign currency securities outside the Scheduled Territories, and, in respect of those held for portfolio investment purposes, after 25 per cent of the proceeds has been sold to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange, to reinvest the balance of the exchange proceeds (investment currency) in marketable foreign currency securities, or to sell the exchange to other residents for such investments or for certain approved direct investment or approved pur­ chases of property for private use outside the Scheduled Territories. Not for Redistribution the official market rate of exchange or, where appropri­ ate, may, w i th Bank of England permission, be retained in foreign currency for use for further outward direct investments in the context of a group reorganization. When foreign currency securities are sold by residents on The Stock Exchange for sterling, an amount of invest­ ment currency in the form of foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) equivalent to 25 per cent of the sale proceeds must be purchased in the investment currency market for resale to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange. Professional dealers making a "book" in foreign currency securities may on application be exempt from the 25 per cent requirement in respect of transactions on the "book" but not in respect of sales of securities held as investments. Investment currency held for a continuous period of 6 months normally ceases to be investment currency unless an amount of investment currency in the form of foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) equivalent to 25 per cent of the amount held is, at the end of the 6-month period, sold to an authorized bank at the current market rate in the official foreign exchange market. Investment currency may normally be retained as investment currency for a maximum of 12 months, after which period any amount remaining must be offered for sale to an author­ ized bank at the current market rate in the official foreign exchange marke t .21 Professional security managers acting on their own behalf and for clients are permitted, subject to certain conditions, to borrow foreign currency for the purpose of making portfolio investments in marketable foreign currency securities. U . K. jobbers and other security dealers may, with permission, arrange day-to-day bor­ rowing of foreign currency, whether from U . K. banks or from nonresidents, to finance a "book" in foreign currency securities, but not to finance holdings of such securities as investments. Residents of other Scheduled Territories are not prevented by the U . K. regulations from buying and selling sterling securities in the Un i ted K ingdom; they may also buy and sell, subject to certain conditions, Rhodesian securities on The Stock Exchange, but they must obtain the permission of the U . K. authorities to buy and sell other foreign currency securities in the United K ingdom. Permission is required for all transfers of securities in the Un i ted K ingdom in which a nonresident of the Scheduled Territories is involved as either transferor or transferee, but most transfers are covered by a gen­ eral authority. In most cases, U . K. companies may issue sterling securities (including bearer securities) under a general permission given by the U . K. authorities. -1 Investment currency may be invested temporarily in short-term government bonds (with up to six months to run before final maturity) or in six-month treasury bills or other forms of recognized short-term money-market paper (including certificates of deposit) without incur­ ring the need to comply with the 25 per cent requirement on resale of the paper. U N I T ED K I N G D OM Nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesian residents may buy sterling securities on The Stock Exchange against payment in foreign currency or in sterling from an External Account. Securities so purchased may be exported from the United K ingdom. Foreign currency securities may be bought and sold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories on The Stock Exchange for settlement in foreign currency or, in certain circumstances, for settlement in sterling exclud­ ing the investment currency premium. Nonresidents must obtain permission to buy securities in the Un i ted K ingdom other than on The Stock Exchange, whether or not the securities are quoted on a stock exchange. Nonresidents other than Rhodesian residents may sell sterling securities in the Un i ted K ingdom for sterling which may be held on External Account or, alter­ natively, may be transferred abroad at official market rates. Most transactions in securities by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia require the specific approval of the Bank of England; subject to certain conditions, however, authorized banks may approve applications by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia to buy and sell sterling securities on The Stock Exchange. Except in respect of U . K. companies controlled by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories (where Bank of England consent is required), warrants issued by registrars, company secretaries, and paying agents in respect of capital payments on matured securities regis­ tered in the names of nonresidents other than Rhodesian residents may be dispatched freely to addresses outside the Scheduled Territories. These warrants may be paid by crediting sterling to an External Account. Authorized banks may freely accept foreign currency deposits and employ them in their foreign currency business. They may also switch such deposits into sterling on a covered basis. Individual ceilings are set on each bank's overall open position in foreign cur­ rencies and on the amount of spot assets which may be held against forward liabilities in foreign currencies. Gold In the United K ingdom gold bullion and gold coins are subject to control. Exemption under the Exchange Con trol Ac t, 1947 exists for: (1) the buying, selling, lending, and borrowing of gold coins minted in or before 1837; (2) the buying and selling of any gold coins minted after 1837 and held in the Un i ted K i n g­ dom, if the seller is a person resident in the Un i ted K ingdom and is not selling on behalf of a person resident outside the Un i ted K ingdom; and (3) the borrowing and lending of any gold coins minted after 1837 and held in the United K ingdom, if both the borrower and the lender are persons resident in the United K ingdom. Transactions both in gold coins not exempted above and in gold bullion may only be undertaken with permission. Permission is normally given for the use of gold bullion for genuine industrial 475 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U N I T ED K I N G D OM and professional purposes. The sale of gold bullion for the manufacture of gold coins, gold medals, etc., is prohibited unless specially authorized. G o ld sovereigns are legal tender but do not circulate in the Un i ted K ingdom. G o ld coins which are legal tender have also been issued in Jersey and the Isle of M a n. Except under license granted by the Treasury, it is an offense to melt down or break up any metal coin which is for the time being current in the Un i ted K i n g­ dom or which, having been current there, has at any time after M ay 16, 1969 ceased to be so. G o ld coins minted after 1837 or gold medals, medallions, tablets, or other pieces in pictorial relief or bearing inscriptions and manufactured after 1837 are subject to individual import licensing, and such licenses are normally given only to authorized dealers in gold. The export of gold bullion and all gold coins requires prior exchange control approval. The export of gold bullion and of post-1837 gold coins to G ibra l tar and the Republic of Ireland is not normally permitted except with the approval of the local control authorities. Au thor i ty has been given to authorized dealers in gold to issue licenses in respect of exports of gold bullion and coin purchased by any non-Scheduled Territory resident in the London gold market against payment in External Account sterling or foreign currency. A license is required from the Department of Trade for the export of gold (and other) jewelry, etc., containing diamonds. The export of gold in manufactured form over 100 years old and valued at <£4,000 and over also requires a license from the Department of Trade. Manufactures of gold other than medals, etc., manu­ factured after 1837 may be imported without quan­ titative restriction under Open General Import License from all sources except Rhodesia. There is a free gold market in London in which gold bars are freely traded among (1) authorized dealers in gold, (2) any nonresidents of the Scheduled Te r r i­ tories, and (3) residents of the O SA who are sellers of new production. The U . K. authorities do not intervene in the market as either buyers or sellers. A commission of XA of 1 per cent is charged on all purchases; there is no commission on sales. Authorized banks may enter into forward transactions in gold without prior permis­ sion from the Bank of England. Banks may also finance purchases of gold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories by lending foreign exchange and may accept gold as collateral for advances in foreign currencies or External Account sterling to nonresidents of the Sched­ uled Territories. Changes during 1976 In addition to the changes listed below, certain changes in quantitative import regulations were made in accordance with E EC decisions, directives, and regu­ 476 lations; most of these related to textiles or beef and veal. January 1. The fourth reduction of 20 per cent in import duties on goods originating in E EC member countries took place. January 1. The import duties on certain textile goods from Portugal, which had been temporarily imposed in 1975, reverted to zero. January 1. Cigars from the Do l lar A rea were placed on Open General Import License. January 1. New quota levels for imports from East­ ern A rea countries came into effect. There were a num­ ber of subsequent modifications. January 15. Imports from all sources other than E EC member countries of portable monochrome and all color television sets and color television tubes not already subject to individual import licensing became subject to import surveillance arrangements. January 24. Imports of certain horticultural products from the Eastern A rea and of petroleum oils and several petroleum products from Romania were placed on Open General Import License. February 1. The limits for export insurance cover under comprehensive guarantees without reference to the E C GD were doubled. February 6. Imports of monochrome television tubes from the Eastern A r ea ceased to require an individual import license. The quota facilities for the importation of color television tubes from the Eastern A rea were withdrawn, and licenses were no longer issued. February 10. Au thor ized banks were enabled to approve certain applications (for up to £ 5 0 , 0 0 0) to credit to External Account, or to remit abroad in foreign currency, the proceeds from the sale of U . K. houses or apartments sold by nonresident individuals. February 10. The rules covering sterling lending to nonresidents were tightened. Banks granting new sterling facilities to residents of the O SA to finance trade had to ascertain that the goods in question were either being imported into or exported from an O SA country; such facilities could not be used to finance domestic trade within an O SA country, nor should they be outstanding for longer than the period of credit agreed between buyer and seller. February 17. Authorized depositaries were advised that deposit certificates and depositary receipts relating to sterling securities were themselves sterling securities (with the exception of depositary receipts which, although relating to underlying sterling securities, were enfaced to the effect that for U . K. exchange control purposes they were foreign currency securities). Except in certain cases of authorized depositaries wishing to engage in the arbitrage of depositary receipts and the underlying sterling securities, the Bank of England was not prepared to give permission for U . K. residents to purchase from persons resident outside the Scheduled Territories depositary receipts relating to sterling securi- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ties or to exchange sterling securities for depositary receipts. March 6. Imports of combined sound recorders and reproducers from the non-Community A rea ceased to require an individual import license. March 11. Quotas for 1976 were imposed on imports of men's woolen suits from Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, and Romania. (On December 30, the quotas for Czechoslovakia and the German Demo­ cratic Republic were extended to calendar year 1977 at the same level.) It was announced that Czecho­ slovakia, Poland, and Romania had agreed to an exten­ sion of the 1975 voluntary restraints on exports to the Un i ted K ingdom of leather footwear (excluding san­ da ls), and that Hungary and Poland had agreed to introduce voluntary restraint on exports to the Un i ted K ingdom of men's and boys' woolen suits. April 1. Continuation of import arrangements for restricted cotton textiles was announced for countries with which agreements under the G A TT Multifiber Arrangement had not yet been concluded or were not to be negotiated. April 1. New quota levels were announced for imports of cotton yarn from Hong Kong, India, and Pakistan for the period January 1, 1976 -Ma rch 31, 1977, and for imports of woven cotton textiles and cotton yarn from Bangladesh, G ibra l tar, Iran, Kuwa i t, Sri Lanka, South A f r i c a, and the Syrian A rab Republic during A p r il 1, 1976 -Ma rch 31, 1977. April 12. The higher rate of value-added tax was reduced from 25 per cent to 12V2 per cent. April 22. The Bank of England withdrew the con­ cessions relating to the eligibility for sale with the benefit of the investment currency premium of two classes of foreign currency assets exempted from certain obligations imposed under the Exchange Con t rol A c t, v iz ., exempted foreign currency securities and exempted cash balances arising from the sale of property situated outside the Scheduled Territories. Permission would no longer be given for exempted foreign currency securities to be sold with the benefit of the investment currency premium; transactions in such securities should be effected only in accordance w i th the terms of the exemption given to the beneficial owner. In addition, the Bank of England was no longer prepared to con­ sider applications for exempted foreign currency arising from the sale of property held for private use outside the Scheduled Territories (whether acquired while the owner was resident outside the Scheduled Territories or not) to be treated as investment currency. Complementary regulations were adopted affecting immigrants and residents who acquired foreign currency assets while work ing abroad. Foreign currency securi­ ties beneficially owned by immigrants at the time of their becoming resident in the Un i ted K ingdom ceased to be eligible for transfer with the benefit of the invest­ ment currency premium unless the immigrant became U N I T ED K I N G D OM resident in the Un i ted K ingdom prior to A p r il 22, 1974. Similarly, permission no longer was given for foreign currency securities, purchased by residents of the Un i ted K ingdom with savings from earnings while working and l iv ing outside the Scheduled Territories for three years or more, to be sold with the benefit of the investment currency premium unless the owner returned to the United K ingdom prior to A p r il 22, 1974 and had been continuously resident in the Un i ted K ingdom since he returned, and the securities were beneficially owned by the person concerned on the date of return. In the case, however, of foreign currency securities owned by immigrants from the Republic of Ireland or G ibra l tar who became resident in the Un i ted K ingdom on or after A p r il 22, 1974, the Bank of England was prepared to consider applications for such securities to be regarded as eligible for transfer in accordance with previous practice if, prior to immigration, the foreign currency proceeds of the securities concerned would have been eligible to be treated as investment currency. April 22. The exchange control concessions for per­ sons who are, or are to be, temporarily employed in the O SA were withdrawn. A l so withdrawn were certain concessions to emigrants taking up employment in the O SA and to those emigrants to the O SA who had planned their departure before June 23, 1972. April 22. The Bank of England ceased to give per­ mission for commissions or fees attributable to the underwriting of foreign currency securities and received in foreign currency to be treated as investment currency. A letter of clarification was issued on A p r il 30. April 22. Authorized depositaries were advised that there was no objection under the Exchange Con trol Act of 1947 to U . K. residents participating in the under­ writing of specific issues of foreign currency securities, and that the Bank of England was prepared to consider applications from authorized depositaries who were pro­ fessional dealers in securities to participate in the under­ writing of specific issues of unquoted securities. April 22. New delegated authorities were given to authorized banks to approve applications for the maintenance of certain foreign currency accounts in connection with the receipt in foreign currency of pensions, directors' fees, dividends and interest, and the proceeds of exports and merchanting business and pay­ ment for imports and merchanting business. They could also approve applications for U . K. residents tem­ porarily working or studying outside the Scheduled Territories to maintain foreign currency accounts with U . K. authorized banks for certain purposes. April 22. Authorized banks were enabled, subject to certain conditions, to approve applications by U . K. resident individuals to purchase investment currency (up to the equivalent of £ 1 5 , 0 0 0, excluding the invest­ ment currency premium) to make payments for certain improvements to property held for private use outside the Scheduled Territories, and to transfer sums at the 477 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U N I T ED K I N G D OM official market rate of exchange or use foreign cur­ rency rents already held on an authorized account to make certain payments for the maintenance of such properties. Authorized banks could approve the latter on an estimated annual basis, provided that remittances were not made more than three months before pay­ ments were due. April 22. W i th respect to emigration to countries outside the Scheduled Territories, banks were informed of certain additions to the payments in the United K i n g­ dom that concessionary banks could allow to be met from funds restricted under Section 40 of the Exchange Con trol A c t, and certain additions to the types of invest­ ment in the Un i ted K ingdom that they could effect using such restricted funds. Banks were reminded of certain aspects of current exchange control practice, notably that assets restricted under Section 40 could be used as collateral for foreign currency borrowing by emigrants, and that former residents of countries now in the O SA who emigrated prior to June 23, 1972 could apply for the removal of any restrictions imposed on their assets by the Bank of England. April 29. A provisional charge to countervailing duty of 16 per cent was imposed on men's leather fashion footwear from B r a z i l. Subsequently, a countervailing duty of 8 per cent was imposed. May 10. The Bank of England ceased to treat as investment currency any part of the proceeds of sales of options on foreign currency securities by U . K. residents. May 17. Surveillance licensing of electronic calcula­ tors from all sources except E EC member countries was maintained on a national basis, following the termina­ tion of Community surveillance arrangements. It was announced that the financial author­ ities of the G roup of Ten countries and Switzerland, together with the Bank for International Settlements, would make available to the Bank of England a stand-by credit of US$5.3 b i l l ion for a period of up to six months. June 9. A quota was established up to M ay 25, 1977 for imports of sacks and bags of polyethylene strip or polypropylene strip originating in Ko rea. June 22. Dealers in the primary market in foreign currency securities, when acting as members of selling groups for new issues, no longer were required to trans­ fer funds from the investment currency market to the official market in respect of certain earnings from their new issue activities. These measures were designed to terminate the use by U . Banks were free to replace the sterling facilities hitherto made available by offering appropriate finance in foreign currency to overseas customers or to U . K. merchants. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value of the United States Do l lar was estab­ lished on October 18, 1973 at 0.736662 gram of fine gold, corresponding to US$42.22 a fine ounce or US$1.20635 = SDR l .1 The convertibility of the U . S. dollar into gold and other reserve assets has been suspended and exchange rates are not maintained within any stipulated margin from parity. There are no restric­ tions on foreign payments, except those imposed for security reasons on transactions involving the authorities or nationals of Cambodia, the People's Republic of Ch ina, Cuba, No r th Ko rea, No r th V i e t -N am, and South V i e t -N am, and those imposed pursuant to UN Security Counc il Resolutions Nos. 232 and 253 on any transfer of funds to, or on behalf of, or for the benefit of, any person in Rhodesia (including the authorities thereof), unless the funds are in payment of imports of strategic and cr i t ical materials of Rhodesian o r ig in .2 The Un i ted States formally notified the Fund on December 10, 1946 that it was prepared to accept the obligations of A r t ic le V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control The Department of the Treasury deals with license applications involving financial or commercial transac­ tions directly or indirectly with Cambodia, Cuba, No r th Ko rea, Rhodesia, No r th V i e t -N am, and South V i e t -N am or their nationals, as specified under the Foreign Assets Con t rol Regulations, the Cuban Assets Con t rol Regula­ tions, and the Rhodesian Sanctions Regulations. It also deals with license applications under the Foreign Funds Con t rol Regulations involving the blocked accounts in the Un i ted States of the above-mentioned countries, as well as the People's Republic of Ch ina, Czechoslovakia, Estonia, the German Democratic Republic, La tv ia, and L i thuan ia. The Bureau of Customs of the Department of the Treasury administers import quotas; such quotas, however, are generally established and allocated by other agencies. Import quotas on specified dairy products are administered by the Department of Agriculture through the issuance of import licenses. A global import quota on sugar is set by the Department of Agr icu l ture. A l l o­ cations and licenses for imports of crude petroleum and petroleum products are issued by the Department of the Interior. F or items subject to export control other than crude petroleum and petroleum products the Department of Commerce is, in general, the responsible authority. 1 U . S. Pub l ic Law N o. 94-564 provides that the par value of the U . S. dollar in terms of gold and SDRs will be repealed when the proposed second amendment to the Fund's Articles of Agreement enters into force. - In addition, certain enemy and occupied area property blocked during W o r ld W ar II remains blocked (Czechoslovakia, Estonia, Ger­ man Democratic Republic, La tv ia, and L i thuan ia ). As regards Rho­ desia, the exception for imports of strategic and critical materials was revoked early in 1977. Payments restrictions in respect of Cuba were eased early in 1977. Imports and Import Payments The importation of merchandise, as well as payment therefor, is prohibited under Treasury regulations, unless licensed, if such merchandise is of Cambodian, Cuban, No r th Korean, No r th Vietnamese, South Vietnamese, or Rhodesian origin. Import quotas are in effect for (1) cotton, certain cotton waste and products, most dairy products, and peanuts, pursuant to Section 22 of the Ag r icu l tu ral Adjustment A c t; (2) certain fish and certain potatoes; (3) sugar; (4) certain meat; and (5) stainless steel and alloy tool steel products. W i th the exception of the import quotas for peanuts, certain cotton and cotton products, butter o i l, and sugar, the above quotas are on a country-of-production basis. In addition, imports of crude o il and o il products are subject to quotas, an import entitlement program, and import license fees. Certain products (such as wheat, cotton, and peanuts), although subject to quantitative restrictions, are not sub­ ject to import licensing because U . S. prices are at or very near world prices. The Un i ted States is a party to the G A TT Arrange­ ment Regarding International Trade in Textiles and to 18 bilateral textile agreements negotiated under the Arrangement's provisions. These agreements set the levels for the partners' exports of textiles and apparel to the Un i ted States. As at the end of 1976, no l im i ta­ tions were applied to imports of crude petroleum and petroleum products, but these were generally subject to import licenses and import license fees. Imports of fresh, frozen, or chilled beef, veal, and mutton are governed in principle by 12 bilateral agreements as an alternative to the imposition of mandatory quotas under the Meat Import A ct of 1964; during the last four months of 1976, however, a temporary quota was in effect. The transfer of funds to Rhodesia for all purposes, including payment for imports of strategic and critical materials (see section on Exchange Rate System, above) is permitted only under license. Other payments and transfers abroad may be made freely, with certain exceptions which are permitted only under license; these exceptions are payments to or for the account of the authorities or nationals of Cambodia, Cuba, No r th Ko rea, No r th V i e t -N am, and South V i e t -N am. Exports and Export Proceeds Munitions can be exported only under license issued by the Office of Munitions Con trol in the Department of State. Licenses are not granted for exports of arms and ammunition to Cambodia, the People's Republic of Ch ina, Cuba, Eastern Europe, No r th Ko rea, South A f r i c a, the U .S .S .R ., No r th V i e t -N am, or South V ie t- N am. Most exports to Rhodesia require licenses and generally no licenses are issued except for educational, 481 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U N I T ED S T A T ES medical, or humanitarian items. A ll exports (except phonograph records, publications, and, to Cuba, limited gift parcels) to Cambodia, Cuba, No r th Ko rea, No r th V i e t -N am, and South V i e t -N am are subject to individual validated licenses. Exports of designated strategic mate­ rials and equipment to a ll other countries (except Can­ ada) also require individual validated licenses. F or many commodities, when exported to countries other than C M EA members, certain A rab states, Cambodia, Cuba, No r th Ko rea, No r th V i e t -N am, or South V ie t- N am, single distribution licenses may be obtained to cover a full year's shipments. The licensing require­ ments applicable to Poland, Romania, and Yugoslavia are less restrictive than those applicable to other Eastern European countries. Exports of certain commodities to all destinations have from time to time been subject to controls for reasons of short supply; as at the end of 1976 such controls were applicable to crude petroleum and petroleum fuels. Export plans for wheat, corn, sorghum, soybeans, and soybean o il are subject to report­ ing requirements in order to avoid the need for controls. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted, except that they are pro­ hibited to and from Cambodia, Cuba, No r th Ko rea, Rhodesia, No r th V i e t -N am, and South V ie t -Nam. Indi­ viduals leaving or entering the country with more than US$5,000 in domestic or foreign currency, travelers checks, money orders, and /or bearer-form negotiable securities must declare these to the customs at the point of exit or entry. Capital Incoming or outgoing capital payments by residents or nonresidents are not subject to exchange control. In addition, inward and outward direct or portfolio invest­ ment are generally free of any other form of approval requirements, although in certain instances compliance with specified banking regulations may be required; with a few exceptions, the Un i ted States does not impose special restrictions on inward investment. However, as noted above, there are restrictions on certain transactions with or involving Cambodia, Cuba, No r th Ko rea, Rho­ desia, No r th V i e t -N am, and South V i e t -N am, and there are certain reporting requirements for travelers entering or leaving the country (as well as corresponding report­ ing requirements for shipment of currency or bearer assets through the ma i ls ). Federal Reserve member banks must meet reserve requirements of 4 per cent on net Eurodollar borrowings from their foreign branches; foreign-owned nonmember banks and agencies and branches of foreign banks volun­ tarily maintain reserves against increases in their net borrowings from foreign sources above their M ay 1973 levels, at the request of the Federal Reserve Board. The foreign currency positions of banks, whether overall or 482 with respect to individual currencies, are not subject to limitation. Gold U . S. citizens or residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad, except for gold transactions involving Cambodia, Cuba, North Ko rea, Rhodesia, No r th V i e t -N am, or South Viet-Nam. Commercial banks may deal in gold bullion and gold coins, w i th the same exceptions. Treasury licensing for importers, exporters, producers, refiners, and processors of gold is no longer required, with the same exceptions. Producers of gold may sell their output in the free market, with the same country exceptions. G o ld may be freely imported except from the countries mentioned above and except counterfeit gold coins. U . S. gold coins remain legal tender at their face value. Commercial imports of gold jewelry are free of quan­ titative restriction but are subject to import duty at a rate of approximately 12 per cent. There is no duty on gold ore, bu l l ion, or coins. A ll forms of gold must be declared at the point of entry into the Un i ted States. Changes during 1976 January 1.
