The Federal Open Market Committee agreed on broad revisions (with effect from Decem­ ber 28) in the Federal Reserve System's Authorization for Foreign Currency Operations and in the Foreign Currency Directive. The main change in the Authori­ zation was to replace the several separate limits on vari­ ous types of spot and forward transactions with a single US$1 b i l l ion l im it on the System's "overall open posi­ tion"; the Federal Reserve Bank of New Y o rk was separately authorized, however, to maintain an overall open position in foreign currencies exceeding that limit by an amount equal to the remaining forward commitments associated with the System's outstanding 1971 swap drawings in Swiss francs. The principal modification in the Directive was to omit the detailed listing of basic purposes and specific objectives of the System's foreign currency operations and to state instead that these were generally to be directed at countering disorderly condi­ tions in the exchange markets. The Committee also agreed upon certain procedural instructions. The main purposes of the revisions were to simplify and clarify the Committee's instructions to the Federal Reserve Bank of New Y o rk and to update the docu­ ments in light of changes under way in the international monetary system and its functioning. The revisions were not intended to signify a change in policy orientation but simply codified current practice under the evolving regime of floating exchange rates. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UPPER VO L TA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange System No par value or central rate for the currency of Upper Vo l ta has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the C FA F r a n c ,1 wh ich is officially maintained at the rate of C F AF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transactions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de l 'A f r ique de l'Ouest ( B C E A O) and commercial banks take place at the rate of C F AF 1 = F 0.02. The B C E AO levies a commission of Vio of 1 per m i ll on transfers from countries outside the West A f r ican Monetary U n i on and a commission of 2.50 per m i ll on transfers to countries outside the U n i o n .2 Exchange rates for foreign currencies are based on the fixed rate for the F rench franc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned, and include a commission. Banks levy a commission on transfers to a ll countries outside the West A f r i c an Monetary U n i o n, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. W i th the exception of those relating to gold, Upper Volta's exchange control measures do not apply to (1) France (and its Overseas Departments and T e r r i­ tories, except the F rench Terr i tory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) a ll other countries whose bank of issue is linked w i th the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Benin, Cameroon, the Central A f r i c an Emp ire, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Ivory Coast, M a l i, N iger, Senegal, and T o g o ). Hence, a ll payments to these countries may be made freely. A ll other countries, except Upper V o l ta itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only with foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the External Finance Bureau in the Directorate of the Treasury and of Pub l ic Accounts in the M in i s t ry of Finance, which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertis­ ing, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Upper V o l t a, inward direct investment and a ll outward invest­ ment, and the soliciting of funds in Upper V o l ta for placement in foreign countries. The approval authority in respect of exchange control (except for imports and exports of gold, forward exchange cover, and business travel allocations in excess of C F AF 400,000) has been delegated to the B C E AO and, w i th in limits specified in the exchange control regulations, to authorized inter­ mediaries. The B C E AO also is authorized to collect, 1 The C FA franc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de l'Afrique de l'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Benin, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 2 Transfers between member countries of the Union are subject to a commission of C F AF 100 for each transfer. The commissions are not levied on transfers ordered by public treasuries and similar institutions or by the Postal Administration of Upper Volta. either direct or through the intermediary of banks, financial institutions, the Postal Administration, and notaries public, any information necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics. A ll exchange trans­ actions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks, the Postal Adm in is tra t ion, or the B C E A O. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Commerce in the M in i s t ry of C om­ merce, Industrial Development, and M ines. Import certificates for liberalized commodities and export attestations are made out by the importer or exporter himself and, when settlement takes place with a country outside the French F ranc A r e a, are visaed by the customs. Prescription of Currency Upper V o l ta is an Operations Account country of the F rench Franc A rea, since the B C E AO maintains an Operations Account w i th the F rench Treasury; settle­ ments with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc A rea are made in C FA francs, French francs, or the currency of any Operations Account country. Settle­ ments with The Gamb ia, Ghana, L ibe r ia, N iger ia, and Sierra Leone are normally made in West A f r ican account­ ing units through the West A f r ican C lear ing House. Cer­ tain settlements with Ghana are to be made through special accounts. Certain settlements with the People's Republic of Ch ina and the Federal Republic of Germany are also channeled through special accounts. Settlements with all other countries are usually made either through correspondent banks in France or the country concerned in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs (or other Franc A rea currencies) through Fo r­ eign Accounts. A ll settlements with Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. B C E AO bank­ notes may be credited to Foreign Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the B C E AO agency in Ouagadougou by authorized banks' foreign correspondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of B C E AO banknotes, F rench banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports originating in or shipped from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Imports from countries in the French F ranc A rea may in pr in­ ciple be made freely, although exceptionally, special 485 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U P P ER V O L TA regulations may be issued. Imports shipped from and originating in E EC countries, with minor exceptions, are liberalized and require only an import certificate (attestation). Most imports from other countries are subject to licensing. Imports from n o n -EEC countries outside the French Franc A r ea are admitted in accord­ ance with an annual import program, determined each year by the Directorate of Commerce. Under this pro­ gram, global quotas are established up to which import licenses are issued for specified commodities. Imports from Ghana are subject to special regulations. A ll import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds C F AF 500,000. The import licenses or import certificates (attestations) entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before shipment if a documentary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodities have already been imported. Most imports are subject to a customs stamp tax of 6 per cent and an import surcharge of 6 per cent. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc A rea are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to exchange control approval, which for many invisibles has been delegated to the authorized banks. A ll payments to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Authorized banks and the Postal Administration have been empowered to make payments to foreign countries freely, on behalf of residents, up to C F AF 50,000 a transfer. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted. Residents traveling for tourism to countries other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc A r ea may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to C F AF 175,000 a person a trip ( C F AF 87,500 for children under ten) for any number of trips a year; any foreign exchange in excess of C F AF 5,000 remaining after return to Upper Vo l ta must be surrendered. The basic allocation for travel abroad for business purposes is the equivalent of C F AF 20,000 a day, with a maximum of C F AF 400,000 a trip. Resi­ dent travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to a maximum of C F AF 25,000 in B C E AO bank­ notes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by any institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury. Resident travelers to other countries of the French Franc A rea may take out any amount in B C E AO banknotes, but if going to a country that is not a member of the West A f r ican Monetary 486 U n i o n, they must declare to the customs the amount taken out if it exceeds C F AF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may freely take out, in addition to any means of payment established in their name abroad, foreign banknotes up to the equivalent of C F AF 175,000 or, subject to the submission of appro­ priate documents (if it was either declared upon entry or acquired by drawing on a Foreign Account in Francs or an Account in Foreign Currency or by exchange of foreign travelers checks, etc .), any large amount. They may also take out any foreign means of payment other than banknotes acquired in Upper V o l ta by debit to a Foreign Account in Francs or an Account in Foreign Currency, again subject to submission of documentation. F ina l ly, they may take out freely up to C F AF 25,000 in B C E AO banknotes, F rench banknotes, and banknotes issued by Operations Account countries. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to countries of the F rench F ranc Area may be made freely but for statistical purposes certain agri­ cultural products require a license from the Directorate of Commerce. Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Exports to all other countries are permitted freely but some also require a license. Certain commodities can be exported in special circum­ stances only. Exports to Ghana are subject to special regulations. Export proceeds received in currencies other than those of France or another Operations Account country must be surrendered within two months of the date on which the payment falls due (the due date stipulated in the commercial contract, which must not, in principle, be later than 180 days after arrival of the goods at their destination). A ll export transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds C F AF 500,000, and the exporter must sign a foreign exchange commit­ ment and submit a customs certification. Most exports are subject to a customs stamp tax of 6 per cent and a statistical duty of 3 per cent. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the F rench Franc A rea may be retained. A ll amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date. Such proceeds and earnings must not be received in or from Portugal, Rhodesia, or South A f r i c a. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the B C E A O, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue maintaining an Opera­ tions Account w i th the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Resident travelers must declare to the customs any foreign means of payment in excess of C F AF 5,000 that they bring in and w i th in eight days after return surrender these to an authorized bank. Capital A ll capital movements between Upper V o l ta and Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Cap i tal movements between Upper V o l ta and France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the F rench F ranc A r ea are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and a ll outward investment, and over the issuing, adver­ tising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Upper V o l t a; these controls relate to the transactions them­ selves, not to payments or receipts. W i th the exception of those over foreign securities in Upper V o l t a, the control measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above), Monaco, the other member coun­ tries of the West A f r i c an Monetary U n i o n, and those other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the F rench Treasury by an Operations Accoun t. Special controls are maintained also over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and institu­ tions, and over a ll publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate building operations abroad; these special controls do apply also to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. A ll investments abroad by residents of Upper V o l ta require prior authorization by the M in is ter of F inance .3 Foreign direct investments in Upper V o l t a4 must be declared to the M in is ter of Finance before they are made. The M in is ter has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the postponement of the projects submitted to h im. The total or partial liquidation of either type of investment also is subject to prior declaration to the M in is ter. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Upper V o l ta investments abroad or foreign invest­ ments in Upper V o l t a, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and the B C E AO within 20 days following each operation. D irect investments are defined as invest­ ments imp ly ing control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, 3 Including those made through the intermediary of foreign com­ panies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Upper V o l ta and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Upper Vo l ta. i Including those made by companies in Upper V o l ta that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Upper V o l ta of foreign companies. Since October 30, 1975, foreign firms operat­ ing in Upper V o l ta are obliged to "Voltai'ze" their capital within two years, up to at least 51 per cent in vital or priority sectors and up to at least 35 per cent in a ll others. The sale to residents of Upper V o l ta of securities of foreign companies operating in Upper Vo l ta requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance, who establishes the sales value. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Upper Vo l ta requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Upper V o l ta Gove rn­ ment and (2) shares that are similar to or may be substituted for securities whose issue, offering for sale, or sale in Upper V o l ta has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the M in is ter of Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization; (1) loans constituting a direct investment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans taken up by industrial firms to finance transactions abroad, by any type of firm to finance imports into or exports from Upper Vo l t a, or by international trading houses previously approved by the M in is ter of Finance to finance international merchanting transactions; (3) loans contracted by authorized banks; (4) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount out­ standing of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed C F AF 100 m i l l ion for any one borrower, provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate and that the proceeds are imme­ diately surrendered by the sale of foreign currency on the exchange market or debited to a Foreign Account in Francs. The repayment of loans not constituting a direct investment requires the special authorization of the M in is ter if the loan itself was subject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Lending abroad is subject only to exchange control authorization by the B C E A O, acting on behalf of the Minister of Finance. Ordinance N o. 7 0 - 0 7 4 / P R E S / P L - TP of December 31, 1970, the Investment Code, provides preferential treat­ ment for foreign investment in Upper V o l t a. Two pref­ erential categories (A and B) are established, in accord­ ance with which preferential treatment with respect to stable rates of taxes, duties, and other fiscal charges may be accorded to specified enterprises for periods of up to 25 years. The benefits under Category B are far more liberal than those under Category A; they are negotiable between the investor and the Government, and the enterprise accorded such benefits must be of exceptional importance to the development of the country. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System No par value or central rate has been established for Uruguay's currency, the New Peso. Exchange transac­ tions take place in a dual exchange market, consisting of a commercial market and a financial market. Payments and receipts in respect of imports other than books (except when the exchange is purchased more than 180 days after the due date), exports other than books, freight and insurance on imports, and most public sector exchange operations are settled in the commercial market, where the exchange rates are fixed (although adjusted from time to t ime ). A ll other exchange transactions take place in the financial market, in which the exchange rate fluctuates freely. On Decem­ ber 31, 1976 the buying and selling rates in the commercial market were NU r $ 3 . 96 and NU r $ 4 . 0 0, respectively, per US $ 1, and those in the financial market were NU r$4 .155 and NU r$4 .160, respectively, per US $ 1. Various additional effective exchange rates arise from the fo l low ing: (1) the application of exchange taxes (detracciones or retenciones) to the proceeds from cer­ tain traditional exports; (2) the payment of subsidies through tax credit certificates (reintegros) on proceeds from certain exports; (3) a 40 per cent tax on certain profit remittances; and (4) the sale in the financial market of the excess of the actual f.o.b. value over the assumed c.i.f. value (aforo) or minimum surrender value (sobreaforos) on wool exports. The Central Bank of Uruguay supplies foreign exchange to the commercial banks for imports, and the proceeds from exports (valued at the officially assessed price or the aforo where applicable) must be surrendered to the monetary authorities.1 There are no restrictions on exchange transactions in the financial market; exchange houses whose principal business is making exchange transactions, must be authorized by the Cen­ tral Bank. Administration of Control Exchange transactions in the commercial market are carried out through authorized banks, banking houses, and the monetary authorities. A ny person or firm may conduct exchange transactions in the financial market. The Bank of the Republic collects import surcharges, export taxes, and consular charges and accepts export and import registrations. Prescription of Currency Payments between Uruguay and the countries with which Uruguay has concluded reciprocal credit agree- ments may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the central banks, within the framework of the L A F TA multilateral clearing system; these coun­ tries are Argentina, Bo l iv ia, B raz i l, Ch i le, Co lomb ia, Ecuador, Mex ico, Paraguay, Peru, and Venezuela. There are separate arrangements for trade in specified goods with Argentina and B r a z i l. Settlements with other countries in the commercial market are made in U .S. dollars or other convertible currencies. Most transactions in the financial market take place in U .S. dollars, Argentine pesos, or Braz i l ian cruzeiros. Imports and Import Payments A ll imports are subject to registration prior to the placing of orders abroad. The registrations are generally valid for 180 days, within which period goods must be cleared through customs. An import declaration (denuncia) must be submitted to the Bank of the Republic before the goods are shipped at origin. Imports of fully assembled automobiles are temporarily prohibited. Most imports are subject to an import surcharge (recargo). Goods are classified into nine categories; goods in one category bear no surcharge; goods in other categories are subject to surcharges of 10, 30, 40, 55, 75, 120, 150, or 200 per cent, payable at the time of registration.2 Imports from L A F TA countries receive a full or partial exemption from these surcharges. Most imports are subject, in addition to any customs duty required, and the above-mentioned import sur­ charge, to an additional import duty of 18 per cent of the c.i.f. value, payable upon customs clearance, and to another import surcharge (recargo tributario a la im­ portation) of 7 per cent of the c.i.f. value, payable two days after import registration.3 A ll imports are subject to consular charges payable in new pesos and calculated on the f.o.b. value at the commercial market rate. These charges are 3.5 per cent for private sector imports of petroleum and petroleum products, alcohol, and tetra- ethyl lead; 0.25 per cent for imports of the same com­ modities by the Adm in is t ra t ion Nac ional de Com­ bustibles, A l cohol y Portland ( A N C A P ) — t he state o i l, alcohol, and cement enterprise; 4 per cent for a ll other private sector imports; and 0.5 per cent for other imports by A N C A P. Import taxes and surcharges are in most cases ca l­ culated either on assumed c.i.f. prices (aforos) estab­ lished for many commodities or on the actual c.i.f. value, whichever is higher. In a few cases, the calculation is based on an officially assessed price, which usually is expressed in U .S. dollars per kilogram. 1 The Central Bank was established on Ma r ch 1, 1967, but some operations are still being carried out on its behalf by the Bank of the Republic. The term "monetary authorities" as used here refers to both banks taken together. 2 On M a r ch 2, 1977 the surcharges of 75, 120, 150, and 200 per cent were reduced to 65, 90, 110, and 150 per cent, respectively. :? On M a r ch 2, 1977 the 7 per cent surcharge was raised to 10 per cent for almost all imports. 489 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U R U G U AY Importers may purchase foreign exchange in the com­ mercial market at any time from 5 days before to 180 days after the payment to the supplier falls due.4 Purchases at any later date must be made in the financial market unless they are refinanced within 180 days.5 Purchases with an exchange rate guarantee (ventas futuras) require a peso deposit at the time of applica­ tion; the exchange is provided on the due date and the applicable exchange rate is the commercial market rate on the date of application for the guarantee. The facility is available only for import transactions that are financed abroad, and capital goods are ineligible. Payments for Invisibles Freight and insurance on imports are settled in the commercial market. Payments for a ll other invisibles may be made freely through the financial market. Cer­ tain profit remittances are subject to a tax of 40 per cent. There are no limitations on the export of foreign or domestic banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds The proceeds of the principal traditional exports, except beef, are subject to taxes (detracciones or retenciones), which are withheld by the monetary autho­ rities on the basis of either the f.o.b. value or the aforo value of the commodity concerned. The tax is stipulated in pesos per unit of export commodity (as a percentage of the f.o.b. value for woo l ), but it may not be more than 50 per cent or less than 0.01 per cent of the peso proceeds of the export, except that for exports of wool the permitted limits are 2 per cent and 35 per cent of the f.o.b. value. The exchange proceeds of traditional exports subject to taxes must be surrendered in full to the monetary authorities, upon receipt. At the end of 1976 the prescribed maximum surrender period was generally not later than 30 days after the date of the shipment authorization request for traditional exports, and 210 days after shipment for nontraditional exports. For wool exports, minimum f.o.b. values (minimum surrender prices or aforos) expressed in U . S. dollars per kilogram have been established for various grades and types. There are special arrangements for the advance surrender (preanticipos) of the exchange pro­ ceeds from exports that are financed in foreign currency, either abroad or by domestic banks. Surrender must be before the export is registered and is permitted for wool, meat, cereals, oilseeds, and nontraditional exports. Sub­ sidies in the form of tax credit certificates (reintegros) of up to 45 per cent of the f.o.b. value are granted on certain (primarily nontraditional) exports. Exports of cattle on the hoof (except when specially authorized), specified minerals (including iron, copper, zinc, aluminum, and n i ck e l ), and protein concentrates * With effect from February 28, 1977 the maximum was lowered to 120 days. 5 With effect from February 28, 1977, 120 days. 490 used for animal feed are prohibited. Exports of sheep­ skin, wheat, sorghum, corn, and sunflower seeds are prohibited when production falls short of domestic con­ sumption requirements. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no surrender requirements on the proceeds from invisibles. A ny individual or firm may accept foreign currencies at the rate prevailing in the financial market. There are no limitations on the import of foreign or domestic banknotes. Capital Inward and outward capital transfers by either resi­ dents or nonresidents may be made freely through the financial market, w i th the exception of certain inward and outward transfers relating to investments registered under the Foreign Investment L aw. However, certain borrowing abroad is controlled, and the amortization or liquidation proceeds of foreign capital registered under the Foreign Investment Law cannot normally be trans­ ferred abroad until three years after the date on which the investment was approved. New foreign investments in Uruguay, as we ll as certain existing foreign invest­ ments, are governed by a Foreign Investment Law (Law N o. 14179 of M a r ch 28, 1974, as amended by Law N o. 14244 of July 26, 1974, Decree N o. 808/974 of October 10, 1974, and Law N o. 14371 of A p r il 29, 1975). Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Uruguay or abroad, provided that the transactions are registered. G o ld may be exported only if accompanied by evidence of prior importation. Any private purchases abroad for nonindustrial use, how­ ever, must either be financed from the buyer's own exchange holdings or settled through the financial mar­ ket. Imports and exports of gold for industrial use are settled through the commercial market. Changes during 1976 January 28. Decree N o. 3 /976 suspended the pro­ hibition on exports of deboned meat. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.265275 gram of fine gold per Venezuelan Bo l ivar. The exchange rate is Bs 4.2925 per U . S. dollar, except that a rate of Bs 4.20 per U . S. dollar applies in any exchange transactions arising in connection with the discharge of liabilities by former foreign owners or concessionaries in the Venezuelan hydrocarbon and iron ore industries. The Central Bank's buying rate for all transactions other than those of the public sector and international organizations is Bs 4.28 per U . S. dollar. The Central Bank's buying rate for the public sector and international organizations and the selling rate between the Central Bank and the commer­ c ial banks is Bs 4 .2925 .1 The commercial banks purchase foreign exchange from the public at rates close to Bs 4.28 per US $ 1. Commercial banks must sell exchange to the public at Bs 4.30 per US$1 for all transactions; foreign banks may only sell foreign exchange that has not been obtained from the Central Bank. Some foreign exchange is also negotiated on the two stock exchanges, where buying and selling rates usually are slightly below B s 4 . 30 per U S $ 1. Exchange houses are permitted to deal only in banknotes, coins, and travelers checks. Venezuela formally accepted the obligations of A r t i­ cle V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from July 1, 1976. Administration of Control There is no exchange control mechanism. Import and export licenses, when required, are generally issued by the M in is t ry of Development or the M in is t ry of A g r i­ culture and Livestock, depending on the commodity; for certain agricultural products, the prior approval of the Ag r icu l tu ral Marke t ing Corporation must be obtained before applications for export licenses are submitted to these ministries. Under the terms of an agreement between the Government and the Central Bank, the latter has the responsibility of ensuring that a subsidy is applied to imports of wheat for human consumption and to certain exports of coffee and cacao. The Superinten- dency of Foreign Investments ( S I E X) is charged with supervision over foreign investment in Venezuela, over contracts for the importation of foreign technology and the use of foreign patents and trademarks, and over borrowing abroad. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Payments between Venezuela and Argentina, Bo l iv ia, B raz i l, Ch i le, Co lomb ia, Cuba, the Dom in ican Republic, 1 The Central Bank does not sell foreign exchange to the public but does sell minor amounts to its staff and certain government officials, at the rate of Bs 4.30 per US$1, for travel expenses. 492 Ecuador, Mex ico, Peru, and Uruguay may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the Central Bank of Venezuela and the central banks of the countries concerned. Imports and Import Payments The import of certain goods is either prohibited or reserved for the Government; these include fully assem­ bled automobiles, certain textiles, coffee, citrus fruit, bananas, pineapples, melons, salt, opium, cigarette paper, natural pearls, and matches. In addition, many other commodities require import licenses; quantitative restric­ tions applicable irrespective of origin are maintained on some of these items for protective purposes. Licenses are valid for all countries except Rhodesia and South A f r i c a. Import licenses for some products are issued on the condition that the importer has purchased domestic products equal to a prescribed percentage of the quantity imported (contingentamiento). A ll other commodities are free from import licensing. Imports from Rhodesia and South A f r ica are prohibited. Import payments may be made freely. Payments for Invisibles A ll payments for invisibles may be made freely; pri­ vate sector purchases of exchange for this purpose are made from commercial banks or exchange houses. Transfers of profits and dividends are limited in princi­ ple to 14 per cent per annum of registered foreign capi­ tal. Resident and nonresident travelers must pay on departure a travel tax of Bs 80 a person a trip; exemp­ tions exist for children under seven, foreign tourists, Venezuelan and foreign diplomats, and personnel of international organizations. Travelers may freely export domestic and foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain furs and hides, scrap metals, and a few other commodities are prohibited. Licenses are required for the exportation of many other commodities. Export licenses for most commodities are issued by the M in is t ry of Development, but those for coffee, cacao, rice, and sugar are granted by the M in is t ry of Ag r icu l­ ture and Livestock. The export of gold and precious stones requires an export license issued by the Ministry of Finance. There are no surrender requirements for export pro­ ceeds or other exchange receipts. Exporters of coffee and cacao may receive an export subsidy calculated to prevent the f.o.b. bolivar prices of these products in Venezuelan ports from falling below specified minimum amounts regardless of external prices. E l ig ib i l i ty for this subsidy is maintained even if the exchange proceeds are not surrendered. In principle, the benefit of these arrangements based on guaranteed minimum prices may ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution V IET NAM (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System V iet N am has two currency areas corresponding to the former No r th and South V iet N am. No par value has been established with the Fund. The rep­ resentative rate for the South Vietnamese dong is SD 2.13087 = S D R 1. On November 30, 1976, the buying and selling rates for the U . S. dollar were SD 1.85 and SD 1.90, respectively, per US $ 1. Exchange rates for 12 other currencies 1 are determined on the basis of the representative rate for the South V ie t­ namese dong and the exchange rates of these cur­ rencies in terms of the SDR, as published by the Fund on the previous business day. Exchange rates for 13 other currencies 2 are determined on the basis of international foreign exchange market quotations. The branch of the State Bank in Hoch im inh C i ty does not buy certain currencies for which it quotes exchange rates to facilitate conversion for accounting purposes. These are A lger ian dinars, Aus tr ian schillings, Burmese kyats, Dan ish kroner, Egyptian pounds, F inn ish markkaa, Guinean sylis, Indian rupees, M a li francs, Netherlands guilders, and Thai baht. A premium of 25 per cent applies to all inward private transfers and receipts from tourism in Australian dollars, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Hong K o ng do l­ lars, Japanese yen, Malayasian ringgit, pounds sterling, Singapore dollars, Swiss francs, and U . S. dollars. The exchange rate of the No r th Vietnamese dong in terms of the U . S. dollar is determined month by month on the basis of a currency basket whose composition and weights are adjusted to changing circumstances. In setting the exchange rate for the U . S. dollar the V ie t­ namese authorities take into account exchange rate developments of the U . S. dollar in the previous month and make a judgmental forecast for the following month. Exchange rates for the other 23 currencies 3 quoted by the State Bank in Hanoi for the period of one month are based on the daily average exchange rate of the respective currency in terms of the U . S. dollar during the previous month. The State Bank in Hanoi does not buy the following currencies which are, however, quoted to facilitate conversion for accounting purposes: A lger ian dinars, Austrian schillings, Burmese kyats, Danish kroner, Egyptian pounds, F inn ish markkaa, Guinean sylis, Indian rupees, M a li francs, and Th ai baht. 1 Australian dollars, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Malaysian ringgit, Nether­ lands guilders, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, and Swiss francs. 2 Algerian dinars, Austrian schillings, Burmese kyats, Danish kroner, Egyptian pounds, Finnish markkaa, Guinean sylis, Hong Kong dollars, Indian rupees, Mali francs, Norwegian kroner, Singapore dol­ lars, and Thai baht. 3 Algerian dinars, Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, Danish kroner, Egyptian pounds, Finnish markkaa, French francs, Guinean sylis, Hong Kong dollars, Indian rupees, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Malaysian ringgit, Mali francs, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Singapore dollars, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and Thai baht. 494 A premium of 50 per cent applies to a ll inward private transfers and receipts from tourism in Aus tra l ian dollars, deutsche mark, F rench francs, Hong K o ng dollars, Malaysian ringgit, pounds sterling, Singapore dollars, Swiss francs, and U . S. dollars. Trade transactions with C M EA countries,4 Albania, the People's Republic of Ch ina, and N o r th Ko rea are settled in "bilateral rubles" at an exchange rate of rub 1 = ND 3.27. Nontrade transactions w i th these countries take place at exchange rates specified in the respective bilateral payments agreements. The exchange rate between the N o r th Vietnamese dong and the South Vietnamese dong is ND 1 = SD 0.80. The only transactions permitted between the two regions are officially authorized trade and travel. Administration of Control V iet N am does not yet have a common exchange control law. A ll exchange and trade regulations apply­ ing in the South before M ay 1975 have been repudiated and new legislation similar to that prevailing in the No r th has been progressively introduced. Exchange control is administered by the State Bank in Hanoi for the No r th and its branch office in Hoch im inh C i ty for the South. A ll foreign trade is a state monopoly and is administered by the M in is t ry of Foreign Trade which authorizes the foreign trade transactions carried out by specialized state import-export corporations. Import and export licenses issued by the M in is t ry of Foreign Trade upon application by the import-export corporation carrying out the transaction are granted only for imports and exports contained in the foreign trade plan. A ll foreign exchange transactions are carried out by the Foreign Trade Bank, wh ich is a branch of the State Bank. Prescription of Currency Payments for trade transactions w i th some countries 5 w i th which V iet N am has bilateral payments agreements are made in "bilateral rubles." Nontrade transactions with these countries and other countries 6 wjhyb_which V iet N am has bilateral payments agreements are made in currencies and in accordance w i th the procedures set forth in those agreements. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents are permitted to maintain nonresident accounts in either foreign currencies or in No r th or South Vietnamese currencies. Nonresidents can freely * Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, and U.S.S.R. 5 Albania, Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Mongolia, North Korea, Poland, Romania, and U.S.S.R. « Egypt, Guinea, India, and Mali. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution reconvert into foreign currency and transfer abroad unused balances in Vietnamese currencies which have been acquired against foreign currency. Imports and Exports An annual import and export plan is drawn up annually for the entire country based on import needs and export possibilities. Import and export transactions are carried out by specialized state import-export cor­ porations on the basis of licenses issued by the M in i s t ry of Fore ign Trade. A ll payments for trade transactions need the authorization of the State Bank and are made through the Foreign Trade Bank. Export receipts are normally channeled through the Foreign Trade Bank and any other receipts from foreign trade have to be surrendered to the State Bank. Imports and exports of precious metals, precious stones, and pearls need the permission of the State Bank. Invisibles A ll transactions in invisibles require individual author­ ization by the State Bank. Foreign exchange is made available upon authorization of the transaction. A ll travel abroad needs ind iv idual authorization and is presently limited to official business for which a ll foreign exchange expenses are covered. (Travel between the No r th and South presently needs official approval. A minimum amount of ND 200 a person can be exchanged V I ET N AM and a maximum is set by the State Bank on a case-by- case basis.) Students abroad in nonsocialist countries who had left the country before A p r il 1975 can receive foreign exchange allocations the amount of which is determined by the State Bank for each individual case. Receipts from transactions in invisibles have to be surrendered to the State Bank w i th in seven days. The export and import of Vietnamese currencies and of securities denominated in Vietnamese currencies need the special permission of the State Bank. Capital Foreign investment in the No r th has been prohibited since 1954. A ll matters concerning past foreign invest­ ment in the South w i ll be settled in bilateral negotiations. A foreign investment law is now in its final drafting stage allowing up to 49 per cent foreign ownership which may rise to 100 per cent in some sectors. Gold On ly the State Bank has authority to purchase, ho ld, and sell gold in any manner, at home or abroad. Physical persons are permitted to own jewelry and artistic and cultural objects of gold for domestic and personal use. Changes during 1976 No significant changes took place. 495 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution WE STERN SAMOA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Western Samoa Ta la has been established with the Fund. A central rate of WS$1 = US$1.67736 was established in 1973. The inter­ vention currency is the U . S. dollar, and Western Samoa avails itself of wider margins. The external value of the tala is determined daily on the basis of the basket of currencies used by New Zealand. Since Decem­ ber 20, 1976 the rate for the New Zealand dollar has been WS$0.76 = $ NZ 1. Exchange rates for other cur­ rencies are determined on the basis of their rates against the New Zealand dollar. On December 31, 1976 the buying and selling rates for the U . S. dollar were WS$0.7909 and WS$0.8090, respectively per U S $ 1. Administration of Control The overall responsibility for the administration of exchange control rests with the Monetary Board, but the authority for the daily administration of the exchange controls and the exchange allocation system rests w i th the Minister of Finance, who is the chairman of the Board. The latter may delegate his approval authority to the F inanc ial Secretary, who in turn may delegate part of his powers to the Secretary of the Monetary D iv i s ion of the Treasury and to authorized banks. A ll payments to nonresidents of Western Samoa require the approval of the M in is t ry of Finance. The M in is t ry, however, has delegated to the Bank of West­ ern Samoa, the only authorized bank, authority to approve certain payments up to any amount and certain other payments up to specified amounts. Prescription of Currency There are no prescriptions as to the currencies in which payments to or from nonresidents of Western Samoa must be made or received. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between the accounts of resi­ dents and nonresidents of Western Samoa. Imports and Import Payments The import of a few commodities is prohibited from a ll sources for reasons of security or health. Other commodities may be imported from any source. Each licensed commercial importer receives an annual allo­ cation of foreign exchange, to be taken up on a semi­ annual basis, wh ich may be used freely for the import of any commodity that is not prohibited, except auto­ mobiles.1 The allocations are made by the M in i s t ry of 1 Rice, flour, sugar, milk products, canned fish, mutton flaps, and spare parts for engines may be imported freely outside the allocation system. During 1976 imports of automobiles, except those by the Government and by nonresidents using their own foreign exchange holdings, were limited to 15 a month. 496 Finance and communicated to the Bank of Western Samoa; the latter automatically provides the foreign exchange required for import payments upon submis­ sion of documentary evidence. Persons who are not licensed importers may import any commodity freely up to WS$100 a person a year but require the prior approval of the M in i s t ry of Finance for imports of higher value. Private buyers of motor vehicles are required to lodge an advance deposit of 50 per cent of the retail value with the importing agency. Payments for Invisibles Payments for certain invisibles, such as overseas con­ tractual obligations and insurance, are approved auto­ matically by the Bank of Western Samoa up to any amount or within limits determined by the M in is try of Finance. Payments in excess of these limits as well as payments for all other invisibles require the prior approval of the M in i s t ry of Finance. Remittances in respect of study abroad are freely authorized. The M in is t ry of Finance approves up to any amount the transfer of genuine income derived locally from pen­ sions, rents, interests, and dividends by persons perma­ nently resident overseas. Residents traveling to Amer ican Samoa, whether for business or private pur­ poses, are entitled to a foreign currency allowance equivalent to US$200 a person a quarter; an additional allowance of US$50 a day is provided to cover hotel expenses. The basic travel allowance for other countries is equivalent to WS$50 a person a day, subject to a limit of WS$ 1,000 a year. The M in i s t ry of Finance grants supplementary allocations when evidence of genuine need is provided. Resident travelers may take out for­ eign banknotes as part of their foreign currency allow­ ance. Travelers may not take out any domestic currency. Exports and Export Proceeds V i r tua l ly a ll exports require the prior approval of the M in i s t ry of Finance. Exports may be prohibited by the Director of Agr icu l ture on grounds of low quality, or by order of the Head of State to alleviate domestic shortages. Cop ra exports are controlled by the Copra Board, cocoa exports by the Cocoa Board, and banana exports by the Banana Board. Export proceeds must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa within a reasonable time after shipment. Where exceptional circumstances exist, the M in i s t ry of Finance may waive this requirement for certain export items. Proceeds from Invisibles A ll receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa. Resident travelers must on return sell to the Bank a ll foreign currency brought in. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign banknotes, but no domestic banknotes. Capital A ll outward capital transfers by residents require the specific approval of the M in i s t ry of Finance and capital received by residents must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa. Inward capital remittances do not normally require approval, but borrowing abroad by nonbank residents does require approval. The transfer of legacies from estates of deceased local residents due to beneficiaries permanently residing overseas is approved up to a limit of WS$ 10,000 a year. The Bank of West­ ern Samoa approves transfers of gifts to relatives and dependents, either for special family occasions or by way of maintenance, up to WS$200 a year for each family group. Foreign investments in specified activities in Western Samoa are encouraged. The Enterprises Incentive A ct N o. 27 /1965, as amended in 1969, makes provision for the granting of certain relief of customs duties, income tax, and business license fees to persons engaged in approved enterprises. Bo th the repatriation of capital and profit remittances on foreign capital are subject to approval by the M in is ter of Finance; such approval is normally granted. W E S T E RN S AM OA Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form. There are no restrictions on imports or exports of gold in any form. Changes during 1976 January. Not for Redistribution Y EM EN ARAB REPUBL IC (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The currency of the Yemen Arab Republic is the Yemen Rial, which is issued by the Central Bank of Yemen. No par value has been established. A ll trans­ actions take place in a free market at an exchange rate which in principle is a fluctuating one but since February 1973 has remained unchanged. On December 31, 1976 the rate for the U.S. dollar was YR1 1 = US$0.22. Exchange rates for other currencies are fixed daily by the Central Bank on the basis of London cross rates against the U.S. dollar. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Minister of Economy who has the authority, acting in consultation with the President of the Council of Ministers, to grant exchange licenses and licenses for imports and exports. Exchange control over transactions in invisibles is super­ vised by the Central Bank. The only commercial banks and authorized dealers are the Yemen Bank for Recon­ struction and Development and branches of seven foreign commercial banks. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency requirements.1 Settlements are usually made in pounds sterling or U.S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Israel are prohibited. Imports of petro­ leum and petroleum products are reserved for the Yemen Petroleum Company. A ll other imports require import licenses. These are generally issued freely. In addition to a license, the importation of certain com­ modities requires the permission of certain government agencies. The importation of certain textiles requires the approval of the Sanaa textile factory. Imports that are financed by the importer with his own foreign exchange held abroad also require an import license. Importers who have obtained an import license may obtain the necessary foreign exchange from the local banks or the free market; a minimum margin deposit of 20 per cent is prescribed against letters of credit. In addition to the applicable customs duty, imports are subject to a defense tax of 5 per cent and a statistical tax of 2 per cent. 1 There is an inoperative bilateral payments arrangement with Egypt. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles may be made freely. Travelers may freely take out any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel are prohibited. For statistical pur­ poses only, all exports require registration forms, which are issued freely by banks; export licenses are not required. Exporters are not required to surrender the foreign exchange proceeds; these may be retained in foreign currency accounts with domestic banks. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles need not be surrendered but may be retained in foreign currency accounts with domestic banks. Travelers may freely bring in any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Capital No restrictions are imposed on inward or outward capital transfers. Both domestic and foreign investment are regulated by Law No. 18 of 1975. Foreign investors in the Yemen Arab Republic are free to transfer abroad any desired proportion of their net profits after taxes or of their capital. Gold Two commemorative gold coins of YRls 20 and YRls 30 have been issued, which do not circulate in the Yemen Arab Republic. By virtue of Ministerial Decree No. 21/1973 residents are free to purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in the Yemen Arab Republic and to import or export gold in any form without an import, export, or exchange license. Changes during 1976 January 21. Decree No. 6/1976 regulated the agencies and branches of foreign companies and com­ mercial firms. March 10. The suspension of the issue of licenses for imports from Japan was terminated. August 27. For customs valuation purposes, prices in foreign currencies henceforth were first converted into U.S. dollars on the basis of free market rates; the U.S. dollar amounts then were converted into Yemen rials at a fixed rate of US$1 = YRls 5.5. August 27. The practice of collecting certain import duties in kind, previously applied to certain foodstuffs, was discontinued. 498 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PEOPLE 'S DEMOCRAT IC REPUBL IC OF Y EM EN (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The currency of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen is the Yemeni D ina r, which is issued by the Bank of Yemen (the central bank) and is defined as equivalent to 2.13281 grams of fine gold. No par value for the Yemeni dinar has been established w i th the Fund. Since February 1973, the central rate has been YD 1 = US$2.89523 or US$1 = YD 0.345395. On December 31, 1976, the Na t ional Bank of Yemen's buying and selling rates for the U . S. dollar were YD 0.343 and YD 0.350. Administration of Control The administration of exchange control is carried out by the Bank of Yemen's General Department for Exchange Con t rol through the Foreign Exchange C om­ mittee, wh ich has delegated certain powers to the D i rec­ tor of Exchange Con t ro l, a member of the Committee. The M in i s t ry of Trade and Supply issues import and export licenses; those for gold and other precious metals require the prior approval of the D irec tor of Exchange Con t ro l. Exchange transactions must be carried out through the intermediary of authorized dealers (licensed commercial banks approved by the Director of Exchange C o n t r o l ); at present the only commercial bank and authorized dealer is the Na t ional Bank of Yemen. Except for payments for imports against letters of credit or documents, which may be approved by the authorized dealer, and for payments by the o il refinery, a ll payments for imports (including those of precious metals) require the prior approval of the D irec tor of Exchange Con t ro l. Certain public corporations are engaged in foreign trade (see section on Imports and Import Payments, be low). The o il refinery is treated as a resident entity but in its operations generally is not affected by the existing exchange and trade controls. Prescription of Currency Exchange transactions must be carried out through the intermediary of authorized dealers in accordance with prescription of currency regulations that are in certain respects similar to those applicable in the Un i ted K ingdom. A ll payments to Israel and Rhodesia are pro­ hibited. Export proceeds and certain receipts from invisibles must be received in prescribed currenc ies1 and surrendered to authorized dealers. Payments for imports must be made in prescribed currencies. Imports and Import Payments W i th minor exceptions, a ll imports other than those of the o il refinery require individual licenses. Goods originating in the Yemen A r ab Republic are exempt from the licensing requirements. Imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. An import program is drawn up annually. In addition, importers may import certain goods with their own exchange; such imports require prior approval by the M in is t ry of Trade and Supply. Payments for imports on a c. & f. basis against letters of credit or documentary drafts can be made by authorized dealers without the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Con t ro l; most other forms of payment for imports require approval. Insurance on imports must be effected locally. A Trade Counc il is in charge of the trading activities of the nationalized companies. The Na t ional Company for Foreign Trade has a monopoly over imports of flour, sugar, wheat, rice, ghee, cooking o i l, tea, and cigarettes. The Na t ional Import Company L t d. imports certain consumer goods not mentioned in Law N o. 37 of 1969. The Na t ional Company for Home Trade is the sole importer of automobiles and other vehicles, all govern­ ment requirements, and most requirements of the public hospitals, as well as other specified items. Imports into and exports from the free port zones w i th in the port of Aden are free of exchange and trade controls (except in respect of transactions between these zones and the rest of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen) and are exempt from customs duties. 499 ©International Monetary Fund. The basic exchange allowance for tourism, which residents may take up without applying for exchange control approval, is the equivalent of YD 125 a person a trip in travelers checks, drafts, and foreign notes and coins (50 per cent of this amount for children under t en ) .2 Allowances for other types of travel are granted on the merits of the applica­ tion. Foreign employees of approved enterprises and the o il refinery are allowed to remit abroad up to 50 per cent of their total earnings (net of taxes); other for­ eign employees, if receiving their salaries from abroad, are allowed to remit 70 per cent of their total earnings. A ll insurance is nationalized; existing policies have been transferred to the Na t ional Insurance and Reinsurance Company, and payments abroad in respect of premiums are not permitted. Travelers may take out the equivalent of YD 5 in domestic banknotes and up to the equiva­ lent of YD 125 in travelers checks, foreign banknotes, or other foreign means of payment. Furthermore, non­ residents may take out any foreign exchange declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports, including petroleum products, are exempt from licenses. A ll exports to Israel and Rho­ desia are prohibited. Except for exports to the Yemen A rab Republic specified by the Foreign Exchange Com­ mittee, export proceeds must be received in prescribed currencies within six months of shipment and must be sold to authorized dealers upon receipt. Most of the proceeds of exports or re-exports to the Yemen A r ab Republic may be surrendered in the national currency of the importing country. Proceeds from Invisibles A ll claims of residents for services rendered to non­ residents must be collected in foreign currency (or received from an External Accoun t) when due and surrendered to authorized dealers. However, Yemeni nationals working abroad are allowed to establish non­ resident foreign currency accounts. Travelers to the Yemen A r ab Republic may alternatively take out up to YR ls 1,000 in Yemen rials. Capital V i r tua l ly a ll capital payments and transactions require prior approval. Expatriates are normally permitted upon departure to remit their l iqu id funds to their country of permanent residence. Foreign investments that have been approved under the Law for the Organization of Industry and the Pro­ motion of Industrial Investment (Law N o. 23 of M ay 14, 1971) may be granted exemptions from import duty and various other tax facilities. A ll remittances abroad of interest and profits require prior approval by the Director of Exchange Control. Profit remittances abroad by foreign firms under Law N o. 23 also are subject to the Exchange Con t rol Law (Law N o. 16) and in any one year should not normally exceed 50 per cent of the accrued net profit. Beginning five years after production has started, the net value of the enterprise (calculated on the basis of actual or book value or surrender or liquidation value, whichever is less) is transferable at the rate of 25 per cent a year; if an expatriate national or a foreign investor encounters difficulties, however, his capital may be retransferred six months after entry. Interest due on any loans obtained abroad after the firm concerned has been established may also be remitted, provided that all duties, taxes, and other government dues have been paid. Gold On ly the monetary authorities and authorized dealers may purchase, hold, or sell gold bu l l ion. Licensed gold­ smiths may purchase, ho ld, and sell other unworked gold and gold coins and ornaments. Other residents may hold gold only in the form of ornaments or numis­ matic coins. Exports and imports of gold by registered goldsmiths require licenses issued by the M in is t ry of Trade and Supply (General Department for Foreign T rade ); in certain cases, the consent of the Foreign Exchange Committee must also be obtained. Travelers may bring in or take out reasonable amounts of gold, in the form of ornaments only (not exceeding YD 100 in value for departing travelers). Imports and exports of gold by travelers are subject only to customs con­ tro l, but if incoming nonresident travelers wish to sell any gold coins or bu l l ion, they must sell them to an authorized dealer.
