Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0433330 gram of fine gold per Yugoslav D ina r. Since July 12, 1973 the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the dinar within announced margins and therefore a ll transactions, except for receipts and payments effected under the procedures set forth for certain countries with which Yugoslavia has bilateral payments agreements, take place at a fluctuating exchange rate. The buying and selling rates for the U . S. dollar in the foreign exchange market in Belgrade on December 31, 1976 were D in 18.2037 and D in 18.2583, respectively, per US$1. The currencies dealt in are Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, F inn ish markkaa, French francs, Iraqi dinars, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Kuwa i ti dinars, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds ster­ ling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U .S. dollars. Administration of Control On the basis of laws governing these matters, the Federal Executive Counc il prescribes the general pro­ visions in respect of foreign trade and exchange trans­ actions. The Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade, by virtue of these general provisions, establishes rules and regulations, makes decisions governing commercial transactions, and issues import and export licenses when required. It is also charged with securing balanced trade w i th payments agreement countries. The Federal Secretariat for Finance prescribes the specific provisions governing exchange transactions. This Secretariat and the Na t ional Bank of Yugoslavia administer the ex­ change controls. The Na t ional Bank prescribes the methods of payment to and from foreign countries; it also licenses compensation transactions. A ll foreign exchange transactions must be carried out through the Na t ional Bank or an authorized bank. The latter are of three types. F u l ly authorized banks, which must have a minimum credit fund of D in 500 m i l l ion and deposits of at least D in 1,000 m i l l ion, may engage in a ll foreign exchange transactions in Yugoslavia and abroad, as well as in foreign credit operations ( in­ cluding the granting of guarantees). L im i ted authorized banks, which must have a minimum credit fund amount­ ing to D in 100 m i l l ion and deposits of at least D in 200 m i l l ion, may conduct foreign exchange operations in Yugos lav ia only; they may neither keep foreign ex­ change accounts abroad nor engage in foreign credit operations, except through the intermediary of a fully authorized credit bank. Au thor ized exchange offices may only deal in foreign banknotes and travelers checks; this status is open to a ll commercial and savings banks, hotels, and specifically authorized tourist agencies. Commercial exports and imports may be effected by all economic organizations (both producing and trading undertakings) registered for this purpose. Registration is effected automatically, provided that certain condi­ tions, including the provision of minimum working capital for trade enterprises, are fulfilled. Economic organizations that are not registered to conduct foreign trade channel their orders through economic organiza­ tions which export and /or import on their own behalf. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from countries with which Yugo­ slavia has bilateral payments agreements are made in the currencies and according to the procedures set forth in those agreements. If no agreement exists, settlement is usually made in a convertible currency. Yugoslavia has payments agreements requiring settlements through bilateral accounts as follows: (1) in U . S. dollars w i th A lban ia, B r a z i l, Czechoslovakia, the German Demo­ cratic Republic, Ghana, Greece, Mongo l ia, and the U .S .S .R .; and (2) in pounds sterling with V iet N am. Certain settlements with Bangladesh, Co lomb ia, Mex ico, and Pakistan take place through special accounts. A degree of multilateralization of payments is provided under the special payments arrangement with Ghana. For purposes of import and export licensing and the operation of nonresident accounts, Ghana is considered to belong to the convertible area. Nonresident Accounts Foreign jur id ical and physical persons may maintain accounts denominated in foreign exchange and in dinars in Yugoslavia according to the following rules. Fo r­ eigners resident outside Yugoslavia may freely open accounts in convertible currencies or in dinars with fully authorized banks in Yugoslavia. Foreign missions and foreigners resident in Yugoslavia may freely open with any authorized bank accounts expressed in foreign currencies or dinars. Foreign exchange accounts in convertible currencies of nonresident jur id ical and physical persons are kept in the currency deposited.1 Balances on these accounts may be used for a ll payments in Yugoslavia, in dinars or in the currency concerned, and abroad, in any con­ vertible currency. Transfers from these accounts are free if made in the currency in which the account is kept; outward transfers in other convertible currencies are subject to the account-holding bank being prepared to make the necessary conversion. Nonresident foreign exchange accounts in bilateral currencies may be opened only for certain foreign 1 Accounts may be denominated in any of the following currencies: Austr ian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, F inn ish markkaa, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U . S. dollars. 501 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA jur id ical and physical persons resident in Yugoslavia. Balances may be used only for dinar payments in Yugo­ slavia or for retransfer to the bilateral country to which the account is related. Foreign jur id ical and physical persons may freely open nonresident accounts in convertible dinars with authorized banks. Such accounts can be credited freely with amounts whose transfer in convertible currency has been authorized and they may be debited freely for permitted payments in Yugoslavia and for transfer abroad in the convertible currency of the account hold­ er's country of domicile. Nonresident jur id ical and physical persons may also open other dinar accounts with authorized banks. These other accounts may be credited with dinars acquired in Yugoslavia in accordance w i th the existing regulations. Balances are, in principle, nontransferable and may be spent in Yugoslavia only for noncommercial payments by the account holder or by members of his close family, or by the owner and staff of foreign firms if the account holder is a foreign jur id ical person. If balances on these accounts derive from copyright royalties or from work performed in Yugoslavia by foreigners, from pensions and disability allowances of persons who have emigrated from Yugoslavia, or from alimony payments, transfers may be effected in accordance with the existing regulations. Resident nationals may maintain foreign exchange accounts or foreign exchange savings deposits in con­ vertible currencies with any authorized bank. These accounts are kept in the currency deposited, are interest bearing, and interest is paid in the foreign currency deposited. Foreign exchange accounts may be retained for an indefinite period of time and may be drawn upon freely for payments in Yugoslavia and abroad on behalf of the account holder or his immediate family; balances are not transferable to other persons or accounts (see section on Proceeds from Invisibles, be low). Yugoslav nationals residing abroad and former emigrants returning to Yugoslavia may also open foreign exchange accounts in Yugoslavia that may be used freely for payments in Yugoslavia or abroad. Foreign exchange accounts in bilateral currencies may be maintained by resident nationals. In the case of the currencies of certain Eastern European countries 2 and Mongo l ia, the accounts are denominated in dollars of account, and for V iet N am in pounds sterling of account; for other bilateral currencies the accounts are kept in the currency deposited. In general, balances may be used only for dinar payments in Yugoslavia or for retransfers to the bilateral country to which the account is related. Imports and Import Payments Commercial imports may be effected only by eco­ nomic organizations registered as participating in foreign 2 Albania, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, and U.S.S.R. 502 trade. In addition to economic organizations specializing in foreign trade, most major industrial producers are registered. The import of certain basic foodstuffs, such as wheat, rice, coffee, lard, edible oils, and sugar, is carried out by economic organizations that have been selected by the Federal Office for Food Reserves, on the basis of public bids. F or most commodities import licenses are not required. A ll commodities included in the foreign trade nomenclature are classified in four categories, largely in accordance w i th the manner in which exchange is made available: LB — l ibe ra l ized goods; GDK — g o o ds imported under global exchange quotas; RK and DK —goods sub­ ject to individual quotas ( RK if individual quotas are fixed by quantity and DK if they are fixed in d inars); and D —imports subject to ad hoc licensing. Goods in the LB category are mainly raw materials, foodstuffs, and spare parts, but they also include some consumer goods. Protective equipment for workers and a ll other goods not specifically included in the G D K, R K, D K, or D lists are also liberalized and free from any quantitative restriction. Exchange for payments for LB imports from the convertible currency area is made available freely in any convertible currency appro­ priate to the exporting country. Payments for imports of liberalized goods from payments agreement countries must be made in the manner prescribed in the relevant payments agreement and may be restricted according to the availability of funds in the appropriate clearing account. The G DK list comprises raw materials, other repro­ duction materials, most capital equipment, and most of those consumer goods not liberalized under the LB regime. Such imports can be made under several dif­ ferent procedures. Those for nonconsumer goods are as follows: each importer of raw materials and other reproduction materials receives a global foreign exchange quota and may use the exchange so allocated to pur­ chase any such goods listed as G D K. Payment for imports of capital goods on the G DK list may be financed from specific exchange allocations; a consider­ able portion may be freely financed from retention quota funds (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, be low), funds originating in depreciation allowances, and credits obtained abroad, including suppliers' credits. The specific exchange allocations are limited mainly to large investment projects, including public utilities; the amounts are determined by the Federal Assembly. Eco­ nomic organizations may acquire foreign exchange at a predetermined proportion of their annual depreciation allowance, a ratio that varies from 10 to 100 per cent according to the economic sector involved. F or consumer goods, trading enterprises agree within the Chamber of Economy on the distribution of G DK quotas among themselves; if the enterprises are unable to agree among themselves on a G DK allocation, the Federal Secretariat for Market and Prices w i ll allocate this quota among ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution them. A part of the G DK quotas is reserved for imports from developing countries. Imports under commodity quotas (list RK or list D K ), mainly selected agricultural and mineral products (such as wheat, sugar, rice, coffee, and salt) but also machine tools and certain plastics, are subject to quotas estab­ lished for each commodity and cannot be imported under any other procedure. The quotas are established either in physical quantities ( R K) or in dinars ( D K ). There are separate quotas in each case for imports from convertible area countries and payments agreement countries; their allocation among importers is decided by negotiations among the economic organizations.3 Add i t ional quotas may be allocated during the year if the enterprise to wh ich the quota is allocated undertakes to increase exports. Exchange is provided automatically for payments for imports of goods subject to the RK and DK regime, but only up to a predetermined quantity or amount for each item. Goods in list D comprise gunpowder, ammunition, opium, motor vehicles, tractors, railroad ro l l ing stock, aircraft, natural gas, and bitumen. Import licenses are required only for list D commodities. These licenses automatically entitle an enterprise to purchase the requisite foreign exchange. F or certain goods there is an additional requirement, irrespective of those set out above, of a special import license ("accordance") issued by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade. At the end of 1976 these goods were 65 LB items, 5 RK items, 2 DK items, and 1 D item. F or a ll items concerned, the Secretariat may prescribe direct importation from the country of origin; these items include a wide range of tropical foodstuffs and fruits, raw materials, fats, oils, and textiles, as well as tin and raw cotton. Private persons who are Yugoslav nationals and hold foreign exchange accounts with Yugoslav banks may use these funds freely to import goods intended for their own use or for the use of close relatives residing with them, regardless of the import regime for the goods. Self-employed Yugoslav nationals may freely and at any time import machinery for small farms or equipment for handicraft production, up to D in 80,000 a shipment. A l s o, Yugoslavs returning from work abroad and non­ residents residing in Yugoslavia for more than three months may import goods up to D in 80,000 intended for their personal needs or the needs of their own house­ ho ld, provided such goods were paid for from the sav­ ings from their foreign earnings; such savings may be 3 In principle, any such allocation among importers must be agreed on among economic organizations within the Chamber of Economy on the basis of resources and requirements taking into account projected growth rates and the proportions of the balance of payments. If the importers are unable to agree among themselves or if the allocation decided upon does not correspond to established principles, the Federal Secretariat for Fore ign Trade is authorized to decide on the distribu­ tion. Imports of coffee, wheat, corn, rice, and sugar for final con­ sumption are administered by the Federal Office for Food Reserves, which is authorized to select the most competitive importer from among registered importers. The import of coffee is contingent upon Yugoslav exports to the supplying country. Y U G O S L A V IA held abroad or in foreign exchange accounts with Yugo­ slav banks. As an exception to the foregoing, owners of foreign exchange accounts and Yugoslav nationals working abroad may import automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, mopeds, and bicycles, together w i th mounted motors and essential spare parts for these vehicles, provided that importation is effected through a registered enterprise and payment is made through a foreign exchange account held at a Yugoslav bank. Yugoslav and foreign nationals are exempt from this prescribed manner of payment and method of importation, however, under the following circumstances: when they return for perma­ nent residence in Yugoslavia, provided that they have spent at least five years abroad; when a vehicle is inherited; when a motor vehicle is purchased out of an insurance indemnity received for a motor vehicle that has been destroyed and had originally been paid for in foreign currency; and if they have spent at least two years abroad continuously and have owned a vehicle for at least two years. Yugoslav citizens returning from a tourist trip abroad may import goods intended for their household. How­ ever, if the value of the goods exceeds D in 5,000, these goods are usually handed over, at the customs office at the point of entry, to a domestic forwarder for delivery to the owner's address; such delivery cannot be made unless the customs duties are paid. Compensation transactions are authorized only in exceptional circumstances. A 1 per cent special tax for customs evidence and a 5 per cent tax equalization charge 4 are payable on a ll commodities not exempt from customs duty. In addi­ tion, an import surcharge of 10 per cent of the c.i.f. value at the border has to be paid for a ll dutiable com­ modities, with the exception that the surcharge is levied at a reduced rate of 7-9 per cent for capital equipment for the development of basic primary product industries, for some reproduction materials, and for certain essen­ t ial items such as hides. Many agricultural commodities are subject to variable import levies. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles related to merchandise trans­ actions, including transportation, are fully liberalized. Exchange to cover export promotion expenses abroad is made freely available to exporters. Pensions, wages, and salaries are transferable under certain conditions. Payments in respect of royalties and alimony granted by court order are freely transferable, but if a payment is to be made to a country with which Yugoslavia main­ tains bilateral payments arrangements, then such pay­ ments may be made only if the agreement in question provides for this to be done on a reciprocal basis. Au tho­ rized banks may sell foreign currency up to the equiva­ lent of D in 1,000 for remittances for court and other * Increased to 6 per cent with effect from January 1, 1977. 503 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Y U G O S L A V IA fees abroad and for specified personal expenses. The Na t ional Bank may authorize the sale of any amount of foreign exchange for the foregoing and for unspeci­ fied purposes when justified in light of the circumstances. Purchases of services abroad, as well as spare parts, fuel, etc., by Yugoslav enterprises involved in interna­ tional freight and passenger transportation are liberalized. There is no basic exchange allowance for tourist travel abroad. However, travel agencies may sell organized tours abroad against payment in dinars up to an amount equivalent to 100 per cent of their individual retention quotas. The Na t ional Bank may also authorize travel agencies to sell foreign exchange for both group and individual travel abroad. Payments for other invisibles may be made from the remitter's own foreign exchange funds (e.g., from retention quotas, or, when made by various social and sociopolitical organizations, from specific annual allocations). Not more than D in 1,500 in domestic currency, in denominations of D in 100 or less, may be taken out by travelers. Foreign travelers may bring in and take out any amount in foreign exchange without declaring it. Exports and Export Proceeds In principle, exports are free of control, except for certain raw materials that are in short supply on the domestic market (including petroleum and petroleum derivatives and certain livestock) and certain other mate­ rials such as gunpowder, weapons, and narcotic drugs. Exports to countries with which Yugoslavia has a bilateral payments agreement are subject to approval by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade ("accor­ dance"). Such approval may be given for a group of commodities or for a ll commodities to be exported within a certain period (global approval). Permission to export to bilateral countries may be made conditional on an undertaking to import from such countries or to export to other countries. Proceeds from exports must be repatriated within 90 days from the date of exportation, unless specific approval is granted to deviate from this rule. The sur­ render of these proceeds is not required. The full export proceeds may be credited to foreign exchange sight deposit accounts which the exporter maintains with an authorized bank of his choice; separate accounts must be established for each currency. Exchange on these accounts may either be used, subject to the relevant regulations, for payments for imports and invisibles or be sold to an authorized bank. Retention quotas may be used to pay for imports of certain consumer goods if such imports are made by economic organizations that are in the catering and tourist industries or are engaged in setting up trade fairs, and by film enterprises; such imports are also permitted as consignment stocks. The part of the export proceeds that remains at the free disposal of the exporter for payments abroad is 504 referred to as the retention quota; the remainder may be retained indefinitely or used for certain payments abroad, but cannot earn interest. The permitted reten­ tion rate is 20 per cent for a ll export earnings from goods and services, with the exception that a rate of 45 per cent applies to tourist organizations and a rate of 100 per cent applies to foreign exchange earnings of Yugoslav enterprises operating abroad and to Yugoslav enterprises operating under long-term cooperation agree­ ments with foreign companies. (Enterprises with long- term cooperation agreements may in any case import up to the value of their production which is a result of that cooperation.) In some instances (services rendered to foreign tourists and sales of newly mined go ld ), sales against payment in dinars are regarded as exports for retention quota purposes. Producing enterprises selling specified consumer goods in Yugoslavia for foreign currency may retain 20 per cent of the foreign exchange thus earned. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be repatriated within 90 days from the date on which the c la im is payable. The performance of construction and engineering ser­ vices in payments agreement countries is subject to an "accordance" issued by the Federal Secretariat for For­ eign Trade. Receipts from services are eligible for retention quotas; the quota for hotels and tourist agen­ cies is 45 per cent. Exchange proceeds may be used for payments abroad connected with the activities of the economic organization concerned, including payments for purchases of equipment and other material for its own needs. The retained exchange is not transferable to economic organizations other than those w i th which the recipients are cooperating in technical and business matters, but it can always be sold to authorized banks. If the exchange is used to pay for imports, the usual import procedures apply. Residents who, while employed abroad, deposited their savings in foreign savings banks and obtained a "savings book," may withdraw their balances in the form of foreign exchange when in Yugoslavia. Residents may ho ld interest-bearing foreign currency accounts in Yugoslavia. The accounts may be credited with the fu ll amount of a person's savings in foreign exchange. These accounts may be used freely for the personal needs of the account holder and of close members of his family; they are not transferable to other persons or accounts and may be retained for an indefinite period of time. Au thor ized trade organizations may sell manufac­ tured goods to foreign tourists in Yugoslavia against payment in foreign exchange at a discount freely estab­ lished by the trade organizations themselves. This dis­ count is granted only on purchases in authorized shops against checks expressed in foreign currencies or against certain foreign banknotes. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Not more than D in 1,500 in Yugoslav banknotes, in denominations of D in 100 or less, may be brought in by travelers. Capital Foreign loans and credits may be freely contracted by fully authorized banks and economic organizations, with the exceptions that no consumer goods may be imported on deferred payment terms and that no foreign financial credits may be taken up whose repayment terms include a grace period of less than two years.5 A ll other inward or outward transfers of a capital nature by residents or nonresidents require individual licenses. Foreign loans and credits must be recorded with the Na t ional Banks of the republics. Loans must ordinarily be repaid with foreign exchange that is either obtained by the economic organization concerned as export reten­ tion quotas and foreign exchange amortization (depre­ ciation) allocations or acquired from banks according to the regulations governing the foreign trade regime. Credits in the former category are subject to prior dinar deposit requirements; the deposits are noninterest bearing and are held with the Na t ional Banks of the republics until full repayment of the foreign credits. F or financial credits and foreign exchange deposits received by business banks for the account of non­ residents, the five basic rates of deposit introduced in A p r il 1972 range from 1 per cent for maturities over ten years to 40 per cent for maturities of less than two years. However, as a temporary measure beginning in mid-December 1972, a dinar deposit of 75 per cent was required for a ll financial credits and foreign exchange deposits by nonresidents regardless of maturity. F or credits for the importation of capital goods, the deposit rates at the end of 1976 were 20 per cent for credits with a maturity of up to three years; 10 per cent for credits of between three and five years; and 1 per cent for credits with a maturity of over five years. However, if the capital goods were imported for investments in under­ developed regions of Yugoslavia, the latter deposit rates were 10 per cent for credits with a maturity of up to three years and 1 per cent for credits w i th a longer maturity and for a ll credits for the import of specially produced capital equipment. Certain foreign credits are specifically exempted from the foregoing deposit requirements; these include credits from specified international financial organizations, credits contracted for or on behalf of the Federal Gov­ ernment or the Na t ional Bank, and credits contracted for the importation of equipment intended for high- priority sectors and activities as defined by Decisions of the Federal Executive Coun c i l. Foreign credits repayable with foreign exchange acquired according to the regulations governing the foreign trade regime are trade credits for raw materials 5 When enterprises issue bonds abroad, they may use 80 per cent of the foreign exchange proceeds for the import of equipment and spare parts for their own needs. Y U G O S L A V IA and intermediate goods, usually with a maturity of up to 360 days. These are exempt from deposit require­ ments. As an exception, if the goods imported on credit are under the LB regime, 25 per cent must normally be deposited with the Na t ional Banks of the republics or the autonomous provinces as a downpayment and the remaining 75 per cent is payable at maturity. Foreigners may invest in certain Yugoslav economic organizations but only through joint ventures; such for­ eign investment is limited to 49 per cent of the organiza­ tion's capital. Profit transfers abroad may be financed from the retention quota and, in addition, profit trans­ fers are permitted up to one third of the joint venture's foreign currency earnings from exports of goods and services. If the law governing joint ventures were to be amended, the legal provisions in force on the date of registration of a joint venture would continue to be applied during the entire life of the investment contract, if the foreign investor so desires or, at the latter's option, any more favorable provisions of the amended legisla­ tion would be applied. Foreign firms are permitted to establish representational offices in Yugoslavia. The investment income earned abroad by Yugoslav economic organizations must be repatriated within 90 days; however, when repatriated the profits are gov­ erned by the regulations for retention quotas. Residents are obliged to repatriate and, with the exception of inheritances, to surrender a ll foreign exchange held or accruing abroad on capital account. Outward capital transfers by residents who are physi­ cal persons are not approved. Economic organizations wishing to participate in foreign enterprises may be allowed under special conditions, by the Federal Secre­ tariat for Foreign Trade and the Federal Secretariat for Finance, to export the necessary capital. A l s o, a D e c i­ sion of the Federal Executive Counc il of October 14, 1955 requires the Yugoslav authorities to continue to permit the remittance of inheritances to citizens of the Un i ted States, provided that the remittance is requested w i th in three years from the date of distribution of the estate. Gold The Na t ional Bank has issued certain commemorative gold coins, which are not legal tender. Foreign travelers are freely permitted to import and export these coins, subject to customs declaration and, for exports, subject to proof that they have been purchased in Yugos lav ia. Residents who are private persons may ho ld gold coins in Yugoslavia, which may be sold to the Na t ional Bank or to any authorized bank, and they may freely ho ld, purchase, import, and sell gold jewelry and other articles of gold. Domestic economic organizations that have been regis­ tered as trading in gold may import gold jewelry under the G DK import regime; they may freely export gold jewelry and other articles of gold. Au thor ized banks may freely export gold coins. Sales of newly mined gold to the 505 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Y U G O S L A V IA National Bank against payment in dinars (calculated by applying the rate of Din 17 per U.S. dollar to a price of US$42.22 an ounce) are regarded as exports and entitle the seller to a retention quota of 20 per cent in convertible foreign exchange. Other domestic sales of newly mined gold by the producers may be made at a price which equals the average quotation in free gold markets abroad. Domestic economic organizations using gold for their normal activities may purchase gold from domestic producers or abroad on the basis of quotas allocated to each such organization individually. Not for Redistribution ZAIRE (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.77734 grams of fine gold per Zaire. A central rate of Z 1 = SDR 1 has been established, and Zaire avails itself of wider margins. The interven­ tion currency is the U . S. dollar. The Bank of Zaire (the central bank) determines the buying and selling rates of the zaire for the U . S. dollar on the basis of the Fund's daily calculations of the U . S. do l lar-SDR rate. The exchange rates between the zaire and other currencies are quoted on the basis of the Fund's daily calculations, if available, or on the basis of their cross rates with the U .S. dollar. Forward exchange transactions are pro­ hibited. Administration of Control The Bank of Zaire has regulatory authority over all foreign trade and payments. Specifically, the Bank has discretionary power to authorize payments and receipts in foreign exchange by residents of Zaire, and to permit the importation, exportation, and transit of goods. Prescription of Currency Payments from nonresidents must be received in listed convertible currencies quoted daily by the Bank of Za i re .1 Special authorization for the acceptance of other currency may only be given in respect of currencies that can be exchanged freely without a discount. Payments to nonresidents must be made in the listed currencies. However, certain settlements with Burund i, Rwanda, and Uganda are made through special accounts established under arrangements concluded by the Bank of Zaire with the central banks of the countries concerned. Nonresident Accounts There are three categories of nonresident accounts: Nonresident Accounts in Zaires, Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts, and Convertible Accounts in Zaires. in Zaires may generally be Nonresident Accounts debited only with the approval of the Bank of Zaire. Such accounts, when opened by diplomatic missions and international organizations established in Zaire, may be debited freely but may be credited only with the pro­ ceeds of sales of foreign currency and with payments made by the Government. Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts may be credited for any permitted payment in foreign currency; they may be debited freely for transfers to accounts abroad or to Resident and Nonresident Foreign Cu r­ rency Accounts, and for sales of foreign currency against domestic currency. Nonresident Za i r ian nationals require special authorization from the central bank to open these accounts with authorized banks; nonresident foreigners may open them freely. Convertible Accounts in Zaires may be credited in accordance with C i rcu lar N o. 131 2 and debited freely for conversion into foreign currency or for any pay­ ments in domestic currency. Such accounts may be held by both residents and nonresidents but must not be credited with payments for exports of goods or services. Imports and Import Payments The importation of a number of goods is prohibited on grounds of public policy; these are mainly arms, ammunition, narcotics, and jukeboxes. The importation of specified luxury items (including certain automobiles, jewelry, and furniture) is prohibited for economic reasons. Import licenses submitted to the Bank of Zaire for prior approval are required for most commodities other than certain priority items (mainly foodstuffs, pharmaceuticals, raw materials, and industrial spare parts). F or most goods subject to license the importer must obtain either a discount of 6 per cent from the exporter's list price or a credit of at least 180 days after shipment, while for specified priority items the importer must obtain a discount of 3 per cent or a credit of 90 days. Those imports which are not subject to import license approved by the central bank are subject to import declarations, which do not require the approval of the central bank. The central bank has issued a general import and payments license which for such goods guarantees the availability of foreign exchange11 when payments fall due, provided that the importer files an import declaration w i th his bank following the actual placing of the order and provided that invoice price and quality have been verified and found accept­ able by the foreign correspondents of the Office Zairois de Controle. Such verification is also required for all other imports. Applications for import licenses, whether requiring foreign exchange or not, are made out at authorized banks, which forward the applications to the central bank after certification. After approval of the appli­ cation by the central bank, which is given in the form of a visa, the import license application is returned to the intermediary authorized bank for validation. Import licenses validated by the authorized banks remain valid for customs clearance for six months starting from the first day of the month following that in which validation by the commercial bank takes place. Foreign exchange is in principle made available for all licensed imports, the validated license constituting at the same time an exchange license; for payments purposes, the license 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, C FA francs, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U . S. dollars. 2 Conversion of foreign currency at the official rate, transfer from another Convertible Account in Zaires, or authorized payments by residents to nonresidents. 3 Th is guarantee has been temporarily suspended. 508 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution remains va l id as long as the relevant payments have not been completed. F or certain priority imports covered by trade credits of 60 days or more the Bank of Zaire is prepared to guarantee the provision of foreign exchange when the payment falls due. The counterpart of the value of goods imported under the Belgian food aid program, the U . S. import support program, and the agricultural aid program must be deposited within 120 to 180 days after their shipment. A ll imports are subject to a statistical tax of 3 per cent ad valorem and a turnover tax of 9 per cent. Fu r­ thermore, commercial banks are instructed to require importers to deposit 20, 25, 50, or 80 per cent of the c.i.f. value of imports (varying according to the nature of the goods), before opening bank guarantees {credits de signature) in their favor. Imports of specified priority items are exempted from the deposit requirement when the importation is effected by specified local companies. In addition, most imports, irrespective of origin, are subject to a temporary import surcharge of either 5 per cent or 20 per cent ad valorem on the c.i.f. value. Payments for Invisibles Po l icy related to payments for invisibles is formulated by the central bank. Certain payments are subject to authorization by the central bank; the approval authority for other current payments has been delegated to the authorized banks. The central bank w i ll not authorize exchange for the payment of commissions in favor of shippers or purchasing agents or for insurance on imports except for imports payable on arrival, and pro­ vided that the supplier has arranged the insurance. Imports and exports between Zaire and ports in Belgium, the Federal Republic of Germany, the Netherlands, and the Scandinavian countries must be shipped in vessels participating in the conference of the Associated Cen­ tral West A f r i ca Lines. Banks are not authorized to pay in foreign currency the maritime freight on ship­ ments that do not meet these regulations, unless an immediate discount is obtained on the invoice, and in the case of exports, banks are not authorized to validate export declarations unless these are marked accordingly. Banks may effect maritime freight payments in foreign currency at the time of shipment only for imports pay­ able upon arr iva l. Ma r i t ime freight charges may be paid in Zaire in local currency when goods are transported entirely by the Compagnie Ma r i t ime Zai'roise. Transfers abroad of rents, profits, and dividends are suspended, while transfers of salaries of foreign nationals, and cer­ tain other current payments, are authorized on the basis of appropriate documentation. Transfers of royalties require the prior approval of the Service de la Propriete Industrielle. Fares for travel abroad may be paid in Zaire in local currency. Zai'rian nationals traveling abroad may buy foreign exchange in amounts depending on the duration of the journey, up to the equivalent in zaires of BF 30,000 a trip; applications exceeding this amount are Z A I RE subject to individual approval by the central bank. The export of domestic banknotes and coins is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may take out any foreign means of payment declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports not covered by general license require individual declarations. Banks are normally authorized to approve such declarations, in which exporters under­ take to collect the exchange proceeds. The declaration must specify the nature of the merchandise to be exported, the price, and the currency in which payment is to be received. Export declarations are normally va l id for three months; within this period, the proceeds must be received and surrendered. Most exports of minerals are subject to special regulations to take into account the time required for processing abroad. For mineral products exported by the Generate des Carrieres et Mines du Zaire (G ECAM IN E S), a provisional payment of a variable portion of the shipment's estimated value has to be received and surrendered within 8 days after shipment. F or diamond exports, two thirds of the value established at a preliminary examination in Zaire must be surrendered before the shipment is dispatched. Export proceeds from coffee must be surrendered within 45 days after shipment, which must take place w i th in a period of three months from the signing of the sales contract. Receipts from other agricultural exports must generally be repatriated w i th in three months of valida­ tion. M i n im um export prices have been established for coffee, tea, ivory, and certain other commodities. A ll exports are subject to a statistical tax of 1 per cent ad valorem, and a ll commodities except cement are subject to export duties. Proceeds from Invisibles A ll exchange receipts from invisibles must be sur­ rendered. The import of domestic banknotes and coins is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign means of payment and may take out on departure the amount declared on entry. Capital The repatriation of new foreign capital brought in under the provisions of the Investment Code (Ordinance- Law N o. 69-032 of June 26, 1969 as amended by Law N o. 74-004 of 1974) is guaranteed, as is the transfer of profits and dividends on such capital. W i th minor excep­ tions, other transfers abroad of capital owned by resi­ dents or nonresidents are not permitted. Gratuitous transfers of real estate are subject to approval by execu­ tive ordinance. The foreign currency assets of the autho­ rized banks are not permitted to exceed their short-term liabilities in foreign currencies. Gold Residents other than the monetary authorities, pro­ ducers of gold, and industrial users are not allowed to 509 ©International Monetary Fund. The import and export of gold in any form, except jewelry constituting the per­ sonal effects of a traveler, require the prior approval of the central bank. Producers are not required to sell their production to the central bank. A ll newly produced gold is exported, w i th the exception of small quantities used domestically for the manufacture of jewelry. Changes during 1976 January 16. (2) The banks were authorized to register and validate all import declarations for imports of foodstuffs, phar­ maceuticals, raw materials, and industrial spare parts, and the system of reserving importation of foodstuffs and pharmaceutical products for certain importers was revoked. (3) Import licenses for all items other than those specified in (1) and (2) continued to require the prior approval of the Bank of Zaire, but it was announced that, apart from imports restricted for eco­ nomic reasons (viz., wheat flour, sugar, beer, mineral water, soft drinks, portland cement, tires and tubes, electric batteries, and iron products), the prior approval requirement would serve only for statistical purposes and would not be the occasion for applying administra­ tive restraints. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA (Position on December 31, 1976) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.14592 grams of fine gold per Zambian Kwacha. Since July 9, 1976 the central rate for the kwacha has been maintained in terms of the SDR at a rate of K 1 = S DR 1.08479, and Zambia continues to avail itself of wider margins. The U . S. do l­ lar is the intervention currency, and the Bank of Zam­ bia's rates for the U . S. dollar are based on the Fund's daily calculation of the U . S. d o l l a r - SDR rate. The Bank of Zambia deals with the Government and with authorized banks normally in U . S. dollars and sterling. Authorized banks are free to deal in other currencies at rates based on daily rates provided by the Bank of Zambia or on the basis of cross rates with the U . S. dol­ lar prevailing in the international foreign exchange markets. In its dealings with the commercial banks the Bank of Zambia applies a margin of V* of 1 per cent for purchases of foreign exchange and Vi of 1 per cent for sales. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Zambia under powers delegated to it by the M in is ter of Finance. M u ch of the authority for approving normal current payments is in turn delegated to commercial banks authorized to deal in foreign exchange. The con­ trol of trade is the responsibility of the Minister of Commerce, who also issues import and export licenses. Overall import policy is made by a committee on which the M in is t ry of Commerce, the M in is t ry of Finance, and the Bank of Zambia are represented. Prescription of Currency Authorized payments, including payments for imports, by residents of Zambia to residents of countries other than Rhodesia may be made in Zambian currency to the credit of an External Account, or in any foreign cur­ rency other than Rhodesian currency. Payments from residents of countries other than Rhodesia may be received in sterling or in Zambian currency from an External Account, or in any foreign currency freely exchangeable for U . S. dollars or sterling. Special regu­ lations apply to settlements with Rhodesia. A ll permitted payments to residents of Rhodesia must be made in Rhodesian currency, in Zambian currency to an External Account earmarked Rhodesia, in sterling to a Rhode­ sian Account in the Un i ted K ingdom, in U . S. dollars, or in Canadian dollars. Proceeds from exports to Rhodesia must be received in U . S. or Canadian dollars. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Zambian currency held w i th authorized banks by residents of countries other than Rhodesia are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited w i th authorized payments from residents of 512 Zambia, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any foreign cur­ rency except Rhodesian currency by nonresidents to authorized banks. They may be debited for payments for any purpose to residents of Zambia, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for purchases of any for­ eign currency other than Rhodesian currency from authorized banks. Blocked Accounts in Zambian currency held with authorized banks by residents of any country other than Zambia are credited with nontransferable capital sums in Zambian currency. A ll debits and credits to such accounts require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. No rma l ly, approval is given for the investment of balances on blocked accounts in Zambian securities, provided that these are held in Zambia to the order of an authorized dealer. The interest on blocked account balances is freely transferable to the account holder's country of residence, except interest due to a resident of Rhodesia, wh ich also is blocked. Imports and Import Payments V i r tua l ly a ll imports from Rhodesia are prohibited, as is the import from a ll countries of certain specified commodities for health, safety, or moral reasons. Per­ sonal and household effects, samples, diplomatic ship­ ments, and means of transportation entering Zambia temporarily do not require individual import licenses, nor do any other goods for personal use and consump­ tion, provided that the person importing them does not import more than K 50 worth of such goods in any period of 90 days. The two major mining compa­ nies and the M in i s t ry of Health are granted "blanket licenses" for bona fide requirements. The Controller of Customs is authorized to admit emergency goods imported without prior reference to the M in is t ry of Commerce. A ll other imports require individual import licenses. Import licensing aims at containing imports within a quarterly exchange a l lo c a t ion1 established by the M i n­ istry of Commerce in consultation w i th the M in is t ry of Finance and the Bank of Zambia. A ll imports under individual licensing are first divided into S I T C2 three- digit groups and further subdivided into end-use group­ ings. Exchange allocations are specified for each of these categories. No rma l ly, raw materials, intermediate goods for further processing in Zambia, pharmaceuticals, and fuel and electricity are licensed liberally; alcoholic beverages, tobacco, durable consumer goods, and other consumer goods are licensed restrictively. No licenses are being issued for specified luxury consumer goods or for items that are produced loca l ly. Not for Redistribution foreign exchange for import payments is automatically made available once an import license has been obtained, subject to presentation of the relevant documents to an authorized bank. P r ior approval by the Bank of Zambia, however, is necessary for payments to Rhodesia and South A f r i ca in excess of K 20,000; payments for imports from Rhodesia and South A f r ica are not nor­ mally permitted unless no alternative source of supply is available. Most imported goods are subject upon customs clear­ ance to sales tax, at a rate of 25 per cent, calculated on the sum of 120 per cent of the customs value plus the applicable import duty. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain limits, for other purposes, such as business travel, is provided by the commercial banks without prior reference to the exchange control authori­ ties, except when payments and transfers in excess of K 20,000 to Rhodesia or South A f r i ca are involved. Special reduced allocations apply to payments for invis­ ibles to Rhodesia, and authorized dealers are not per­ mitted to make foreign exchange available for travel to Rhodesia. F or other countries, exchange is granted as follows: The basic exchange allowance for business travel is K 50 a day for up to 15 days a person a calendar year. Exchange is provided, subject to certain limits, for other purposes such as education and medical treatment. Applications for amounts exceeding the limits may in certain circumstances be granted by the exchange control authorities if they are satisfied that exceptional treatment is justified. There is a tourist travel allowance of K 300 an adult for each calendar year. Applications for remittance abroad of part or all of payments for adve r t is ing, management, accoun t ing, administrative, engineering, and consulting services ren­ dered to residents by nonresidents are subject to ind i­ vidual approval by the Bank of Zambia, which gener­ ally grants the required permission, provided that the fees charged are reasonable, that they relate to existing contracts, and that these services cannot be provided domestically.3 Profits and dividends of subsidiaries and branches of companies whose head offices are situated outside Zambia may be transferred abroad up to 10 per cent of the nonresident share of the equity capital or 30 per cent of net profits accruing to the nonresi­ dent owners of incorporated companies, whichever is sma l le r .4-5 Fore ign companies operating in Zambia may 3 Services rendered by a parent company abroad to its branch or wholly owned subsidiary in Zambia are not generally approved. 4 An auditor's certificate must be submitted to the effect that the amount sought to be transferred represents bona fide realized profits derived from the year's operations after full provision has been made for local taxation. The profit and loss account and balance sheet for the year in respect of which application is being made must also be submitted. 5 Under the terms of the 1977 budget, private investors were allowed to remit 15 per cent of the paid-up capital or 50 per cent of profits. Expatriate farmers were permitted to remit 12.5 per cent of their after tax profits, instead of 10 per cent. Z A M B IA remit declared profits and dividends once a year after the end of the accounting year. The remittance of depre­ ciation allowances is not permitted. Foreign nationals employed in Zambia on a contract basis and recruited after December 4, 1971 are allowed to remit to their country of domicile a third of their annual earnings. Foreign nationals recruited before December 4, 1971 and still employed on a contract entered into prior to that date are allowed to remit to their country of domicile one half of their annual earn­ ings. Foreign nationals availing themselves of these arrangements are not entitled to the regular allowances for travel, education, maintenance, etc.; only one third of their leave pay is transferable. To facilitate payments of small amounts, individuals are freely permitted to remit abroad up to K 10 a month for purposes normally approved by the exchange control authorities (including family maintenance). Travelers leaving Zambia may take out a maximum of K 10 in Zambian currency .6 Exports and Export Proceeds A ll exports valued at over K 50 require a license; minerals, however, are exported under general agree­ ments w i th the mining companies. The export of cer­ tain metals is reserved, in principle, for an official agency, the Me tal Marke t ing Corporation. Most exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Certain commodities are subject to licensing mainly to ensure domestic supplies of needed goods and of certain strategic materials, such as implements of war, lead in any form, certain minerals, petroleum products, certain rough and uncut precious stones, scrap and old metals, and jute bags. F or most goods, however, export licenses are issued freely, and some goods are covered by an open general license. Export proceeds in foreign currency appropriate to the country of destination must be offered for sale to an authorized bank within six months of the date of ship­ ment; the foreign exchange proceeds of copper exports, however, must be credited to a Bank of Zambia account in London upon receipt. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any currency must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. There is no limitation on the amount of foreign currency notes that may be imported by travelers, except that travelers from Zaire are allowed to import only up to the equivalent of K 20. Travelers arriving in Zambia may bring in a maximum of K 10 in Zambian currency.6 Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted but, w i th the exception of overseas short-term financing of imports other than certain capital goods, a ll borrowing outside Zambia requires the approval of the exchange control 6 Pr ior to the announcement of December 22, 1976, to take effect January 4, 1977, Zambian currency might not be imported or exported. 513 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Z A M B IA authorities. Outward transfers of capital are controlled, but nonresidents are normally permitted to repatriate their investments when they have satisfied the authorities that the original investment was made with funds brought into the country from sources outside Zambia. Local borrowing by companies controlled either directly or indirectly from outside Zambia is restricted to a debt/equity ratio of 1 to 2. However, the Bank of Zambia permits borrowings in excess of this l im it for certain priority sectors of the economy, provided the borrowings secure higher employment opportunities and /or savings of foreign exchange. In general, residents are not permitted to transfer capital abroad and, with certain exceptions, are required to offer for sale to an authorized bank any foreign exchange which accrues to them. As a special measure, however, residents may purchase Zambian securities quoted on recognized stock exchanges abroad, provided that the securities so acquired are registered in the names of specified nominees and that in the event of subsequent disposal of these securities the sales proceeds are repatriated. A ll income earned from these invest­ ments must be repatriated. Emigrants are granted exchange as follows: (1) Per­ sons 50 years of age and over are allowed K 8,000 on departure, and subsequent annual transfers of K 5,000. (2) Ma r r ied persons under 50 are allowed K 4,000 on departure, together with K 250 for each ch i ld, up to a maximum of K 5,000 for a family unit. Thereafter, annual transfers of K 3,000, together with K 250 for each ch i ld, up to a maximum of K 4,000 for a family unit are permitted. (3) Unmarr ied persons under 50 are allowed K 2,000 on departure, and subsequent annual transfers of K 1,500. In addition to their emigra­ tion allowance, emigrants may remit gratuities, compen­ sation payments, and terminal benefits up to a maximum of K 8,000 on departure, and up to K 5,000 as annual transfers. In addition, there are special facilities for expatriate farmers. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Zambia for numismatic purposes. W i th this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require exchange control approval as well as import or export licenses issued by the Minister of Commerce; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Gold-bearing slime is exported by copper companies as a by-product for refin­ ing and sale abroad. Foreign exchange for imports of gold may be provided w i th the permission of the Bank of Zambia. Changes during 1976 February 1. A tourist travel allowance of K 300 for an adult in each calendar year was introduced. March 26. The requirement that import licenses must be endorsed by Bank of Zambia officials for payment purposes was discontinued. March 30. A ll proceeds in foreign currencies realized from exports and retained in correspondent accounts of commercial banks were to be surrendered to the central bank. This measure was not implemented as it was overtaken by another measure introduced on July 21 (see be low ). June 9. Capitalization of free reserves in excess of the remittable portion under the formula 10 per cent or 30 per cent of equity or profits, whichever was the lower, was allowed provided that (1) the amount to be capitalized represented bona fide realized profits derived from the year's operations of the applicant company after full provision for local taxation had been made and subject to a maximum amount of accumu­ lated undistributed profits for a period of three years; and (2) no element of revaluation of properties for whatever purpose was involved. Capitalization was also allowed where new funds had been brought into the country specifically for that purpose. July 9. The tie between the kwacha and the U .S. dollar was broken and the currency became linked to the S DR at a rate of K 1 = S DR 1.08479 as against the former implicit rate of K 1 = S DR 1.35767173. July 9. Import licenses were henceforth to be issued on a c.i.f. instead of the previous f.o.b. basis. July 21. A ll export receipts by Zambian companies were to be received via irrevocable letters of credit. July 24. A ll Un i ted Nations Development Program and Un i ted Nations personnel holding diplomatic pass­ ports were to be allowed on departure from the country to convert the balances in their External Accounts into convertible currencies. November 19. Business travel allowances were raised from K 40 to K 50 a day; the allowance for medical travel was increased from K 20 to K 25 a day; and the education allowance was raised from K 3,000 to K 3,500 a year. December 22. It was announced that w i th effect from January 4, 1977 travelers leaving or entering Zambia would be permitted to export or import a maximum of K 10 for each person in Zambian currency. 514 ©International Monetary Fund.
